webTitle: Day eleven: Reasons to be fearful

fields.headline: Day eleven: Reasons to be fearful
fields.standfirst: Fiachra Gibbons looks forward to tomorrow night's Palme d'Or, and says that although it hasn't been a vintage year for Britain, Alan Shearer's best work since the McDonald's ad was on show
fields.trailText: Fiachra Gibbons looks forward to tomorrow night's Palme d'Or, and says that although it hasn't been a vintage year for Britain, Alan Shearer's best work since the McDonald's ad was on show
fields.body:
One worries for Kim Basinger. The Hollywood star who may or may not present the Palme D'Or tomorrow night - she still hasn't shown up - may be right not to leave her ranch. Last year's farce when the rather tired and emotional French star Sophie Marceau presided over a shambles which ended in Rosetta, a film which almost no one had seen - or seen since - winning, may be nothing on histrionics this time round.

The joker in the pack is Lars Von Trier, the mad, bad and dangerous Danish director whose feud with his leading lady, Björk, has done so much to enliven the festival - he called her a "mad woman" and accused her of eating her costume.

Von Trier, who drove all the way down from Copenhagen in his camper van - he's too claustrophobic to fly - is not best pleased by some of the reviews of Dancer In The Dark, his emotionally shattering musical in which Björk sings from the scaffold. While several of the butchest critics on the circuit sobbed right through it, Variety, the industry bible, hated it with a venom, labelling it "artistically bankrupt on almost every level".

Given that the last time a Cannes jury tried to fob Von Trier off with a minor prize the director called jury chairman Roman Polanski a "midget" and kicked his scroll into the audience. I'd be a very worried if I was Luc Besson.

Besson, a man who looks more and more like a missing member of Duran Duran, is picture of misery as it is. Those in the know blame the French director's recent break-up with the model-turned-actress Mila Jovovich whom he made a star in The Fifth Element and Joan Of Arc. It might, of course, just have been having to watch the three-hour 40-minute Japanese film Eureka, which some steel-buttocked critics emerging blinking into the light proclaimed a masterpiece.

Anyone can see the poor boy is still pining, and there must have been another pang when Mila turned up at Dame Liz Taylor's $100,000-a table Aids bash with a younger and slimmer model. The prospect of Catherine Deneuve in a porn movie may just restore his will to live. Lars Von Trier has been teasing the ice queen of the French cinema with the chance to reprise her housewife hooker in Luis Bunuel's Belle du Jour in a skin flick he is threatening to make.

"I think I might have to make a few changes to the script," said Deneuve coyly, only for the great Dane to reply, "Yes, Catherine knows more about these things than I do."

 Those sensitive souls who worried that Alan Parker might inflict his "philistine" taste for blockbusters on the public now he's running the new Film Council, can breathe easy. I feared the worst when Lynne Ramsay, the brilliant Scottish director whose stunning debut Ratcatcher was the arthouse find of the festival last year, accidentally spilled a glass of wine all over him. But turning to face the culprit, Parker's scowl softened into a smile, "I'll treasure that stain," he said. "It will be my Jackson Pollock."

 Even though it's been a surprisingly good Cannes, it hasn't been a vintage one for the Brits. Ken Loach's Bread And Roses is not tipped for major honours, though there is hope in the Director's Fortnight where Mark Herman's Purely Belter and Stephen Daldry's debut Dancer - films that both owe a debt to Loach's Kes - have won friends.

Herman, who directed Brassed Off, is particularly excited by Alan Shearer, who plays himself in the bittersweet comedy about two fans struggle to get a season ticket to see Newcastle United. "I think it's his best work since his McDonald's ad."

fields.headline: The Casket
fields.trailText:
"But - now listen! - on no account open this casket, however

Curious you may feel, Psyche, after it has been filled with divine beauty."
fields.body:
(A version of an episode in Book VI of The Golden Ass by Apuleius)

"But - now listen! - on no account open this casket, however

Curious you may feel, Psyche, after it has been filled with divine beauty."
So spoke the inspired, prophetic tower. Psyche made her way
To Taenarus where she obtained a pair of coins for the ferryman, and the required
Barley cakes soaked in wine and honey. There she began her descent
To the underworld: as the tower had instructed, she ignored
The lame drover and his hobbling donkey, made Charon take his obol

From her tongue, stopped her ears to the cries of the dead
Swimmer, spurned the crafty weavers at work
On their infernal looms, then soothed three-headed Cerberus with one
Of her sweet, dripping cakes. Finally she arrived at the palace
Of Proserpine, where she would not relax on the cushions the Queen
Proffered, and declined all food but a hunk of coarse, black bread. Squatting
At Proserpine's feet, she explained her commission from Venus; at once
The casket was whisked away to be filled in secret, then returned,
Sealed. On her swift journey back she used her other barley cake
To silence the rabid jaws of Cerberus, and again made hell's ferryman
Accept his payment from her mouth. But on regaining the white
Light of day she so adored, Psyche, although eager
To fulfil the task Venus had set her, suddenly fell prey
To temptation. "I must be mad," she mused, "to carry, like this,
Beauty, and not take a little for myself, to please my divine lover."
Accordingly, she opened the box, but found inside, not beauty,
But nothing, or rather an evil, insidious coma, a thick
Cloud of drowsiness which suffused and invaded her limbs until she collapsed
Where she stood on the path, and there she lay, slumped like a corpse, fast asleep.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: A poem to the hidden depths of the Sahara, plus Wales
fields.body:
Desert Divers
Sven Lindqvist
(Granta, £8.99)
Buy it at BOL

A poem to the Sahara, and those whom it has obsessed; language as bare and hard as sand and gravel (plaudits to translator Joan Tate). The blue-painted doors reverberate in heat, the fly buzz is audible, the grasshoppers smash into the windscreen before your eyes. Lindqvist's own dreams are wakeful; his narratives of Pierre Loti and other romantics are dreamlike. All culminate in the absurd truth of the rtass, employed to dive beneath the slowly filtered and pooled dark waters to clean the wells of this only superficially dry landscape. Commandeered our dreams too, leading to nightmares of early monoplanes canoeing the air over the desert dunes. Sensational.

Wales
Jan Morris
(Penguin, £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

More romanticism. Morris concentrates intensely on goatfolds and disused nuclear power stations, turning over every lichened stone to reveal the history and pre-history gleaming beneath. No false picturesqueness: neither fake Celtic scrolls nor how-green-was-my-pit-valley nostalgia. This is a hard eye staring at a bleak landscape, where the Tudors politicked; where a religion of Nordic severity was expressed in austere chapels through music Rome would envy; where the Eistedfodd, a daft post-Goethe fantasy of antiquity, was inserted into the calendar by the Victorians, and is now as totally real as tea-tents can make it. Written as a devotion.

webTitle: In the temple of artistic jokers

fields.headline: In the temple of artistic jokers
fields.standfirst: Ruth Brandon tells John Cunningham about the contradictory Surrealists
fields.trailText: Ruth Brandon tells John Cunningham about the contradictory Surrealists
fields.body:
Ruth Brandon rails against biographers who are obsessed with telling us how many slices of toast their subject had for breakfast; she rants about academics who find a few unknown letters by a famous name and base a book on them.

She's scathing about our weakness for biographies that reveal everything about the famous and infamous - childhood, family, career, sex, scandal - except their ideas, which might bore us, we're so lazy. No wonder Brandon has such fierce views about biographies: she writes them herself. But rather than concentrate on a single life in great detail, she prefers groups, movements, big themes.

The Surrealists are the latest, that group of painters, writers and film-makers who, between the two world wars, invented their own brand of artistic chaos. Queer and quarrelsome, gifted and gauche, they fitted a magic lens into our spectacles which turned the mundane into the bizarre.

"Surreal Lives is an examination of the way art and politics influenced each other between the wars," says Brandon. "It sounds very grandiose, but it opened up all kinds of questions about the way politics influences what people write and paint. And it's about the nature of charisma - why people will follow one person who is a star."

André Breton was the guiding light of the movement. The young poet was a medical auxiliary in Paris in 1917 when he arranged to meet a friend at a tiny Montmartre theatre. It was a momentous evening. The play was by Guillaume Apollinaire, who coined the word "surrealism". On stage, a fat woman unbuttoned her blouse to reveal her breasts: two balloons, which she flung at the audience. Breton's friend, witnessing the birth of surreal drama, was Jacques Vaché. He was confident, cynical, with a black sense of humour; the very opposite of the awkward, earnest Breton. After his early death, his influence on Breton remained mesmerising.

With Breton as its core theorist, the movement grew, with Swiss, French and Spanish strands, and with a cast of rampaging egotists - among them Marcel Duchamp, Man Ray, Louis Aragon, Salvador Dali, Tristan Tzara, Louis Buñuel.

There are countless books on each of them, but Brandon realised there wasn't a collective biography, so she set out to weave the blindingly coloured, separate threads together. She places Breton at the centre: "Surrealism was his creation, built on his own character and as a reaction to very specific circumstances. He was neurotically homophobic, but he fell in love with Vaché, building his characteristics into a kind of temple."

An unruly temple of revolutionary art, in spite of Breton's attempt to lay down rules. Pretty much the position of Brandon herself when she started on the book. With such a wide canvas, verifying every last detail or chasing every survivor wasn't so important.

She spent much time at her home, mulling over the many books on the Surrealists and the notes she'd made from archives in Paris, and coming up with a thesis of her own.

It was a lonely endeavour at times. Sure, she's got a husband (an academic) and a daughter to care for, but faced with the quiet of her booklined room, "sometimes I'd ask myself, 'Christ, do I have anything new to say?' And I'd say, 'Yes Ruth, you do. Stick with the theme.' "

For Brandon, feisty, fiftysomething and used to researching a lone furrow, the doubts didn't last long. Others would be daunted, but she thrives on the challenge of constructing an intellectual framework, then cladding it with biographical material to form a book.

The formula can be worrying, but so far she has always made it work. A decade ago, she was fascinated by early socialists - Havelock Ellis, Shaw, the Webbs, Wells - and their notions about social and political reform, not least the sexual emancipation of women.

Digging among the Fabians, Darwinists and New Lifers, what did she find? "A huge contradiction between their public and private lives," says Brandon. Although females such as Eleanor Marx, Margaret Sanger and Rebecca West were intellectually equal to the men, they allowed themselves (with some exceptions) to be used "in the more old-fashioned way" by them.

You get the impression that these late-Victorian worthies wouldn't dare treat Brandon in the same way if she'd been in their circle. But how would she have fared as a contemporary of the Surrealists?

She has this in common with them: "I'm a kind of natural anarchist; not very respectful of institutions." But that wouldn't have been enough to allow her to enter a movement in which women weren't practitioners.

Still, that barrier didn't tempt Brandon to do a demolition job in Surreal Lives. Though critical, she warms to some of them, particularly Buñuel the film-maker. "He's the only one who's a truly great artist. Duchamp was a jokester. He's unquestionably been the most influential, but he copped out. Aragon was a second-rate poet. And Dali, he was self-obsessed and more or less psychotic."

She has a cold eye for their contradictions. The Surrealists were famous for playing jokes on the public, yet were humourless themselves. They despised the bourgeoisie, but happily accepted them as patrons. Now their work is safely tucked away in the world's great galleries, their revolutionary input spent. Time for Brandon to turn her attention to more dangerous trends: her next theme is the car, and how it changed life in the 20th century.

fields.headline: Pop music
fields.trailText: No surprise, then, to see the official Buena Vista Social Club book sucking on a cigar and swinging its heels at the top of the pop-music bestsellers
fields.body:
The marvellous septuagenarian Cuban musicians who comprise the Buena Vista Social Club have become the Gypsy Kings of their generation, the coffee-table vaguely "ethnic" band it's fashionable to like, thanks to Wim Wenders's ponderous film homage. No surprise, then, to see the official BVSC book sucking on a cigar and swinging its heels at the top of the pop-music bestsellers.

Also riding high are The Rose That Grew From Concrete, not an urban gardening self-help book but the collected lyrics of sadly departed gangsta rapper Tupac Shakur (for karaoke evenings among the Staines massive), and 45 by Bill Drummond, a charmingly barking memoir from one of the brains behind the KLF. Elsewhere there's a curiously retro feel - Tom Jones, Elvis, Dusty Springfield, pub rock (No Sleep Till Canvey Island). Maybe people who buy Britney Spears or Steps records don't know how to read anyway...

fields.headline: Our finest hour
fields.standfirst: The Burning Blue tells us why we should be proud of helping to defeat Nazism
fields.trailText: The Burning Blue tells us why we should be proud of helping to defeat Nazism
fields.body:
The Burning Blue: A New History of the Battle of Britain
ed Paul Addison and Jeremy A Crang
(Pimlico, £14)

A personal digression, if I may: a few years ago one of those pompous and sinister revisionist historians (of the kind who think that Churchill was a mistake, and that we should have let Hitler get on with it so that we could keep the Empire) foolishly made a life-long enemy when he accused me, on live national radio, of being a bolshy leftie who would have been a conscientious objector during the second world war.

This is a rash, not to mention offensive, thing to say to anyone, particularly someone half of whose family would have been wiped out had Hitler's invasion plan for these islands succeeded. (Excuse me - my grammar goes to pieces as I contemplate this pustule, who, one assumes, would have volunteered instantly - for the Germans.) Anyone who doubts that the war against Fascism was urgently necessary and just is - how can we put this? - suspect. I think of this particularly after reading Stephen Moss's interview with Tom Paulin in this paper the other day: if Paulin thinks it's worth celebrating the second world war, then that should be good enough for us, too.

So here is a book commemorating 60 years since the RAF put an end to the gravest threat this country ever endured. My eagerness to salute it - and the people who did so much to stop us from speaking in German - means that I am doing so a week or two before it is actually published.

But it is terrific. It's not only an acknowledgment of the heroism of the fighter pilots (and all the ancillary crew), but a serious contribution to the historical record. Seventeen contributors write about the Battle from pretty much every conceivable angle; and Addison and Crang have chosen them well.

Sebastian Cox's writing may not exactly catch fire, for example, but his essay on the RAF's response to the Luftwaffe's attacks is useful history; Richard P Hallion's piece on the American perspective is a fascinating mine of information on the state of America before its entry into the war. We learn, for instance, that we should grovel in awe of our good fortune that Roosevelt was president at the time; we should be grateful that Lindbergh, the aviator hero yet vehement isolationist, distrusted the media; and that had the RAF not been an autonomous service, we would probably all be speaking German and revisionist historians would have nothing to complain about. Nor would the USAF be the global power it is now

There are, for my money, four outstanding contributions. One is Hans Ekkehard-Bob's "Memories of a German Veteran"; Wallace Cunningham's memories of a British ditto, Nigel Rose's touching, indiscreet letters to his parents while with 602 squadron (people really did say "wizard", as in "wizard cakes"); and Owen Dudley Edward's mad but enthusiastic piece on "The Battle of Britain and Children's Literature".

This details, inter alia, the spat between George Orwell and the creator of Greyfriars, Frank Richards, and contains the memorable sentence "It is aggravated by Puritanismus Orwelleanus, the art of enjoying oneself and then analysing why one shouldn't have." Oh, and Angus Calder's essay on cinematic representations of the battle is excellent, too.

This is not an automatically worshipful book; it poses questions about the morality of war, the existence of heroism, the reliability of memory. But it treats the subject honestly and with justice. And it tells us why we won: because, it would appear, it helps to come from a society that is sceptical of authority rather than in blind, unthinking terror of it.
fields.bodyText: The Burning Blue: A New History of the Battle of Britain ed Paul Addison and Jeremy A Crang (Pimlico, £14) A personal digression, if I may: a few years ago one of those pompous and sinister revisionist historians (of the kind who think that Churchill was a mistake, and that we should have let Hitler get on with it so that we could keep the Empire) foolishly made a life-long enemy when he accused me, on live national radio, of being a bolshy leftie who would have been a conscientious objector during the second world war. This is a rash, not to mention offensive, thing to say to anyone, particularly someone half of whose family would have been wiped out had Hitler's invasion plan for these islands succeeded. (Excuse me - my grammar goes to pieces as I contemplate this pustule, who, one assumes, would have volunteered instantly - for the Germans.) Anyone who doubts that the war against Fascism was urgently necessary and just is - how can we put this? - suspect. I think of this particularly after reading Stephen Moss's interview with Tom Paulin in this paper the other day: if Paulin thinks it's worth celebrating the second world war, then that should be good enough for us, too. So here is a book commemorating 60 years since the RAF put an end to the gravest threat this country ever endured. My eagerness to salute it - and the people who did so much to stop us from speaking in German - means that I am doing so a week or two before it is actually published. But it is terrific. It's not only an acknowledgment of the heroism of the fighter pilots (and all the ancillary crew), but a serious contribution to the historical record. fields.headline: Wigged out
fields.standfirst: Malcolm Bradbury follows Diderot on a journey to Saint Petersburg in To the Hermitage
fields.trailText: Malcolm Bradbury follows Diderot on a journey to Saint Petersburg in To the Hermitage
fields.body:
To the Hermitage
Malcolm Bradbury
Picador, £16, 498pp

Books beget books, writers are all in awe of or in desperate competition with one another, and there are as many interpretations of a work of literature as there are readers to plough through it. Everyone knows that, or at least everyone who's read their beginner's guide to literary theory.

Malcolm Bradbury's narrator - like the author himself, a novelist-cum-academic - lives and breathes this stuff, but remains at a rather sceptical distance from it. When he's invited by a pair of grant-obsessed Swedish academics to Stockholm, thence to sail for St Petersburg as part of a shadowy enterprise called The Diderot Project, he doesn't ask too many questions, but merely congratulates himself on jumping aboard another gravy-train and packs his bags.

The mode of transport, however, turns out to be a gravy-boat, packed with an odd assortment of equally bemused travellers. As soon as our hero claps eyes on one, an American chap called Jack-Paul Verso who turns up in a baseball cap emblazoned with the legend I LOVE DECONSTRUCTION, the alarm-bells start ringing. "I know his type at once," muses our man, "he's a funky professor". But funky professors - along with hapless narrators - are a staple of Bradbury, Lodge and co's campus humour, frequently deployed to comic effect, and they do little real harm in the world. Unlike tyrants and emperors and revolutionaries, who people the second strand of To the Hermitage.

The ghastly crew on board the Vladimir Ilich are sailing towards Saint Petersburg in the wake of French philosophe Denis Diderot, summoned there by Catherine the Great in 1773 to school her in the wisdom of the Englightenment. In the chapters that alternate with the ship-of-fools tale, Bradbury recreates Diderot's journey to his patron's palace, where he finds himself at the beck and call of his mistress and her maniac empire-building, and caught in the middle of court conspiracies.

This is a baggy and diffuse novel, whose frequent references to Laurence Sterne and the delights of digression are an attempt to win us over to authorial recklessness that doesn't quite work. We get, for example, an opening meditation on progressive Swedish society; the peregrinations of writers' corpses from Descartes to Sterne; the perils of visiting Finland; and the political vicissitudes of Boris Yeltsin. All of these, and the amiable satire on modern academia, are delivered with a kind of matey blokeishness presumably designed to soften, but also strengthen, the book's more serious points.

Those are rehearsed, in the main, in Diderot's lonely and compromised spell on the banks of the Neva, although there too Bradbury cannot resist comic tweaks and turns - jokey references to wigs and bowels and courtesans, and the spectacle of Voltaire, Mozart and Jefferson hovering in the wings.

But all this larking about is meant to bolster the over arching theme of Posterity, of the Book of Destiny slowly unfolding, and the steady percolation of ideas through the centuries. There are a number of problems for the poor author or thinker: encroaching feebleness and death, the literal disappearance of books, papers and manuscripts, the vagaries of fashion and the moods of patrons, and the mutation and evaporation of meaning.

Even Bradbury, whose loving curatorship of Diderot's oeuvre provides the most interesting strand of the novel, underlines the hazards of reputation in his Preface, in which he informs us that he himself has been Posterity's spin-doctor, and has single-handedly reorganised Diderot's website.

But perhaps we ought not to take Bradbury too seriously. His homage to the man who coined the phrase l'esprit de l'escalier - coming up with the witty riposte when you're on your way out of the room - is itself something of a jeu d'esprit, a warm-hearted shaggy-dog story for those who like their Enlightenment philosophy sweetened by a few gags along the way.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: Miscasting mars this production of Elizabeth Jane Howard's acclaimed chiller
fields.body:
Falling
Elizabeth Jane Howard
(Macmillan, £15.99, 540 mn abridged)
Buy it at BOL

Fragile and lonely after two divorces, writer Daisy Langrish, 60, moves to the country and into the clammy tentacles of an artful older seducer. Henry Kent is looking for a woman to save him from creeping indigence. On the page, this chiller oozes deliciously along in two voices: his account of his campaign and hers of her gradual slide towards doom. But it needs careful casting, because the performers are effectively playing roles rather than just reading.

Here Robert Lindsay's chocolatey young voice is hardly credible for a pensioner roué. This might not jar so badly if his character, Kent, did not early on describe Langrish's "unexpectedly high clear voice that sounded so much younger than it was". This simply cannot fit Janet Suzman's smoky tones, fabulous though they are. Alas, the mismatch mars this production of a novel that was deservedly acclaimed in print form.

fields.headline: Continental rifts
fields.standfirst: Victoria Brittain laments the west's failures of nerve in Africa
fields.trailText: Victoria Brittain laments the west's failures of nerve in Africa
fields.body:
Me Against My Brother: At War in Somalia, Sudan, and Rwanda
Scott Peterson
Routledge, £14.99, 357pp

Across the Red River: Rwanda, Burundi and the Heart of Darkness
Christian Jennings
Orion, £18.99, 256pp
Buy it at BOL

The United Nations humiliation in Sierra Leone last week was a disaster almost as inevitable as the UN experience in Somalia almost a decade ago. Twenty-five Pakistani UN soldiers died on one day of that mission, while 2,000 Somalis and 18 US soldiers were killed later in the Americans' vengeful manhunt.

"Somalia" became the shorthand for subsequent UN failures in Africa that were really failures of American intelligence and nerve - the key ones being in Rwanda and Angola. Somalia, still without a central government a decade after the world lost interest, is also shorthand for the collapsed nation-state in Africa. Sierra Leone, well before the world woke up and looked in recent weeks, had become another, ahead of the precarious states of Democratic Republic of Congo, Liberia or Congo-Brazzaville.

The best part of Scott Peterson's book is on Somalia, where he describes the miscalculations and stupidities of the key US players. President George Bush's special envoy to the country was Robert Oakley, a retired ambassador and veteran of Cold War years in Vietnam. His preoccupation in Somalia was to ensure the safety of the 25,000 US forces sent to "save Somalia" as part of the 38,000 troops of the Unified Task Force who were intended to cut the circle of famine, warlords, and undeliverable food mountains. But, as Peterson puts it, Oakley made the initial decision "to leave the warlord arsenals intact and to make no concerted attempt to disarm Somalia". The warlords' prestige actually increased during the early days of the US involvement.

But the mission mandate changed between the Bush and Clinton presidencies. Another American figure from the past then played a key role. April Glaspie - the US foreign service officer notorious for having given Saddam Hussein the signal of US ambivalence on the eve of his invasion of Kuwait in 1990 - was made the UN number two in Somalia. Petersen reveals that Glaspie went well beyond the UN mandate in her involvement in the political and judicial systems, and in working openly to marginalise the powerful General Aidid.

Glaspie authorised the June 5, 1993 mission by a Pakistani UN unit to inspect Radio Mogadishu, source of anti-UN propaganda and a known weapons site. When Aidid's men were notified of the impending inspection, the message "this means war" came back. The Pakistanis were not given that message, and went to their doom with minimal security precautions. Peterson sums it up: "The result of this American-approved 'inspection' was the largest single-day massacre of UN peace-keeping troops since 1961, when 44 Ghanaians were killed in the Congo."

The book details how, in early 1994, American pressure to avoid "another Somalia" allowed the genocide in Rwanda to continue. The UN force was actually cut back, "sending a clear message to Rwanda's murderers that they could act with impunity". But Peterson, a reporter for the Daily Telegraph and photographer with Gamma, Time and Newsweek, has neither the reflective depth nor the golden pen of Philip Gourevitch, whose We Wish to Inform You that Tomorrow We Will be Killed with our Families remains the only bearable book on the genocide. Gourevitch had a secret: he listened to Africans.

Peterson attempts to distance himself from the macho, Boy's Own style of journalist usually found in African war zones. But he has brought into his book too many stories of tempers lost on air strips, narrow escapes and bad behaviour for the distance to be convincing. Western journalists, like the UN, have a bad reputation in Africa for arrogance and for not understanding much. This book is not going to change that.

However, Christian Jennings's book on war in Rwanda and Burundi makes Peterson's seem restrained and carefully researched. This must surely be a candidate for the worst book ever published by Victor Gollancz. Jennings has filled his pages with the love affairs, diarrhoea attacks and sweating moments of terror of himself and his friends - journalists and aid workers who like plenty of beer, sex and expletives with their Africa. He places Fidel Castro fighting in the Congo when he means Che Guevara, and the Angolan army fighting on the side of Rwanda and Uganda in the period when in fact they were on opposing sides.

The tragedies of imploding countries like Sierra Leone have complex economic and political roots. Hasty western interventions, like these gung-ho books, only serve to confuse the issues and postpone the day when western politicians and their electorates will understand that Africans, from the region, are the only ones to solve the problems.

fields.headline: Random House cover-up
fields.trailText: Martin Amis helps to keep the beautiful people that way, plus country living and the final word
fields.body:
 The Loafer, like Julian Barnes, did not attend Martin Amis's soirée this week. We hear, though, that guests were ferried from their cars to the entrance hall - a distance of about, ooh, 20 yards - under the protection of golfing umbrellas held by shivering Random House staff. Such acts of gallantry are always welcome in these brutish days, especially given the well-known fact that writers and other beautiful people shrivel up like the Wicked Witch of the West when confronted by a drop of rain.

 We always take in Country Life here in Clerkenwell, so it was a delight to see a letter from rural recluse Jeanette Winterson in the current issue. Her beef, though, was not with the parlous state of hedgerows, but with the magazine's Agromenes column. Agromenes, apparently a former cabinet minister, had taken issue with a decision to award a lottery grant to Stonewall rather than to a charity for ex-servicemen and women. Winterson's rebuttal was no surprise, but those who remember her leather-clad doorstepping days will find the forum oddly genteel. The missive, however, reassuringly comes from a village by the name of Upper Slaughter.

 Samuel Beckett is to lecture from beyond the grave, according to his biographer James Knowlson. A former student of Beckett's from his brief career at Trinity College, Dublin, has presented Knowlson with her 1930-31 lecture notes, "almost verbatim" transcriptions of Beckett's thoughts on Balzac. Before Balzac fans get too excited, however, they might remember that Beckett was no great fan, once unkindly describing his characters as "clockwork cabbages".

fields.headline: The unquiet mind
fields.standfirst: Gavin Lambert views the life of the great director through his diaries in Mainly About Lindsay Anderson
fields.trailText: Gavin Lambert views the life of the great director through his diaries in Mainly About Lindsay Anderson
fields.body:
Mainly about Lindsay Anderson: A Memoir
Gavin Lambert
Faber, £16.99, 302pp
Buy it at BOL

"Anderson, if you go on like this you are going to be persona non grata with a great many people." Thus Lindsay Anderson's form master berrated him at the age of 13. "And I said to him 'You're probably right, Sir, but I think it's too late to do anything.' "

To anyone who worked with Lindsay - director of such classic films as If..., This Sporting Life, and O Lucky Man - he was both mentor-idealist and bullshit-detector extraordinaire. In my life his influence was profound. More than 30 years ago, rehearsing David Storey's In Celebration at the Royal Court, Lindsay shouted at me: "Don't just do something! Stand there!" What he meant was: "Receive and be true!" For Lindsay, being true to himself was a great source of pain and suffering. In one of the earliest entries from his diary for January 14, 1942, he describes himself thus: "In a way, I'm a split personality - the wrong mind in the wrong body."

It is through the "dark" mirror of these diaries that Gavin Lambert movingly reflects on the connection of these two boyhood friends, who remained close from their public schooldays in Cheltenham to Lindsay's death in France in 1994.

Both men are and were homosexual. Lambert's ease with his sexuality, his grateful acceptance of his first sexual liaison with his history master at prep school, contrasts with Lindsay's distress and torment. Throughout his life he would fall hopelessly in love, usually with heterosexual, married actors: they included Richard Harris, Albert Finney, Malcolm McDowell and lastly Frank Grimes.

"At the age of 21," Lambert notes, "Lindsay arrived at another definitive conclusion about himself. 'I will never be loved as I wish to be, for myself.' Then he told himself, 'Love is what you haven't got. I wonder if your homosexuality is what cuts you off like this.' "

Later, in his forties, living in Los Angeles and after a couple of broken love affairs, Lambert himself decides to keep a journal: "Hoping (but failing) to enlighten myself about myself, I start to keep a diary: 'I feel lazy, remote. I am deeply sick of cruising... Most of my life I have lived with someone. Now for the first time in my life I feel extreme loneliness."

As if on cue, Lambert is introduced to the teachings of Krishnamurti by Christopher Isherwood and his lover Don Bachardy. Krishnamurti's advice: "You only free yourself from anxiety when you stop resisting it, and the mind is quiet. The quiet mind is a free mind." In turn Gavin tried to introduce Lindsay to these ideas, but he would have none of it. He wrote of Krishnamurti: "I saw him in Washington, frail and elegant, communicating with great clarity ideas that personally I couldn't make head or tail of. I seemed to be the only person there who couldn't."

This was a typical example of Lindsay's stubborn resistance to any sort of interference with his own psyche. He dismissed as "impractical" the suggestion that perhaps conflicts in the external world resulted from conflicts within ourselves, and couldn't be settled until we settled our own personal accounts. His own unique unquiet was the source of his creativity, and so perhaps he dared not meddle with it.

Mainly About Lindsay Anderson is also a tale of exile and isolation. Lindsay exiled himself at home, where he described the past as a snug refuge from the present. Gavin Lambert exiled himself to Los Angeles, where the past was only half forgotten and still very young. The potency of Lambert's dual portrait lies in the connections he makes between the two protagonists and their various circles: from that other infamous exile from the Royal Court, Tony Richardson, to Nicholas Ray, the demon-driven director of Rebel Without a Cause, with whom Lambert had a covert affair that spirited him to Los Angeles to begin a career as a scriptwriter. (At a distance, Ray played Dostoevsky's Roghozin to Lindsay's Prince Myshkin from The Idiot - his overt anguish was a mirror image of Lindsay's introverted pain.)

Lambert takes us from his own dismay at the exploitation of Ray's death by Wim Wenders in his drama-doc Lightning Over Water, to Lindsay's final film, Is this All There Is? - another documentary - in which he cast the ashes of actresses Jill Bennett and Rachel Roberts, both friends and both of whom committed suicide, into a chrysanthemum-strewn Thames.

Lambert modestly observes at one point: "The past is only relatively more secure than the present, the biographer who believes in 'objective truth' is deceiving himself." Mainly About Lindsay Anderson is indeed written from a particularly subjective viewpoint. But it is a view that rings the bell of truth. Lindsay would have been very pleased - and perhaps a little surprised.

Throughout his life he would fall hopelessly in love, usually with heterosexual, married actors: they included Richard Harris, Albert Finney, Malcolm McDowell and lastly Frank Grimes. "At the age of 21," Lambert notes, "Lindsay arrived at another definitive conclusion about himself. 'I will never be loved as I wish to be, for myself.' Then he told himself, 'Love is what you haven't got. I wonder if your homosexuality is what cuts you off like this.' " Later, in his forties, living in Los Angeles and after a couple of broken love affairs, Lambert himself decides to keep a journal: "Hoping (but failing) to enlighten myself about myself, I start to keep a diary: 'I feel lazy, remote. I am deeply sick of cruising... Most of my life I have lived with someone. Now for the first time in my life I feel extreme loneliness." As if on cue, Lambert is introduced to the teachings of Krishnamurti by Christopher Isherwood and his lover Don Bachardy. Krishnamurti's advice: "You only free yourself from anxiety when you stop resisting it, and the mind is quiet. The quiet mind is a free mind." In turn Gavin tried to introduce Lindsay to these ideas, but he would have none of it. He wrote of Krishnamurti: "I saw him in Washington, frail and elegant, communicating with great clarity ideas that personally I couldn't make head or tail of. I seemed to be the only person there who couldn't." This was a typical example of Lindsay's stubborn resistance to any sort of interference with his own psyche. He dismissed as "impractical" the suggestion that perhaps conflicts in the external world resulted from conflicts within ourselves, and couldn't be settled until we settled our own personal accounts. His own unique unquiet was the source of his creativity, and so perhaps he dared not meddle with it. Mainly About Lindsay Anderson is also a tale of exile and isolation. Lindsay exiled himself at home, where he described the past as a snug refuge from the present. Gavin Lambert exiled himself to Los Angeles, where the past was only half forgotten and still very young. The potency of Lambert's dual portrait lies in the connections he makes between the two protagonists and their various circles: from that other infamous exile from the Royal Court, Tony Richardson, to Nicholas Ray, the demon-driven director of Rebel Without a Cause, with whom Lambert had a covert affair that spirited him to Los Angeles to begin a career as a scriptwriter. (At a distance, Ray played Dostoevsky's Roghozin to Lindsay's Prince Myshkin from The Idiot - his overt anguish was a mirror image of Lindsay's introverted pain.) Lambert takes us from his own dismay at the exploitation of Ray's death by Wim Wenders in his drama-doc Lightning Over Water, to Lindsay's final film, Is this All There Is? - another documentary - in which he cast the ashes of actresses Jill Bennett and Rachel Roberts, both friends and both of whom committed suicide, into a chrysanthemum-strewn Thames. Lambert modestly observes at one point: "The past is only relatively more secure than the present, the biographer who believes in 'objective truth' is deceiving himself." Mainly About Lindsay Anderson is indeed written from a particularly subjective viewpoint. But it is a view that rings the bell of truth. Lindsay would have been very pleased - and perhaps a little surprised.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: A superior comfort read, plus For The Relief Of Unbearable Urges, Mother Tongue and Needlepoint
fields.body:
A Certain Age
Tama Janowitz (Bloomsbury, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

"Florence had been around too long. At thirty-two, without a good background (anyway, an ordinary background, ordinary, pet rather than show quality), without money of her own, having slept with a few too many men - who was going to want her?" Watchers of Sex and the City or Ally McBeal will know the rest, but Janowitz has unashamedly borrowed a better class of model - Edith Wharton - for her tale of the modern marriage market and delivered a slap in the face to the rest of the thirtysomething book pack. The writing is classy, the bitchy Hamptons/Fifth Avenue women sharply realised, and though Janowitz is clearly cashing in, A Certain Age is a superior comfort read.

For The Relief Of Unbearable Urges
Nathan Englander
(Faber, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Even very good short stories often read as exercises in style: a gentle skit, a small tragedy or a condensed epic as tryouts for the big novel. Englander, though, achieves a richness and a coherence in his debut collection that reaches beyond a series of finely turned fragments. These nine fables of the Hasidim, stretching from Hitler and Stalin's Eastern Europe to modern-day Israel and a Brooklyn basement wig-maker have qualities of urban myth and contemporary fairy-tale. Englander celebrates a world where, though faith is sorely tested and life is full of absurdity, humanity triumphs and characters are redeemed in unexpected ways.

Mother Tongue
John Helmer
(Quartet, £7)
Buy it at BOL

What starts off as small-town Essea farce soon becomes tragedy as Hal, the 15-year-old narrator, probes his relationship with Libby, a mother for whom Mum is definitely not the word. Helmer has taken the everyday story of adolescence - puberty, schoolyard thuggery and first glimpses into the adult world - and explored its extreme and dangerous limits. Libby loves shoes, short skirts and flirting, even with her son and his schoolmates. Hal can't help but be confused, especially when he finds out how far her web of deception spreads. Helmer writes with unadorned directness: Mother Tongue - though disturbing - is highly readable.

Needlepoint
Jenny Roberts
(Diva, £8.95)
Buy it at BOL

This lesbian thriller probably won't find its way beyond specialist bookshops, but it deserves to be read by more than a niche market. Cameron has the short hair and the big Harley Davidson of a dyke the straight world would recognise. When she can't get over her sister's mysterious death in Amsterdam, she sets off to conduct her own investigation. The women-only angle means that the only male Cameron really relates to is her cat, Tibby, but this is an excellently paced, well-plotted thriller. True, Needlepoint does not depart from the crime format, but it's a recipe Roberts does well.

fields.headline: The young Turk
fields.standfirst: James Wood  applauds Martin Amis'  tender defiance in Experience
fields.trailText: James Wood applauds Martin Amis' tender defiance in Experience
fields.body:
Experience
Martin Amis
Cape, £18, 412pp
Buy it at BOL

Experience is a beautiful, and beautifully strange book, and it is unlike anything one expected. One feared a trough of plaint: either a sad, Gosse-like reckoning with the father; or an angry, journalistic reckoning with those journalists who have hunted Amis from tooth to tooth.

But Experience is not quite a memoir, nor is it quite a portrait of his father, nor is it really an autobiography. It is an escape from memoir; indeed, an escape into privacy. In the very book which might, at first glance, seem most exhibitionist, most shamelessly metropolitan, Amis has softly retreated to the provinces of himself.

His book often reads like a letter to his family and closest friends. It is sometimes embarrassing to read; the ordinary reader feels voyeuristic, at times almost uninvited, but very moved. What seems at first just gossip and guestlists - sprays of names offered without explanation, diaristic footnotes, a refusal to universalise - soon becomes a kind of tender defiance, as if Amis wanted the book to vibrate with an atmosphere of wounded privacy.

Thus Experience has an undulating, open-ended form, something like a notebook whose pagination has been erased. Obvious chronology is scrambled, so that at any page or two we might move from the mid-1990s back to Amis's earliest childhood days, forward to the 1970s, then forward to the moment at which Amis is writing the book itself, and so on.

The book's reminds us that, in an inversion of the usual adage, life is lived backwards but is thought forwards. For we are always thinking forwardly: what next?; yet more often than not what comes next has already been decided by the court of our past, so we must live backwardly. Amis's book is imbued with this sense of the past, especially childhood, as a future already determined.

One such determinism - it is the book's major theme - is that innocence will necessarily become experience, song turn to growl. This will happen gradually, as life teaches us its experience. But, as Amis describes it, that change happened savagely and very quickly to him, in 1994 and 1995. These years are the book's pregnable pivot, the wound to which the text recurs again and again.

In 1994, Amis learned that his cousin, Lucy Partington, who had disappeared in 1973, was one of Frederick West's victims. He grieved, and grieves, for his cousin, and some of the book's loveliest passages evoke her, and childish holidays spent with her on the beach in Wales. The Partington family were innocence, while the Amises were experience. The Partingtons were from the village, the Amises were from town, and when the families met, "the lion lay down with the lamb". (Echoes of Milton and Blake on innocence and experience.)

Also around this time, Amis lost an old friend (Julian Barnes), an old agent (Pat Kavanagh), separated from his wife and two children, became horribly famous for his teeth (not, of course, the extraction of a few molars, but the reconstruction of his entire jaw), and lost his father, who died in November, 1995. He also learned that he was the father of a 17-year-old daughter, Delilah Seale, whom he had never met. Amis did not really collapse so much as die into middle age. Innocence had been vandalised. His tears, as the Psalmist has it, had become his meat, day and night.

These experiences are wrought in a rich and sedimented prose that displays all of Amis's usual powers of nimble paradox (a chemist that smelled of "decaying penicillin", a tennis court strewn with "shop-fresh garbage"), with wonderful plumage and peacockery: his head, during toothache, "TV-shaped with swellings", or the delicious sentence used to describe his father's stately, plump fall on the Edgware Road: "It was a work of colossal administration."

Yet as the book describes Kingsley's last days in hospital, Amis knows how to dilute his tangs, and let a flatter, harder prose report the inevitable: "How hard it is to die. You have to chase it, panting." And finally, this bony epitaph, as Martin looks at his father's corpse: "It is 1995 and he has been there since 1949." What is so moving is the rightful selfishness of those dates: he does not write "since 1922", which would be Kingsley's birthdate, but "since 1949", which is his own - for his is the reality that now matters.

The book's oblique patterns educate us in the ways that the past contains the seeds of its future. For instance, we read of Kingsley Amis's divorce from Martin's mother, and Kingsley's second divorce from Martin's stepmother; we already know, because of the book's switchback form, that Martin's divorce will follow many years later. Likewise, in the course of the book, a daughter is lost (the Partingtons' daughter) and a daughter found (Delilah Seale), and a daughter birthed (his baby daughter with his new wife, Isabel Fonseca). And a father is lost, while a father-substitute (Saul Bellow) is found. And through it all, the fearful symmetry of father and son: one writer begetting another.

This layering of incident allows Amis, most beautifully, to touch the hems of his themes without dragging too strongly on them. When, for instance, Martin regrets that he lost touch with his stepmother after her divorce from Kingsley, he laments "our vanished relatedness, cancelled by law but not by feeling". Yet that tiny elegy speaks forward too, perhaps, to another, later vanished relatedness, that between Martin and his first wife, Antonia Phillips. There is a sense in which Amis is continually speaking through people to other people in this book, a sun happy to be outshone by their moons. This self-dimming is something new and unexpected in his work, and suggests a new emotional climate.

As Nabokov does in his memoir, Speak, Memory, so Amis buries his patterns deep in the aesthetic textures of his book. At one point, he tells us that a local Italian restaurant serves a dish which might be translated as "from grandmother's handbag". There is a joke that one might as well fancy "a plate of hairgrips and DentuFix". The book has, not surprisingly, established teeth as one of its themes of hardship: there is a funny riff about the indignity of Martin's having to buy Steradent for his dentures. Thus "Dentufix". But why "hairgrips"?

Seventy-four pages later, we learn in a footnote that Lucy Partington's body was found with rope, packing tape, and "two hairgrips". So a plate of "hairgrips and DentuFix" is, essentially, a plate of experience, a plate of pain. From such painful, painstaking pebbles, such subtleties of detail and implication, is this fine, affecting book built.

fields.headline: In a green shade
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Bate argues that literature and ecology spring from the same source in The Song Of The Earth - Andrew Rissik isn't so sure
fields.trailText: Jonathan Bate argues that literature and ecology spring from the same source in The Song Of The Earth - Andrew Rissik isn't so sure
fields.body:
The Song Of The Earth
Jonathan Bate
Picador, £18, 322pp
Buy it at BOL

Literature has always had a pastoral side, a garden spot. In every age and culture, writers have used language drawn from the natural world - the old, direct words that evoke air, space and light, the mysteries of the elements or the seasons - to express what is inexpressible. The medieval poets, whether they were describing divine ecstasy or the agonies of profane love, chose the image of a garden as their representative metaphor: just as the eye rejoiced at the harmonious beauty of physical place, so would the soul open itself to God, or the heart yield to the beloved.

It's as if the dream of a paradise or an Eden simply isn't conceivable without weather, or sunlight, or running water - without a vision of the effortless fecundity of the earth. Both the self-conscious, individualistic art of poetry and the Jungian folk memory that is our collective legacy seem to lead us back to the same lost, idealised space where our most basic needs were once satisfied: the homeland, the village, the garden, the earth.

So, broadly, runs the seductive half-truth that is academically teased out for nearly 300 earnest, dogmatic pages by Jonathan Bate in this ecological critique of English literature. Writing from a fashionably talked-up horror at the maimed and polluted state of the natural world, Bate proposes that literature and ecology spring from the same root. Poetry is Green because it's in poetry's nature to be organic, to return us to the things that our more "cultivated" selves have lost or forgotten. His book, in his own words, is "about the capacity of the writer to restore us to the earth which is our home".

Bate is subscribing to a peculiarly modern, essentially agnostic sentimentality. He sets the green, teeming earth, or rather the sheer sensuousness of nature, where religion once stood: at the centre of our moral universe. As he sees it, the human mind turns in extremis not to God, nor to itself, but to its position in the physical order of things - to what Wallace Stevens termed "actuality". Clearly, this ignores the nature of the world's large body of metaphysical and mystical poetry.

To Plato and Aristotle, or Dante, or John Donne and his successors, or the Sufi mystics, or a Byzantine Greek poet such as Romanos, or W B Yeats or T S Eliot, wisdom was achieved through many kinds of inter-relatedness, many kinds of love, in which a respect for the created world certainly played a part. Yet these poets all reached ultimately beyond the material. They knew that life was a movement forward, an evolution, out of safety and certainty, toward what was desired by the spirit but never completely known. Poetry, for them, was about the soul, and the soul's long journey home to God.

The Song Of The Earth is disappointing because it's more a poetic fallacy in critical form than a bona fide critical study. It has little of the shrewd, wide-ranging critical horse-sense of Bate's impressive The Genius Of Shakespeare, and none of the closely argued, revelatory scholarship of his earlier Shakespeare and Ovid. It strains to celebrate the richness of poetic writing while trying, often desperately, to restrict poetry's meaning. Despite the tortuous, jargon-strewn analysis, it doesn't really persuade; it emotes. It wants us to accept, to feel as truth, what is actually an unsustainable eco-political opinion - that literature begins in pastoral, and that the making of poems is (or ought to be) a form of restorative ecological social work.

Much of what is wrong or foolish in it can be traced back to an inadequate historical or a false anthropological sense. Bate talks angrily about our "alienation", about the greed and rapacity with which we have ransacked the earth's resources, without appreciating that the urge to tame animals, to fish, hunt and cultivate the earth proceeds from the same, common, over-mastering human need. It's in our nature - not the result of some later corruption, or fall from grace - to dam the river, to fell the forest, to take the lamb from the sheep, the egg from the bird.

Poetry is not naturally part of nature, nor is it naturally passive. It belongs to the life of the world, because it's part of the life of the world. Its struggle is violent, tarnished, social and human; life-taking as well as life-giving. As Peter Conrad wrote definitively in his Everyman History of English Literature, "In the beginning is the epic. Literature begins there. It caters to the first human need, for it is the poem of force, the poem as force..."

Bate's thinking is flawed by anachronism. He is nostalgic, as only a wistful contemporary urbanite can be, for a natural world that, Camelot-like, never was but should have been. This must be why so many of the poems and books he discusses - from Rousseau and Frankenstein to Elizabeth Bishop and Les Murray - were written after the 18th-century Age of Enlightenment had taken some old imaginative magic out of the landscape and purged the earth of its primitive superstitious enchantment. Poetry has been trying, ever since, to put it back.

It must also be why he can take seriously the work of a philosopher like Martin Heidegger, whose wish-fulfilling Late Romantic notions of the sacredness of "home" and "the earth" in reality helped the Nazis to create for Germany a bogus Bavarian pre-history - clean, blond, healthy, Aryan - that became, briefly, a living, terrifying lie. Bate quotes the literary theorist Paul de Man who asks, "What is the pastoral convention, then, if not the eternal separation between the mind that distinguishes, negates, legislates and the original simplicity of the natural?"

In his hatred of alienation, Bate fails to see that human beings were technological from the beginning, because their minds were technological. So, too, is nature itself. As quantum physics has amply demonstrated, there is no "original simplicity".

At its worst, The Song Of The Earth is an absurd book, written in a style often wretchedly close to academic self-parody, and tailor-made for the politically correct, historically ignorant, second-generation flower children of the dumbed-down modern campus.

Yet in it, and for all his infuriating archness of tone, Bate is also trying to do something courageous and far-sighted. His best chapter is an excellent, tautly detailed analysis of four individual poems: Byron's "Darkness", Keats's "To Autumn", Coleridge's "Frost at Midnight" and Wallace Stevens's "Sunday Morning". Here, detaching himself a little from the tangle of his relentless eco-theorising, he is able to write about language with a rare, deep-reaching critical insight, searching beneath the skein of words for the essential loneliness of soul which lends to all poetry its unmistakable note of yearning. He is arguing, if only he could see it, not for ecology or "the earth" but for a redeeming sense of natural beauty.

Much of what is wrong or foolish in it can be traced back to an inadequate historical or a false anthropological sense. Bate talks angrily about our "alienation", about the greed and rapacity with which we have ransacked the earth's resources, without appreciating that the urge to tame animals, to fish, hunt and cultivate the earth proceeds from the same, common, over-mastering human need. It's in our nature - not the result of some later corruption, or fall from grace - to dam the river, to fell the forest, to take the lamb from the sheep, the egg from the bird. Poetry is not naturally part of nature, nor is it naturally passive. It belongs to the life of the world, because it's part of the life of the world. Its struggle is violent, tarnished, social and human; life-taking as well as life-giving. As Peter Conrad wrote definitively in his Everyman History of English Literature, "In the beginning is the epic. Literature begins there. It caters to the first human need, for it is the poem of force, the poem as force..." Bate's thinking is flawed by anachronism. He is nostalgic, as only a wistful contemporary urbanite can be, for a natural world that, Camelot-like, never was but should have been. This must be why so many of the poems and books he discusses - from Rousseau and Frankenstein to Elizabeth Bishop and Les Murray - were written after the 18th-century Age of Enlightenment had taken some old imaginative magic out of the landscape and purged the earth of its primitive superstitious enchantment. Poetry has been trying, ever since, to put it back. It must also be why he can take seriously the work of a philosopher like Martin Heidegger, whose wish-fulfilling Late Romantic notions of the sacredness of "home" and "the earth" in reality helped the Nazis to create for Germany a bogus Bavarian pre-history - clean, blond, healthy, Aryan - that became, briefly, a living, terrifying lie. Bate quotes the literary theorist Paul de Man who asks, "What is the pastoral convention, then, if not the eternal separation between the mind that distinguishes, negates, legislates and the original simplicity of the natural?" In his hatred of alienation, Bate fails to see that human beings were technological from the beginning, because their minds were technological. So, too, is nature itself. As quantum physics has amply demonstrated, there is no "original simplicity". At its worst, The Song Of The Earth is an absurd book, written in a style often wretchedly close to academic self-parody, and tailor-made for the politically correct, historically ignorant, second-generation flower children of the dumbed-down modern campus. Yet in it, and for all his infuriating archness of tone, Bate is also trying to do something courageous and far-sighted. His best chapter is an excellent, tautly detailed analysis of four individual poems: Byron's "Darkness", Keats's "To Autumn", Coleridge's "Frost at Midnight" and Wallace Stevens's "Sunday Morning". Here, detaching himself a little from the tangle of his relentless eco-theorising, he is able to write about language with a rare, deep-reaching critical insight, searching beneath the skein of words for the essential loneliness of soul which lends to all poetry its unmistakable note of yearning. He is arguing, if only he could see it, not for ecology or "the earth" but for a redeeming sense of natural beauty.

fields.headline: The old devil
fields.standfirst: The Letters of Kingsley Amis overshadow Martin Amis in death just as the old devil did in life
fields.trailText: The Letters of Kingsley Amis overshadow Martin Amis in death just as the old devil did in life
fields.body:
The Letters of Kingsley Amis
Edited by Zachary Leader
HarperCollins, £24.99, 1208pp
Buy it at BOL

There seems something rather poignant about the narrow gap between this huge volume of Kingsley Amis's letters and the accompanying memoir of his son, Martin. (And wouldn't it have displayed - finally - a great sense of humour if Junior had actually gone ahead and called his book My Struggle, as the wags always wanted him to? I, for one, would have become his slave on the spot.) Even in his grave the old devil leads the way, with his human, all too human, self-exposé; the son still seems a pale, posturing shadow, with one eye on the mirror and the other on posterity.

Though it was Mart who was supposed to be the looker and the groover, Kingsley seems to have been a lot more fun as both a husband and a chum; his letters to Philip Larkin, in particular, reveal him as an extravagantly devoted and frank friend. You can't help thinking that Amis was, at heart, a bit of a bender, as most misogynists are; his hair had that tell-tale natural bouffant, almost every letter to Larkin ends with the word "bum" (an "in" joke between them, apparently).

In a shockingly moving sequence of letters to his second wife Elizabeth Jane Howard (his "Dearest Dove"; I've certainly resorted to this endearment, and I bet you have, but can we ever imagine Mart taking his eye off the future archives long enough to do so?), he lets drop the fascinating information that "Thanks to you I have dismissed for ever any lingering doubts about masculinity and all that."

Much has been made of Kingsley Amis's "decline," but in context - of both this book and contemporary male novelists - even his embracing of fogeyism seems far preferable to the pathetic holding on to youth (usually in the form of a young woman, though Bono will do at a pop) which so afflicts the current crop; see Rushdie banging on about "rock'n'roll" for the full horror of this. Amis always hated all the right things - Ted Hughes, Thurber, Thorpe - and when he begins to love the wrong things - John Wayne, Frederick Forsyth, Mrs Thatcher - it's best to remember that nobody's perfect, and that dyspepsia can do dreadful things to the judgement.

And to remember that he was never a straightforward Thatcherite suck-up (unlike moi): "Will someone please explain," he asks Larkin ingenuously in 1980, "why Polish strikers are heroes but British strikers are bums." Anyway, it's pretty easy to forgive a misanthrope who reserves his most savage searchlight for himself; it's the self-adoring sneerers, like Mart, who stick in the craw.

The sheer un-Americaness of Amis Major is a bracing delight, especially compared to his son's craven cleaving to the dump; his is the England before self-help, when self-knowledge seemed rather more to the point. For good or ill, you get the feeling of a life lived, not merely analysed, here; the letters headed Swansea, Glamorgan and Hertfordshire are literally a world away from the London-New York-Los Angeles perfume-bottle mantra that marks the progress of today's successful novelist.

Married at 26 to a pregnant 17-year-old (not quite Martin, is it?), he reveals a usually obscured truth about writing; that the pram in the hall and the spouse in the dumps, far from being the enemy of creativity, are both excellent catalysts in galvanising the necessary loathing of the human condition in a certain sort of novelist.

You can imagine him sitting in the early afternoon of that flat north-Oxford light that Angela Huth describes so well in her novels, waiting for advances to turn up and marriages to wear out. Yet there is all the time the awareness of a marriage partner being "a fellow sufferer," as the philosopher said, rather than an oppressive bitch; even of Howard he writes to Brian Aldiss: "By God, she was hard to live with, but living without her seems altogether pointless."

His irritation, yet empathy, with women explains why his female characters have such presence and oomph, as opposed to the assorted underwear models, masochists and murder victims of Martin - who additionally, of course, was young enough to know better, having reached adulthood at the height of second-wave feminism. And, surely, few men are so lovable that their ex-wives will let them spend their dotage in a granny flat beneath their new marital home, as Kingsley's first wife did; I remember a friend of mine's mother asking the Kilmarnocks to dinner at some point in the 80s, to which Lady K replied: "We'd love to, so long as we can get a baby-sitter for Kingsley."

But it is in the end Larkin, not Hilly or Jane, whose long shadow looms over the book like a post-coital conqueror; the mourner at every Whitsun wedding and the bridegroom at every funeral. This is a long book, and the private baby-talk between Amis and Larkin pales quite early on; it feels indecent to linger over it too long, like accidentally hearing a couple you vaguely know having sex in the next room. The streak of melancholy that runs through Amis's life does, in the end, seem to stem from the fact that his heterosexuality was something of a curse to him, the way homosexuality traditionally was to others; "I wish we lived in the same town," he writes to Larkin as early as 1949, "one of the ways in which I feel I am wasting my youth is in not seeing you much more often dalling."

Who knows, if he'd been born in Martin's time, he might have been able to follow his heart and let it all "hang out," as they say. But then it is doubtful whether he would have left us such a ceaselessly fresh and adorable body of work, from Take A Girl Like You up to The Old Devils - a quarter-century of exasperation made poetry. Repression is the mother of the metaphor, when all is said and done, and ever more shall be so.

fields.headline: Firefighter
fields.standfirst: William Shawcross spent the last 10 years as a fly on the wall at the UN. Deliver Us From Evil tells the inside story of a turbulent decade
fields.trailText: William Shawcross spent the last 10 years as a fly on the wall at the UN. Deliver Us From Evil tells the inside story of a turbulent decade
fields.body:
Deliver Us From Evil
William Shawcross
Bloomsbury, £20, 404pp
Buy it at BOL

United Nations troops taken hostage, a weak government under threat from warlords, a major western power despatching its own forces with an opaque mandate and total obscurity about its intentions - the current drama in Sierra Leone is only the latest example of the recurring world crises that William Shawcross has been watching at close range for the last 10 years.

A fly on the wall at UN headquarters for some of that time, Shawcross was given unprecedented access by Kofi Annan, first when he headed the peace-keeping department and later as secretary-general. He accompanied the soft-spoken Ghanaian on numerous trips. The result is a profile both of Annan and the organisation that he heads. Inevitably, and this is no criticism of Shawcross, they both come out well. Annan is a good man heading a good organisation, which is flawed more by the environment in which it works than by its own faults.

The point is made throughout Shawcross's book that the UN is the sum of its constituent governments' parts. They usually fail to provide the troops or money they promise, and then they blame the UN when things go wrong. On the rare occasions when things things go right, they take the credit for themselves.

There is also a sad inability in governments to learn lessons. Annan's observations in his private report to New York on Nato's airstrikes on the Bosnian Serbs in the aftermath of Srebrenica in 1995 bear an uncanny resemblance to Nato's mistakes four years later in Kosovo. He criticised Nato because it had no plans except for more air strikes, and failed to provide accurate information on the damage they had inflicted.

Shawcross describes his book as "fragments of the last decade" and an account of "some of the problems encountered by interventions". He is low-key, cautious, and reasonable, and his approach is unmistakably British, with its understated but manifest resentment of American high-handedness, and constant sneers at the French. But there are few recommendations here.

One obvious conclusion to be drawn from recent failures is that the UN needs to move towards having a standing army of national contingents, jointly trained and ready for prompt use in emergencies under UN command. Surprisingly Shawcross does not deal with this, and in a recent Guardian article on Sierra Leone, he bizarrely preferred the use of mercenaries.

In an important agenda-setting challenge for this year's Millennium Summit in September, Kofi Annan is making a strong request for improvements here. "Our system for launching operations has sometimes been compared to a volunteer fire department, but that description is too generous. Every time there is a fire we must first find fire engines and the funds to run them," he writes. Some member governments have offered troops on "standby" but their availability is not confirmed.

Shawcross also elides the serious grounds for criticism of UN operations in action. The UN is an easy butt for attack from its ill-wishers, just as the "faceless Brussels bureaucrats" are for Eurosceptics. But there are genuine problems in the field when the peace-keeping machine - with its inflated salaries, excessive security, untransparent operating style, and exaggerated mistrust of the locals - is elevated too high above the war-shattered and poverty-stricken populations it is meant to serve.

As the UN increasingly moves into delivering "good governance" and trying to reconstruct civil society and failed states in new "protectorates" like Bosnia, Cambodia, and Kosovo, overlap and lack of co-ordination between the UN and other outside agencies are becoming major issues. On his travels Shawcross must have seen this, and it is not a fault of the member governments alone. There is a "UN culture" that needs to be changed.

But these are the warts on an otherwise pleasant UN face. Shawcross is right to accentuate the positive, and point out that Kofi Annan has done more than any of his predecessors to open the UN up and reform some of its practices. Narrow-minded governments are the bigger problem.

webTitle: Former Sun editor Larry Lamb dies, aged 71

fields.headline: Former Sun editor Larry Lamb dies, aged 71
fields.standfirst: Read Larry Lamb's obituary
fields.trailText: Sir Larry Lamb, Rupert Murdoch's onetime blood brother in inaugurating the topless Page Three Girl era of British tabloid journalism, has died, aged 71, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Sir Larry Lamb, Rupert Murdoch's onetime blood brother in inaugurating the topless Page Three Girl era of British tabloid journalism, has died, aged 71, it was announced yesterday.

He had been in poor health since a heart attack in Australia eight years ago. He died on Thursday.

Last night, Mr Murdoch and Lady Thatcher - whom Lamb backed in the 1979 general election - both praised him.

Lady Thatcher called him "a great editor and a huge influence on the world of British newspapers". Mr Murdoch said: "Larry Lamb towered above the editors of his generation. He had an unerring instinct for the political and popular tastes of the day.

"Through the pages of the Sun, he helped reinvent popular journalism. To this day, his inspiration lives on within its pages."

Sir Larry edited the Sun from 1969 to 1981. Within seven years under his leadership it became the biggest-selling paper in Britain.

Link to obituary page

fields.headline: Platitudes in sound
fields.standfirst:
Soweto String Quartet
Royal Festival Hall, London
**
fields.trailText:
Soweto String Quartet
Royal Festival Hall, London
**
fields.body:
The rise of the Soweto String Quartet has been one of the great symbolic successes of the new South Africa. The three Khemese brothers and viola player Makhosini Mnguni were all born and raised in Soweto; they formed the quartet in 1978, but it wasn't until violinist Sandile Khemese had spent seven years studying music in England that the group hit upon its commercially successful brew of classical, crossover and township pop.

The quartet's fondness for amplified fusion music overshadows the more interesting parts of their repertoire. Much of their performance features the four string players sawing at their instruments at the front of the stage while their five-piece band booms away behind them. There is little scope for any meaningful interplay. The music is so determined to mix any number of international styles that it ends up with no fixed identity. It isn't rock, it isn't jazz and it isn't interesting. Bossa Baroque, by Dave Grusin, is supposed to be a blend of samba and JS Bach, but is merely trite. Shut Up and Listen, although supposedly mixing African music with an Irish jig, is a platitude in sound.

The best of the quartet's music occurs when they play alone. Here they mix formal, classical discipline with the rawer edges of folk and pop and generate a natural swing. This worked particularly well in My Lover and a version of Dvorak's Songs My Mother Taught Me.

But then it was back to the big band. By the time the set climaxed with a happy-clappy version of The Lion Sleeps Tonight, enough was much more than enough.

webTitle: Lever looks to develop employees' artistic skills

fields.headline: Lever looks to develop employees' artistic skills
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Lever Brothers UK this week launched a unique corporate change initiative to provide personal and team development through joint projects with artists and arts organisations.
fields.body:
Lever Brothers UK this week launched a unique corporate change initiative to provide personal and team development through joint projects with artists and arts organisations. In association with its sister company Elida Faberge the Lever Catalyst programme seeks to involve staff in the improvement of their working environment and, by going beyond traditional sponsorship, to develop employees' core skills of creativity, writing, thinking and communicating. The programme will work to boost skills through workshops run by a variety of arts-based trainers. The project kicked off with the unveiling of its art collection showing a variety of works hung on the walls of its Kingston headquarters' stairwell stretching over six floors.

James Hill, Lever Brothers chairman said: "Project Catalyst is an experimental HR programme to show that employers need to think creatively themselves if they want to inspire employees."

To mark next week's Adult Learners' Week, the Institute for Employment Studies and the National Organisation for Adult Learning have published a review of adult learning in England. The report shows that while participation in education and training is rising, there is a clear divide between those who benefit from education and training and those who do not. Co-author Jim Hillage says: "We hope the review will act as a source of comprehensive information on the state of adult education in England at the end of the 20th century. It will form a benchmark from which the impact of the new reforms can be measured." For copies of the report, priced £25, tel 01476-541061.

The latest research by the Management Charter Initiative (MCI) shows that innovation and change places new demands on organisations and their leadership capabilities that old-style hierarchybased approaches cannot easily accommodate. To address the issue of developing leaders who are fit for the future MCI and the Royal Military Academy are hosting a conference at Sandhurst next Wednesday, May 24. Speakers include Julian Richer, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, the Chief Constable of Royal Ulster Constabulary, John Monks, the TUC general secretary and General Sir Michael Jackson. For booking details tel MCI on 020-7872-6900.

fields.headline: Unfinished business
fields.standfirst:
Royal Philharmonic Orchestra/ Robert Bachmann
Barbican, London
**
fields.trailText:
Royal Philharmonic Orchestra/ Robert Bachmann
Barbican, London
**
fields.body:
Bruckner famously dedicated his Ninth Symphony to God; equally famously, he died before he finished it. The three-movement torso ranks among his greatest works, but the so-called problem of the missing finale has continued to nag in some quarters. In 1991, a performing version of the complete symphony - mind-bogglingly called the Samale-Phillips-Cohrs-Mazzuca edition - was produced by four musicologists. It has received neither the publicity nor the acclaim accorded to Deryck Cooke's completion of Mahler's Tenth and Antony Payne's version of Elgar's Third. This, in fact, was its UK premiere.

Whether it will ever take its place in the standard repertoire is debatable. Even though the symphony is technically unfinished, the three-movement version forms a complete statement in aesthetic, emotional, devotional and psychological terms. The ending of the adagio - with its magical transition from minor to major and flowing string phrases over the central chorale - is music of such spiritual certainty that it seems logical that the work should end here.

The new finale jolts us into territory that contrasts doubt with glory. The divine has become terrifying as vast brass fanfares blare judgmentally. The second subject quivers in abasement. It is impressive, but I remained unconvinced. Matters weren't helped by the performance: Swiss conductor and academic Robert Bachmann is a less than perfect interpreter of this edition.

Bruckner detractors, who see him as nothing more than solemn and grandiloquent, will have their views reinforced by Bachmann's approach. A pompous religiosity replaces religious fervour and genuine spirituality. God's majesty is equated with a high decibel count. The performance didn't find the RPO on its best form either. Only the scherzo pulverised as it should and the finale seemed merely loud. There is, perhaps, a case for the completed version of Bruckner's Ninth - but it has yet to be made.
