fields.headline: Liquidators in weekend of talks
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Liquidators of Boo.com are this weekend locked in talks with a number of potential buyers for the internet sportswear business, which collapsed in spectacular style this week.
fields.body:
Liquidators of Boo.com are this weekend locked in talks with a number of potential buyers for the internet sportswear business, which collapsed in spectacular style this week.

KPMG, the accountancy firm managing the sale, said that several possible purchasers had lodged refundable deposits of £1m, opening the door to talks.

"We are spending the weekend in talks with these interested parties and hope to find a suitable purchaser for the Boo.com business," said Mick McLoughlin, a partner in KPMG's corporate recovery department.

"A core staff of some 30 key Boo.com people have been retained to assist us with these negotiations," he said.

"If a sale is to be achieved it is imperative that any conclusion is reached as soon as possible as there are no funds for a prolonged liquidation process.

"We have not laid off any staff, as we are aware that these are key assets of the business. The clock is ticking for the future of Boo.com"

The events of the last week, which saw the company's high profile investors run out of patience, have secured Boo.com an unenviable epitaph as the most high profile failure of the internet generation.

It is not clear yet whether it will be sold as an ongoing business or broken up, if a sale is agreed at all.

A number of potential buyers have been suggested, although Adidas, the German sportswear manufacturer, was forced to deny any interest yesterday.

The company which was set up 18 months ago had been seeking another £20m to stay afloat on top of the estimated £80m already poured in.

The business was founded by two 30-year old Swedes, Ernst Malmsten and Kasja Leander, who have agreed to stay on until Boo.com's sale is agreed.

fields.headline: Missing the fun
fields.standfirst:
The Recruiting Officer
Festival Theatre,Chichester
**
fields.trailText:
The Recruiting Officer
Festival Theatre,Chichester
**
fields.body:
The 2000 Chichester season begins with the beating of a miltary drum, but the overall effect is more of a whimper than a bang. James Kerr's production approaches George Farquhar's 1706 play about military officers attempting to enlist recruits as if it were a dirge, not a comedy. Tanya McCallin's plain set looks beautiful in Tom Mannings' atmospheric lighting, but its blank nothingness is part of the void at the heart of this dispiriting production.

Farquhar's roll of wide-eyed country folk, lovelorn heiresses and sergeants and contsables with an eye to the main chance, scamper across the stage but seldom leave much impression. Only Natalie Walter's Rose, a girl well aware of her charms and ready to capitalise upon them, Nicholas Le Prevost's blustering Captain Brazen and Nicholas Tennant's Sergeant Kite, a decent man corrupted by his calling, give any sense of fully rounded characters.

Part of the problem with Kerr's production is that it fails to provide any real social or financial context: the play appears to take place in some burnished no man's land rather than the small Shropshire town with its distinct social hierarchy that Farquhar specifies. You need to know of the social and financial gulfs between the would-be lovers to understand why Silvia disguises herself as a boy to test Plume and why Melinda is so wary of Worthy's suit.

The detailed depiction of army life is rather more successful, particularly in the relationships between the soldiers. But it is hard to sit through this dreary three hours when the payback in terms of laughs is so paltry. It is not an experience that will win any recruits either for Farquhar or the Festival theatre.

fields.headline: Eternally dull
fields.standfirst:
Solemn Mass for a Full Moon in Summer
The Pit, Barbican, London
*
fields.trailText:
Solemn Mass for a Full Moon in Summer
The Pit, Barbican, London
*
fields.body:
Michel Tremblay's play, presented by the Edinburgh Traverse in a Scottish translation by Martin Bowman and Bill Findlay, kicks off the Barbican's BITE season. It is as archly pretentious as its title suggests. Set on six moonlit Montreal balconies and using the form of a secular mass, it explores the tormented passions of five assorted couples and a solitary, grieving widow.

Desperation is the stuff of drama but it only becomes interesting when given a social and economic context. Tremblay's wailing duos, however, are defined purely by their emotions and their genitalia. A harassed daughter looks after her crippled father but you learn nothing about the "work accident" that caused him to lose his arms. The tetchy Yvon complains about spending all his time at work "watching the telephone" but we never discover precisely what he does. Similarly the middle-aged lesbian lovers, whose relationship has dwindled into contempt, exist in a vacuum.

Tremblay attempts to fill the void with choral speech, overlapping phrases and lush lunar imagery. But I was reminded of those bad, quasi-religious verse dramas turned out in the 40s by people like Charles Williams. At only one point, when the characters in unison beg divine forgiveness, was I moved: otherwise it is a dramatically inert tenement tone-poem in which words substitute for action.

As directors, Philip Howard and Ros Steen orchestrate the intercut duologues and choral speeches as best they can. Among the cast, Molly Innes and John Kazek have a nice time as a pair of hetero hot-bloods, endlessly snogging, while Ann Scott-Jones has her moments as a widow recalling the joys of marital passion. But in its unsparing focus on decontextualised emotion, Tremblay's knee-trembler makes 90 minutes seem like an eternity.

Until June 3. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

webTitle: Panic selling of hi-tech stocks follows crash of Boo.com

fields.headline: Panic selling of hi-tech stocks follows crash of Boo.com
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's hi-tech stocks suffered one of their blackest days yesterday as the knock-on effects from the high profile crash of the online fashion venture Boo.com reverberated through a jittery City.
fields.body:
Britain's hi-tech stocks suffered one of their blackest days yesterday as the knock-on effects from the high profile crash of the online fashion venture Boo.com reverberated through a jittery City.

Almost 10% was wiped off the value of technology stocks as investors feared that other companies would follow Boo.com into liquidation.

Dealers reported a wave of panic selling to match the buying frenzy that accompanied the arrival to the market of lastminute.com three months ago.

Jeremy Batstone, head of research at NatWest stockbrokers, said: "We are definitely in a crash scenario in the tech sector and we question the ability of some stocks to recover to previous highs. Positive sentiment is disappearing fast."

The accountants PriceWaterhouseCoopers added to the gloom with a warning that other companies will follow Boo.com.

Lastminute.com, the company which symbolised the market's infatuation with the internet, closed last night at 141p, after falling 13p on the day. It is now worth less than a third of the 525p peak it reached on the day of its launch.

Overall, London's Techmark index lost 291.1 points to close at 3052.19, a fall of 8.73% on the day. The woes of the high technology sector spread to the blue chip FTSE100 index, which lost 187 points, or 3%, to close at 6045.4. In all, £42bn was wiped off the value of the London market.

The Footsie's fall was fuelled by tech stocks including Energis, the telecoms group, which lost 406p to £21.05, the software manufacturer Baltimore Technologies down 70p to 419p and the hand-held com puter manufacturer Psion, which fell 99p to 562p.

Mr Batstone said investors were likely to be selective in their stock selection after the recent falls. "I think people should see losing money as a very important lesson about markets," he added. "If you lose money in the markets it should act as a hearty dose of reality."

The falls started in the US overnight and with continuing weakness in North American markets yesterday, London stocks plummeted further. Worries over the prospect of rising US interest rates have knocked confidence on the other side of the Atlantic.

Wall Street was down more than 200 points in early afternoon trading after official figures revealed the US trade deficit ballooned to a record £30.2bn in March.

Traders fear that the deficit is a sign that the US federal reserve will need to raise interest rates again after this week's half point rise, to get inflation under control.

Rising interest rates are generally bad for stocks because they cut into corporate profits by increasing the cost of borrowing money.

"There is a lot of fear out there," said Alfred E. Goldman, a director of market analysis at A.G. Edwards and Sons Inc, in St Louis. "People are concerned and worried about how high interest rates will go."

Technology stocks which are particularly vulnerable to interest rate fears were also hard hit in the US. In early trading, the Nasdaq composite fell 132.32 points, or 3.74%, to 3,406.39 as some of its most heavily weighted stocks sank. Semiconductor, software and computer maker companies all fell heavily. Cisco fell 2 1/2 to 52 7/8, Intel lost 2 15/16 to 121 and Apple Computer dropped 5 5/16 to 95 7/16.

fields.headline: From gofer to partner
fields.standfirst:
When her husband abruptly lost his job, Patricia Ewen fulfilled her dream and became a top lawyer. Michael Edmands talked to her
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: When her husband abruptly lost his job, Patricia Ewen fulfilled her dream and became a top lawyer. Michael Edmands talked to her
fields.body:
I am mightily impressed by women of the Wirral. First there was Lorraine Rogers, who dragged Tranmere Rovers football club, only 48 hours from the knacker's yard, back from the brink. Now there is the redoubtable Patricia Ewen. Ms Ewen who, at the age of 35 and with two tiny children, decided when her husband came home sacked, to save the family by going back to school to become a lawyer. She is now a senior partner with Silverbeck Rymer.

As with Lorraine, football figures in Ms Ewen's background, though more tenuously. She attended grammar school just down the road from Everton. "Our family retains a soft spot for Everton," she says.

She first followed her father into the civil service via the Department of Employment. "When I took the test I was given the diplomatic service examination by mistake, which I passed. I thought I missed a great opportunity when my mother wouldn't sign the papers allowing me to travel." So there she sat in a Liverpool dole office for eight years. It was a very soft system, both for the dole dodgers and those building up their pension rights, she says. "I kept saying to myself this is not for me." About this time she spotted an advertisement in the Liverpool Echo for telephone salespeople. "It sounded interesting," she says. So off she went making cold calls for classified ads. She had to fill an arts and leisure page with ads every week.

With the job came invitations to local restaurants and venues. "They would invite me along, probably to make up the numbers, but it was fun," she says. But once more she was beginning to get what she calls the itch to move on. Then, in 1979, she got pregnant and left the Echo. Her son Nick has recently celebrated his 21st birthday and a second child, Jennifer, is studying for her A levels. Home with the babies, Ms Ewen started a sand wich business. "A friend and I made early designer sandwiches in my kitchen and went around selling them in local factories and offices, but I still knew I wasn't going to be a stay-at-home mother." So she applied to building societies for part-time work. The local Alliance & Leicester offered a 10am to 2pm shift that "was perfect for a work ing mother". Within two weeks, the event that shaped her future hit the Ewen household. It was 1983, both children were in private education and her husband was working in the building trade. "One night Ken came home and told me the company had gone belly-up and he had lost his job. His boss had salted the money away in the Cayman Islands or some place and from then on there was no money coming in."

She agrees that what had hit like a thunderbolt was probably her break. "This was serious. I had to take the lead and bring some money into this family," she says. She admits to always having thoughts about one day becoming a solicitor. "I like working with people and assisting them," she says. So what does she do? She puts the kids in the car, heads down to an open day at the local college and asks how to become a lawyer.

"I was 35 years old with two kids and was going for it," she says. She embarked on a part-time course and completed six years, by which time she had to gain work experience for the second part of her qualifications. She hawked herself around several law offices without success. "I wasn't put off," she says, "Because I felt I was good." This upbeat attitude paid off with another break. A friend had got a job as re ceptionist at Liverpool-based law firm Silverbeck Rymer and told Jim Rymer about the student mother. He agreed to see her. "He now boasts that he dragged me out of the gutter," she laughs. But he did see her and called her back to offer her a job as office "gofer." She got her degree from Chester College of Law and in 1992 became a senior partner at Silverbeck.

"Ken losing his job galvanized me. It crystallised what was already in my head. This would be my career for the rest of my working life." The firm is about to open another office in Manchester to add to Liverpool and Chelmsford, Essex. She's certain of her own worth. "I'm the one going out and getting the business," she says. "But it's no longer possible to show up with a smile and a pleasing personality. The insurance industry is our bread and butter and they mean business. They want to see the figures," she says. And it seems Ms Ewen is the one to provide them.

fields.headline: Radio days
fields.standfirst:
It's one medium whose future is assured but getting you voice on the airwaves is still a daunting challenge. Liz Stuart has a guide for wannabe wireless workers
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: It's one medium whose future is assured but getting you voice on the airwaves is still a daunting challenge. Liz Stuart has a guide for wannabe wireless workers.
fields.body:
The one form of media whose demise the internet doom-mongers are not predicting is radio. Perhaps because you can listen and log on at the same time, or perhaps because web radio is taking the medium into the technological future, radio, it is accepted, is here to stay.

Unfortunately, that does not mean that jobs abound. Journalism has always been a difficult profession to break into, and although radio is expanding in some ways, it is consolidating in others.

Will Baynes, secretary of the Broadcast Journalism Training Council, says: "One of my jobs is to place students on our recognised courses into work experience positions. But stations which took people last year, when I call them this year, say they no longer have anyone available to supervise a placement.

"With so many commercial stations coming under one management jobs are being cut to increase revenues and, unfortunately, the first to go are in the newsroom," he says.

But, with persistence, a radio journalism job is possible. At the age of 35 Martin Bedford decided that accountancy was not for him. In the face of scorn from his peers, he took an MA in radio at Goldsmiths College and within three years he had made it to the position of producer working on the BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

As with most areas of the media, there is an official entry route into radio and a back-door version which may be longer and more painful, or, if you are lucky, meteoric. As Martin Bedford says: "There is no formula."

The recognised way in is by studying for a radio journalism qualification. There are courses at both under- and post-graduate level, but the former should be viewed with large amounts of scepticism, as this is still the way they are regarded by media owners. They are too theoretical, and journalism is widely recognised as a trade rather than an art form.

Better are the apprentice-like postgraduate diplomas and MAs. These one-year, mostly bi-medial (that is, covering television as well as radio) courses give a thorough grounding in reporting skills, shorthand, technical aspects of production and recording and media law. What they do not do is guarantee a job at the end, even if you have obtained one of the rare bursaries offered by such organisations as Channel 4, ITN and the BBC, although they will have alumni links with radio stations and often include a work-place ment element. The courses are expensive - self-funding is the norm, often by taking out a Career Development Loan - and they cannot teach that feel for a story or interviewing technique which only on-the-job experience gives - but of ten potential employers will not look at someone who has not taken one. They show that you are serious about journalism.

But Nicholas Wheeler, chief editor of ITN radio, which manages LBC, News Direct Radio and produces the independent radio news which is syndicated to commercial stations throughout the country, holds out some hope for the self-starter.

"Occasionally I just come across someone who impresses me with their potential. It will usually be someone who has written to me repeatedly, sent me tapes, come in to see me and to see the programme being put out. They just have that spark, and so I take them on," he says, adding that this will only be one person per year, however.

Richard's route to the newsroom

The first foray into radio for Richard Edgar was working for a Restricted Service Licence station in Sheffield. This is a temporary licence granted to voluntary groups allowing them to broadcast for up to one month.

"The station, Forge FM, used to be attached to Sheffield University, where I was studying for an MA in the psychology of music. I went in with the intention of concentrating on arty issues, but someone grabbed me for the newsroom. That's where I developed my passion for news - it was such a buzz reading the bulletins, seeing the second hand coming up to the hour," he says.

On the back of this experience, he decided to take a postgraduate diploma in broadcast journalism at the University of Central Lancashire, during which he was offered a work placement at the BBC World Service.

"That gave me an in at the BBC and meant I was more eligible for another work placement, at Radio Sheffield. I was also at an advantage because I knew the area."

Radio Sheffield offered him a one-month contract which was extended into a full broadcast journalist job. "Reporting was fantastic. I got my own district to cover - I was always dashing off in the radio car covering a huge range of stories."

His next paid job was at World Television News as a radio reporter, which is where he first covered business issues. "I saw the job in the BBC's business unit advertised and decided to go for it. The board (the BBC interview) went so badly that I almost apologised for wasting their time," he says.

After two years at the unit, during which time he was made a senior broadcast journalist, Edgar now presents and produces the World Business Report for the World Service. "I have finally found that what I really love is being on air," he says.

Taking the mike

 Do not bother with an undergraduate media course.

 Do bother getting work experience in radio as soon as possible - preferably with a local radio station. Experience on hospital or student radio still counts.

 You will often have more chance of getting a job as a producer or researcher if you have an area of technical expertise, for example scientific knowledge or you are able to speak an "unusual" language.

 The BBC submits potential employees to a ferocious interview process formerly known as a "board". Gen up as much as possible on BBC policy and make sure you have read and mentally digested a tome called the Producer Guidelines. You will be expected to be very familiar with this (although most of it is common sense).

 Before applying for a job make sure you have listened to as much radio as possible - not just the programme or area you are applying to work in but as many different styles of programme as possible. This will show at interview.

 It is also worth reading up on digital radio, web radio and other new developments in the medium. Not only may these new areas be actively recruiting, an understanding of the future trends in technology will show up in an interview.

 Broadcast Journalism Training Council 020-7727-9522, www.bjtc.org.uk.

webTitle: It's the economy - don't be stupid

fields.headline: It's the economy - don't be stupid
fields.standfirst:
Nick Pandya introduces a series on the challenges of running new technology firms and the effect it will have on our work practices
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Nick Pandya introduces a series on the challenges of running new technology firms and the effect it will have on our work practices.
fields.body:
Now one of the first requirements for a man who is fit to handle pig iron... is that he shall be so stupid and phlegmatic that he more nearly resembles in his mental makeup the ox.

No, it's not some hard-nosed Victorian industrialist talking, but the most charismatic management teacher of the 20th century, Fredrick Winslow Taylor. It was he who gave the business world "scientific management" or time and motion studies, universally despised by the workers of the world. His idea of organising work based on analysis of the component tasks boosted productivity to unprecedented levels so that the prosperity of the developed economies is unimaginable without him.

Taylor was not alone. Henry Ford, talked about "the reduction of the necessity for thought on the part of the worker", too. And yet both Taylor and Ford were wrong: people are not oxen. That message got through to business leaders in the 20s and 30s after workers' often violent response to time and motion studies. Big business was forced to concede that workers were human and that they are "knowledge workers". What is incredible in this first year of the new millennium is that despite all the hype about how the new knowledge-based digital economy is transforming corporate structures, most companies find it unbearable to imagine new ways of organising working practices.

The key issues now facing managers are the same as those which their counterparts wrestled with in the 80s: attracting and motivating workers, the value of teams, organising by projects, using infotech wisely and delayering management structures.

In the real world, skilled, knowledgeable workers are making the most of the frictionless dot.com economy. They work for whomever and from wherever they like. Millions of freelance workers roam cyberspace selling their knowledge-based labour to such organisations as may need their services in an anonymous transaction at an optimal price.

The message for corporate leaders is the opposite of Taylor's. In the digital economy management is seen as an art. Corporate leaders who understand that to gain competetive advantage they have to tap their employees' tacit knowledge will be at the forefront of companies in the digital economy. Organisations which truly believe that human capital is their most important asset and have put in place strategic human resource frameworks will be the next generation of high-performance businesses.

The world is moving so fast that there is no time to argue with corporate conservatives adopting a wait-and-see approach. By the time they grasp the threat it may be too late to mount an effective counter-attack by rapidly e-enabling their enterprises.

Asked to pick a company he most admired for successfully realising the potential of the internet, John Noakes, business manager of Biztalk Microsoft, chose Harley Davidson for its ability to embrace a global sales network with the appropriate inter net, intranet and extranet technologies in a way that totally revitalised the business.

Over the next five weeks this page will invite hands-on e-business practitioners to discuss their vision of a truly web-enabled enterprise.

Next week Alex Allen, the government's e-envoy, kicks off the series deconstructing e-commerce and the part the government is playing in developing an economic climate to support it. Following articles will address issues such as how to educate the board to embrace the new electronic paradigm, by Marco Rochat of PricewaterhouseCoopers. Louise Proddow of Sun Microsystems outlines how to get your dot.com idea online by using application service providers.

Richard Watney, chief executive of Elateral, explains how to manage a brand in e-business space and Will White, deputy director of the Management Consultancies Association, will discuss why Howarth Consulting picked up MCA's first ever e-consulting award which helped the charity Cards for Good Causes boost its revenues, showing that even voluntary organisations benefit from adopting e-commerce.

webTitle: England must find cure for the spot-kick 'disease'

fields.headline: England must find cure for the spot-kick 'disease'
fields.trailText: Our players are going to have to get over this psychological hurdle. Either that or they damn well take their chances during open play.
fields.body:
Sportsmen in their prime do not countenance failure. Like a child in a school play who has no fear of forgetting lines or feeling embarrassed wearing a silly costume, Faldo, Borg and Beckenbauer in their pomp were never stage-struck.

And for some inexplicable reason, four men from Galatasaray were blessed with this overwhelming confidence in Copenhagen on Wednesday evening, whereas two men from Arsenal (via Croatia and France) succumbed to sport's cruellest humiliation. Davor Suker and Patrick Vieira, world-class performers, were reduced to shambling wrecks when wearing an English club shirt.

Glenn Hoddle described England's inability to kick a ball from 12 yards into a goal measuring eight yards by eight feet as a "disease" and gave it as an excuse for not practising penalties a great deal in preparation for France 98. His successor as coach of the England team, Kevin Keegan, spoke last week about being unable to "recreate the same conditions" on the training field.

Something mysterious is going on here. We had Chris Waddle and Stuart Pearce against Germany in Italia 90, we had Gareth Southgate in Euro 96 and then David Batty in the last World Cup. Why do we keep failing in these shoot-outs?

Some will point to a deficiency in our mental make-up; others will insist that we simply don't practise enough.

Hoddle said after Batty's failure against Argentina: "I'm not denying practice does help, but a golfer can practise 1,000 putts on the putting green and he can then go out on the last day of a tournament when there's a big crowd and miss. If it was all down to practice then it would be a simple scenario."

But surely practice helps boost confidence and gives those poor souls who are confronted with a shoot-out enough mental images of past successes to carry with them during that long walk from the halfway line.

You only have to witness the amount of time Zola puts in at the Chelsea training ground to see how those wonderful bending free-kicks he delivers are not a result of natural ability alone. A repetitive routine of taking dozens a day helps fine-tune his natural gifts.

Whether it's taking penalties, serving with consistent accuracy at 120mph, tapping a ball into a cup from six inches, or indeed sitting a maths test, if you are crippled with tension you are doomed.

The golf commentator Peter Alliss described this overpowering tension when he suffered from a career-threatening attack of the yips.

"I stood over the ball, lining up the putt," he told me, "and suddenly I was gripped by negative thoughts. I couldn't visualise the ball going in. I was frightened of failure and I could barely draw back the putter to make contact with the ball."

Fifa's president Sepp Blatter, head of the game's world governing body, isn't a fan of penalty shoot-outs, suggesting that this do-or-die solution, fit more for the Colosseum than a soccer stadium, promotes "individualism" in the game and causes great "trauma" to the players.

Perhaps what he is forgetting is that shoot-outs provide unforgettable moments of drama and tension for the spectator.

It's the nearest thing to a gladiatorial fight to the death that the civilised world can conjure. At boxing big nights, movie stars pay thousands to sit at ringside for a world heavyweight championship to hear the groans, to smell the fear and to get a splash of blood on their tuxedos.

Wednesday evening's Uefa Cup final was pretty turgid for 90 minutes and wasn't a lot better during extra-time, where the golden-goal rule was in operation. The best bit was the shoot-out.

There appears to be no rational alternative to the shoot-out, other than to employ a complex series of solutions based on the number of corner kicks, the number of yellow cards or the number of genuine attempts at goal.

They could, I suppose, add up the collective wealth of the players (which England would usually win) or give marks out of 10 for the better turned-out team, but that would be unfair on the Albanians.

No, we are simply stuck with this kick to the death. And it just means that our players are going to have to get over this psychological hurdle. Either that or they damn well take their chances during open play.

fields.headline: Adams orders a pick-me-up
fields.standfirst: Marseille's Robert Pires is the No1 target for Arsène Wenger in summer sales
fields.trailText: Marseille's Robert Pires has become the No1 target for Arsenal in the summer sales as Arsène Wenger seeks to strengthen this squad for a renewed assault on Europe next season.
fields.body:
It was nearly 3am on the flight home from Copenhagen when the voice of Tony Adams came over the PA. Truly this was the captain speaking, and his message to the team and the fans in the aftermath of Arsenal's Uefa Cup final defeat was clear.

"It's not how you protect yourself when you're falling down that's important," said the 33-year-old - and as a recovering alcoholic he should know. "What matters is how you get up when you've fallen." This summer Arsenal have a lot of getting up to do.

By most standards it has not been a disastrous season. Finishing second in the Premiership and the Uefa Cup is a record Leeds, Liverpool and others would gladly take. But for Arsène Wenger and Adams a second successive term without a trophy - and a second successive failure in the Champions League - constitutes underachievement.

The strengthening process seems likely to begin faster than you can say Galatasaray. Yesterday the France midfielder Robert Pires, in whom Wenger admits an interest, announced he was considering a £7m move from Marseille.

"As far as I know I will be leaving to join Arsenal and playing in the Champions League next season," said the 26-year-old, who scored the winner against Chelsea in that competition in February. "I will just give myself a couple of days to think about it.

"Nothing has been settled yet, but if I join it would be to play on the left side of midfield. That is my natural role and one I occupied with Metz but I have hardly had the chance to do so with Marseille.

"Marc Overmars currently plays in that position for Arsenal. But there is the possibility that he might leave because Luis van Gaal at Barcelona has expressed an interest in him. However, even if he stays put I can still see myself moving."

Further new arrivals seem certain, notably a centre-forward to replace Davor Suker. Arsenal might have been celebrating rather than commiserating today if the Croatian, with his last touch for the club, and Patrick Vieira had found net instead of woodwork in the shoot-out against Galatasaray. But they can have few complaints after a below-par performance. The line that divides success and failure is notoriously thin and too often of late Arsenal have been just the wrong side of it.

Wembley did not help in the Champions League, yet they were only a wasted Nwankwo Kanu penalty in Fiorentina from going through. Injuries disrupted a Premiership campaign which ended 18 points adrift of Manchester United. Adams's presence and leadership, in particular, were missed during his absence. Dennis Bergkamp has had a poor year by his standards.

In key areas this has been a period of transition. Thierry Henry needed time to settle into Nicolas Anelka's shoes and Arsenal suffered for that. At the back the famous five have grown older and been split. It can be no coincidence that 43 league goals were conceded this season compared with 17 last term. Whether Nigel Winterburn will remain at Highbury, as Wenger hopes, is open to doubt. Emmanuel Petit is another with an uncertain future.

A run of 12 consecutive wins from March was a pointer to promise for next season, eight of them in the Premiership to secure a Champions League berth which Wenger admitted was more important than winning the Uefa Cup.

Yet the manager must have been dismayed by his players' performance on Wednesday. Tactically Galatasaray outwitted them, tackling tigerishly and closing down quickly to knock them out of their rhythm. Then, for the third time in cup shoot-outs this season, Arsenal lost their nerve.

Not that Adams sounded dismayed. After winning the Cup Winners' Cup in Copenhagen in 1994 he proclaimed over the plane intercom: "Now let's get lamped." This time the pronouncement was more sober. "The fat lady is not singing. This team has got a couple more trophies in it yet."

That is my natural role and one I occupied with Metz but I have hardly had the chance to do so with Marseille. "Marc Overmars currently plays in that position for Arsenal. But there is the possibility that he might leave because Luis van Gaal at Barcelona has expressed an interest in him. However, even if he stays put I can still see myself moving." Further new arrivals seem certain, notably a centre-forward to replace Davor Suker. Arsenal might have been celebrating rather than commiserating today if the Croatian, with his last touch for the club, and Patrick Vieira had found net instead of woodwork in the shoot-out against Galatasaray. But they can have few complaints after a below-par performance. The line that divides success and failure is notoriously thin and too often of late Arsenal have been just the wrong side of it. Wembley did not help in the Champions League, yet they were only a wasted Nwankwo Kanu penalty in Fiorentina from going through. Injuries disrupted a Premiership campaign which ended 18 points adrift of Manchester United. Adams's presence and leadership, in particular, were missed during his absence. Dennis Bergkamp has had a poor year by his standards. In key areas this has been a period of transition. Thierry Henry needed time to settle into Nicolas Anelka's shoes and Arsenal suffered for that. At the back the famous five have grown older and been split. It can be no coincidence that 43 league goals were conceded this season compared with 17 last term. Whether Nigel Winterburn will remain at Highbury, as Wenger hopes, is open to doubt. Emmanuel Petit is another with an uncertain future. A run of 12 consecutive wins from March was a pointer to promise for next season, eight of them in the Premiership to secure a Champions League berth which Wenger admitted was more important than winning the Uefa Cup. Yet the manager must have been dismayed by his players' performance on Wednesday. Tactically Galatasaray outwitted them, tackling tigerishly and closing down quickly to knock them out of their rhythm. Then, for the third time in cup shoot-outs this season, Arsenal lost their nerve. Not that Adams sounded dismayed. After winning the Cup Winners' Cup in Copenhagen in 1994 he proclaimed over the plane intercom: "Now let's get lamped." This time the pronouncement was more sober. "The fat lady is not singing. This team has got a couple more trophies in it yet."

fields.headline: Medical row looms over Casiraghi
fields.trailText: Chelsea are awaiting the results of medical examinations on their injured striker Pierluigi Casiraghi which may lead to a £4m insurance claim being filed.
fields.body:
Chelsea are awaiting the results of medical examinations on their injured striker Pierluigi Casiraghi which may lead to a £4m insurance claim being filed.

Although Casiraghi appears determined to return from the serious knee ligament injury which has kept him out for 18 months, Chelsea fear the Italian's playing career is over.

In a move which may well lead to a dispute with the striker, a then Chelsea record £5.4m signing in May 1998, the London club have set the claim process rolling. But specialists must first confirm that the 31-year-old Casiraghi's career is over and there already appears to be a disagreement over accessing his medical records.

Chelsea reportedly have said that Casiraghi, due to watch his side in tomorrow's FA Cup final, has given them permission to access medical reports. These would be forwarded to the insurers.

But Casiraghi's agent Fabio Parisi said: "Pierluigi has not signed anything ... the club are still paying his contract and he is still a Chelsea player." His lawyer Fraser Reid said: "Pierluigi still believes he can be a professional footballer with Chelsea or any other club that might be interested in him."

Meanwhile, another former Chelsea player, Brian Laudrup, announced yesterday that his career was over due to a chronic achilles tendon injury.

Laudrup, also 31, has quit after a 14-year career that saw the Danish forward win 81 caps and play for Rangers before a spell with Chelsea which ended early in the 1998-99 season after complaining of homesickness. He went to FC Copenhagen but then moved on again, to Ajax.

West Ham have completed the £4m signing of the French striker Frédéric Kanouté from Lyon with the midfielder Marc Vivien Foe going in the opposite direction for £6m.

Chesterfield have named Nicky Law, caretaker since March, as their new manager.

webTitle: Zola lines up a parting shot

fields.headline: Zola lines up a parting shot
fields.standfirst: Chelsea's Italian talisman still hopes to do the right thing by his many fans
fields.trailText: Roy Collins finds Chelsea's Italian talisman still hoping to do the right thing by his many fans.
fields.body:
The sentiment would be beyond the understanding of David Beckham, who begs for privacy even as he is selling pictures of his wedding, his child, his dog and his latest tattoo to Hello! magazine. But the most beautiful aspect of life in England for Gianfranco Zola is the ease with which he is able to retreat out of range of the paparazzi lenses.

Okay, Zola is not married to a pop star for whom publicity is a raison d'etre . But he is still a high-profile, world-renowned footballer at a club that has an even more fashionable image than Manchester United.

Yet he says: "I love the passion of the fans at matches and the atmosphere they create. And the fact that, after enjoying all that, you can go home, relax and live your life. There is nowhere else you can do that and it is why I will be very sad when I have to leave England."

Zola, 34 in two months' time, talks like a man who, mentally at least, already has his bags packed. He could be off soon after the final whistle of tomorrow's FA Cup final if Chelsea cannot give assurances that he will have a leading role next season. Although he insists that age has not withered him, the odds are that he will be a victim of the club's plans to regenerate the side.

To many supporters, his departure from Chelsea seems unthinkable. In four years at Stamford Bridge he has become the heart of the side, if not the club. He even managed to spread his charm so wide that, after arriving only in November of the 1996-97 season and playing only 23 games, he won the Footballer of the Year award by a landslide.

In a popularity competition among Chelsea players, Zola would reduce all his team-mates to the role of Norwegians in the Eurovision Song Contest. You only have to watch him clowning in training, playfully stroking George Weah's face as he tries to give an interview, and issuing instructions to the club chef at the club's Harlington headquarters. And signing autographs long after fellow players have revved their Ferraris down the nearby M4.

On the field, his goals have added the grace notes to Chelsea's most memorable performances this season. He scored in the trouncing of Sunderland on the Premiership's opening day, in the 5-0 destruction of Galatasaray that now looks sensational. And, of course, in the most memorable night of all, when Barcelona were thrashed 3-1 at the Bridge.

Chelsea failed to hold on at the Nou Camp but Zola says: "We did very well in the Champions League. We started with an excellent performance against AC Milan and proved that we can compete with the best teams in Europe.

"Unfortunately, we did not do so well in the Premiership. So we need to close the season properly in the FA Cup final. I think we deserve something after the season we have had. It would be a pity not to close the season properly, to win the Cup and do things right."

Zola has a great sense of doing things right, which is why he can only offer one of those impossibly wide, toothy smiles when asked whether he has already signed a prenuptial agreement with the Istanbul club Fenerbahce. Before making any decisions, he says, he will sit down with the Chelsea manager Gianluca Vialli and managing director Colin Hutchinson next week to discuss their views on what role, if any, they envisage for him next season.

He is not content to accept a cameo role, which has as much to do with his age as his ego, though he still believes in his own talents. He says: "I may be almost 34 but I am still very competitive. I always have things to prove. The day I don't feel that I have anything to prove to anyone I will probably stop playing."

He has little to prove to Vialli, the Chelsea fans or the football world at large. And at Chelsea, he says, he has had the happiest days of his life. Both because of a style of football that has remained sexy long after the departure of Ruud Gullit and because of a privacy unknown in Italy or the Beckham household, which has allowed him to smell the flowers along the way.

He does not yet know whether he will play any part in tomorrow's final against Aston Villa. But it is certain that Vialli, who also embraces the concept that there is a correct way of doing things, will not replicate the treatment he received from Gullit in the 1997 final against Middlesbrough.

Vialli, who for months was ignored by his former friend Gullit on and off the training field having lost his place in the team, was left sitting on the Wembley bench for 88 minutes. When he was finally brought on, ironically for Zola, it seemed to be almost a deliberate act of humiliation by Gullit.

Even if Vialli cannot find a starting place for Zola tomorrow, one suspects he will give him a decent run. A chance to milk the applause and say his farewell to Chelsea fans if it is his final game. A chance, as Zola himself might say, to close out a season and a phase of his life in the proper manner.

webTitle: City hound Bassett at the last

fields.headline: City hound Bassett at the last
fields.standfirst: Barnsley win 5-2 on aggregate
fields.trailText:
Barnsley 1 - 2 Birmingham
Barnsley win 5-2 on aggregate
fields.body:
The drama and controversy that has attached itself to so many play-off contests in this, and other, seasons was largely absent from Oakwell as Dave Bassett continued his remarkable one-man promotion industry. But spare a thought for Birmingham City.

A season beset by injury offered no respite in the post-season. Ten first-team players, including two goalkeepers were absent from this effort to overhaul a 4-0 first-leg deficit.

As if those odds were not unfavourable enough, they faced a manager who is to the promotion campaign what Bill Gates is to computers, churning them out at a rate and with an accomplishment others cannot match. If Barnsley beat Ipswich in the play-off final it will be their manager's eighth elevation, beating the record he shares with Graham Taylor.

If the pendulum of destiny is not already swinging towards South Yorkshire, then the fact that Bank Holiday Monday will be Barnsley's first Wembley appearance in their 113-year history - making them the last team in the top two divisions to appear at the stadium - may help to swing it.

Birmingham's effort was laudable, if doomed. With a large travelling support packed behind one goal, the visitors attacked the mission with the aim of unsettling Bassett and his four-goal cushion.

At times it looked like it might work. The opening seconds saw a Bryan Hughes header hit Chris Morgan, wrongfooting his keeper and going a corner, while a Gary Rowett free-kick caused momentary alarm.

Hughes sent a right-foot vol ley, from the corner of the area, over the goal and Marcelo was allowed two shots on goal in the same attack, Kevin Miller saving well from the second.

But every tick of the clock dragged Barnsley a second closer to that historic date at Wembley and by the time Paul Furlong missed Birmingham's best chance of the first quarter, heading Marcelo's cross just wide, their slender chance seemed to have disappeared.

If Bruce Dyer had been two feet to the right with a fearsome drive following a poor slip by defender Darren Purse, the whole issue would have been academic.

But in the 34th minute Birmingham's energetic start produced the desired effect.

A deep leftwing cross from full-back Michael Johnson hung tantalisingly in the air long enough for his fellow full-back Gary Rowett to arrive unmarked and place a perfectly executed header looping into the top corner of the goal.

Birmingham desperately needed an early second-half goal if they were to add to Bassett's unease.

But in the 55th minute it was Barnsley's Matty Appleby and the effective Craig Hignett who swept the ball forward with City at full stretch for Dyer to ease between two defenders and score with a finish of training-ground ease from 15 yards.

There were a few more moments of hope left in Birmingham's season. In the 75th minute the substitute Stan Lazaridis, with his first touch of the game, sent a short corner darting into the box for Marcelo to head in unmarked.

fields.headline: Move over Arnie
fields.standfirst: Every Monday during the close season we asked a county player how he'd been filling his time before the cricket started again. Speaking in February, this is how Ed Giddins, who took 5 for 15 in the first Test against Zimbabwe at Lord's yesterday, revealed he'd been building up his muscles for the new season
fields.trailText: Ed Giddins, 28, opens the bowling for Warwickshire. He played for Sussex from 1991 to 1996 but was banned for a year for using cocaine. He won his first Test cap against New Zealand at The Oval last summer, taking four for 79, but was overlooked for the winter tours before returning triumphantly yesterday.
fields.body:
Ed Giddins, 28, opens the bowling for Warwickshire. He played for Sussex from 1991 to 1996 but was banned for a year for using cocaine. He won his first Test cap against New Zealand at The Oval last summer, taking four for 79, but was overlooked for the winter tours before returning triumphantly yesterday.

"This winter has been rather different. I've spent the majority of it up at the Lilleshall Human Performance Centre. I've been working with the trainers up there, joining in with a lot of footballers coming back from injury. I'm not that up on football so I'm not sure if I've been with anyone famous, apart from Jason Lee - Pineapple Head.

My new muscles helped me with all the lifting I had to do over Christmas when I was running a Christmas-tree business with Surrey's Nadeem Shahid. It went OK. Last year not many people were selling trees but this year everyone was, and people started getting nasty. Someone spray-painted our shop and we got some threatening letters. So the Christmas trees look like they might have been put to bed.

After Christmas Nad and I, on a whim, went to Heathrow airport and 20-odd hours later found ourselves on Sydney Harbour Bridge, celebrating with the masses. We met up with Ian Salisbury, Jason Ratcliffe and some others. I was originally going to stay for the rest of the winter but I came back on January 14 because I wanted to do more work at Lilleshall. I've got one week left and then we go back to Warwickshire full time.

I go to Warwickshire every Monday. A gym has just been built there and there is a new fitness guru, Simon Hollyhead. This is new for us because there has never been any quality training facility during the winter at Warwickshire - we were pretty much left to our own devices. Now we might not be able to bat or bowl but we all look like Arnold Schwarzenegger.

I am reluctant to say if I feel much fitter because every single bloody March or April you read cricketers saying they are so much fitter than they were last year. But I have done lots of work. I haven't done any bowling outside yet, but my serve at tennis is definitely quicker. I serve with a bent-arm action so everyone says that it is not much different to my bowling.

It's been very quiet on the party front. I had a large millennium night, like a million other people, but nothing much since then. I've been listening to Talk Sport in the car and watching the cricket on Sky, whose coverage was very good.

I've had no contact with anyone from England though I phoned David Graveney from the Christmas-tree shop to let him know I was available. He said, 'Thanks very much, I'll let the South Africans know.'

I'm looking forward to working as a unit with the lads up at Warwickshire, and to bowling in tandem with Allan Donald. Last year he wasn't fit. Of course there's also the small matter of rectifying the fact that we're in the wrong division."

Ed Giddins was talking to Tanya Aldred.

webTitle: A rare glimpse of a pot of gold

fields.headline: A rare glimpse of a pot of gold
fields.trailText: The second day of the Test series was just like the first: a ragbag of weather (it never rains but it hails), only half a day's play in terms of overs, but more than enough for England to dominate. This is what home Tests must have been like in the late Fifties, when Peter May and co. lorded it over hapless teams of cannon fodder from New Zealand or India.
fields.body:
The second day of the Test series was just like the first: a ragbag of weather (it never rains but it hails), only half a day's play in terms of overs, but more than enough for England to dominate. This is what home Tests must have been like in the late Fifties, when Peter May and co. lorded it over hapless teams of cannon fodder from New Zealand or India.

It was a great day for rainbows, and England's batsmen had a rare glimpse of a pot of gold. Yesterday Ed Giddins took the softest five-for in living memory; today the top order motored to the easiest first-innings lead in the 23 years that Cornhill Insurance have been laying on close-of-play drinks. It's tempting fate to say it, but we'll say it anyway: it was like watching Worcestershire v Oxford University in the Parks.

At least it was when anyone but Heath Streak was bowling. If you were picking a composite team out of these two sides, Streak is the one Zimbabwean who could be sure of a place (at the expense, on current evidence, of Darren Gough). Streak was impressively reminiscent of Chris Cairns and Dion Nash at Lord's last year: full of heart but also full of guile, varying his length, pace and swing. He has 3 for 41; the rest of the attack, if you can call it that, has 0 for 117, on a pitch that is still favouring the bowlers.

England lost only two wickets in the day. Mike Atherton got an inducker that kept low when he was surely on course for his first Test hundred at Lord's - and doubtless aware that he may not get another go in this game. Still, he had quietly played himself back into form, and his feet were moving better than they have for much of the past three years.

Nasser Hussain missed out altogether, regressing to his younger self with a recumbent slice straight to the man at backward point, shrewdly placed by Andy Flower. Alec Stewart came close to a similar faux pas when he hooked off-balance and his top-edge bisected the two men waiting for the catch. But Graeme Hick began serenely, as if he too was struck by the resemblance to the Parks. His foot movement was decisive, right forward for the push-drive, right back for the whipped pull, until he was past 50, when a leaden poke at Neil Johnson gave poor A Flower his second embarrassing miss of the match.

In the WCM office, we had had a sweepstake on what Hick would score in his first Test innings against his former countrymen. Tanya Aldred said 2, I said 14, and Steven Lynch went for 168. Which goes to show: if in doubt, Ask Steven.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly.

Mike Atherton got an inducker that kept low when he was surely on course for his first Test hundred at Lord's - and doubtless aware that he may not get another go in this game. Still, he had quietly played himself back into form, and his feet were moving better than they have for much of the past three years. Nasser Hussain missed out altogether, regressing to his younger self with a recumbent slice straight to the man at backward point, shrewdly placed by Andy Flower. Alec Stewart came close to a similar faux pas when he hooked off-balance and his top-edge bisected the two men waiting for the catch. But Graeme Hick began serenely, as if he too was struck by the resemblance to the Parks. His foot movement was decisive, right forward for the push-drive, right back for the whipped pull, until he was past 50, when a leaden poke at Neil Johnson gave poor A Flower his second embarrassing miss of the match. In the WCM office, we had had a sweepstake on what Hick would score in his first Test innings against his former countrymen. Tanya Aldred said 2, I said 14, and Steven Lynch went for 168. Which goes to show: if in doubt, Ask Steven. Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly.

webTitle: Hick puts England in a position of strength

fields.headline: Hick puts England in a position of strength
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe 83
England 175 for 3
fields.trailText: England are in a strong position at the end of a rain-interrupted second day of the first Test against Zimbabwe at Lord's. Amid several showers - and one burst of hail - England closed on 175 for 3 and lead Zimbabwe by 92 runs. Graeme Hick, playing his first Test innings against his former countrymen, was unbeaten on 62, with Alec Stewart not out 14.
fields.body:
England are in a strong position at the end of a rain-interrupted second day of the first Test against Zimbabwe at Lord's. Amid several showers - and one burst of hail - England closed on 175 for 3 and lead Zimbabwe by 92 runs. Graeme Hick, playing his first Test innings against his former countrymen, was unbeaten on 62, with Alec Stewart not out 14.

Play began an hour late after some early rain in London, but Mike Atherton was soon into his stride, square-cutting the left-arm medium pace of Bryan Strang for four, before going down on one knee to launch the same bowler to the cover boundary. But Zimbabwe struck back when Nasser Hussain, who had already taken successive boundaries off Strang (through mid-off, then through the covers), drove hard at Heath Streak and was well taken by Bryan Murphy at cover point above his head. Hussain had made 10, and England were 49 for 2.

Hick joined Atherton and didn't take long to tuck into Zimbabwe's bowling, which looked innocuous when Streak wasn't charging in from the pavilion end. Hick pulled Neil Johnson for a cracking four, and brought up England's hundred by repeating the shot against Guy Whittall, whom he square-cut for another boundary next ball.

Atherton reached fifty with a scurried single into the covers, but fell shortly after when Streak trapped him leg before for 55 - even if replays showed that Atherton had got an inside edge.

But from 113 for 3, England were troubled only by the weather as Hick moved up a gear. Strang suffered most: first Hick square-cut him powerfully for four, then played a delightful late-cut for three next ball before smashing Strang through the covers for four more. He got to a fine fifty with yet another cover-driven boundary, again off Strang, whose lack of pace gave him little margin for error.

The players went off for bad light at 5.11pm, re-emerged at 5.40 and trotted off again five minutes later, much to the annoyance of the crowd. When they came out for one final go at 6.35, with the score on 160 for 3, Hick was immediately put down by Andy Flower behind the stumps as he edged a nothing drive at Johnson. The ball ran away for four. It was Flower's second bad miss after dropping Mark Ramprakash yesterday evening off an even simpler chance. Who knows how much events in Zimbabwe are playing on his mind.

But England survived until the close, and are now in a formidable position. Their only problem might be the weather. More showers are forecast for tomorrow - it could be another frustrating day.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: Day ten: The Waterworks, a period howler, empty seats and planet celeb

fields.headline: Day ten: The Waterworks, a period howler, empty seats and planet celeb
fields.standfirst: Fiachra Gibbons reports on John Waters, the Sound of Mucus, and models modelling themselves to death; a French London-set period piece that left the French in raptures, but actually left a lot to be desired; empty screening seats, and Liz Taylor's star-studded Aids benefit
fields.trailText: Fiachra Gibbons reports on John Waters, the Sound of Mucus, and models modelling themselves to death; a French London-set period piece that left the French in raptures, but actually left a lot to be desired; empty screening seats, and Liz Taylor's star-studded Aids benefit
fields.body:
Cecil B Demented, John Waters' new film about a group of movie-lovers who kidnap and torture stars as revenge for being subjected to crummy performances may not be his best film, but Waters the raconteur was on vintage form when he went head to head with American comedian Joan Rivers in Cannes last night.

Rivers, a walking warning of the hazards of cosmetic surgery, managed to ply a string a confessions from the Baltimore Catholic boy gone bad.

Hairspray, his biggest hit, it emerged, was also his greatest disappointment. "I accidentally made a family movie. When I got a PG rating, I was so ashamed. I wanted to slit my wrists." Then came a slightly worrying insight into the mind of the adolescent auteur. "I used to get my kicks at drive-in movies. Baltimore was the place that they tested all the Russ Meyer stuff on. I think it was those women and their amazing projectile breasts that had such a forming influence on me. We used to get up to all sorts of things. I left the drive-in once in handcuffs - everybody looks better under arrest."

Waters revealed that he had persuaded his straight-laced middle-class dad to cough up the money for his first film, Eat Your Make-Up, "which involved us kidnapping supermodels and forcing them to eat their make-up. There was also some very harrowing scenes where we made them model themselves to death."

His father has watched his career with horror since. "He always tells me that my films are spreading like cancer. [My parents] still wish I had made the Sound of Music - but I would have probably made the Sound of Mucus."

 Meanwhile, back in the competition where the films shown last often win (despite Rosetta last year when there was no one left round to see it), Esther Kahn kicked off a busy weekend. A French film set in Victorian London, its director Arnaud Desplechin was hailed "a genius" by no less than eminent French critic Michel Sciment, and the film "a masterpiece". However most of the English-speaking critics were left wondering what all the fuss was about.

Apart from some horrific period howlers - people didn't say "fuck" all the time in the 1880s - its evocation of the Jewish East End was also well off the mark.

 Michael Haneke's Code Inconnu, starring Juliette Binoche, was a major disappointment, with lots of empty seats long before the screening finished, and Roy Andersson's Songs from the Second Floor, was not quite the Palme d'Or contender many had expected. With the score of Benny Andersson (of Abba fame), it is a crazy, totally odd comedy about a man cracking up somewhere in the far North. Andersson shot it in a studio in his back garden, but there's nothing confined about the film.

 Dame Liz, who looked like she'd come to land at Cannes from somewhere beyond our solar system, doddered to her huge £100,000-a table Aids benefit to the sound of cheering and whistles from around 700 assembled fans. Although ordinary mortals were kept well away from the saintly celebs, it was clear from the interesting variety of walking methods on show as they left several hours later that a good night was had by all. It was not recorded how, or on what, Dame Liz left the building.

fields.headline: Father figures
fields.standfirst: In case Tony Blair has forgotten how - or how not - to raise a child, we offer a selection of cautionary tales...
fields.trailText: In case Tony Blair has forgotten how - or how not - to raise a child, we offer a selection of cautionary tales...
fields.body:
John Gummer
Many high profile parents like to keep their children out of the media spotlight. Not John Gummer. As agriculture minister at the height of the BSE crisis he displayed a streak of political expediency unknown even in today's opportunistic Tory party when he force-fed his four-year-old daughter Cordelia a hamburger in front of the press. In the same month Mr Gummer was secretly discussing whether the entire British herd should be culled or not.

Cronos
In classical mythology Cronos was more of a moderniser than Tony Blair. The King of the Titans (whom we now know as Saturn or Old Father Time) lay the foundations for the world as we know it when he castrated his father Uranus (heaven) on the advice of his mother Gaea (earth) and separated heaven from earth. Warned by his parents that one of his children would overthrow him, Cronos experienced difficult family relationships that manifested themselves in displays of the utmost control freakery. He swallowed his five children Hestia, Demeter, Hera, Hades, and Poseidon one by one until Zeus (who his mother had hidden on Crete) grew up, forced Cronos to disgorge his siblings, and waged war on his father.

Jonathan Aitken
We do not know if history will record the convicted former cabinet minister as a more or less likeable figure than Cronos but the small detail that he allowed his 17-year-old daughter to commit perjury on his behalf may mean we remember him as a less than perfect father.

Bill Clinton
Chelsea Clinton is trailed around campus by a posse of secret service agents as she studies medicine at Stanford university. Mr Blair has protected his children from press intrusion but he would do well to learn from Bill Clinton that when there is a time when even the most powerful man in the world cannot protect his daughter. Carolyn Starr, daughter of her father's tormentor, Kenneth, compounded the peculiarity of Miss Clinton's time at Stanford. Chelsea once told Starr to stay away from her.

Earl Russell
In 1848, Lord John Russell became the last prime minister to father a child in office until Mr Blair had his surprise. He was a different man to Downing Street's current incumbent and led a government dogged by poor trade, high unemployment and the Irish Potato Famine. He was eventually brought down by a minister he had sacked, Lord Palmerston.

fields.headline: Booked by the KitKat cop
fields.standfirst: Quick snacking, kissing birds and toilet trauma
fields.trailText: Quick snacking, kissing birds and toilet trauma
fields.body:
Criminally chocolatey fingers
Those who feel the police are not doing enough to apprehend the real criminals in society will gratified by events in Hampshire this week, where a man was fined for eating a KitKat. Trouble started when Kevin Storey, 33, of Grantham, Lincolnshire, was driving down the M3 on his way to a christening in Poole. Just outside Winchester he was signalled to pull over onto the hard shoulder by a police patrol car. Since he was at the time doing 68mph in a zone restricted to 50mph he feared that he was about to receive a speeding ticket. The officer concerned, however, was less interested by Mr Storey's speed than the fact that he had been driving whilst eating a two-fingered chocolate KitKat. Although the KitKat had actually been unwrapped by Mr Storey's wife, it nonetheless presented a serious hazard to other road users, explained the officer, since the mouth-watering combination of crisp crunchy wafer and rich milk chocolate could distract his attention from the motorway ahead. He was duly cautioned and issued with a £20 on-the-spot fine, although this was later withdrawn on appeal. "We accept that in this case our patrolmen was a little over-zealous," admitted a police spokesman. "KitKats aren't, in themselves, a significant threat to law and order. If it had been a Ginsters Cornish Pasty, on the other hand, he wouldn't have got off so lightly." The Hampshire Chronicle

Swan luck
There are some situations for which no amount of first-aid training can prepare you. One such is giving the kiss of life to a swan. But this was the course of action a Scottish man was forced to take recently when he found a sick swan floating in the river at the bottom of his garden. Des McAllister, of Kilmun, was weeding his herbaceous borders when he noticed the stricken bird bobbing around in the fast-flowing River Echaig. Realising it was in trouble he stripped to his underpants, waded out into the river and brought it back to shore. It was showing no signs of life, and so whilst his wife called the Scottish Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, Mr McAllister began giving it mouth-to-mouth resuscitation. "I'd never done anything like it before," he explained. "But it was a shame to see such a beautiful bird in such a pathetic state." Amazingly, after just a few gentle breaths into the creature's nostrils, it regained consciousness, and, after flapping its wings and hissing for a while, duly flew off over the treetops. "I saw him straddling a bird in his underpants," recalled one neighbour, "Kissing its beak and shouting 'Come on! Come on!' That's when we decided to put our house on the market and move elsewhere."
Dunoon Observer

Peacock peril
More bird-related news from Watford, where residents on an estate in South Oxhey have been plagued by a delinquent peacock. No one knows when the peacock actually arrived in Birkdale Gardens, nor where it originally came from. Residents are unanimous, however, in their desire to get rid of it. "You've never heard so much bloody noise," said one man. "It squawks all night long. The other day I looked out of the window at 4am and saw my neighbour trying to squirt it with a water-pistol to shut it up." As well as being disturbed by the bird's calls - especially loud now as breeding season kicks in - residents are also concerned about the potential hazard to motorists. "It's always strutting out into the road and drivers have to swerve to avoid it," complained another resident. "One old lady drove straight into a rhododendron bush. She was ever so upset." The local council has undertaken to remove the bird, but it has so far evaded capture. "It's ruining the neighbourhood," fumed one man. "People complain about asylum seekers, but at least they don't flap their wings at you and crap all over your crazy paving."
The Watford Observer

Bog down
Reference has been made before in these pages to the public toilet crisis currently afflicting Aberdeen. This week Aberdeenshire residents brought their fight to London, lobbying the social services secretary Alastair Darling to halt the closure of public conveniences around the county. Aberdeenshire Council is closing 69 of its 105 public lavatories in an effort to cut £316,000 from its annual budget. Whilst the closures will save money, however, they have met with staunch opposition from local people who see their lavatories as an essential part of the community. "I love our public loo," said one man. "I've got my own toilet, but I often use the public one instead because it's so much cleaner and you meet all sorts of interesting people. The other day I found myself standing beside a man who'd climbed The Matterhorn. You just don't get that sort of thing at home." Old people in particular are suffering as a result of the closures, and Mr. Darling was asked to urge Aberdeenshire Council to rethink its policy. As activist Carol Donald, 57, of Ellon, so lyrically put it:
Life can be 'ell in Ellon,
Fan yer burstin' for the lavvy.
Oh would the good Lord send us
Some cooncillors wi' savvy!

Letter of the Week
As a taxi driver in Bath I am frequently asked why the taxi-queues are so long in the early hours of Sunday morning. I explain that fewer drivers are prepared to put up with the bad behaviour of a few young males, and therefore finish work at midnight. An example of what we are faced with happened to me in the early hours of last Saturday, when I picked up two young men from the Abbey rank, who informed me that they were studying for an MA at Bath University. During the course of the journey I chatted quite amiably with the passenger next to me whilst the one in the rear seat decided to have a jolly jape by throwing my rubber floor mats out of the window and stealing my new seat covers. Bearing in mind that these are an example of our future leaders, I found this petty crime and childish behaviour almost beyond belief. This is why, in future, I will not carry in my cab any young male students unless accompanied by either their mother or else a responsible adult to supervise their behaviour. And this is also why I won't work the late shift any more and the queues in the early hours will get longer and longer.
Name and Address Supplied
The Bath Chronicle

fields.headline: Fiji's PM seized in coup
fields.standfirst: Comment: the net and the Fiji coup
fields.trailText: President Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara  of Fiji today declared a state of emergency after a local businessman took the prime minister hostage and claimed power in the name of indigenous Fijians.
fields.body:
President Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara of Fiji today declared a state of emergency after a local businessman took the prime minister hostage and claimed power in the name of indigenous Fijians.

After months of simmering ethnic tensions in Fiji, seven masked, armed men stormed parliament and took the entire government hostage, saying they had seized power in the island nation. The gunmen fired at least two shots from AK-47 rifles inside parliament before locking up prime minister Mahendra Chaudhry, his ministers and MPs of the ruling coalition in the legislature's upper chamber. No injuries were reported among the estimated 50 hostages.

Mr Chaudhry is Fiji's first ethnic Indian prime minister and his year-old administration the first to be dominated by Indo-Fijians, a fact that has not gone down well with some indigenous Fijians. George Speight, who described himself as the coup leader, said he had seized power on behalf of all ethnic Fijians. He appointed an opposition lawmaker as interim prime minister in Mr Chaudhry's place and suspended the constitution.

Mobs of youths rampaged through the streets of the capital, Suva, after the coup, burning and looting shops, while up to 5,000 people gathered outside parliament chanting and cheering in support of the attack. A pall of smoke hung over downtown Suva as dozens of shops, mostly owned by ethnic Indians - went up in flames.

Police imposed a curfew and troops fanned out across the city to protect private property. There was no indication the soldiers were moving to end the hostage standoff in parliament. Mr Speight said the ethnic Fijian-dominated armed forces "are passive but remain at the beck and call and the control of the civilian government that is in place at this time that is headed by myself".

He also said Mr Chaudhry and his supporters were safe in the parliament building. President Ratu Mara appealed to the hostage takers to release the lawmakers and urged the army and police to restore the rule of law. "I regret to say what is happening today is not in accordance with the constitution and is therefore unlawful," he said.

The failure of Fiji's police and army to try to put down the revolt led to fears that the rebels may command widespread support from native Fijians. But one analyst said Mr Speight had little support.

"He is a person who is, I think, politically naive, personally ambitious and eager for some limelight," said Professor Brij Lal of the Australian National University. "I don't think he represents any constituency except a group of disgruntled Fijians."

Sitiveni Rabuka, a former army colonel who led two coups in 1987, visited parliament and pleaded with the gunmen to surrender, but they refused. Mr Rabuka, who held power in Fiji for 12 years after the coups, was accompanied by senior army and police officials, an apparent indication that the initial attack had no military backing.

Mr Speight, the son of an opposition politician, declared earlier that he was taking control "on behalf of every individual member of the indigenous Fijian community". His father is a close friend of Sitiveni Rabuka, who headed a 1987 coup and was prime minister until exactly one year ago. Mr Speight was a rising corporate star in Fiji until the fall of the last government, which included his father. Mr Speight was a partner in a local business, Heath Fiji Ltd, an insurance brokering firm, until he was sacked last year over allegations of misuse of funds. He was also chairman of Fiji Pine and Fiji Hardwood Ltd. The latter was a government-owned company boasting the largest mahogany reserves in the world, worth millions. He was sacked from both positions by the new government.

Tension has been building between minority ethnic Indians, who make up about 44% of the island nation's 813,000 people, and the majority Fijians, who account for 51%. The crisis came on the first anniversary of the election of Mr Chaudhry, who has been accused by Fijian nationalists of promoting pro-Indian policies. They have criticised his attempts to persuade Fijian landowners to renew expiring leases on farm land held by thousands of ethnic Indian tenants who are the core of his political support.

The attempted coup was widely condemned and Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, called for Mr Chaudhry's immediate release.

"We condemn the armed occupation of the Fijian parliament and the detention of the prime minister and members of the government," he said in a statement. "We call for their immediate release. We support the prompt return to democratic government within the terms of the Fijian constitution."

Prime Minister John Howard of Australia, who was on a visit to South Korea, expressed his outrage, saying:: "I'm horrified that such an act should be carried out against a democratically elected leader, a fellow Commonwealth prime minister." The US Embassy in Suva also condemned the power grab: "The consequences of any seizure of power would be very substantial."
