fields.headline: Hicks with flicks
fields.standfirst: Fast cars, big hair, skintight jeans  and heaving cleavage - the Dukes Of Hazzard had it all going on. Now they're back in a new movie  and enjoying a major fashion moment, reports Will Hodgkinson
fields.trailText: Fast cars, big hair, skintight jeans and heaving cleavage - the Dukes Of Hazzard had it all going on. Now they're back in a new movie and enjoying a major fashion moment, reports Will Hodgkinson
fields.body:
Back in the very early 80s, before Reclaim The Streets was even thought of, an awesome number of Ford Capris up and down the country developed mysterious dents on their bonnets. There was also a rash of cases of cars having their front windows smashed, but with no evidence of any attempts at theft. These acts of auto destruction were not the work of proto anti-car anarchists or even bored thugs, but overenthusiastic pre-teens living out a fantasy of being Saturday teatime television's most amenable heroes: Bo and Luke from The Dukes Of Hazzard. The Ford Capri, suburban Britain's own answer to the revved-up muscle cars that America produced in the late 60s, was the unfortunate victim of the kids' belief that it looked a bit like the General Lee, Bo and Luke's Yankee-defying 1968 Dodge Charger. The Dukes Of Hazzard had achieved that ultimate mark of success: creating a societal crisis.

It didn't stop there. While their younger sisters fought over who was to play at being Daisy Duke, the big boys attached "dixie" horns to their cars and engaged in high-street chases with police pandas through the streets of Basildon. There were even rumours of young men checking into A&E with ruptured testicles after attempting to go for that authentic Bo'n'Luke bulge with the aid of unnaturally tight jeans.

Now they're back in Hazzard In Hollywood, which opened in the US this week. Incredibly, they are also enjoying something of a fashion moment. "It's Daisy Duke, really," says stylist Jane Stevenson. "What most people remember her for is really short, running-up-the-arse hotpants, as much cleavage as possible, and skintight jeans, and pretty much every designer has done that look for this summer."

In America, hotpants were even renamed Daisy Dukes in her honour. Ralph Lauren, Chloe and Louis Vuitton have all included Daisy Dukes in their new collections. "Her bronzed skintone and long wavy hair is also very in at the moment - everyone is trying to re-create it with lots of fake tan," adds Stevenson. "It's basically an American, late-70s/early-80s look that developed from Charlie's Angels."

Bo and Luke, meanwhile, were classic 70s studs: tight jeans, unbuttoned shirts, and big, dusty cowboy boots. "Daisy Duke was every boy's wet dream and every girl's wannabe, but Bo and Luke were super-sexy too," says Stevenson. "Faded, worn-in jeans, bulging crotches, and an amazing ability to leap in and out of car windows. What more could you ask for?"

What more, indeed. Bo, Luke and Daisy Duke were true American heroes. In proper hillbilly fashion, they were all cousins, appeared to be lacking parents, and were looked after by the kindly Uncle Jesse, a grits-eating grandpaw in a babygrow who was in continual battle to defend his farmland against the evil Boss Hogg, Hazzard County's bigwig and the Dukes' number one enemy.

The degenerate, stogy-chewing, belt-stretching Hogg, who wore a white three-piece suit and drove a suspiciously clean white stretch Cadillac, disliked the fact that the Duke boys were always poking their nose into his dubious business ventures, and stopped at nothing to get his lackey, the local sheriff Rosco P Coltrane, to arrest them.

Rosco soon discovered that Bo and Luke were running a lucrative moonshine business, and slapped a probation order on them which meant they could never leave Hazzard County. Cousin Daisy, meanwhile, got first-hand information of Boss Hogg's evil plans from working at his bar The Bear Pit, so the Dukes had no choice but to fight for the cause of justice and engage in at least two high-speed car chases per episode while they were at it. The result was always the same: blond Bo, a stock-car racing driver, being forced to jump over a river in the General Lee, and Sheriff Rosco and his deputy Enos (pronounced "Enis") having to say goodbye to yet another patrol car and give each other doleful looks as it sank into the bog.

From this simple premise came a whole host of wildly original touches. Bo and Luke reasoned that, in the name of fighting for justice, they needed to weld the doors of the General Lee to its chassis so that they could never be opened, much to the annoyance of Uncle Jesse, whose belly got wedged in the window every time he tried to climb in. It was painted its distinctive orange because that was the only colour the moonshine-sozzled mechanic Cooter could find. In an effort to rival the "Seaman Stains" notoriety of Captain Pugwash, the screenwriters briefly replaced Enos with Cleetus (pronounced "Clittus"), but moral outrage decreed this was going too far.

Then there was big bad Boss Hogg, diverting funds from an old people's home to build a strip joint; putting his mama's ashes in a stock-car racing trophy which he stole; attempting to uproot a cemetery to build a shopping mall on it. To highlight his badness, Bo and Luke were unnaturally nice: always remembering to say "yes, sir" and "yes, mam", never cussing and certainly never killing anybody - the worst they did was shoot an arrow at Sheriff Rosco's butt. Likewise, Daisy Duke may have dressed in a way that made Rosco call her "a half-nekkid female woman", but she was no tramp, and she could hold her own, whether behind the bar at The Bear Pit or behind the wheel of Dixie, her trusty jeep. She also had a Superwoman-like ability to run in high heels.

The good times couldn't last forever, of course. Problems began in 1982, when John Schneider and Tom Wopat, the actors who played Bo and Luke, decided to strike over wages. CBS brought in Coy and Vance Duke, a couple of wussie chancers who were meant to be their cousins, but nobody was convinced. The producers duly agreed to the original Dukes' demands and brought them back, but the momentum was gone, and by 1985 the show was over.

In America, however, once they love you, they love you forever, and public demand brought the team back together in 1997 for Hazzard Reunion.Uncle Jesse and Boss Hogg are no longer with us, but Bo, Luke and Daisy Duke are still fighting for the little guys and protecting the old ways from being abused. In Reunion, they take on a corrupt developer who is planning to build a theme park on Uncle Jesse's old farm (they have to run in a cross-country moonshine race to stop her, obviously); in Hazzard In Hollywood, Bo and Luke have to save Daisy from an evil mogul who has kidnapped her after promising to make her a star.

These days, the Dukes are a little chunky but they can still squeeze into the window of that Dodge Charger and outrun Sheriff Rosco any day. More important, their appeal is still intact, even if their figures aren't: The Dukes Of Hazzard is a homage to a more innocent time. All you needed to know about those boys was in the first bar of that famous honky-tonk theme of theirs. "They're just good old boys, never meanin' no harm/ Beats all you never saw, been in trouble with the law/Since the day they was born." Amen to that.

 Dukes Of Hazzard, midnight,TNT, Mon-Fri

webTitle: Police accused of errors over race attack

fields.headline: Police accused of errors over race attack
fields.standfirst:
Victim's family want investigation assigned to Grieve task force

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The family of a refugee whose head swelled to twice its size after he was repeatedly stamped on during a racial attack has accused the Metropolitan police of making a series of errors in their investigation.
fields.body:
The family of a refugee whose head swelled to twice its size after he was repeatedly stamped on during a racial attack has accused the Metropolitan police of making a series of errors in their investigation.

Tewodros Afework, 24, has remained unconscious since the assault three weeks ago in Camden Town, north London.

Mr Afework, an Eritrean who fled to Britain as a child from war in Ethiopia, was beaten and kicked to the floor by a white male just after midnight on April 24.

Witnesses say the man shouted racial abuse, raining blows and kicks on his head and body in an attack which police are treating as attempted murder. Mr Afework's family fear that even if he survives, he may have suffered severe brain damage.

They describe Mr Afework, nicknamed "Teddy", as a devout Christian who was gentle and kind.

The family will today launch their own campaign to find the attacker, by handing out leaflets at the crime scene in the hope that new witnesses will come forward.

Mr Afework's sister, Meaza, 27, said: "It's terrible and distressing. Sometimes we don't know what to do and where we will ask for help to catch the person who did this."

The family wants the case to be taken over by Scotland Yard's race and violent crimes task force, headed by deputy assistant commissioner John Grieve. At two meetings, they have raised their concerns with detectives who are at present handling the case.

The frenzied assault on Easter Monday happened near a Sainsbury's supermarket.

The family say police errors include delaying for a week photographing Mr Afework's injuries, which could aid a successful prosecution. Police say they could not get a photographer but that any prosecution would be unaffected.

The family say detectives did not try to take footprints off Mr Afework's head, which could lead to the perpetrator, until they asked for it.

Police say the family have a valid point, but when they checked the feasibility, forensic experts said this was impossible.

Police admit a delay in securing CCTV footage from cameras mounted on the supermarket outside which the attack occurred. They say this is because the store initially told them the cameras were not on, and when the video was checked it yielded nothing.

The family are also worried that three weeks on, seven videotapes have still not been viewed.

The family say a police leaflet asking for information contained errors which could have lost witnesses. Police admit the errors but say their effect was not detrimental.

Police also admit that despite their leaflets and an appeal board at the crime scene, they are yet to receive a single phone call about the case.

Speaking on behalf of the Afework family, Suresh Grover of the Monitoring Group, who is advising them, said: "The police investigation lacks strategy and resources. It has already made mistakes.

"Three weeks have lapsed since this horrific, racially motivated attack on Teddy, and the family have become more stressed and anxious about finding the attacker."

Teddy's brother and three sisters have not heard from their parents, who are believed to still be in Ethiopia, for over three years. They take it in turns to keep a bedside vigil.

Meaza says that to try and help her brother regain consciousness she sings him hymns he was fond of, talks to him, and massages his feet.

She said: "He's between death and life, it's so hard seeing your own brother suffering, while the person who did this is walking on the street free."

Detective Inspector Sean Roderick, of Camden police, leading the investigation, said that within the last week he had received extra resources, with four extra detectives joining the team, taking the total to 10.

He said:"This inquiry is moving in the right direction and I'm confident we're going to find out the suspect in this case."

Groups helping race attack victims report an increase in the targeting of asylum seekers.

Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the Refugee Council, said there could be a link between such attacks and the rhetoric over asylum seekers from politicians.

"We are extremely concerned that there appears to be a growth in the number of racially motivated attacks, at the same time that the language of some politicians and newspapers is becoming more and more extreme."

Police have described the suspect as in his late 20s to early 30s, 6ft 3in tall, gaunt, and wearing dark clothing including a black jacket and black jeans, and smart in his appearance.

 Anyone with information can call Crime Stoppers on 0800 555 111 or the Monitoring Group on 0800 374 618.

fields.headline: Cups, Creosote and Catalonia
fields.trailText: UP FOR YE CUPPE!
fields.body:
UP FOR YE CUPPE!

The final of the world's oldest and grandest football competition will be played out tomorrow. Aston Villa and Chelsea's of Chelsea are the two lucky teams competing in the final of the FA's year-long nostalgia event Ye Cuppe, and both teams are desperate to succeed so they can qualify for Eur... so they can bask in the glory of lifting the famous trophy.

"There is a lot at stake on Saturday because entry to [Euro-Vase] is very important," explained John Gregory, who clearly understands the romance of the big day. "In terms of encouraging people to want to come here in the first place, it will be beneficial if you can offer them European football. I'm sure the Inter Galactic Cup is not going to be too exciting for prospective players," football's Mr Comedy continued, cracking gags of such quality that the Fiver drifted into a daydream about Joe Pasquale.

Gregory, who has a full squad to pick from with Ian Taylor and David James returning from injury, has hit upon an intelligent plan to inspire his most likely match-winner before this crucial game. He's offered temperamental genius Benito Carbone a take-it-or-leave-it contract which comes to £13,000-a-week less than the player wants. That should do the trick, eh?

Once Gianluca Vialli has stopped guffawing at Gregory's wonderful plan, he'll get around to picking a team of his own. It shouldn't be too stressful an exercise - the only doubt surrounds Albert Ferrer, who has an ankle injury, and in any case there's a ready-made replacement waiting in the shape of ex-Ajax defender Mario Melchiot. The only remaining question that could possibly keep the Blues boss up all night is: do I start with Chris Sutton?

Sweet dreams Luca!

Chelsea (probable): De Goey, Babayaro, Melchiot (or Ferrer), Desailly, Leboeuf, Wise, Deschamps, Poyet, Di Matteo, Zola, Flo.

Subs from: Harley, Morris, Petrescu, Weah, Sutton, Cudicini, Terry, Hitchcock, Lambourde, Ambrosetti.

Villa (probable): James, Ehiogu, Southgate, Barry, Delaney, Taylor, Merson, Boateng, Wright, Dublin, Carbone.

Subs from: Enckelman, Watson, Thompson, Joachim, Hendrie, Stone, Walker, Ghrayib, Samuel.

IN THE PSYCHIATRIST'S BED

For the third year in a row, Alan Shearer will be spending Cup final Saturday doing nothing. The England skipper did have a trip to Creosote World marked down in his diary, but sadly it's closed for refurbishment - one coat is never really enough, is it? Ever resourceful, Shearer has instead chosen to fill up his idle hours by giving interviews to the press, interviews that provide a revealing insight into the mind of the Geordie enigma.

With all eyes on some round robin in Holland or other, Shearer made his first shocking revelation by confessing he doesn't like penalty shoot-outs all that much. "There are not many times when I get nervous, but I do a little bit with penalties," said Shearer, whom many Newcastle fans are actually convinced is made of iron ore. "There's pressure standing there with thousands of people watching you in the stadium and at home on television," he went on. "You have to pick your side and not change it and try to get a bit of pace behind it."

The thought of a 'Shearer in self-doubt shocker' headline caused the majority of the press pack to collapse at this point. But those who remained afoot saw Alan air his views on the 'hooligan problem'. "It was very unfortunate the other night, they're certainly not nice things," he said. "It isn't nice for our game and it isn't nice for England as a whole." So, after years of uncertainty, we now know that Alan Shearer places his penalties and likes people to be nice. Remember, you read it here first.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"If I was up against Gianfranco Zola I would certainly give him a quick welcome to the Premiership" - Chelsea legend Ron 'Chopper' Harris gives those fancy dan foreigners a piece of his mind. Gianfranco Zola has been playing in the Premiership since 1996.

GAAL STONE

The Fiver regrets not being able to make it round the De Boers' house on Wednesday night. The cheery Dutch twins were celebrating their 30th birthday you see, and all their bestest pals were there. Unloved Finnish international Jari Litmanen, technically unimpressive defender Winston Bogarde and Louis van Gaal, Catalonia's most wanted, were all there - presumably bearing gifts of buckskin luggage (with airport tags already attached). Cor, the fun they must have had.

Yes, these are tough times in Barcelona's Dutch quarter. If Deportivo snatch a point against Espanyol this evening then they win the title and Van Gaal gets the boot. In fact it looks like ol' Cheesehead will be shown the door whatever happens. Barca's vice-president Juan Gaspar hinted cryptically at the future last night when he said: "I'm sure Van Gaal won't even be the coach after Friday." A press conference will take place tomorrow afternoon, and it's unlikely to be for the signing of Pierre van Hooijdonk.

With 744 sports pages to fill daily, the Spanish press is already speculating on the identity of not one, but two successors. Most tend to agree that short-term duties (ie: arranging flower displays in the trophy cabinet) will be performed by the youth team coach Llorenç Serra Ferrer. In the long term, Arsene's Arsenal Wenger has been mentioned, as has Johan Cruyff, but the favourite is Ronald Koeman. The legendary Barca sweeper was formerly assistant to Van Gaal, is mates with outgoing club president Josep Lluís Núñez and, oh yes, holds a Dutch passport. Will these people never learn?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Leeds United chairman Peter Ridsdale is believed to have authorised the purchase of either Sol Campbell or Rio Ferdinand for £13m. Whether their bid is successful remains to be seen, however. As Harry Redknapp said this morning, "The day we sell him [Rio] and our other young players is the day this club starts to die."

Paris St Germain have joined the list of clubs chasing Newcastle's Didier Domi. They are also interested in re-signing centre-back Alain Goma, who joined the Toon for £4.25m last summer but spent most of the past season injured.

Gianfranco Zola has been offered the chance to join Napoli this summer, after they achieved promotion to Serie A.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Arsenal are hoping to complete a £7m deal for Marseille winger Robert Pires in the next seven days. The Frenchman is expected in London next week for talks and he said today: "For the moment I haven't met anyone with a view to a transfer, but I think that the issue will be sorted out in a few days."

Henrik Larsson has asked to play in Celtic's last home game of the season against Dundee United to prove his fitness for Euro 2000. Sweden have named a preliminary 20-man squad for Euro 2000 with two places being left free, one to possibly accommodate Larsson.

Everton striker Kevin Campbell is almost certain to miss the beginning of next season after picking up an infection in his knee after surgery.

Watford have placed Northern Ireland defender Mark Williams on the transfer list.

Kilmarnock have announced a new £500,000 three-year sponsorship deal with leisurewear company TFG Sports.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5pm)

New York, London, Paris, Munich, everybody's talking about futbol.

Best of the FA Cup (7pm, 9.30pm, 1am, 5.30am)

An all-night session with George Best. Not what it sounds.

Hold The Back Page (11pm, 1.30am SS2)

No McCaff today, so it's Brian Woolnough's One Night Only Noticeboard instead. "I really think that you ought to take paternity leave, Tony, it would do you the world of good. I can take care of things here for a bit. Luv Gordon." New Dad? Email the.boss@theguardian.com for help, but don't expect to get any.

Sky Sports 2: Spanish Football (11.30pm)

Laugh at teams with lots of money getting themselves relegated.

British Eurosport: Football (1.15am)

Laugh at a channel doing things on the cheap.

fields.headline: Double vision
fields.standfirst: Lovable funsters or tight-lipped enigmas? Jonathan Romney meets the endlessly inventive Coens in Cannes and gets the lowdown on how they updated The Odyssey - without reading Homer
fields.trailText: Lovable funsters or tight-lipped enigmas? Jonathan Romney meets the endlessly inventive Coens in Cannes and gets the lowdown on how they updated The Odyssey - without reading Homer
fields.body:
The Coen Brothers may not have the strangest film in Cannes this year, but they can certainly boast the drollest promotional giveaway. It's a three-ounce tub of waxy, orange-coloured, sweetly-scented stuff labelled "Dan Men's Pomade". It carries the portrait of a rakishly coiffed George Clooney, looking determined and modelling a convincing facsimile of Clark Gable's moustache.

As promo novelties go, it makes a change from T-shirts and tote bags, and it relates more precisely to the advertised film than is usually the case. In the Coens' new film, O Brother, Where Art Thou?, Clooney's character Ulysses Everett McGill, an escapee from a southern chain gang, wouldn't go anywhere without a dab of Dapper Dan to sweeten his locks. His flight across the deep south is, you can imagine, rather more facetious than the 30s chain gang movies that the Coens take as their model.

Minnesota-born brothers Joel and Ethan are known for liking their bit of fun, and in their latest film, they haven't stinted themselves. O Brother is several films in one: a tale of three desperadoes on the lam in rural Mississippi; a blues and country musical; and, allegedly at least, a rewrite of Homer's Odyssey. Not that they've actually read the Odyssey, they admit. Fortunately, Ethan Coen says, one of the film's leads, Tim Blake Nelson, is a classicist. "I wonder if he read it in Greek? I know he read it." "Yeah," confirms Joel. "Did he?" Ethan insists. "I don't know if he read it in Greek," says Joel. "I know he read it."

"Between the cast and us," says Ethan, "Tim Nelson is the only one who's actually read the Odyssey." There's little point, then, kicking yourself if you can't place all the allusions. The Sirens are easy enough, a trio of singing Amazons doing their laundry in the Mississippi. And the Cyclops is John Goodman in an eyepatch.

Scylla and Charybdis I was less certain about. "Scylla and Charybdis? Where were they?" puzzles Ethan. The whirlpool at the end, surely? "Oh," the brothers chorus, "the whirlpool." Ethan grins pensively. "Oh, yeah, sure, Scylla and Charybdis." Joel says, "It's very, you, usually know selectively based on the Odyssey." Interviewers often lament that with the Coens, there's no point even asking: they don't give anything away.

They have this reputation as tight-lipped enigmatic sorts who make enigmatic films. And yet the films pretty much speak for themselves; they are flawlessly accessible, even if you don't catch all the references to old movies and pulp paperbacks. The only thing that properly seems bizarre about the brothers' work is the breadth of their imagination: they specialise in pinpointing the kind of images and cultural references that are usually outside the remit of contemporary American cinema.

There's nothing that bizarre, if you think of it, about choosing to set a crime thriller in snowbound Minnesota, as the brothers did in Fargo, and having villains who relax by going to see Jose Feliciano in concert; it's just that it took the Coens to think of it. Every Coen film describes a world so thoroughly conceived that each one is its own fictional micro-climate; in a sense the brothers don't really need to add much commentary. Hence, perhaps, the sense that when they give interviews, they are aware of the futility of the venture.

Here they are in Cannes again, sitting in the casino on top of the Carlton hotel, and although they have visited several times in the past (their Barton Fink won the Palme d'Or in 1991), they don't quite seem to belong. Older brother Joel looks as though he's done all the interviews he wants to in a lifetime, Ethan as though he's never done one in his life. Joel seems to have dressed for the part of the hot auteur in town and then let it all get messed up over a rough morning: shoulder-length hair more scrupulously crimped than previously, in a black jacket that could be either very cheap or very expensive; both the beard and the low mutter are reminiscent of Frank Zappa, and he keeps looking absently around the room as if he's wondering how long it is till lunch.

The friendlier Ethan, in a murky brown plaid shirt, with a scraggy beard and a faceful of freckles, constantly grins broadly, occasionally giving a wheezy laugh, and seems to be relishing various private jokes as if they've only just crossed his mind. Despite the grandiose title, O Brother, Where Art Thou? is as downhome and earthy a film as has come out of recent American cinema, although it lacks the lightness of touch of the Coens' best comedies.

It shares its title with the apocryphal movie planned by Joel McCrea's idealistic Hollywood director in Preston Sturges' 1941 comedy Sullivan's Travels (currently on re-release). Sullivan heads out across America to research his serious Steinbeckian hobo drama, only to conclude that it's a far nobler calling to make 'em laugh.

But the Coens' O Brother is not entirely the film that Sullivan would have made. "It pretends to be a big important movie," says Ethan, "but the grandiosity is obviously a joke. It is what it is, it's a comedy. There is a chain-gang interlude in Sullivan's Travels, but that's it." O Brother is another example of the Coens' partiality to period: Miller's Crossing, Barton Fink and The Hudsucker Proxy all explored past decades, and even their last film, The Big Lebowski, had a certain distance, being set in the early 90s as opposed to 1998.

"We tend to do period stuff," says Ethan, "because it helps make it one step removed from boring everyday reality." Their latest film carries a considerable weight of historical authenticity, not least in the soundtrack of vintage southern music - gospel, Delta blues and early country swing - assembled by singer-songwriter and one-time Dylan collaborator T-Bone Burnett.

One of the film's themes is the congruence of pre-war American pop with history and politics, as the errant jailbird trio encounter various real-life characters, among them gangster George "Baby Face" Nelson and blues singer Tommy Johnson, who, like the better known Robert Johnson, was reputed to have sold his soul to the devil in exchange for blues prowess. Another real character is Texas governor Pappy O'Daniel, who would go electioneering accompanied by a "stump band", a music show to whip up popular support. "They'd draw the crowds," explains Joel. "People came to listen to the music and then they'd have to listen to the speech."

The film's southern history, musical and political, looks detailed enough to have been thoroughly researched, but the Coens insist it wasn't. "It's all stuff that to one extent or another we were aware of," Joel says. "It was all back there somewhere and filtered up into the script. We weren't going out and doing research and trying to apply it to a story, it's all much more haphazard. It wasn't like we were trying to create a realistic picture of the time and place so much as an imagined world where all those things intersect - real people and made-up people."

Both are keen that the film shouldn't be taken too seriously, even though for the first time (give or take the socialist convictions of their playwright Barton Fink, and the trendy crypto-fascists in The Big Lebowski) they seem to be focusing on political realities in O Brother. "The political undercurrent of the movie," says Joel, "functions primarily for dramatic purposes, because the politics are frankly pretty primitive. The bad guys are racial bigots and KKK Grand Dragons, and the good guys are the heroes of the movie. So it's all kind of a story thing."

Even so, the film pulls off something of a coup in managing to be more politically flippant than American comedies have managed since Mel Brooks's heyday. The scene where the heroes blithely wander into a torchlit KKK rally might, I suggest to the brothers, strike some viewers as being of questionable taste.

"Taste," says Joel, "has never been something we've worried about." "We're not big on taste," agrees Ethan, his grin broadening even further. "And actually, if you don't pander to undue sensitivities then it ends up usually not being much of a problem. More prominent was Gates of Eden, the short story collection that Ethan published in 1998. It's a three-ounce tub of waxy, orange-coloured, sweetly-scented stuff labelled "Dan Men's Pomade". It carries the portrait of a rakishly coiffed George Clooney, looking determined and modelling a convincing facsimile of Clark Gable's moustache. As promo novelties go, it makes a change from T-shirts and tote bags, and it relates more precisely to the advertised film than is usually the case. In the Coens' new film, O Brother, Where Art Thou?, Clooney's character Ulysses Everett McGill, an escapee from a southern chain gang, wouldn't go anywhere without a dab of Dapper Dan to sweeten his locks. His flight across the deep south is, you can imagine, rather more facetious than the 30s chain gang movies that the Coens take as their model. Minnesota-born brothers Joel and Ethan are known for liking their bit of fun, and in their latest film, they haven't stinted themselves. O Brother is several films in one: a tale of three desperadoes on the lam in rural Mississippi; a blues and country musical; and, allegedly at least, a rewrite of Homer's Odyssey. Not that they've actually read the Odyssey, they admit. Fortunately, Ethan Coen says, one of the film's leads, Tim Blake Nelson, is a classicist. "I wonder if he read it in Greek? I know he read it." "Yeah," confirms Joel. "Did he?" Ethan insists. "I don't know if he read it in Greek," says Joel. "I know he read it." "Between the cast and us," says Ethan, "Tim Nelson is the only one who's actually read the Odyssey." There's little point, then, kicking yourself if you can't place all the allusions. The Sirens are easy enough, a trio of singing Amazons doing their laundry in the Mississippi. And the Cyclops is John Goodman in an eyepatch. Scylla and Charybdis I was less certain about. "Scylla and Charybdis? Where were they?" puzzles Ethan. The whirlpool at the end, surely? "Oh," the brothers chorus, "the whirlpool." Ethan grins pensively. "Oh, yeah, sure, Scylla and Charybdis." Joel says, "It's very, you, usually know selectively based on the Odyssey." Interviewers often lament that with the Coens, there's no point even asking: they don't give anything away. They have this reputation as tight-lipped enigmatic sorts who make enigmatic films. And yet the films pretty much speak for themselves; they are flawlessly accessible, even if you don't catch all the references to old movies and pulp paperbacks. The only thing that properly seems bizarre about the brothers' work is the breadth of their imagination: they specialise in pinpointing the kind of images and cultural references that are usually outside the remit of contemporary American cinema. There's nothing that bizarre, if you think of it, about choosing to set a crime thriller in snowbound Minnesota, as the brothers did in Fargo, and having villains who relax by going to see Jose Feliciano in concert; it's just that it took the Coens to think of it. Every Coen film describes a world so thoroughly conceived that each one is its own fictional micro-climate; in a sense the brothers don't really need to add much commentary. Hence, perhaps, the sense that when they give interviews, they are aware of the futility of the venture. Here they are in Cannes again, sitting in the casino on top of the Carlton hotel, and although they have visited several times in the past (their Barton Fink won the Palme d'Or in 1991), they don't quite seem to belong. Older brother Joel looks as though he's done all the interviews he wants to in a lifetime, Ethan as though he's never done one in his life. Joel seems to have dressed for the part of the hot auteur in town and then let it all get messed up over a rough morning: shoulder-length hair more scrupulously crimped than previously, in a black jacket that could be either very cheap or very expensive; both the beard and the low mutter are reminiscent of Frank Zappa, and he keeps looking absently around the room as if he's wondering how long it is till lunch. The friendlier Ethan, in a murky brown plaid shirt, with a scraggy beard and a faceful of freckles, constantly grins broadly, occasionally giving a wheezy laugh, and seems to be relishing various private jokes as if they've only just crossed his mind. Despite the grandiose title, O Brother, Where Art Thou? is as downhome and earthy a film as has come out of recent American cinema, although it lacks the lightness of touch of the Coens' best comedies. It shares its title with the apocryphal movie planned by Joel McCrea's idealistic Hollywood director in Preston Sturges' 1941 comedy Sullivan's Travels (currently on re-release). Sullivan heads out across America to research his serious Steinbeckian hobo drama, only to conclude that it's a far nobler calling to make 'em laugh. But the Coens' O Brother is not entirely the film that Sullivan would have made. "It pretends to be a big important movie," says Ethan, "but the grandiosity is obviously a joke. "We tend to do period stuff," says Ethan, "because it helps make it one step removed from boring everyday reality." Another real character is Texas governor Pappy O'Daniel, who would go electioneering accompanied by a "stump band", a music show to whip up popular support. "They'd draw the crowds," explains Joel. fields.headline: Belgrade's youthful spark of hope
fields.standfirst: Matthew Collin sees the growth of a resistance movement in the Serbian capital
fields.trailText: Matthew Collin sees the growth of a resistance movement in the Serbian capital
fields.body:
Despite being forcibly ejected from his office by armed police, losing his job, his income and his security, Ivan is in fine spirits. "At least there is an energy out on the streets now. Something is happening. We aren't sure what, yet, but it has to be better than nothing."

Ivan, a DJ with the Belgrade independent radio station B2-92 - shut down by the Milosevic regime for the fourth time in a decade last Wednesday - is one of a dwindling number of young progressives in the city. He has seen thousands of like minds emigrate in search of light and liberty; he has watched his city become emasculated by poverty, his social life wither. He stays in Belgrade, and dedicates his life to preserving some last vestiges of normality, although he often wonders whether it is worth it.

Ivan is happy because the storm has broken: the disillusionment which hung over Belgrade, heavy and suffocating, has given way to action. The sporadic protests since the end of the Nato bombing have largely been pallid affairs, with none of the vital creativity and imagination of the mass uprising of 1996-7. Now it's different.

In the past few months, some tiny sparks of hope have emerged from the stultifying apathy which envelops Belgrade's younger generation: the Otpor (Resistance) student movement, which has been spreading like a virus, its clenched-fist symbol ubiquitous on walls, posters and T-shirts all over Belgrade; the nationwide pro-democracy techno DJ tour with its slogan Silence Won't Do; the terrace chants of the Red Star FC fans ("Save Serbia, Slobodan, kill yourself") which fired up the demonstrators who fought with police last Wednesday night. None of these have been co-opted or corrupted by the opposition political parties, whose incompetence and infighting has made Belgrade's youth regard them with distrust.

"How will it end? I don't know," says Ivan. "Nobody does. But now we can feel it, coming closer each day."

 Matthew Collin is the author of a forthcoming book on the resistance movement in Belgrade. Ivan's name has been changed by request.

fields.headline: Mrs Blair in hospital
fields.trailText: 19 May, 4.30pm: Cherie Blair was taken to hospital today, prompting fresh speculation that she is about to give birth.
fields.body:
Cherie Blair was taken to hospital today, prompting fresh speculation that she is about to give birth.

Mrs Blair, 45, who is expecting her fourth child, arrived at the Chelsea and Westminster Hospital in a grey Ford Galaxy. The car left without her.

The prime minister remained at Downing Street today working.

A spokeswoman for the hospital refused to confirm that Mrs Blair had been admitted. A Downing Street source said he would not be "running a commentary on the birth."

Police erected crowd control barriers outside the hospital for what seemed like the start of a media vigil as a large number of reporters and photographers gathered.

Mrs Blair and her husband went to the Chelsea and Westminster on Wednesday night after she experienced some discomfort, but they left soon afterwards.

fields.headline: The old curiosity shop
fields.standfirst: Thrown your pashmina on the rubbish heap of history? Rescue it now! Some day it may be priceless.  Molly Gunn meets a woman already striking vintage gold
fields.trailText: Thrown your pashmina on the rubbish heap of history? Rescue it now! Some day it may be priceless. Molly Gunn meets a woman already striking vintage gold
fields.body:
Hands up anyone who owns a Prada bowling bag. Last year's Gucci feathered jeans? How about a pair of Chloe Aviators with diamanté heart? Keep them. "They may be out of fashion by next season, but in future they'll be turn-of-the-century collectables," says Tracy Tolkien of vintage emporium Steinberg and Tolkien on London's King's Road. Her new book, Vintage: The Art Of Dressing Up (Pavilion, £19.99, published tomorrow), will be full of such tips and a bible for anyone interested in vintage clothes.

Vintage fashion items have always provided inspiration for designers, but never more so than today. The autumn/winter 2000 collections, staged in March, were awash with references from every decade since the 20s. There were 40s-style trenches at Galliano, full 50s skirts at Hussein Chalayan, drop-waisted 20s dresses at Antonio Berardi, 80s minis at Versace (and everywhere else).

"I see designers in the shop and I know what's in next season by what they're picking," Tolkien says. "It's tradition - like if you're a writer, you read old books. They want to see what's been done before."

Tolkien is used to people looking to her for inspiration. In the 12 years since she came to London from America and opened Steinberg and Tolkien with her father and brother, anyone who's anyone in the fashion world has walked through her doors. "Every designer I've ever heard of has come in. Galliano, McQueen, Lagerfeld, Ford ... all of them."

The attraction of Steinberg and Tolkien lies in the sheer diversity of clothes and accessories, which have been culled from every decade. Schiaparelli, Balenciaga, Courrèges, Ossie Clark ... The shop is probably the only place in London where you will see an embroidered piano shawl from the 1880s hanging next to a yellow plastic mini from the 1980s, or a 1920s silk flapper dress draped near an original Chanel suit.

"We try to get things that are special to each period," Tolkien explains. She and her brother, Mark Steinberg, search high and low for vintage finds, at thrift stores and auctions. "It's fascinating that you can find, in the attic of a country house, clothes that belonged to generations of women who have passed away and they can be revived and worn again by a whole new generation."

Never was there a generation more into vintage clothing than today's. Gucci's floral-themed Woodstock collection for spring/summer 99, last autumn's 70s Love Story feel and this season's pussy bows have prompted people who would never before have dreamed of shopping second-hand to start trawling for original finds. "Fashion has always been cyclical," Tolkien says. "We shouldn't repeat but we will always come back, either because the old ways flatter the female form or because they are comfortable. There will always be certain key motifs that come and go."

There are designers, she adds ("I won't name them because they are customers"), who do nothing but copy. "But with someone like Galliano, you can see an influence from something he bought, but he's changed it. Making a reference to history and taking it further is an art form. Copying is not."

Keen fashion followers are already on the lookout for vintage finds to wear come autumn. After all, why buy clothes inspired - or copied - from vintage if you can go straight to the horse's mouth? Celebrities caught on long ago. Kate Moss wore a vintage column dress to Cannes last year, Nicole Kidman wore an old gold silk shift dress to the premiere of Eyes Wide Shut, Winona Ryder and Sadie Frost wore vintage to the Oscars.

Of course, not everyone can afford to recreate next season's looks by buying designer vintage and many people wouldn't know where to look in the first place. But Tolkien's book should provide a starting point. "The best thing to do when creating looks for next season is to mix," she advises. "Go with a trend but put your own twist on it." She points to her original 70s snakeskin shirt teamed with a new pair of black trousers.

Her book outlines 20th-century fashion by decades, listing key items and names to watch out for, such as Kelly bags from the 50s, or 80s pleated pieces by Issey Miyake and Yohji Yamamoto. There are hints on what not to buy ("Avoid pieces labelled Chanel Creations, as these are usually poorly made") and on special features to look for ("Most of Ossie Clark's best designs come with a tiny secret pocket inside, said to be just big enough for a key and a $10 bill"). At the back of the book, there is also an extensive list of worthy vintage shops in the UK, US and Europe, plus some websites.

"Vintage looks so individual. That's the main difference - you can be very fashionable without looking like a fashion victim," Tolkien says. So what are you waiting for?

fields.headline: Hair colour consultations
fields.trailText: We thought it was only bored housewives who went to "get their colours done" - that is, paid for a consultation to find out which Jaeger outfits best matched their autumn skintones. But apparently it's all the rage to find out which hues are "you" - only this time the fad has nothing to do with clothes. The latest trend - wouldn't you just know it - is to analyse your hair.
fields.body:
We thought it was only bored housewives who went to "get their colours done" - that is, paid for a consultation to find out which Jaeger outfits best matched their autumn skintones. But apparently it's all the rage to find out which hues are "you" - only this time the fad has nothing to do with clothes. The latest trend - wouldn't you just know it - is to analyse your hair.

According to the professionals, spur-of-the-moment dyeing is a no-no; before leaping from chestnut brown to screaming red, you have to go through a consultation to see what colour really suits you. Ker-ching! Welcome to L'Oréal's new Talking Colour initiative (tel 0800 072 6699 for details): before you even get to smell the sweet scent of peroxide, you are asked to consider your clothes, lifestyle and personality, in a quiz best suited to the pages of J17. Are you, for instance, classic, romantic or natural? Tick box. Social, sporty or shy? Tick box. You then move on to tone analysis, where colour cards (like paint swatches) are held in front of your face to see if you are a "cool" or "warm" person.

Schwarzkopf's Igora Color System (01296 314 189) runs along the same lines, concentrating on your tones to determine the nine hair colour types that "belong to you". Next they give you a Colour Passport which tells you which clothes and make-up should complement you, too. This is where it gets annoying, as however much you like a hair colour, the stylist will usually tell you it doesn't suit you.

Both of these consultations take roughly 15 minutes: the bonus is that you end up with a hair colour specifically tailored to your needs - perfect if you're not sure what you want or are colour-shy. For us, though, the joy of hair colouring will always be grabbing a random dye from Boots and seeing what happens. Philistines, we know.
fields.bodyText: We thought it was only bored housewives who went to "get their colours done" - that is, paid for a consultation to find out which Jaeger outfits best matched their autumn skintones. But apparently it's all the rage to find out which hues are "you" - only this time the fad has nothing to do with clothes. The latest trend - wouldn't you just know it - is to analyse your hair. According to the professionals, spur-of-the-moment dyeing is a no-no; before leaping from chestnut brown to screaming red, you have to go through a consultation to see what colour really suits you. Ker-ching! Welcome to L'Oréal's new Talking Colour initiative (tel 0800 072 6699 for details): before you even get to smell the sweet scent of peroxide, you are asked to consider your clothes, lifestyle and personality, in a quiz best suited to the pages of J17. Are you, for instance, classic, romantic or natural? Tick box. Social, sporty or shy? Tick box. fields.headline: Most wanted:  Scan
fields.trailText: Apparently Japanese fasherati consider it uncool to speak into a mobile. With texting, internet and m-mail cropping up as fast as annoying ring-tones, we suppose it was inevitable that actual talking would become passé.
fields.body: Apparently Japanese fasherati consider it uncool to speak into a mobile. With texting, internet and m-mail cropping up as fast as annoying ring-tones, we suppose it was inevitable that actual talking would become passé. Ever wish for the good old days? Tomorrow sees the launch of a new free m-feature, called Scan, the latest accessory for mobile aficionados who want to save their energy as well as their vocal cords. How so? If you hear a cool CD at a friend's house or you spot someone reading a good book on the train, instead of searching high and low for it, all you do is type the item's barcode into your phone and in seconds you'll get a text message back, listing cheap online deals available through your phone. Soon you'll be able to do it with clothes and beauty products, too. Simply log on to www.scan.com Far too clever for its own good, but pretty handy all the same.

fields.headline: Most everywhere:  waistless jeans
fields.trailText: We never thought we'd see the day, but it seems Mariah Carey - the same Mariah Carey who brought us such dubious style statements as skintight minidresses, shaggy blonde perms and belly jewellery - is the woman behind this spring's most trendy trend.
fields.body:
We never thought we'd see the day, but it seems Mariah Carey - the same Mariah Carey who brought us such dubious style statements as skintight minidresses, shaggy blonde perms and belly jewellery - is the woman behind this spring's most trendy trend.

Waistless jeans have been spotted on many a flat-bellied miss eager to show off the fruits of her early May sunbed sessions. Waistless jeans, I hear you query? What foolish new term must be added to the fashion lexicon next? And how can jeans not have a waist? Easy, with a little help from your scissors. Waistless jeans start at the hips: waistband, belt loops and top button are brazenly sawn off to achieve that low-slung effect so beloved of the brown tummy brigade.

The jeans (faded old ones look best) are worn skintight so they can't fall down: belts (thin, diamanté) are slung snake-like round the hips and left to dangle. All Saints, Kylie and Gisele have recently been seen sporting the look (well, they would, wouldn't they?) but, as with most super-fashionable trends, it's not quite as easy for the rest of us to pull off.

If you must try it yourself, here's a handy tip for achieving that frayed look along the top: attack the edge with a cheese grater. Did I hear someone at the back saying that fashion is a time-consuming bore for people without a life? Come, come.

webTitle: Shuttle Atlantis on course for International Space Station

fields.headline: Shuttle Atlantis on course for International Space Station
fields.standfirst: Nasa Human Spaceflight
fields.trailText: Just minutes before sunrise, the space shuttle Atlantis roared off the launch pad at Florida's Kennedy Space Centre on an urgent mission to the International Space Station, where power was running short and its orbit was slowly failing.
fields.body:
Just minutes before sunrise, the space shuttle Atlantis roared off the launch pad at Florida's Kennedy Space Centre on an urgent mission to the International Space Station, where power was running short and its orbit was slowly failing.

Lift-off was at 10.11am GMT on Nasa's fourth try to send the shuttle aloft. Three launches were scrubbed in April by bad weather. Atlantis' pilot, Scott Horowitz, turned out to be right when he held up a sign before crawling into the shuttle. The sign read: "4th time is a Charm!" Never mind that he'd scratched out "3rd."

The seven Atlantis astronauts will be the first crew to visit the unfinished outpost in almost a year. They will spend five days making repairs inside and outside the seven-story structure and delivering more than 2,000 pounds (900 kg) of supplies for future long-duration crews. Also packed aboard Atlantis were an Olympic 2000 torch, unlit of course, and an Olympic flag that will fly in Sydney in September.

The top priority of this 10-day mission is to restore full power to one of two station modules now in orbit. Astronauts will replace four of six solar-charged batteries that have malfunctioned. Next in importance is using thrusters on Atlantis to boost the station's orbit about 17 miles to a standard orbit of some 235 miles above Earth. Although the atmosphere is extremely thin at such distances, it has been enough to slowly degrade the station's orbit by about 1.5 miles a week.

With the boost, the station can be properly positioned for an automatic docking with its next major component, a Russian service module with living quarters and enough fuel to keep the station up on its own. The Russians plan to launch the module, dubbed Zvezda, in mid-July.

Spacewalking astronauts will also try to lock-down a wobbly construction crane outside the station and repair a communications array.

"We're ready to rock and roll," said pilot Scott Horowitz.

The station, a $60 billion project involving 16 nations, is still six months away from being fully habitable and a year away from conducting real science.

When completed, perhaps by 2005, it will have as much pressurized living space as a Boeing 747, will spread over most of an acre and be one of the brightest objects in the evening sky.

Nasa spokeswoman Eileen Hawley described the launch as "on-time and flawless."

The mission is commanded by James Halsell and piloted by Horowitz. Mission specialists Mary Ellen Weber, Jeff Williams, James Voss and Susan Helms are joined by Russian cosmonaut Yuri Usachev.

webTitle: The Journals of Sylvia Plath: part two

fields.headline: The Journals of Sylvia Plath 1950-1962
fields.standfirst:
The Journals of Sylvia Plath 1950-1962
Faber and Faber £21
fields.body:
1.

July 1950 - I may never be happy, but tonight I am content. Nothing more than an empty house, the warm hazy weariness from a day spent setting strawberry runners in the sun, a glass of cool sweet milk, and a shallow dish of blueberries bathed in cream. Now I know how people can live without books, without college. When one is so tired at the end of a day one must sleep, and at the next dawn there are more strawberry runners to set, and so one goes on living, near the earth. At times like this I'd call myself a fool to ask for more ...

2.

Ilo asked me today in the strawberry field, "Do you like the Renaissance painters? Raphael and Michelangelo? I copied some of Michelangelo once. And what do you think of Picasso ... These painters who make a circle and a little board going down for a leg?" We worked side by side in the rows, and he would be quiet for a while, then suddenly burst out with conversation, speaking with his thick German accent. He straightened up, his tan, intelligent face crinkling up with laughter. His chunky, muscular body was bronzed, and his blonde hair tucked up under a white handkerchief around his head. He said, "You like Frank Sinatra? So sendimental, so romandic, so moonlight night, Ja?"

3.

A sudden slant of bluish light across the floor of a vacant room. And I knew it was not the streetlight, but the moon. What is more wonderful than to be a virgin, clean and sound and young, on such a night? ... (being raped.)

4.

Tonight was awful. It was the combination of everything. Of the play "Goodbye My Fancy," of wanting, in a juvenile way, to be, like the heroine, a reporter in the trenches, to be loved by a man who admired me, who understood me as much as I understood myself. And then there was Jack, who tried so hard to be nice, who was hurt when I said all he wanted was to make out. There was the dinner at the country club, the affluence of money everywhere. And then there was the record ... the one so good for dancing. I forgot that it was the one until Louie Armstrong began to sing in a voice husky with regret, "I've flown around the world in a plane, settled revolutions in Spain, the North pole I have charted ... still I can't get started with you." Jack said: "Ever heard it before?" So I smiled, "Oh, yes." It was Bob. That settled things for me - a crazy record, and it was our long talks, his listening and understanding. And I knew I loved him.

5.

Tonight I saw Mary. Jack and I were pushing out of the theater in a current of people, and she was edging the other way in a dark blue jacket. I hardly recognized her with her eyes downcast, her face made up. But beautiful. "I've been looking all over for you," I said. "Mary. Call me, write me." She smiled, a little like the Mary I used to know, and she was gone. I knew I would never have a friend quite like her. So I went out in a white dress, a white coat, with a rich boy. And I hated myself for my hypocrasy. I love Mary. Betsy is nothing but fun; hysterical fun. Mary is me ... what I would be if I had been born of Italian parents on Linden Street. She is something vital, an artist's model, life. She can be rude, undependable, and she is more to me than all the pretty, well-to-do, artificial girls I could ever meet. Maybe it's my ego. Maybe I crave someone who will never be my rival. But with her I can be honest. She could be a prostitute, and I would not give a damn; I'll never deny her as a friend ...

6.

Today is the first of August. It is hot, steamy and wet. It is raining. I am tempted to write a poem. But I remember what it said on one rejection slip: After a heavy rainfall, poems titled RAIN pour in from across the nation.

7.

I love people. Everybody. I love them, I think, as a stamp collector loves his collection. Every story, every incident, every bit of conversation is raw material for me. My love's not impersonal yet not wholly subjective either. I would like to be everyone, a cripple, a dying man, a whore, and then come back to write about my thoughts, my emotions, as that person. But I am not omniscient. I have to live my life, and it is the only one I'll ever have. And you cannot regard your own life with objective curiosity all the time ...

8.

With me, the present is forever, and forever is always shifting, flowing, melting. This second is life. And when it is gone it is dead. But you can't start over with each new second. You have to judge by what is dead. It's like quicksand ... hopeless from the start. A story, a picture, can renew sensation a little, but not enough, not enough. Nothing is real except the present, and already, I feel the weight of centuries smothering me. Some girl a hundred years ago once lived as I do. And she is dead. I am the present, but I know I, too, will pass. The high moment, the burning flash, come and are gone, continuous quicksand. And I don't want to die.

9.

Some things are hard to write about. After something happens to you, you go to write it down, and either you over dramatize it or underplay it, exaggerate the wrong parts or ignore the important ones. At any rate, you never write it quite the way you want to. I've just got to put down what happened to me this afternoon. I can't tell mother; not yet, anyway. She was in my room when I came home, fussing with clothes, and she didn't even sense that something had happened. She just kept scolding and chattering on and on. So I couldn't stop her and tell her. No matter how it comes out, I have to write it.

It rained all afternoon at the farm, and I was cold and wet, my hair under a silk print kerchief, my red ski jacket over my sweatshirt. I had worked hard on beans all afternoon and picked over three bushels. Since it was five o'clock, people were leaving, and I was waiting beside the cars for my ride home. Kathy had just come up, and as she got on her bike she called, "Here comes Ilo."

I looked, and sure enough, there he was, coming up the road in his old khaki shirt with his familiar white handkerchief tied around his head. I was on conversational terms with him since that day we worked together in the strawberry field. He had given me a pen and ink sketch of the farm, drawn with detail and assurance. Now he was working on a sketch of one of the boys.

So I called, "Have you finished John's picture?"

"Oh, ya, ya," he smiled. "Come and see. Your last chance." He had promised to show it to me when he was done, so I ran out and got in step with him on his way to the barn. That's where he lives.

On the way, we passed Mary Coffee. I felt her looking at me rather strangely. Somehow I couldn't meet her eyes.

"Hullo, Mary," Ilo said.

"Hello, Ilo," Mary said in an oddly colorless voice.

We walked by Ginny, Sally, and a crowd of kids keeping dry in the tractor shed. A roar went up as we passed. A singsong, "Oh, Sylvia." My cheeks burned.

"Why do they have to tease me?" I asked. Ilo just laughed. He was walking very fast.

"We're going home in a little while," Milton yelled from the washroom.

I nodded and kept walking, looking at the ground. Then we were at the barn, a huge place, a giant high ceilinged room smelling of horses and damp hay. It was dim inside; I thought I saw the figure of a person on the other side of the stalls, but I couldn't be sure. Without saying a word, Ilo had begun to mount a narrow flight of wooden stairs.

"You live up there? All these stairs?"

He kept walking up, so I followed him, hesitating at the top.

"Come in, come in," he said, opening a door. The picture was there, in his room. I walked over the threshold. It was a narrow place with two windows, a table full of drawing things, and a cot, covered with a dark blanket. Oranges and milk were set out on a table with a radio.

"Here," he held out the picture. It was a fine pencil sketch of John's head.

"Why, how do you do it? With the side of the pencil?"

It seemed of no significance then, but now I remember how Ilo had shut the door, had turned on the radio so that music came out.

He talked very fast, showing me a pencil. "See, here the lead comes out, any size." I was very conscious of his nearness. His blue eyes were startlingly close, looking at me boldly, with flecks of laughter in them.

"I really have to go. They will be waiting. The picture was lovely."

Smiling, he was between me and the door. A motion. His hand closed around my arm. And suddenly his mouth was on mine, hard, vehement, his tongue darting between my lips, his arms like iron around me.

"Ilo, Ilo!" I don't know whether I screamed or whispered, struggling to break free, my hands striking wildly, futiley against his great strength. At last he let me go, and stood back. I held my hand against my mouth, warm and bruised from his kiss. He looked at me quizzically, with something like surprised amusement as he saw that I was crying, frightened. No one ever kissed me that way before, and I stood there, flooded with longing, electric, shivering.

"Why, why," he made sympathetic, depreciating little noises. "I get you some water."

He poured me out a glass, and I drank it. He opened the door, and I stumbled blindly downstairs, past Maybelle and Robert, the little colored children, who called my name in the corrupted way kids have of pronouncing things. Past Mary Lou, their mother, who stood there, a silent, dark presence.

And I was outdoors. A truck was going by. Coming from behind the barn. In it was Bernie - the horrible, short, muscular boy from the washroom. His eyes glittered with malicious delight, and he drove fast, so I could not catch up with him. Had he been in the barn? Had he seen Ilo shut the door, seen me come out? I think he must have.

I walked up past the washroom to the cars. Bernie yelled out, "Why are you crying?" I wasn't crying. Kenny and Freddy came by on the tractor. A group of boys, going home, looked at me with a light flickering somewhere in their eyes. "Did he kiss you?" one asked, with a knowing smile.

I felt sick. I couldn't have spoken if someone had talked to me. My voice was stuck in my throat, thick and furry.

Mr. Tompkins came up to the pump to watch Kenny and Freddy run the old stock car. They were nice, but they knew. They all must know.

"There's cutie pie," Kenny said.

"Cutie pie and angel face." Freddy said.

So I stood there, arms folded, staring at the whirring engine, smiling as if I was all right, as if nothing had happened.

Milton sat in the rumble seat with me going home. David drove, and Andy was in front. They all looked at me with that dancing light in their eyes. David said in a stiff, strained voice, "Everybody in the washroom was watching you go into the barn and making wisecracks."

Milton asked about the picture. We talked a little about art and drawing. They were all so nice. I think they may have been relieved at my narrow escape; they may have expected me to cry. They knew, though, they knew.

So I'm home. And tomorrow I have to face the whole damn farm. Good Lord, It might have happened in a dream. Now I can almost believe it did. But tomorrow my name will be on the tip of every tongue. I wish I could be smart, or flip, but I'm too scared. If only he hadn't kissed me. I'll have to lie and say he didn't. But they know. They all know. And what am I against so many ...?

10.

This morning I had my two left wisdom teeth out. At 9 A.M. I walked into the dentist's office. Quickly, with a heavy sense of impending doom, I sat in the chair after a rapid, furtive glance around the room for any obvious instruments of torture such as a pneumatic drill or a gas mask. No such thing. The doctor pinned the bib around my neck; I was just about prepared for him to stick an apple in my mouth and strew sprigs of parsley on my head. But no. All he did was ask, "Gas or novacaine?" (Gas or novacaine. Heh, heh! Would like to see what we have on stock, madam? Death by fire or water, by the bullet or the noose. Anything to please the customer.) "Gas," I said firmly. The nurse sneaked up behind me, put a rubber oval over my nose, the tubes of it cutting pleasantly into my cheek. "Breathe easily." The gas sifted in, strange and sickeningly sweet. I tried not to fight it. The dentist put something in my mouth, and the gas began to come in in big gulps. I had been staring at the light. It quivered, shook, broke into little pieces. The whole constellation of little iridescent fragments started to swing in a rhythmic arc, slow at first, then faster, faster. I didn't have to try hard to breathe now; something was pumping at my lungs, giving forth an odd, breathy wheeze as I exhaled. I felt my mouth cracking up into a smile. So that's how it was ... so simple, and no one had told me. I had to write it, to describe how it was, before I went under. I fancied my right hand was the tip of the arc, curved up, but just as my hand got into position, the arc would swing the other way, gaining momentum. How clever of them, I thought. They kept the feeling all secret; they wouldn't even let you write it down. And then I was on a pirate ship, the captain's face peering at me from behind the wheel, as he swung it, steering. There were columns of black, and green leaves, and he was saying loudly, "All right, close down easily, easily." Then the sunlight burst into the room through the venetian blinds; I breathed hard, filling my lungs with air. I could see my feet, my arms; there I was. I tried hard to get back in my body again ... it was such a long way to my feet. I lifted my hands, to my head; they shook. It was all over ... till next Saturday.

11.

Emile. There it is; his name. And what can I say? I can say he called for me at nine Saturday night, that I was still weak from having two wisdom teeth out that morning. I can say that we went on a double date dancing at Ten Acres, that I drank five glasses, in the course of the evening, to the bottom, of sparkling tawny gingerale, while the others drank beer. But that's not it. Not at all. This is how it was. I dressed slowly, smoothing, perfuming, powdering. I sat upstairs in the moist gray twilight, with the rain trickling down outside, while the family talked and laughed with company down on the porch. This is I, I thought, the American virgin, dressed to seduce. I know I'm in for an evening of sexual pleasure. We go on dates, we play around, and if we're nice girls, we demure at a certain point. And so it goes. We walked into the bar and sat down, two by two. E. and I had the initial strangeness to rub off. We began to talk - about the funeral he went to this morning, about his twenty year old cousin who broke his back and is paralyzed for life, about his sister who died of pneumonia at twelve years. "Good lord, we're morbid tonight," he shuddered. And then, "You know something I've always liked ... I mean wanted to like? Dark eyes and blonde hair." So we talked about little things, how words lose their meaning when you repeat them over and over; how all people of the Negro race look alike until you get to know them individually; how we always liked the age we were at best. "I pity Warrie," he said, nodding at the other boy. "He's twenty-two, out of Amherst, and he has to work the rest of his life. When I figure ... only two more years of college."

"I know, I've always dreaded birthdays."

"You don't look as young as you are."

"I don't see," I said, "how people stand being old. Your insides all dry up. When you're young you're so self-reliant. You don't even need much religion."

"You're not by any chance a Catholic?" He asked as if it were quite unlikely.

"No. You?"

"Yes." He said it very low.

There was more small talk, more laughing, sidelong glances, more of the unspoken physical friction that makes each new conquest so delightful. In the air was the strong smell of masculinity which creates the ideal medium for me to exist in. There was something in Emile tonight, a touch of seriousness, a chemical magnetism, that met my mood the way two pieces of a child's puzzle fit together. He has a fine face, dark hair, and eyes with enormous black pupils; a straight nose, a one-sided flashing grin, a clean-cut chin. He is neatly made, with small, sensitive hands. I knew it would be the way it was. On the dance floor he held me close to him, the hard line of his penis taut against my stomach, my breasts aching firm against his chest. And it was like warm wine flooding through me, a sleepy, electric drowsiness. He nuzzled his face in my hair; kissed my cheek. "Don't look at me," he said. "I've just come out of a swimming pool, hot and wet." (God, I knew it would be like this.) He was looking at me intently, searchingly, and our eyes met. I went under twice; I was drowning; and he flicked his gaze away. On the way to Warrie's at midnight, Emile kissed me in the car, his mouth wet and gentle on mine. At Warrie's, more gingerale, more beer, and dancing with the dim light from the porch, Emile's body warm and firm against mine, rocking back and forth to the soft, erotic music. (Dancing is the normal prelude to intercourse. All the dancing classes when we are too young to understand, and then this.) "You know," Emile looked at me, "we ought to sit down." I shook my head. "No?" he said. "How about some water, then. Feel all right?" (Feel all right. Oh, yes. Yes, thank you.) He steered me out to the kitchen, cool, smelling of linoleum, with the sound of the rain falling outside. I sat and sipped the water he brought me, while he stood looking down, his features strange in the half-light. I put the glass down. "That was quick," he said. "Should I have taken longer?" I stood up and his face moved in, his arms about me. After a while I pushed him away. "The rain's rather nice. It makes you feel good inside, elemental, just to listen." I was backed against the sink; Emile was close, warm, his eyes glittering, his mouth sensuous and lovely. "You," I said deliberately, "don't give a damn about me except physically." Any boy would deny that; any gallant boy; any gallant lier. But Emile shook me, his voice was urgent, "You know, you shouldn't have said that. You know? You know? The truth always hurts." (Even clich*s can come in handy.) He grinned, "Don't be bitter; I'm not. Come away from the sink, and watch." He stepped back, drawing me toward him, slapping my stomach away, he kissed me long and sweetly. At last he let go. "There," he said with a quiet smile. "The truth doesn't always hurt, does it?" And so we left. It was pouring rain. In the car he put his arm around me, his head against mine, and we watched the streetlights coming at us, blurred and fluid in the watery dark. As we ran up the walk in the rain, as he came in and had a drink of water, as he kissed me goodnight, I knew that something in me wanted him, for what I'm not sure: He drinks, he smokes, he's Catholic, he runs around with one girl after another, and yet ... I wanted him. "I don't have to tell you it's been nice," I said at the door. "It's been marvelous," he smiled. "I'll call you. Take care." And he was gone. So the rain comes down hard outside my room, and like Eddie Cohen, I say, "... fifteen thousand years - of what? We're still nothing but animals." Somewhere, in his room, Emile lies, about to sleep, listening to the rain. God only knows what he's thinking.
