fields.bodyText: 1. July 1950 - I may never be happy, but tonight I am content. Nothing more than an empty house, the warm hazy weariness from a day spent setting strawberry runners in the sun, a glass of cool sweet milk, and a shallow dish of blueberries bathed in cream. Now I know how people can live without books, without college. When one is so tired at the end of a day one must sleep, and at the next dawn there are more strawberry runners to set, and so one goes on living, near the earth. At times like this I'd call myself a fool to ask for more ... 2. Ilo asked me today in the strawberry field, "Do you like the Renaissance painters? Raphael and Michelangelo? I copied some of Michelangelo once. And what do you think of Picasso ... These painters who make a circle and a little board going down for a leg?" We worked side by side in the rows, and he would be quiet for a while, then suddenly burst out with conversation, speaking with his thick German accent. He straightened up, his tan, intelligent face crinkling up with laughter. His chunky, muscular body was bronzed, and his blonde hair tucked up under a white handkerchief around his head. He said, "You like Frank Sinatra? So sendimental, so romandic, so moonlight night, Ja?" 3. A sudden slant of bluish light across the floor of a vacant room. And I knew it was not the streetlight, but the moon. What is more wonderful than to be a virgin, clean and sound and young, on such a night? ... (being raped.) 4. Tonight was awful. It was the combination of everything. Of the play "Goodbye My Fancy," of wanting, in a juvenile way, to be, like the heroine, a reporter in the trenches, to be loved by a man who admired me, who understood me as much as I understood myself. And then there was Jack, who tried so hard to be nice, who was hurt when I said all he wanted was to make out. There was the dinner at the country club, the affluence of money everywhere. And then there was the record ... the one so good for dancing. I forgot that it was the one until Louie Armstrong began to sing in a voice husky with regret, "I've flown around the world in a plane, settled revolutions in Spain, the North pole I have charted ... still I can't get started with you." Jack said: "Ever heard it before?" So I smiled, "Oh, yes." It was Bob. That settled things for me - a crazy record, and it was our long talks, his listening and understanding. And I knew I loved him. 5. Tonight I saw Mary. Jack and I were pushing out of the theater in a current of people, and she was edging the other way in a dark blue jacket. I hardly recognized her with her eyes downcast, her face made up. But beautiful. "I've been looking all over for you," I said. "Mary. Call me, write me." She smiled, a little like the Mary I used to know, and she was gone. I knew I would never have a friend quite like her. So I went out in a white dress, a white coat, with a rich boy. And I hated myself for my hypocrasy. I love Mary. Betsy is nothing but fun; hysterical fun. Mary is me ... what I would be if I had been born of Italian parents on Linden Street. She is something vital, an artist's model, life. She can be rude, undependable, and she is more to me than all the pretty, well-to-do, artificial girls I could ever meet. Maybe it's my ego. Maybe I crave someone who will never be my rival. But with her I can be honest. She could be a prostitute, and I would not give a damn; I'll never deny her as a friend ... 6. Today is the first of August. It is hot, steamy and wet. It is raining. I am tempted to write a poem. But I remember what it said on one rejection slip: After a heavy rainfall, poems titled RAIN pour in from across the nation. 7. I love people. Everybody. I love them, I think, as a stamp collector loves his collection. Every story, every incident, every bit of conversation is raw material for me. My love's not impersonal yet not wholly subjective either. I would like to be everyone, a cripple, a dying man, a whore, and then come back to write about my thoughts, my emotions, as that person. But I am not omniscient. I have to live my life, and it is the only one I'll ever have. And you cannot regard your own life with objective curiosity all the time ... 8. With me, the present is forever, and forever is always shifting, flowing, melting. This second is life. And when it is gone it is dead. But you can't start over with each new second. You have to judge by what is dead. It's like quicksand ... hopeless from the start. A story, a picture, can renew sensation a little, but not enough, not enough. Nothing is real except the present, and already, I feel the weight of centuries smothering me. Some girl a hundred years ago once lived as I do. And she is dead. I am the present, but I know I, too, will pass. The high moment, the burning flash, come and are gone, continuous quicksand. And I don't want to die. 9. Some things are hard to write about. After something happens to you, you go to write it down, and either you over dramatize it or underplay it, exaggerate the wrong parts or ignore the important ones. At any rate, you never write it quite the way you want to. I've just got to put down what happened to me this afternoon. I can't tell mother; not yet, anyway. She was in my room when I came home, fussing with clothes, and she didn't even sense that something had happened. She just kept scolding and chattering on and on. So I couldn't stop her and tell her. No matter how it comes out, I have to write it. It rained all afternoon at the farm, and I was cold and wet, my hair under a silk print kerchief, my red ski jacket over my sweatshirt. I had worked hard on beans all afternoon and picked over three bushels. Since it was five o'clock, people were leaving, and I was waiting beside the cars for my ride home. Kathy had just come up, and as she got on her bike she called, "Here comes Ilo." I looked, and sure enough, there he was, coming up the road in his old khaki shirt with his familiar white handkerchief tied around his head. I was on conversational terms with him since that day we worked together in the strawberry field. He had given me a pen and ink sketch of the farm, drawn with detail and assurance. Now he was working on a sketch of one of the boys. So I called, "Have you finished John's picture?" "Oh, ya, ya," he smiled. "Come and see. Your last chance." He had promised to show it to me when he was done, so I ran out and got in step with him on his way to the barn. That's where he lives. On the way, we passed Mary Coffee. I felt her looking at me rather strangely. Somehow I couldn't meet her eyes. "Hullo, Mary," Ilo said. "Hello, Ilo," Mary said in an oddly colorless voice. We walked by Ginny, Sally, and a crowd of kids keeping dry in the tractor shed. A roar went up as we passed. A singsong, "Oh, Sylvia." My cheeks burned. "Why do they have to tease me?" I asked. Ilo just laughed. He was walking very fast. "We're going home in a little while," Milton yelled from the washroom. I nodded and kept walking, looking at the ground. Then we were at the barn, a huge place, a giant high ceilinged room smelling of horses and damp hay. It was dim inside; I thought I saw the figure of a person on the other side of the stalls, but I couldn't be sure. Without saying a word, Ilo had begun to mount a narrow flight of wooden stairs. "You live up there? All these stairs?" He kept walking up, so I followed him, hesitating at the top. "Come in, come in," he said, opening a door. The picture was there, in his room. I walked over the threshold. It was a narrow place with two windows, a table full of drawing things, and a cot, covered with a dark blanket. Oranges and milk were set out on a table with a radio. "Here," he held out the picture. It was a fine pencil sketch of John's head. "Why, how do you do it? With the side of the pencil?" It seemed of no significance then, but now I remember how Ilo had shut the door, had turned on the radio so that music came out. He talked very fast, showing me a pencil. "See, here the lead comes out, any size." I was very conscious of his nearness. His blue eyes were startlingly close, looking at me boldly, with flecks of laughter in them. "I really have to go. They will be waiting. The picture was lovely." Smiling, he was between me and the door. A motion. His hand closed around my arm. And suddenly his mouth was on mine, hard, vehement, his tongue darting between my lips, his arms like iron around me. "Ilo, Ilo!" I don't know whether I screamed or whispered, struggling to break free, my hands striking wildly, futiley against his great strength. At last he let me go, and stood back. I held my hand against my mouth, warm and bruised from his kiss. He looked at me quizzically, with something like surprised amusement as he saw that I was crying, frightened. No one ever kissed me that way before, and I stood there, flooded with longing, electric, shivering. "Why, why," he made sympathetic, depreciating little noises. "I get you some water." He poured me out a glass, and I drank it. He opened the door, and I stumbled blindly downstairs, past Maybelle and Robert, the little colored children, who called my name in the corrupted way kids have of pronouncing things. Past Mary Lou, their mother, who stood there, a silent, dark presence. And I was outdoors. A truck was going by. Coming from behind the barn. In it was Bernie - the horrible, short, muscular boy from the washroom. His eyes glittered with malicious delight, and he drove fast, so I could not catch up with him. Had he been in the barn? Had he seen Ilo shut the door, seen me come out? I think he must have. I walked up past the washroom to the cars. Bernie yelled out, "Why are you crying?" I wasn't crying. Kenny and Freddy came by on the tractor. A group of boys, going home, looked at me with a light flickering somewhere in their eyes. "Did he kiss you?" one asked, with a knowing smile. I felt sick. I couldn't have spoken if someone had talked to me. My voice was stuck in my throat, thick and furry. Mr. Tompkins came up to the pump to watch Kenny and Freddy run the old stock car. They were nice, but they knew. They all must know. "There's cutie pie," Kenny said. "Cutie pie and angel face." Freddy said. So I stood there, arms folded, staring at the whirring engine, smiling as if I was all right, as if nothing had happened. Milton sat in the rumble seat with me going home. David drove, and Andy was in front. They all looked at me with that dancing light in their eyes. David said in a stiff, strained voice, "Everybody in the washroom was watching you go into the barn and making wisecracks." Milton asked about the picture. We talked a little about art and drawing. They were all so nice. I think they may have been relieved at my narrow escape; they may have expected me to cry. They knew, though, they knew. So I'm home. And tomorrow I have to face the whole damn farm. Good Lord, It might have happened in a dream. Now I can almost believe it did. But tomorrow my name will be on the tip of every tongue. I wish I could be smart, or flip, but I'm too scared. If only he hadn't kissed me. I'll have to lie and say he didn't. But they know. They all know. And what am I against so many ...? 10. This morning I had my two left wisdom teeth out. At 9 A.M. I walked into the dentist's office. Quickly, with a heavy sense of impending doom, I sat in the chair after a rapid, furtive glance around the room for any obvious instruments of torture such as a pneumatic drill or a gas mask. No such thing. The doctor pinned the bib around my neck; I was just about prepared for him to stick an apple in my mouth and strew sprigs of parsley on my head. But no. All he did was ask, "Gas or novacaine?" (Gas or novacaine. Heh, heh! Would like to see what we have on stock, madam? Death by fire or water, by the bullet or the noose. Anything to please the customer.) "Gas," I said firmly. The nurse sneaked up behind me, put a rubber oval over my nose, the tubes of it cutting pleasantly into my cheek. "Breathe easily." The gas sifted in, strange and sickeningly sweet. I tried not to fight it. The dentist put something in my mouth, and the gas began to come in in big gulps. I had been staring at the light. It quivered, shook, broke into little pieces. The whole constellation of little iridescent fragments started to swing in a rhythmic arc, slow at first, then faster, faster. I didn't have to try hard to breathe now; something was pumping at my lungs, giving forth an odd, breathy wheeze as I exhaled. I felt my mouth cracking up into a smile. So that's how it was ... so simple, and no one had told me. I had to write it, to describe how it was, before I went under. I fancied my right hand was the tip of the arc, curved up, but just as my hand got into position, the arc would swing the other way, gaining momentum. How clever of them, I thought. They kept the feeling all secret; they wouldn't even let you write it down. And then I was on a pirate ship, the captain's face peering at me from behind the wheel, as he swung it, steering. There were columns of black, and green leaves, and he was saying loudly, "All right, close down easily, easily." Then the sunlight burst into the room through the venetian blinds; I breathed hard, filling my lungs with air. I could see my feet, my arms; there I was. I tried hard to get back in my body again ... it was such a long way to my feet. I lifted my hands, to my head; they shook. It was all over ... till next Saturday. 11. Emile. There it is; his name. And what can I say? I can say he called for me at nine Saturday night, that I was still weak from having two wisdom teeth out that morning. I can say that we went on a double date dancing at Ten Acres, that I drank five glasses, in the course of the evening, to the bottom, of sparkling tawny gingerale, while the others drank beer. But that's not it. Not at all. This is how it was. I dressed slowly, smoothing, perfuming, powdering. I sat upstairs in the moist gray twilight, with the rain trickling down outside, while the family talked and laughed with company down on the porch. This is I, I thought, the American virgin, dressed to seduce. I know I'm in for an evening of sexual pleasure. We go on dates, we play around, and if we're nice girls, we demure at a certain point. And so it goes. We walked into the bar and sat down, two by two. E. and I had the initial strangeness to rub off. We began to talk - about the funeral he went to this morning, about his twenty year old cousin who broke his back and is paralyzed for life, about his sister who died of pneumonia at twelve years. "Good lord, we're morbid tonight," he shuddered. And then, "You know something I've always liked ... I mean wanted to like? Dark eyes and blonde hair." So we talked about little things, how words lose their meaning when you repeat them over and over; how all people of the Negro race look alike until you get to know them individually; how we always liked the age we were at best. "I pity Warrie," he said, nodding at the other boy. "He's twenty-two, out of Amherst, and he has to work the rest of his life. When I figure ... only two more years of college." "I know, I've always dreaded birthdays." "You don't look as young as you are." "I don't see," I said, "how people stand being old. Your insides all dry up. When you're young you're so self-reliant. You don't even need much religion." "You're not by any chance a Catholic?" He asked as if it were quite unlikely. "No. You?" "Yes." He said it very low. There was more small talk, more laughing, sidelong glances, more of the unspoken physical friction that makes each new conquest so delightful. In the air was the strong smell of masculinity which creates the ideal medium for me to exist in. There was something in Emile tonight, a touch of seriousness, a chemical magnetism, that met my mood the way two pieces of a child's puzzle fit together. He has a fine face, dark hair, and eyes with enormous black pupils; a straight nose, a one-sided flashing grin, a clean-cut chin. He is neatly made, with small, sensitive hands. I knew it would be the way it was. On the dance floor he held me close to him, the hard line of his penis taut against my stomach, my breasts aching firm against his chest. And it was like warm wine flooding through me, a sleepy, electric drowsiness. He nuzzled his face in my hair; kissed my cheek. "Don't look at me," he said. "I've just come out of a swimming pool, hot and wet." (God, I knew it would be like this.) He was looking at me intently, searchingly, and our eyes met. I went under twice; I was drowning; and he flicked his gaze away. On the way to Warrie's at midnight, Emile kissed me in the car, his mouth wet and gentle on mine. At Warrie's, more gingerale, more beer, and dancing with the dim light from the porch, Emile's body warm and firm against mine, rocking back and forth to the soft, erotic music. (Dancing is the normal prelude to intercourse. All the dancing classes when we are too young to understand, and then this.) "You know," Emile looked at me, "we ought to sit down." I shook my head. "No?" he said. "How about some water, then. Feel all right?" (Feel all right. Oh, yes. Yes, thank you.) He steered me out to the kitchen, cool, smelling of linoleum, with the sound of the rain falling outside. I sat and sipped the water he brought me, while he stood looking down, his features strange in the half-light. I put the glass down. "That was quick," he said. "Should I have taken longer?" I stood up and his face moved in, his arms about me. After a while I pushed him away. "The rain's rather nice. It makes you feel good inside, elemental, just to listen." I was backed against the sink; Emile was close, warm, his eyes glittering, his mouth sensuous and lovely. "You," I said deliberately, "don't give a damn about me except physically." Any boy would deny that; any gallant boy; any gallant lier. But Emile shook me, his voice was urgent, "You know, you shouldn't have said that. You know? You know? The truth always hurts." (Even clich*s can come in handy.) He grinned, "Don't be bitter; I'm not. Come away from the sink, and watch." He stepped back, drawing me toward him, slapping my stomach away, he kissed me long and sweetly. At last he let go. "There," he said with a quiet smile. "The truth doesn't always hurt, does it?" And so we left. It was pouring rain. In the car he put his arm around me, his head against mine, and we watched the streetlights coming at us, blurred and fluid in the watery dark. As we ran up the walk in the rain, as he came in and had a drink of water, as he kissed me goodnight, I knew that something in me wanted him, for what I'm not sure: He drinks, he smokes, he's Catholic, he runs around with one girl after another, and yet ... I wanted him. "I don't have to tell you it's been nice," I said at the door. "It's been marvelous," he smiled. "I'll call you. Take care." And he was gone. So the rain comes down hard outside my room, and like Eddie Cohen, I say, "... fifteen thousand years - of what? We're still nothing but animals." Somewhere, in his room, Emile lies, about to sleep, listening to the rain. God only knows what he's thinking. Continue

fields.headline: Cherie's choice
fields.standfirst:
Was Mrs Blair trying to prove something by working right up until the last week of pregnancy? Maureen Freely, who did the same, says few women would do it unless they felt they had to

Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: Was Mrs Blair trying to prove something by working right up until the last week of pregnancy? Maureen Freely, who did the same, says few women would do it unless they felt they had to
fields.body:
Just listen to this. Actually, I'd be shocked if you hadn't heard already. On Tuesday, Cherie Booth took a case to the high court, even though it was only eight days before her due date . The cause couldn't have been worthier. And talk about ironic. She was there to ask the Lord Chief Justice to rule that her husband's government was acting illegally in depriving more than 2.5m parents of unpaid parental leave. In balancing the competing interests of employers and parents, she said, the court should be taking account of the "protected status of family life". She argued her case, observers said later, with eloquence and remarkable cool. But it's not clear if anyone heard her. People were just too excited about her bump.

She looked as if she was about to pop, but did that stop her? She seemed determined to put on a perfect show of strength. Perhaps this is why she didn't even think to ask for the court to break with tradition and provide her with a chair. During the two hours she spent on her feet, she even found time for a joke. She kept herself going, we hear, by drinking several glasses of mineral water. She only showed signs of flagging at the very end of her submission. And how relieved she looked, when the judges indicated that she was finally free to sit down.

But perhaps she is less happy today, after all the criticism she's been getting for pushing herself too hard, for sending out such negative messages to the rank and file, for making lesser mortals feel bad if they spend their last weeks of pregnancy resting. People are beginning to wonder why she is bothering to have this child at all, if work is so important to her. What's the rush? What is she trying to prove?

Let's hope she's not hoping to break the record. If she is, she's going to have to try much, much harder. The last time I looked at the figures, the record holder in the machisma stakes was a Scottish executive who finalised a multibillion pound deal for her employers during the first stage of labour. Even after her waters broke, she stayed at her desk, videoconferencing with her associates on the other side of the Atlantic for another three hours. She's far from the only one. There are a lot of very tough women out there, who are managing to do their very best work right through pregnancy and beyond, without causing a single ripple. So it's no longer possible to say it's impossible for a pregnant woman to work right up to her due date. But you have to ask why a woman would choose to do so.

Are they trying to prove something? I know I was, when I was pregnant the first time. This was not just silliness on my part, although there was plenty of that, too. The social adjustments you have to make when pregnant for the first time are, if anything, more difficult than the physical adjustments. When you are accustomed to being treated like an adult, it is not pleasant to have everyone around you suddenly treat you like a child. You are always hearing that you are not to worry if your mind has turned to mush. If you raise your voice to insist that, actually, your mind is no mushier than it's ever been, no one listens.

Everyone smiles at you indulgently and attributes your short temper to hormones. So naturally, you feel as if you have something to prove. But even if you do prove it, you may wonder later if it was worth the effort. I spent my last trimester racing against time to finish a translation.

It seemed so important then. But all that sitting in straight, uncomfortable chairs, gasping for breath and struggling to reach the typewriter keys was for nothing, as no one wanted to publish it. I would have been better off putting my feet up. I would also have adjusted more easily to motherhood had I not felt compelled to take papers into hospital.

I went into my second pregnancy wanting to let my body set the pace. I was determined not to work until the bitter end this time. But I had a book to finish. I had been working on it for four years and wanted to draw a line under it to devote full attention to the baby. I drove myself so hard to meet this deadline that I came down with pneumonia. I had to spend the last five weeks of pregnancy in bed.

So when I was pregnant for the third time, eight years later, I had been cured of all delusions. I knew how hard it was to strike a balance, and also how important it was. But this time it was out of my hands. I couldn't stop work because I was single with two young children to support.

I couldn't even take maternity leave because I didn't have a proper job. I had a column. I was on a retainer, which meant that my employers could let me go whenever they felt like it. So when they asked me to file two extra columns in my last two weeks, in addition to the ones I would be filing anyway, I was quick to say how delighted I was by the prospect. But, really, I wasn't. Really, I was in pain. I filed my second standby piece on a Monday, and my regular piece on a Tuesday. On the Wednesday, I gave birth. I filed another column six days later. A few days later, the editor rang to say that he would no longer be needing my services.

It was hard to get work for a while after that, because everyone thought I was on maternity leave. But where there is a will and a house full of children who depend on your earnings, there is always a way. This is not to say I sailed through my last pregnancy two years later. I had trouble walking, was short of breath and got very dizzy after two hours on the computer. But I still managed to put in eight- or nine-hour days right through to the day my daughter was born. And I was back at the computer two days later. I had this article to do, you see, and I had missed the deadline. The subject I was meant to be writing about was scorn.

Scorn was certainly what I got from the midwife when she caught me at the screen. "You should be focussing on your baby," was what she said. But if she had ever paused to put her ideological blinkers aside and see things from my point of view, she would have seen that I had compelling reasons to keep working.

But there must be something wrong with a society that puts more and more women into this position. For those of us who have been there and lived to tell the tale, it's the flip comments that hurt the most. First you have to push yourself far beyond the limit, so that you can bring in enough money to buy the groceries and pay the mortgage. Then, the moment you have a chance to put your feet up, you have to hear how silly and irresponsible and unmaternal you are to be working so late. You stand accused of not caring for your children, of having "other priorities". This is the cruellest accusation of all.

There may be a few women out there who work late because they are unmaternal, but most of us who've worked right through our pregnancies have done so because we have no other option. We love our children, so we wanted to make sure they could eat. If we'd had more economic security, we might have made other choices.

It was to argue for the protection of family life that Cherie Booth made her famous last appearance in court. I am sure it was exhausting for her, and as time wore on, increasingly painful. She must have known from the start what a fuss everyone would make about her "condition". She must have known that people would be paying more attention to her breathing patterns and her water intake than her words, and that she would be accused, yet again, of setting a dangerous precedent. She went ahead because she felt so strongly about the issues and knew how high the stakes were, and thought that her appearance in court would raise the case's profile. For all our sakes, I hope she wins.

I couldn't even take maternity leave because I didn't have a proper job. I had a column. I was on a retainer, which meant that my employers could let me go whenever they felt like it. So when they asked me to file two extra columns in my last two weeks, in addition to the ones I would be filing anyway, I was quick to say how delighted I was by the prospect. But, really, I wasn't. Really, I was in pain. I filed my second standby piece on a Monday, and my regular piece on a Tuesday. On the Wednesday, I gave birth. I filed another column six days later. A few days later, the editor rang to say that he would no longer be needing my services. It was hard to get work for a while after that, because everyone thought I was on maternity leave. But where there is a will and a house full of children who depend on your earnings, there is always a way. This is not to say I sailed through my last pregnancy two years later. I had trouble walking, was short of breath and got very dizzy after two hours on the computer. But I still managed to put in eight- or nine-hour days right through to the day my daughter was born. And I was back at the computer two days later. I had this article to do, you see, and I had missed the deadline. The subject I was meant to be writing about was scorn. Scorn was certainly what I got from the midwife when she caught me at the screen. "You should be focussing on your baby," was what she said. But if she had ever paused to put her ideological blinkers aside and see things from my point of view, she would have seen that I had compelling reasons to keep working. But there must be something wrong with a society that puts more and more women into this position. For those of us who have been there and lived to tell the tale, it's the flip comments that hurt the most. First you have to push yourself far beyond the limit, so that you can bring in enough money to buy the groceries and pay the mortgage. Then, the moment you have a chance to put your feet up, you have to hear how silly and irresponsible and unmaternal you are to be working so late. You stand accused of not caring for your children, of having "other priorities". This is the cruellest accusation of all. There may be a few women out there who work late because they are unmaternal, but most of us who've worked right through our pregnancies have done so because we have no other option. We love our children, so we wanted to make sure they could eat. If we'd had more economic security, we might have made other choices. It was to argue for the protection of family life that Cherie Booth made her famous last appearance in court. I am sure it was exhausting for her, and as time wore on, increasingly painful. She must have known from the start what a fuss everyone would make about her "condition". She must have known that people would be paying more attention to her breathing patterns and her water intake than her words, and that she would be accused, yet again, of setting a dangerous precedent. She went ahead because she felt so strongly about the issues and knew how high the stakes were, and thought that her appearance in court would raise the case's profile. For all our sakes, I hope she wins.

fields.headline: Laura Blundy by Julie Myerson
fields.standfirst: (4th Estate, £15.99) digested in the style of the original
fields.trailText: Tender gothic love story masquerading as the Victorian handsaw massacre
fields.body:
Ewan didn't like ornaments. He liked the metal dog even less when I, Laura Blundy, stove his skull in with it. I felt a soft smashing, a caving-in of bone and brain then a jet of blood sloshed out and hit the wall beneath the dado rail. I gripped my crutch tightly and caught my breath. I started laughing. A hand shot out and grabbed my ankle. He was a fighter, Ewan, I'll give him that. I picked up a poker, took aim between his eyes and pressed down, waiting for a definite juicy crunch. He didn't move again.

He had to die, did Ewan. I couldn't let anything come between me and my Billy. Billy was only 23 years old, 15 years my junior. He was a foundling, but a good husband to Cally and his kids. Ever since Billy had pulled me out of the Thames when I tried to drown myself, we had been inseparable. We loved each other, me and Billy.

Ewan never did understand why I wanted to kill myself. He was a surgeon and we had met when I was taken to hospital after being knocked down by a carriage. My leg got infected and he had to saw it off. I blacked out as he severed the membranes and grabbed the jaw-tooth saw and started working it through my marrow, turning the sawdust in the blood box into a mulch of black gruel. He had taken a fancy to me after this, and we had got married and I had tried to be the good wife, but there was so much about me I couldn't tell him.

My father had had a shop and we had been quite well-off until he died. Then I found myself on the street and I was raped when I was 15 by a gentleman in the back of a carriage and got pregnant. I loved that boy, I really did. But living in the filth of London, with all that cess, almost killed us and I had to give him away to the Foundling hospital.

"You've done it now, and no mistake," said Billy. We went back to the house and cut Ewan's body up. The legs and thighs came off easy, but the knife got caught in his neckbone as I tried to saw his head off. We wrapped the parts in the tarpaulin and took them to the river. We weighted the legs and chucked them in and they sank with a glorious plop. But the head, with Ewan's stupid grin taunting us, floated. We fished it out and lit a bonfire. The flesh does not burn to ashes, as you might think. It stays like charred meat and his teeth are coated shiny brown from the smoke and the fat.

"Why did you not look for your child?" says Billy. "He died," I says. "One day I went back to the hospital and was just told he had died." He asks me if I saw the grave and I tell him I never went because, and this is shameful, I went to prison. For murder. I was let out because it turned out the mother had done it, but God knows, I had wanted to kill that baby. For being alive when mine wasn't.

We're home free, now, me and Billy. We're on the way to Folkestone to start again in France. Only I don't tell Billy that I did once go to see where he was buried. And the gravestone said, Laura Blundy. I wasn't saved by Billy, I drowned. But I have what I want. I gave you comfort once, Billy, and now I'll give it again.

fields.headline: New computer virus warning
fields.standfirst:
British firms warned to be vigilant over 'more sophisticated' version of Love Bug
The Love Bug
fields.trailText: Computer experts in the UK today warned against a new virus carried through e-mail which last night paralysed companies across America.
fields.body:
Computer experts in the UK today warned against a new virus carried through e-mail which last night paralysed companies across America.

The new virus is described as a more sophisticated variant of the "Love Bug", which caused millions of pounds of damage across the world earlier this month.

Graham Cluley, of Sophos Anti-Virus, said the bug had not hit British computers yet - but warned people to be vigilant.

"We have been working on this since 2am this morning when we got reports in from America," he said.

"The virus takes on the name of someone in your address book, meaning it looks exactly like a normal e-mail, with the subject line starting 'fw:'. It carries an attachment which also picks up a random name, so there is nothing like the Love Bug to distinguish it.

"The only way of spotting it is that the attachment ends 'Vbs.' We would advise people to be cautious. A good idea might be to put a block on any attachments with the 'Vbs.' ending."

The virus takes up a substantial amount of memory it may therefore be slower to spread than the Love Bug. Computers at several large companies in the US were infected late last night, according to Dave Perry, spokesman at anti-virus software company Trend Micro, in Cupertino, California. One company had all of its 5,000 computers infected, he said.

Like the Love Bug scourge that spread to millions of computers two weeks ago, the new virus arrives in an attachment to an email. However, it is not identified by an "ILOVEYOU" subject line. Instead, the subject line changes to a random word or phrase every time a computer is infected.

The virus randomly chooses a recently opened file from the Start/Document folder in the Microsoft Start menu and attaches it to the email as a .vbs file.

Experts at Symantec AntiVirus Research Centre, one of the industry's largest dedicated team of virus experts, with offices in the US, Japan, Australia and the Netherlands, said each time the virus spreads it mutates itself to evade detection.

Clicking on the attachment will activate the virus. Like Love Bug, it will send itself to everybody in the user's address book. It will then destroy most of the files on the hard drive, rendering the computer useless until the operating system is reinstalled.

As with the Love Bug, only recipients running Microsoft's Outlook email programme for Windows are vulnerable and there is no danger if the attachment is not opened, virus experts said.

Investigators suspect the Love Bug originated in the Philippines, where several people have been questioned.

Microsoft has said it will make available a modification to Outlook next week that will warn users about suspect email attachments.

fields.headline: The Love Bug
fields.trailText: The "love bug" has been dubbed the fastest-moving and most widespread computer virus ever seen, affecting computer systems worldwide. It infected tens of millions of computers, not only spreading by email like last year's Melissa virus, but through instant messaging systems that let people chat in real time on the net.
fields.body:
The "love bug" has been dubbed the fastest-moving and most widespread computer virus ever seen, affecting computer systems worldwide. It infected tens of millions of computers, not only spreading by email like last year's Melissa virus, but through instant messaging systems that let people chat in real time on the net.

In the latest case, earlier this month, the original virus appeared in emails as "ILOVEYOU", enticing users to open the message, only to paralyse their e-mail systems. One of its variants uses the phrase "fw: joke" in the subject line.

Another had a subject line that reads "Susitikim shi vakara kavas puodukui...", which is Lithuanian for "Let's meet this evening for coffee...". Lithuanian officials said on Friday they would investigate possible local origins of the virus. Although the bug apparently did originate in Manila, computer networks in the Philippines were not much affected.

Other notable viruses

 Melissa. Described as a typical macro virus with an unusual "payload", Melissa, when opened, attempted to e-mail itself to up to 50 other people. Melissa infected about a million computers and caused £50m of damage. David Smith, a 31-year-old computer programmer from Newark, New Jersey, was responsible for Melissa.

 Back Orifice 2000. A cunning programme written by a group called The Cult of the Dead Cow. It allows people to take remote control of Windows machines and was released summer in Las Vegas at Def Con, the seventh annual convention for virus writers and hackers from around the world. Mainly aimed at system administrators.

 W32/Mypics. Similar to Melissa. It arrived via email with the message: "Here's some pictures for you!" and contains the file pics4you.exe, which, once opened, will point a user's home page in the internet explorer browser to an adult pornography site.

 W95, alias Chernobyl and CIH.Spacefiller. Chernobyl is a very destructive virus that destroys data. It infects 32-bit Windows 95/98/NT files but is only capable of functioning under Windows 95/98. When an infected program on a Windows 95/98 machine is run, it becomes resident in the computer's memory. An infected system, therefore, must be rebooted from a clean system disk before scanning with an anti-virus product.

 XM.Laroux, alias ExcelMacro/Laroux, Excel.Laroux, and Laroux. This virus is the first working Excel macro virus found in general circulation. The macros are stored in a hidden datasheet named "laroux." When an infected spreadsheet is opened, the Check_Files macro copies the worksheet with the virus code into a spreadsheet file stored in the Excel startup directory. This enables the infection of all other spreadsheets opened or created on the infected system in the future.

fields.headline: The FA Cup final
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the world's oldest football competition on the net...
fields.trailText: 1. The FA Cup kicks off at 3pm on Saturday as Aston Villa and Chelsea go head to head in the oldest football competition in the world.
fields.body:
1. The FA Cup kicks off at 3pm on Saturday as Aston Villa and Chelsea go head to head in the oldest football competition in the world.

2. Neither side has won anything this season or exactly set the league alight so the game could go either way. It may be worth a flutter.

3. The final has been played at Wembley stadium since 1923 when Bolton Wanderers beat West Ham United 2-0 in front of a crowd some estimates put as high as 200,000.

4. This one however will be the last played under the famous twin towers before work begins on the new national stadium.

5. Fifteen clubs played for the cup when the competition started. The Wanderers won the first final in 1872 and again the next year, but had to hand the prize over to the likes of Oxford University (1874), the Royal Engineers (1875), Old Etonians (1879), Clapham Rovers (1880) in subsequent years.

6. Five hundred and eighty members of the football association entered the competition this season. Manchester United did not.

7. The 10-times winners withdrew from the competition so they could contest FIFA club world championship in Brazil.

8. The Cup Final hymn Abide With Me was sung for the first time in 1927, the year Cardiff City beat Arsenal to take the Cup back to Wales for the one and only time.

9. Four years ago Roberto Di Matteo scored the fastest-ever goal in a Wembley Cup final when he lashed in a shot after 43 seconds to set Chelsea on their way to a 2-0 win over Middlesbrough.

10. 80 miles of cable are used by the television companies on Cup final day. If you can't get to a TV watch minute-by-minute coverage on Football Unlimited and relive some classic finals of the past.

fields.headline: Make-or-break for Ulster, says Mandelson
fields.standfirst: Government 'has no plan B' if IRA offer is rejected
fields.trailText: The next week could be "make or break" for the future of Northern Ireland, secretary of state Peter Mandelson said today as Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble began his campaign for the renewal of power sharing with Sinn Fein.
fields.body:
The next week could be "make or break" for the future of Northern Ireland, secretary of state Peter Mandelson said today as Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble began his campaign for the renewal of power sharing with Sinn Fein.

Mr Trimble will recommend the IRA offer on arms to his 860-strong ruling council but has postponed the meeting by a week to give himself more time to persuade sceptical Unionists.

"I think it's make-or-break week for Northern Ireland," Mr Mandelson told the BBC, claiming that the government had no alternative plan if the unionists rejected Mr Trimble's recommendation.

"We don't have a plan B because I think that what is on offer from the IRA is unprecedented, and I don't think it's going to come back again in this form for the foreseeable future.

"That is why the choice that the Ulster Unionists are going to make next Saturday - and I'm not going to tell them how to vote - I would just say this to them the choice you make is going to determine the course of Northern Ireland politics, its political stability, and also its economic prosperity for a generation to come. It is as important as that."

The Northern Ireland secretary said there was a certain "rugged honesty" about the IRA statement and its offer to open up some of its arms dumps to independent inspection. It's a very important first step. Nothing of the sort has ever been offered by the IRA before."

Mr Trimble said he had postponed the Ulster Unionist council meeting because he had been clarifying a number of issues, including the flying of the Union flag and the future of the Royal Ulster Constabulary name, until a few days ago.

"Of course it would be very much easier if the republican movement would say simply, clearly and frankly that the war is over, and they are now disposing of their arms in a proper way," he told the Today programme.

"I am not going to mislead people when there isn't absolute certainty of their intention, but they have made an offer, they have said that they will put their arms beyond use completely and verifiably."

Mr Trimble, who will launch a province-wide campaign to explain his decision to his grassroots members, faces bitter opposition from the anti-Good Friday agreement camp within his party.

Five of his Westminster MPs - Jeffrey Donaldson, William Ross, William Thompson, Roy Beggs and Martin Smyth, have signed a letter of protest against the disarmament/devolution deal.

East Londonderry MP William Ross said the IRA statement did not constitute decommissioning and accused the Ulster Unionist leader of breaking his pledges to the party.

"This is a question of a word solemnly given to the electorate of Northern Ireland and now being deserted," said Mr Ross. "Nothing has changed since February. What we have seen is an awful lot of spin doctoring. There is no question anywhere in the statement but that the IRA intends to hold on to its weapons.

"Unionist party policy was 'no guns, no government' not 'stored guns and in government'."

There were fierce words from Democratic Unionist party leader the Rev Ian Paisley, who today dubbed David Trimble "the chief salesman of the IRA".

The DUP leader refused to release details of his party's alternative to the agreement, saying there was no point as it had already been rejected by the government.

webTitle: Trimble buys time, but at what price?

fields.headline: Trimble buys time, but at what price?
fields.standfirst: As the Ulster Unionist leader urges acceptance of arms inspection measures proposed by the Provisional IRA, Derek Brown asks what the future holds for David Trimble's troubled and divided party
fields.trailText: As the Ulster Unionist leader urges acceptance of arms inspection measures proposed by the Provisional IRA, Derek Brown asks what the future holds for David Trimble's troubled and divided party.
fields.body:
Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble faces a nerve-jangling week as he strives to persuade his truculent and suspicious party back into the Northern Ireland peace process.

The party's ruling council was due to meet tomorrow, but the vital vote has been put back a week. The delay is ominous, for it lays bare the deep divisions in the party and indeed in the province.

According to this morning's Irish Times, the postponement is something of a panic measure, ordered after party managers took soundings from the 860 council members, and discovered, to their horror, that the vote was likely to go against Mr Trimble by more than two to one.

The Unionist leader is urging his party to accept the Provisional IRA offer to start opening its arms dumps to international inspection, as a first step towards permanent disarmament.

Mr Trimble is brave to embrace the IRA formula, which is as flawed as it is audacious. His party cohorts are understandably asking some cogent and awkward questions. How many caches will be revealed? What guarantee is there that the republicans will not reclaim their weapons? How long will the process take?

The fact is that the Unionists have been outflanked, and they know it. If they accept the IRA proposal, they risk splitting their party. If they reject it, they will be branded as anti-peace.

The great danger is that the party will make its acceptance conditional upon further concessions by the British and Irish governments, the ultimate arbiters of the fragile peace. Already, the Unionists are loudly rattling their sabres over reform of the Royal Ulster Constabulary - a crucial part of the wider process.

Mr Mandelson, a consummate deal-maker, is making it plain that he has little more to offer the Unionists. That message has not been lost on Mr Trimble, who has nailed his colours to the mast of power sharing. But the coming week will undoubtedly be marked by frantic horse trading, and the sound and fury of a party which has long been accustomed to dictating events, but which now finds itself backed into a take-it-or-leave-it corner.

fields.headline: The Journals of Sylvia Plath 1950-1962
fields.standfirst:
The Journals of Sylvia Plath 1950-1962
Faber and Faber £21
fields.trailText: Back
fields.body:
Back

12.

There are times when a feeling of expectancy comes to me, as if something is there, beneath the surface of my understanding, waiting for me to grasp it. It is the same tantalizing sensation when you almost remember a name, but don't quite reach it. I can feel it when I think of human beings, of the hints of evolution suggested by the removal of wisdom teeth, the narrowing of the jaw no longer needed to chew such roughage as it was accustomed to; the gradual disappearance of hair from the human body; the adjustment of the human eye to the fine print, the swift, colored motion of the twentieth century. The feeling comes, vague and nebulous, when I consider the prolonged adolesence of our species; the rites of birth, marriage and death; all the primitive, barbaric ceremonies streamlined to modern times. Almost, I think, the unreasoning, bestial purity was best. Oh, something is there, waiting for me. Perhaps someday the revelation will burst in upon me and I will see the other side of this monumental grotesque joke. And then I'll laugh. And then I'll know what life is.

13.

Tonight I wanted to step outside for a few moments before going to bed; it was so snug and stale-aired in the house. I was in my pajamas, my freshly washed hair up on curlers. So I tried to open the front door. The lock snapped as I turned it; I tried the handle. The door wouldn't open. Annoyed, I turned the handle the other way. No response. I twisted the lock; there were only four possible combinations of handle and lock positions, and still the door stuck, white, blank and enigmatic. I glanced up. Through the glass square, high in the door, I saw a block of sky, pierced by the sharp black points of the pines across the street. And there was the moon, almost full, luminous and yellow, behind the trees. I felt suddenly breathless, stifled. I was trapped, with the tantalizing little square of night above me, and the warm, feminine atmosphere of the house enveloping me in its thick, feathery smothering embrace.

14.

This morning I am at low ebb. I did not sleep well last night, waking, tossing, and dreaming sordid, incoherent little dreams. I awoke, my head heavy, feeling as if I had just emerged from a swim in a pool of warm polluted water. My skin was greasy, my hair stiff, oily, and my hands as if I had touched something slimy and unclean. The thick August air does not help. I sit here lumpishly, an ache at the back of my neck. I feel that even if I washed myself all day in cold clear water, I could not rinse the sticky, untidy film away; nor could I rid my mouth of the furry unpleasant taste of unbrushed teeth.

15.

Tonight, for a moment, all was at peace inside. I came out of the house-across-the-street a little before twelve, sick with unfulfilled longing, alone, self-reviling. And there, miraculously was the August night. It had just rained, and the air was thick with warm damp and fog. The moon, full, pregnant with light, showed strangely from behind the small frequent clouds, poised like a picture puzzle that had been broken, with light in back, outlining each piece. There seemed to be no wind, but the leaves of the trees stirred, restless, and the water fell from them in great drops on the pavement, with a sound like that of people walking down the street. There was the peculiar smell of mould, dead leaves, decay, in the air. The two lights over the front steps were haloed with a hazy nimbus of mist, and strange insects fluttered up against the screen, fragile, wing-thin and blinded, dazed, numbed by the brilliance. Lightning, heat lightning flicked off and on, as if some stage hand were toying with the light switch. Two crickets, deep in the cracks in the granite steps, sang a sweet, haunting-thin trill. And because it was my home, I loved them. The air flowed about me like thick molasses, and the shadows from the moon and street lamp split like schizophrenic blue phantoms, grotesque and faintly repetitious.

16.

Upstairs, in the bright, white, sterile cubicle of the bathroom, smelling of warm flesh and toothpaste, I bent over the washbowl in unthinking ritual, washing the proscribed areas, worshipping the glittering chromium, the light that clattered back and forth, brittle, blinding, from the faucets. Hot and cold; cleanliness coming in smooth scented green bars; hairs in thin, penciled lines, curving on the white enamel; the colored prescriptions, the hard, glassed-in jars, the bottles that can cure the symptoms of a cold or send you to sleep within an hour. And then to bed, in the same potentially fertile air, scented of lavendar, lace curtains and the warm feline odor like musk, waiting to assimilate you - everywhere the pallid waiting. And you are the moving epitome of all this. Of you, by you, for you. God, is this all it is, the ricocheting down the corridor of laughter and tears? Of self-worship and self-loathing? Of glory and disgust?

17.

A little thing, like children putting flowers in my hair, can fill up the widening cracks in my self-assurance like soothing lanolin. I was sitting out on the steps today, uneasy with fear and discontent. Peter, (the little boy-across-the-street) with the pointed pale face, the grave blue eyes and the slow fragile smile came bringing his adorable sister Libby of the flaxen braids and the firm, lyrically-formed child-body. They stood shyly for a little, and then Peter picked a white petunia and put it in my hair. Thus began an enchanting game, where I sat very still, while Libby ran to and fro gathering petunias, and Peter stood by my side, arranging the blossoms. I closed my eyes to feel more keenly the lovely delicate-child-hands, gently tucking flower after flower into my curls. "And now a white one," the lisp was soft and tender. Pink, crimson, scarlet, white ... the faint pungent odor of the petunias was hushed and sweet. And all my hurts were smoothed away. Something about the frank, guileless blue eyes, the beautiful young bodies, the brief scent of the dying flowers smote me like the clean quick cut of a knife. And the blood of love welled up in my heart with a slow pain.

18.

Now I'll never see him again, and maybe it's a good thing. He walked out of my life last night for once and for all. I know with sickening certainty that it's the end. There were just those two dates we had, and the time he came over with the boys, and tonight. Yet I liked him too much - way too much, and I ripped him out of my heart so it wouldn't get to hurt me more than it did. Oh, he's magnetic, he's charming; you could fall into his eyes. Let's face it: his sex appeal was unbearably strong. I wanted to know him - the thoughts, the ideas behind the handsome, confident, wise-cracking mask. "I've changed," he told me. "You would have liked me three years ago. Now I'm a wiseguy." We sat together for a few hours on the porch, talking, and staring at nothing. Then the friction increased, centered. His nearness was electric in itself. "Can't you see," he said. "I want to kiss you." So he kissed me, hungrily, his eyes shut, his hand warm, curved burning into my stomach. "I wish I hated you," I said. "Why did you come?" "Why? I wanted your company. Alby and Pete were going to the ball game, and I couldn't see that. Warrie and Jerry were going drinking; couldn't see that either." It was past eleven; I walked to the door with him and stepped outside into the cool August night. "Come here," he said. "I'll whisper something: I like you, but not too much. I don't want to like anybody too much." Then it hit me and I just blurted, "I like people too much or not at all. I've got to go down deep, to fall into people, to really know them." He was definite, "Nobody knows me." So that was it; the end. "Goodbye for good, then," I said. He looked hard at me, a smile twisting his mouth, "You lucky kid; you don't know how lucky you are." I was crying quietly, my face contorted. "Stop it!" The words came like knife thrusts, and then gentleness, "In case I don't see you, have a nice time at Smith." "Have a hell of a nice life," I said. And he walked off down the path with his jaunty, independent stride. And I stood there where he left me, tremulous with love and longing, weeping in the dark. That night it was hard to get to sleep.

19.

Today the doorbell rang; it was little Peter. So I came out and sat on the front steps with him. I could sit by the hour listening to his prattling. He was jealous of Bob, asking in a small tight voice, "Who was that boy over your house? Who does he like best, Warren or you?" And then, "He called me pipsqueak. If you had a baby would you call him pipsqueak?" "I'm not tan," he continued. "It's dirt. I don't like the looks of dirt, but I like the feel of it. Clean doesn't feel good because you're all wet." He played with Warren. I went up to my room, and I heard a commotion outside. Peter had climbed to the level of the window in the little maple tree and was shaking the leaves down. -

20.

From a letter to Ed - "Your letter came just now ... The one about your walk in the city, about war. You don't know quite what it did to me. My mental fear, which can be at times forced into the background, reared up and caught me in the pit of my stomach; it became a physical nausea which wouldn't let me eat breakfast.

Let's face it: I'm scared, scared and frozen. First, I guess, I'm afraid for myself ... the old primitive urge for survival. It's getting so I live every moment with terrible intensity. Last night, driving back from Boston, I lay back in the car and let the colored lights come at me, the music from the radio, the reflection of the guy driving. It all flowed over me with a screaming ache of pain ... remember, remember, this is now, and now, and now. Live it, feel it, cling to it. I want to become acutely aware of all I've taken for granted. When you feel that this may be the good-bye, the last time, it hits you harder.

I've got to have something. I want to stop it all, the whole monumental grotesque joke, before it's too late. But writing poems and letters doesn't seem to do much good. The big men are all deaf; they don't want to hear the little squeaking as they walk across the street in cleated boots. Ed, I guess this all sounds a bit frantic. I guess I am. When you catch your mother, the childhood symbol of security and rightness, crying desolately in the kitchen; when you look at your tall, dreamy-eyed kid brother and think that all his potentialities in the line of science are going to be cut off before he gets a chance ... it kind of gets you.

21.

Here I sit in the deep cushioned armchair, the crickets rasping, buzzing, chirring outside. It's the library, my favorite room, with the floor a medieval mosaic of flat square stones the color of old book-bindings ... rust, copper, tawny orange, pepper-brown, maroon. And there are deep comfortable maroon leather chairs with the leather peeling off, revealing a marbled pattern of ridiculous pink. The books, all that you would fill your rainy days with, line the shelves; friendly, fingered volumes. So I sit here, smiling as I think in my fragmentary way: "Woman is but an engine of ecstasy, a mimic of the earth from the ends of her curled hair to her red-lacquered nails." Then I think, remembering the family of beautiful children that lie asleep upstairs, "Isn't it better to give in to the pleasant cycles of reproduction, the easy, comforting presence of a man around the house?" I remember Liz, her face white, delicate as an ash on the wind; her red lips staining the cigarette; her full breasts under the taut black jersey. She said to me, "But think how happy you can make a man someday." Yes, I'm thinking, and so far it's all right. But then I do a flipover and reach out in my mind to E., seeing a baseball game, maybe, perhaps watching television, or roaring with careless laughter at some dirty joke with the boys, beer cans lying about green and shiny gold, and ash trays. I spiral back to me, sitting here, swimming, drowning, sick with longing. I have too much conscience injected in me to break customs without disasterous effects; I can only lean enviously against the boundary and hate, hate, hate the boys who can dispel sexual hunger freely, without misgiving, and be whole, while I drag out from date to date in soggy desire, always unfulfilled. The whole thing sickens me.

22.

Yes, I was infatuated with you; I am still. No one has ever heightened such a keen capacity of physical sensation in me. I cut you out because I couldn't stand being a passing fancy. Before I give my body, I must give my thoughts, my mind, my dreams. And you weren't having any of those.

23.

There is so much hurt in this game of searching for a mate, of testing, trying. And you realize suddenly that you forgot it was a game, and turn away in tears.

Back

webTitle: Breast cancer drug helps to cut deaths by a third

fields.headline: Breast cancer drug helps to cut deaths by a third
fields.trailText: Deaths from breast cancer in Britain have dropped by nearly a third since the late 1980s, the most rapid and dramatic decline there has ever been in any type of cancer anywhere in the world.
fields.body:
Deaths from breast cancer in Britain have dropped by nearly a third since the late 1980s, the most rapid and dramatic decline there has ever been in any type of cancer anywhere in the world.

Figures for both the UK and the US - which is experiencing a similarly steep decline in the death rate, about a quarter since 1990 - are revealed today in the Lancet by Sir Richard Peto and his colleagues at the Imperial Cancer Research Fund's clinical trials service unit in Oxford.

"We have got the best decrease in breast cancer deaths of any country within the World Health Organisation," said Professor Peto. Better cancer treatments, from screening to radiotherapy and chemotherapy, have all contributed to the picture, he said, but the greatest difference has been made by a British invention - the hormonal drug tamoxifen, which was developed in Britain and widely used here from the 1980s.

The US's hesitance to embrace tamoxifen has meant that their death rates have not dropped as quickly as in Britain. "The States were gung-ho for early screening and radiotherapy and chemotherapy but didn't think tamoxifen was serious. But it is," said Prof Peto.

Mortality from breast cancer had risen by 26% between 1957 and 1987 and the NHS was castigated for lagging behind Europe and the US in cancer survival rates. But between 1990 and 1999, breast cancer deaths dropped from 160,000 to 140,000, he said.

Data collated by the Cancer Research Campaign and the Office for National Statistics between 1986 and 1990 showed that about 67% of women diagnosed with breast cancer in England and Wales were still alive five years later. This compared with more than 70% for Europe as a whole, and more than 80% for the US. But the steep and steady drop in the British death rate means that when the figures are updated, the position of the UK is likely to improve dramatically.

Prof Peto said that the UK also had, along with Finland, the best figures in the world for cutting lung cancer deaths. They have dropped from 80,000 a year in 1965 to 40,000 a year in 1995 thanks to the efforts to persuade people to stop smoking.

fields.headline: Sex and the law
fields.standfirst: The government is looking to reform Britain's sex laws. Ros Taylor explains why
fields.trailText: The government is looking to reform Britain's sex laws. We explain why
fields.body:
Why do British sex laws need reform?
Britain has a number of outdated laws which have remained on the statute books. Some are simply risible and it would be a waste of parliamentary time to abolish them. Others are more serious anomalies which conflict with both more recent legislation and - importantly - the Human Rights Act, which comes into effect next autumn. Still others do not reflect the enormous changes in society during the twentieth century. Consequently, the home secretary, Jack Straw, has set up a sexual offences review group which has just reported its findings to ministers. The report will be published next month.

For example?
Incest is only illegal when it is between blood relatives. An adopted parent or an in-law cannot be prosecuted on grounds of incest for sex with their child.

Male prostitutes are liable to be put in jail for 'importuning' - soliciting for sex or contact - but women can only be arrested for importuning for sex, and will not be jailed for the offence. Similarly, living off immoral earnings is an offence for a man, but not for a woman.

Although prostitution is not illegal, no more than one woman can practise it in the same premises (making brothels illegal) and soliciting in a public place - such as waiting on a pavement for kerb-crawlers - is against the law.

The male flasher in the dirty raincoat is committing an offence, but if a woman were to expose herself in public, she could not be prosecuted for indecent exposure.

What about date rape?
At the moment, the sentencing guidelines for rape are the same whether the victim knows the rapist or not. Only 18% of cases brought by a woman end in a conviction, partly because rape by a stranger is easier to prove; a male acquaintance can usually make a convincing case that he believed the woman gave her consent.

The lord chief justice has ruled out the idea of grading sentences according to the degree of violence involved. Instead, the home secretary wants to widen the evidence of proof that a woman did not consent to sex.

Does this mean the homosexual age of consent will go down to 16, too?
This is where the Human Rights Act comes in - although it is also relevant to the issues of gender equality for sex offences. Plaintiffs can already take the government to the European Court of Human Rights to have their cases judged against the European Convention. From the autumn they will be able to do the same in UK courts when the convention becomes law in this country. Even kissing in the street is currently an offence of gross indecency for male couples - but not for heterosexuals.

Is that why Mr Straw is acting now?
That, and pressure from teachers to clarify the law on Section 28 (which, much to education secretary David Blunkett's anger, many Tory MPs still refuse to reform) as well as from groups such as Stonewall who campaign for gay equality.

Will there be opposition to the planned reforms?
It seems very likely. A number of Tory MPs are likely to oppose any attempt to liberalise teaching about homosexuality or to lower the age of consent, as are 'pro-family' groups. There may well be protests from the emerging men's movement, who may resist attempts to reduce the burden of proof needed to convict a man of rape.

webTitle: New attempt to repeal gay clause angers teachers

fields.headline: New attempt to repeal gay clause angers teachers
fields.standfirst:
Legal duty to follow guidelines denounced by unions

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government yesterday resumed its efforts to repeal the section 28 law, which bans local authorities from promoting homosexuality in schools, but infuriated teaching unions by insisting that they will have a legal duty to follow new guidelines on sex education.
fields.body:
The government yesterday resumed its efforts to repeal the section 28 law, which bans local authorities from promoting homosexuality in schools, but infuriated teaching unions by insisting that they will have a legal duty to follow new guidelines on sex education.

A new amendment to the learning and skills bill, which has been tabled by the Department for Education and Employment, is designed to place responsibility for sex education in schools firmly on teachers, governors and parents, with no powers for local education authorities.

But ministers want schools to be "statutorily" obliged to follow the guidance.

This move was condemned by teaching unions as "unnecessary interference" which would also increase teachers' workloads.

In a further change designed to dampen fears about "gay propaganda" being sent direct to schools, health authorities are being ordered to ensure that any material they produce is in line with the guidance and appropriate to the age, religious and cultural background of the youngsters concerned.

The government's attempts to repeal section 28 of the 1988 Local Government Act have so far been frustrated by the House of Lords, which first voted to keep it and then rejected a compromise clause in the learning and skills bill. The new amendment is likely to be debated in the Commons during the bill's committee stage next week.

The education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, was understood to be furious that the Tories have maintained their opposition to the repealing of section 28, even after he introduced new guidelines which highlight the importance of stable relationships.

Yesterday he said: "Effective sex and relationships education is important in preparing young people for adulthood and in reducing teenage pregnancies.

"However, parents are understandably concerned to ensure that what is taught is appropriate for the age of their child and for use in schools. This amendment gives statutory underpinning to our guidance, which will ensure that governors properly consult parents in developing their school's curriculum".

He claimed that with the new guidance and the amendment, parental rights would be "strengthened and unaffected" by the repeal of section 28, which was originally introduced by the Tories.

But the shadow education secretary, Theresa May, said: "Section 28 goes much further than sex education and this does not replace it."

The forthcoming guidance from the DfEE makes it clear that sex education should be set within the wider frame work for personal social and health development which was issued to schools last year.

The second largest teaching union, the National Union of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, warned that it was unnecessary and would mean that every school's sex education policy required approval by governors and parents.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary, said: "This is something schools do not need and appears to have been done in a forlorn attempt to appease the bishops in the House of Lords.

"We may well add this to the list of duties which our members would be prepared to boycott".

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "Teachers do not need statutory guidance in an area which is totally inappropriate for the government to interfere in.

"If anything, this could make teachers less likely to teach sex education."

webTitle: Go-ahead for reform of sex laws

fields.headline: Go-ahead for reform of sex laws
fields.standfirst: Ministers braced for controversy
fields.trailText: Ministers planning the biggest overhaul of Britain's sex offence laws for a century are set to include new definitions or offences relating to prostitution, pimping, rape, oral sex, incest and indecent exposure.
fields.body:
Ministers planning the biggest overhaul of Britain's sex offence laws for a century are set to include new definitions or offences relating to prostitution, pimping, rape, oral sex, incest and indecent exposure.

The package, sometimes reforming laws dating back to the Napoleonic wars, will also offer fresh equalising measures to protect homosexuals on top of the planned cut in the age of consent to 16 for gays.

Laws labelling acts such as males kissing in public as gross indecency and open to five years imprisonment will be scrapped.

The reforms will also extend protection for children from sexual abuse by figures in positions of authority and trust.

Ministers are bracing themselves for a backlash in an area of huge religious and political controversy following the rows over section 28 and the age of consent votes.

They will say the reforms are required to prevent a breach of the European Convention on Human Rights and stress that the package has been prepared following wide consultation with religious groups, charities, lawyers and specialists.

The measures have been drawn up by civil servants working on the sexual offences review group, a body set up by the home secretary, Jack Straw.

After lengthy consultations, its report has just gone to ministers and will be published next month. The expectation is that legislation will follow.

Mr Straw has told the Commons that the current sex laws are anachronistic and need wholesale review. He has also told gay campaign groups that equalising the age of consent is not a sufficient move to end discrimination against gays.

He has commissioned internal Home Office research suggesting the police and courts are finding it difficult to bring convictions in cases where the victim knows the alleged rapist, so-called date rape.

The reforms will follow the advice of the lord chief justice and reject the idea of rape offences graded according to the degree of coercion or violence used. It will, however, attempt to respond to concern over low conviction rates by widening evidence of proof that the woman's consent was not freely given to include silence, ambiguous behaviour and absence of clearly expressed unwillingness.

The Labour MP for Crosby, Claire Curtis-Thomas, said: "It cannot be right that only 18% of cases brought by women end in a conviction."

She said a constituent had been gang raped by four men, and as a result was having a child.

She failed to win a conviction and one of the men was now able to demand access and custody.

The reforms are also expected to call for action to do more to help young male victims of rape.

Diana Lamplugh, from the Suzy Lamplugh Trust, said: "These are some of the most vulnerable witnesses and the number of cases is massively under-reported."

The current law shows a difference between men and women.

Male importuning is an imprisonable offence whether it is for prostitution or for contact. By contrast, for women it is an offence only for prostitution, and then it is not imprisonable.

The reforms are also likely to include changes to penalties for incest so that incest can be defined as sex between an adopted parent or mother-in-law or father-in-law and the child. At present, incest has to be between blood relations.

Investigation of laws relating to sex offences has thrown up a series of anomalies. Men and women face different charges if they have sex with underage children with consent.

In a further anomaly, foreplay can be classified as indecent assault, leading to 10 years, while unlawful intercourse can produce only a two-year sentence.

On prostitution, it is not an offence to be a prostitute or commit a sexual act for money, but it is a crime to solicit in a public place or for two prostitutes to operate together in the same premises.

It is a crime for a man, but not a woman, to live on the immoral earnings of a woman. A woman can be convicted only of directing or controlling prostitutes.

Finally, only men and not women can be found guilty of indecent exposure.

Welcoming the expected reforms, Eban Harris, the Liberal Democrat MP, said: "These reforms will start to bring our sex laws out of the 19th century, if not yet into the 21st century."

Stonewall, the gay rights pressure group, refused to comment on the package, largely because it has been one of the groups involved in drawing up the proposals.

Children's groups are expecting the reforms to extend the groups to whom special protection must be given including the mentally and physically disabled.

But the Home Office will be concerned that the reforms wil not simply be seen as modernisation of a legal jumble, but as another attempt to extend gay rights, partly under pressure from the European Convention on Human Rights.
