webTitle: Two divisions don't mean half the quality

fields.headline: Two divisions don't mean half the quality
fields.trailText: Keep it to yourself for the moment, but things might be looking up for the County Championship. Usually derided as the root of all England's evils, it enjoyed the sort of competitive week that the new system was designed for. Six of the eight games went into a fourth day, two teams battled through three sessions to secure draws, and there were big innings - including two double-centuries - and big wicket-hauls - including three of six or more in an innings. The sort of stats that you'll find every week in Australia's Pura Milk Cup, maybe, but manna from heaven for the quality-starved county game.
fields.body:
Keep it to yourself for the moment, but things might be looking up for the County Championship. Usually derided as the root of all England's evils, it enjoyed the sort of competitive week that the new system was designed for. Six of the eight games went into a fourth day, two teams battled through three sessions to secure draws, and there were big innings - including two double-centuries - and big wicket-hauls - including three of six or more in an innings. The sort of stats that you'll find every week in Australia's Pura Milk Cup, maybe, but manna from heaven for the quality-starved county game.

In a month of poor weather the most encouraging sign was the number of big team totals. Northants racked up 585 (only two teams did better in last year's competition) at four an over against a Shoaib-less - and thus hopeless - Notts; Warwickshire compiled 548 for 7 at the expense of Sussex; and elsewhere there were scores of 417, 399 (at Headingley), 387, 333 and 300 for 4. Yes, there were low scores: but as Zimbabwe discovered yesterday, this is England in May.

When it was announced that the Championship would split in two, some argued that the wickets would get even worse as counties strove to produce results to survive in the new dog-eat-dog three-up, three-down system. As yet, it hasn't happened.

At least that's what the stats argue. So far this season there have been 21 completed matches in the Championship: 15,413 runs had been scored for the loss of 533 wickets. That's an average of 28.92 runs per wicket. At a similar stage last year, when the ECB barely had enough pitch inspectors to go round, the figures were 15,689 runs, 539 wickets at an average of 29.11. Not much difference. And as the weather gets better, so should the wickets.

The county game exists for two reasons - ostensibly as a form of entertainment in its own right, and, more convincingly given the crowds it attracts, as a breeding-ground for the Test team. And better pitches are desirable on both counts. The matches last longer, which should keep the members quiet, and the players benefit too: bowlers have to work for their wickets, and so are better prepared for the flat pitches they usually encounter in international cricket, while the batsmen can build the big innings that England frequently lack. It's an old argument, but try telling that to the apologists for uncovered wickets.

It's far too early to say the tide has turned - but at least it hasn't turned in the wrong direction. And if the efforts of Gloucestershire (174 for 9 to draw with Glamorgan) and Kent (255 for 8 to keep Surrey at bay) are anything to go by, teams will be scrapping for every point. So far, two divisions haven't meant half the quality.

One final note: David Sales, the meat in Northamptonshire's middle-order sandwich, cracked 276 against Notts last week. It means he has now made eight first-class centuries, four of which have exceeded 200 (and one of those was a triple). He has clearly learnt the art of constructing an innings, and it's an art which might one day serve him well for England. But if he'd been brought up on sticky dogs, it's an art he might never have learnt.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All of today's gossip tied up with cord and bundled into the boot of a Cortina.
fields.trailText: Leeds want to sign both Rio Ferdinand and Sol Campbell this summer, for £13m apiece. The Mirror believes that Chairman Peter Ridsdale has authorised approaches to both West Ham and Tottenham. Hammers manager Harry Redknapp acknowledged Leeds' interest in Ferdinand, but he told the Mirror: "The day we sell him and our other young players is the day this club starts to die."
fields.body:
Leeds want to sign both Rio Ferdinand and Sol Campbell this summer, for £13m apiece. The Mirror believes that Chairman Peter Ridsdale has authorised approaches to both West Ham and Tottenham. Hammers manager Harry Redknapp acknowledged Leeds' interest in Ferdinand, but he told the Mirror: "The day we sell him and our other young players is the day this club starts to die."

Barcelona will approach Arsene Wenger about becoming their manager once, as expected, they dismiss Louis van Gaal this weekend. According to the Daily Mail, Wenger is very high on the list of possible replacements, along with former Barca coach Johann Cruyff.

Paris St Germain have entered the race to sign Newcastle's in-demand full-back Didier Domi, according to the Daily Star. Newcastle signed Domi from PSG only last year, but the French club are rebuilding their side for the Champions League and Domi fits their bill. The Star suggests that PSG will also re-sign Alain Goma, who has had an injury-hit time at St James's Park since signing for £4.25m last summer.

Arsenal are looking to sneak in front of Spurs and sign Wimbledon's out-of-contract keeper Neil Sullivan this summer. Sullivan has already held talks at White Hart Lane about a move, but, according to the Sun, Arsene Wenger hopes to speak to Sullivan himself this weekend.

Robbie Fowler has assured Liverpool fans that he will be staying at the club. "I've got no rift with the manager and the manager has got no rift with me", the England striker is quoted as saying in the Daily Star. "He supported me 110% and I'm not going to have a bust-up with someone who backs me to the hilt. In fact, I'm going to support him."

Fulham are close to signing Metz striker Louis Saha according to Teamtalk. 27-year-old Saha, who impressed during a loan spell at Newcastle last year, has told reporters in France that he wants to join the Cottagers.

Planet Football reports that Napoli have emerged as contenders for Gianfranco Zola's signature this summer.

webTitle: The Polygon Bar and Grill and Tiger Lil's, London SW4

fields.headline: The Polygon Bar and Grill and Tiger Lil's, London SW4
fields.standfirst:
Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15
Quick bites . . . where to eat out in under 15 minutes
Cheat's kitchen : Food on the net
On the menu: mostarda di Cremona
fields.trailText: Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15
fields.body:
Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15

The Polygon Bar and Grill , 4 The Polygon, Clapham, London SW4. Tel: 020-7622 1199

A world of influences come together at this smart south London restaurant, thanks to chef Darryn Pitman: don't be surprised to see springbok alongside rocket and seabass on the menu. Dishes change every four weeks or so, and ingredients are well-sourced. Come early for the £10 two-course deal: very few dishes are barred to the more frugal diner and portions are generous. The atmosphere, too, doesn't falter, even at this early hour (you must order by 7.30), thanks to chatty Claphamites lounging on the orange banquettes. Staff, like the food, seem to have been gathered from around the globe, and greet customers as if they eat here every night. Which some of them probably do.

Quick bites . . . where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Tiger Lil's , 16a Clapham Common Southside, London SW4. Tel: 020-7720 5433

It's as quick as your legs can take you at this DIY wok diner. All you can eat for £13 or so, with the advantage that you select the raw ingredients (rather than limp and elderly pizza), and take them to a chef, who will add chilli, garlic, noodles, herbs and sauces of your choice before fierily cooking them in front of you. It's fast, but the lure of multiple trips to the woks might mean that you miss your 15-minute limit. A word of warning: go at a busy time and you'll find yourself in a queue behind a 20-strong birthday party - this is most definitely a place for groups, not for a quiet nibble. At least the fresh ingredients are restocked frequently, so you won't be left with the scraps.

Creamy green ravioli

2 packs of chilled ravioli (any type)

1 head of broccoli/packet of French beans

1 jar of Sacla creamy basil sauce

3tbsp strained Greek yoghurt

1 Divide broccoli into florets (or top and tail beans and cut in half).

2 Empty the sauce and yoghurt into a non-stick pan. Heat gently.

3 Add ravioli and vegetables to pan of boiling water and cook as instructed for the ravioli.

4 Drain vegetables and ravioli and place in serving dish.

5 Pour the sauce/yoghurt mix over the ravioli and shake gently to coat. CA Chodan, Maidenhead, Berks.

Cheat's kitchen : Food on the net
www.farmaround.co.uk

Just when you thought it couldn't get any easier . . . Not content with delivering fresh organic produce to your door, this firm based in London's New Covent Garden market will wash, peel, slice, baton or shred your vegetables too. Prices start from £15.90 for the no-effort boxes.

Pros: Ultra-fresh veg from small organic producers across the UK and Europe, and an emphasis on traditional fruit and veg from traditional growing regions. Organic pasta, sauces and oils too, for the easy way to a quick meal.

Cons: Too little information online about ordering and delivery, which at the moment is by phone, fax or email only.

Coming soon: Online ordering.

On the menu: mostarda di Cremona

Sounds a bit like mustard. Well it is, but not in the English sense.

No Colman's in sight? Not a driblet. It's made with fruit.

Fruit? Originally quinces or grapes, but now with pears, cherries, figs and apricots, stewed together in a heavy syrup made peppy with mustard.

Ah, hence the name. Who can we thank for this exotic combo? The citizens of Cremona in northern Italy. Home of Antonio Stradivarius.

How would he have eaten his mostarda? As the classic condiment for bollito misto (boiled meats). But it goes well with meats cooked most ways.

If you have any hints for Cheat's kitchen, send them to The Guzzler, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

webTitle: May 19: In brief and latest casting news

fields.headline: May 19: In brief and latest casting news
fields.trailText: Michael Winterbottom forms web design company, Umberto Eco signs deal with Fine Line, new version of The Exorcist for US, Chen Kaige to film in London, and Gerard Depardieu, Frank Skinner and Madonna on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Building on the success of the revolutionary Kingdom Come website (see our review), director Michael Winterbottom has teamed up with Revolution Films to form a film and TV website design company - Resolve Media. Kuhn told Screen magazine: "The Kingdom Come website is eloquent testimony to the attractions of independent film" - the site has attracted over 500,000 hits - "there is so much yet to be done with movie web sites. Today's sites hardly scratch the surface of what's achievable."

 After 12 years of refusing numerous offers from film-makers such as Stanley Kubrick and Milos Forman, Italian author Umberto Eco has finally struck a deal with Fine Line Features for a big screen adaptation of his bestselling novel Foucault's Pendulum. The metaphysical thriller concerns three book editors who decide as a joke to invent a worldwide conspiracy theory. The game turns deadly when they start to disappear one by one. The book has sold 14 million copies worldwide since its publication in 1988, but Eco had resisted all previous approaches, in part due to his disappointment with the movie version of his novel The Name of the Rose.

 Warner has announced that a new version of The Exorcist featuring hitherto unseen material will be given a cinematic release in the US this Halloween. There are no details of whether it will be released in Britain yet.

 Chinese director Chen Kaige will make his English-language film debut with the London-set Killing Me Softly. Based on Nicci French's bestselling novel, the erotic thriller will star Heather Graham.

 Gerard Depardieu's next project is to be another period epic (following Vatel). The French actor has signed for Vidocq - Fighting a Myth, a $25m high-tech gothic thriller.

 British actor-comedian Frank Skinner has signed to star in Crust, a comedy to be written and directed by newcomer Mark Locke.

 Madonna is to join the cast of Peter Greenaway's The Pulse Luper Trilogy, playing 'the femme fatale'. The $10m film has also attracted the likes of Isabella Rossellini, Amanda Plummer, Dawn French and Kathy Bates.

 The official Hannibal site is now online www.mgm.com/hannibal.

fields.headline: Shane Warne's little earners
fields.standfirst: wisden.com's new column reveals this week how Shane Warne will be making a packet, why David Lloyd fell foul of MCC pettiness when he was England coach, and  where the Zimbabweans are staying (it's five-star)
fields.trailText: Shane cleans up
fields.body:
Shane cleans up

Shane Warne may not yet be filling his boots in county cricket, but he's certainly filling his pockets. The Australian superstar now looks set to earn a total of some £700,000 from his summer with Hampshire, making him easily the highest-paid cricketer in England this season.

Warne has already secured sponsorship deals, media contracts, a book deal and other commercial work which will dwarf his Hampshire salary, reportedly in the £150-£165,000 bracket, and further offers are still rolling in to the London offices of his UK manager, Michael Cohen, who says: "We've been deluged with interest."

Warne has just agreed to make a TV commercial for The Times, for which he's writing an exclusive weekly column. A TV ad for "The Thunderer" should hold no fears for Warne, who regularly pops up between overs on Australia's Channel Nine advertising OneTel, the telecommunications company.

Cohen will not discuss figures, but says his client will earn a "considerable sum" from his many UK activities. He describes the Times column as "very lucrative", which means probably not far off six figures. Cohen has also negotiated a very big deal for Warne's autobiography, to appear in August 2001, published by Hodder & Stoughton. Warne starts work on the book this summer.

Then there's the arrangement with a BMW dealership in Southampton, for which Warne is doing promotional work. As part of the deal, he and his wife Simone have each been supplied with BMWs. A Ferrari owner back home, Shane is now making do with a £46,000 BMW 535i.

There are some other handy earners: Warne is to appear on both of BBC1's sports quiz shows, A Question of Sport and They Think It's All Over. His recent appearance on John Inverdale's BBC chat show On Side will have yielded a decent cheque, too.

Cohen - whose company MPC Entertainment also looks after Bob Woolmer and Jeremy Beadle - is at pains to stress that he has not said yes to everything. "We've turned down many lucrative contracts because of Shane's cricket," Cohen says. "He's here to play the game. Nothing can interfere with that: money is irrelevant." He says there have been 20 requests from TV shows, 16 of which have met with a firm no.

Would-be paymasters are evidently not deterred by Warne's poor start to the season: two pairs in his first two championship matches made him a surprise pace-setter in wisden.com's Battle of the Bunnies.

Lloyd says MCC questioned England World Cup practice session

THE launch of David Lloyd's autobiography at Harrods in London on Tuesday was thinly attended, for reasons that had nothing to do with Lloyd. Most cricket writers were in Somerset for the funeral of Chris Lander, the popular cricket correspondent of The Mirror, who has died aged 59 after a brief battle with cancer.

Lander, who had a great sense of humour, would have savoured two of Lloyd's examples of the pettiness of some officials. In Anything But Murder (CollinsWillow, £16.99, published May 16), Lloyd recalls receiving an "insensitive" letter from the ECB as he was leaving the England coaching job. It asked him to return his mobile phone, and his ECB Barclaycard, "cut into two pieces", and to "make immediate (underlined) arrangements to return the ECB car to Lord's." This was before the World Cup had even reached the semi-final stage. Lloyd felt he was being chased, "as if they felt sure I would scarper with the family silver."

A month earlier, on the morning of the World Cup opener against Sri Lanka at Lord's, Lloyd suffered "a classic example of MCC small-mindedness". As he conducted an England fielding practice on the outfield, an MCC steward bore down on the group, calling: "Who is in charge here?" Lloyd replied: "I am". The steward shot back: "Have you had permission to be on here throwing balls at stumps?".

The practice session continued, but as Lloyd puts it: "None of us could quite believe this. Here we were, the eyes of the nation upon us as we started the quest to win a World Cup at our own headquarters....and some chap in a blazer was asking if we had permission to be on the field. Somehow, it made everyone laugh, easing the tension, and the rest of the day proceeded entirely to plan." England cruised to victory by eight wickets.

Zimbabwe's home from home

Where are England and Zimbabwe staying for the Lord's Test? Unlike some boards, the ECB likes to separate Test combatants. So England are, as usual, at the four-star Marriott Hotel in Swiss Cottage, a few minutes' drive from the ground. As is also customary, each player has a room to himself.

The players almost had to cope with running into someone several of them wouldn't wish to see straight after the criticisms of them in his book: D Lloyd. Bumble was booked into the Marriott by his publishers, who had no idea England would be there. Aware of the potential for embarrassment, Lloyd switched to another hotel.

Meanwhile Zimbabwe are further afield - back in the five-star Royal Garden Hotel, High Street Ken, where they stayed for their World Cup matches at Lord's and The Oval. The Royal Garden was designated the "official headquarters" hotel for all visiting World Cup squads, even though it had never previously played host to international cricket teams.

This time, Zimbabwe officials made clear that they would look no further for their team's visits to the capital. Barry Dudleston, the first-class umpire and tour operator who's handling the tourists' arrangements, says: "The players enjoy being fairly central. They can nip outside and grab a tube, or walk to a pub - don't forget that hotel bars are quite expensive." Getting out and about to unwind is also more important when players share rooms, as do Zimbabwe's (the captain, Andy Flower, is an exception). The bulk of the bill, incidentally, is picked up by the ECB.

This week, the Royal Garden has none of the buzz which surrounded the World Cup, when "Carnival of Cricket" flags flew outside and recognisable faces thronged the lobby. On one memorable night, 36 hours before the Final, some South African players, heartbroken after their semi-final defeat by Australia, were urging any Pakistan player they came across in the lobby to hammer the Aussies for them. Meanwhile Shoaib Akhtar was struggling to fend off teenage admirers. So persistent was one group of girls that for ten minutes his car couldn't pull away for a - rather late - evening out.

Such excitement seems unlikely to return - even when England join Zimbabwe at the hotel for their one-dayer at The Oval on July 8.

Stewart's title setback

Events have not been kind to Alec Stewart's account of his England leadership, A Captain's Diary, published on the eve of last year's World Cup. The book now reappears in paperback form with a new title, a new ghostwriter and a new cover.

It has had to be been renamed Alec Stewart's England Diary (CollinsWillow, £6.99, May 15) after Stewart lost the captaincy when his original book had only been on the shelves for a few weeks. Gone too is the cover picture of the then captain, in England blazer, standing proudly in front of an emblem of the three lions, replaced by a shot of him keeping in a one-dayer.

In an unusual arrangement, the original work had been put together by Brian Murgatroyd, then the ECB's media relations officer. But last September Murgatroyd defected to the Australian Cricket Board. Enter the BBC's Patrick Murphy, a veteran author, who helped Stewart produce two new chapters, covering the World Cup, his firing, and the Tests since. All concerned will be hoping for better luck this time - hardback sales of 7,500 copies were a disappointment.

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). He is also a former deputy editor of The Daily Telegraph's Peterborough column. He can be contacted at cdelisle@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Cruise turns stuntman
fields.trailText: Look closely at the stunts during this summer's blockbuster Mission: Impossible 2. Action hero Tom Cruise really is just that, it seems
fields.body:
Look closely at the stunts during this summer's blockbuster Mission: Impossible 2. Action hero Tom Cruise really is just that, it seems. Cruise insisted on performing dangerous stunts himself, including an opening sequence in which he scales a cliff with his bare hands and hangs from a rock ledge by his fingertips.

Director John Woo told Entertainment Weekly: "I was really mad that he wanted to do it, but I tried to stop him and I couldn't. I was so scared I was sweating. I couldn't even watch the monitor when we shot it."

But co-star John Polson remarked: "the opening sequence just wouldn't have been the same if he hadn't done it himself... You can tell that it's really just him."

fields.headline: Clooney and DeVito together again
fields.trailText: George Clooney and Danny DeVito, last seen together in Steven Soderbergh's Out of Sight (which DeVito also produced), are to team up again. Clooney is in talks to star in Revelation, which DeVito will direct for Warner Bros
fields.body:
George Clooney and Danny DeVito, last seen together in Steven Soderbergh's Out of Sight (which DeVito also produced), are to team up again. Clooney is in talks to star in Revelation, which DeVito will direct for Warner Bros.

This will be DeVito first directing job in over four years; his last effort was the 1996 children's film Matilda. Clooney would play an Internal Affairs cop who is shot during an assassination attempt on a cardinal, and whose search for the assassin parallels his own religious journey.

Clooney will next be seen in The Perfect Storm opposite Mark Walhberg, and as an ex-con in the Coen Brother's O Brother Where Art Thou?, which premiered to critical acclaim last week at Cannes. He is also attached to play Danny Ocean in Soderbergh's remake of the Rat Pack ensemble comedy Ocean's Eleven.

fields.headline: Ritchie arrested over assault
fields.trailText: Police revealed today that Guy Ritchie, Madonna's other half, and director of the forthcoming Snatch, was arrested on suspicion of assaulting a man outside the pregnant star's London home
fields.body:
Police revealed today that Guy Ritchie, Madonna's other half, and director of the forthcoming Snatch, was arrested on suspicion of assaulting a man outside the pregnant star's London home.

The director was released on bail to return to the police station on June 1 pending further inquiries.

Police said the victim was a 20-year-old man, whose injuries were minor and did not require hospital treatment. Media reports said the man was believed to have been a fan waiting outside the couple's home in an attempt to get a glimpse of Madonna.

Earlier this month, British tabloids reported that Madonna's love life and domestic affairs were in turmoil, and that the singer flew into London for crisis talks about her future with Ritchie, director of the British gangster film Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, after he refused to move to Los Angeles.

webTitle: Crowe joins the multi-million dollar men

fields.headline: Crowe joins the multi-million dollar men
fields.trailText: This year's hottest property, Russell Crowe, may soon be priced out of the league of many of the smaller studios with whom he made his name
fields.body:
This year's hottest property, Russell Crowe, may soon be priced out of the league of many of the smaller studios with whom he made his name. As Gladiator approaches the $100m gross mark, its star is being courted for several plum projects, and could well be getting $15m for his next film. Crowe's agent should have little difficulty securing such a deal for his client, despite it being more than double what Crowe got for Proof of Life, which he's currently filming.

Among the projects for which Crowe has been approached are Ron Howard's A Beautiful Mind, Jon Amiel's North of Cheyenne, and the Warner Bros mobster movie 33 Liberty Street.

A Beautiful Mind is based on a book by Sylvia Nassar and tells the true story of John Forbes Nash Jr., a mathematical genius with matinee-idol looks who suffered from schizophrenia but miraculously recovered and later received a Nobel Prize. Apparently Tom Cruise had also expressed interest in the role.

webTitle: News: Off-screen violence casts gloom over glitz

fields.headline: News: Off-screen violence casts gloom over glitz
fields.trailText: Backstreet muggings, glassings and indecent assaults have darkened an atmosphere already soured by an epidemic of thefts from hotel rooms. Even the beautiful Croisette along the beach, where the main parties are held, has not been immune
fields.body:
It is Cannes' glitziest party, and last night a host of stars and supermodels paid $100,000 a table to be at Dame Elizabeth Taylor's charity ball. But beyond the cordon thrown around the celebrities a frightening wave of violence has robbed the festival of much of its glamour.

Backstreet muggings, glassings and indecent assaults have darkened an atmosphere already soured by an epidemic of thefts from hotel rooms. Even the beautiful Croisette along the beach, where the main parties are held, has not been immune - 10 people were hurt when riot police broke up a brawl with gatecrashers trying to get into the bash the pop group All Saints threw for their film Honest.

There were nasty scenes too outside the Palais du Cinema, where the main competition films are screened, as angry ticket-holders, told the cinema was full, tried to scale the barriers to see the Lars Von Trier film Dancer in the Dark.

Even tempers among the critics are frayed, with punches thrown and shirts ripped in the melee to get into Ang Lee's new film, ironically a martial arts flick.

But there is nothing comic about what has been happening on the streets. Nikki Parker, head of publicity for Denmead Marketing, was grabbed in her hotel room by an intruder wearing a stocking over his face. "I swear it has got out of hand this year," she said. "I do not feel safe anymore. Something has to be done."

British journalist Charlotte Edwards was wrestled to the ground in the lobby of her hotel while a porter stood by, and film buyer Jess Ticks was dragged along a main shopping street in daylight by a thief who ripped her bag from her back. So many Americans have been done over that their embassy has set up a temporary consulate in the festival's American pavilion. "It is just one tale of woe after another," the consul said.

Cannes veteran Tivi Magnusson had a bottle smashed over his head as he chatted outside the Petit Majestic, one of the festival's more convivial watering holes. "I have been coming here for 29 years but I never thought anything like this would happen to me." The same night another festival-goer was headbutted by a biker nearby.

Local police blame an influx of gangs of muggers from Marseille for most of the trouble, and say extra officers and members of the French CRS riot police are being drafted in.

Security was noticeably tight yesterday near Palm Beach hotel in preparation for Elizabeth Taylor's Cinema Against Aids party, organised with Elton John. Gregory Peck, Prince Albert of Monaco, Jeremy Irons, Catherine Deneuve, and directors John Waters and Jonathan Demme were all expected to attend. Elizabeth Hurley and Kenneth Branagh headed the British contingent.

Many blame the increase in street crime this year on Cannes mayor Maurice Delauney's ban on beach parties going on longer than 12.30am. With thousands of thirsty people milling around after midnight looking for parties to take them into the wee small hours, revellers are more vulnerable.

fields.headline: Arms and the money
fields.standfirst: The prime minister's interventionism needs to be backed up by an increase in defence spending
fields.trailText: The prime minister's interventionism needs to be backed up by an increase in defence spending
fields.body:
This week has highlighted the most serious challenge facing the Blair government, which isn't health, education, or the euro, but defence. The government announced a £1bn contract to buy missiles from a European consortium, just as we watched ("proud - and concerned", as the New York Times puts it) our troops trying to sort out the intractable problems of Sierra Leone.

Although Robin Cook and Geoff Hoon clearly understand the concern, that getting into Freetown is easier than getting out, they don't mention the deeper problem, which is how it is all to be paid for. In no other field is there such a frightening dissonance between ends and means, between the government's theory and practice, between interventionist rhetoric and cheese-paring reality.

Every new mission shows up the fact that the armed forces now operate on a shoestring. A leaked report from the Commons public accounts committee has revealed that in the Kosovo campaign last spring the RAF's stocks of laser-guided bombs ran critically low, tents were almost useless, and morphine supplies were near their use-by date.

Our armed forces were being run down well before the end of the cold war and the supposed peace dividend. You can see this on an everyday basis. Reviewing books on the Korean war recently, I couldn't help noticing that most of the famous regiments which fought there no more than 50 years ago - Glosters, Northumberland Fusiliers, 8th Royal Irish Hussars, King's Own Scottish Borderers - no longer exist. This country has fewer men under arms today than it did in the 1780s.

All those reductions have been made to save money. Defence spending has been on a falling curve. In 1951, the proportion of government spending which went on defence was 24%. In 1961 it was 18%; in 1997 less than 7%. Given the choice of guns or butter, we have chosen butter, or at any rate the NHS and invalidity benefit.

"And a good thing too", the old anti-militarists of the left will say. But the one person who cannot say that is Tony Blair. He wants guns as well as butter - and he has forgotten that what undid the Attlee government was the attempt to build a lavish welfare state while also maintaining huge imperial and military commitments, when the country could barely afford either, let alone both.

There is an honourable case for absolute pacifism, even if most of us can't bring ourselves to accept it, and there is an excellent case for doing as Costa Rica did more than 50 years ago when it abolished its armed forces. "Defence" is an Orwellian word at the best of times, and in much of the world "defence forces" are used either for aggressive wars abroad or for oppressing the populace at home.

Maybe the best case of all is for the "pacificism" advocated by the 19th-century radicals: keep armed forces, but for defence in the strict sense. This country might have been a garden, John Bright claimed in one rhetorical flourish, if it had "adopted the principle of non-intervention in every case where her interests were not directly and obviously assailed".

That is not at all the position of our bellicose prime minister. Neither pacifist nor pacificist, he is so far from a non-interventionist that he could have borrowed Michael Heseltine's industrial boast: Blair wants to intervene militarily before breakfast, lunch and dinner. He supports Nato and its bizarre eastward expansion, and the American plans for "Star Wars Two", a new and unimaginably expensive missile defence system.

On top of that he favours a European defence initiative, he takes us into a "progressive war" in the Balkans, and he claims to follow an ethical foreign policy, which means intervening from Kosovo to Sierra Leone where our interests are not directly and obviously assailed. The one thing he still doesn't say is who is going to pay for all this.

We know who pays for our defence at the moment. None of the European members of Nato spends more than 2.8% of GDP (the French figure) on defence, except for Greece and Turkey. Of the other large European countries, Great Britain spends 2.6%, Italy 2%, Germany a mere 1.5%.

And the United States spends 3.2% of GDP on defence. The Americans have, for half a century, been indirectly subsidising the European welfare state by picking up the bill for our defence. Is it any wonder that there is a new mood of isolationism in America, voiced by such men as Patrick Buchanan?

It is not as though Europe today is a poor dependant of rich Uncle Sam, as in the postwar days of Marshall aid. Buchanan may be a bigot and a demagogue, but when he asks why 270m Americans, with a domestic product of $7,800bn, should be expected to defend 375m citizens of the European Union, with a combined economic product of $8,600bn, it is hard to think of a good answer.

A year ago, Tony Blair presented himself as the new Churchill, preaching defiance against Milosevic with the words: "No compromises, no fudge, no half-baked ideals." If he was serious about that, and all his other military ambitions, then it follows defence spending must increase very steeply. No compromises or fudge: when will this be done, and how?

 comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: France and Germany keen to rev the euro-engine

fields.headline: France and Germany keen to rev the euro-engine
fields.standfirst: Informal summit aims to put strained partnership back on track
fields.trailText: Informal summit aims to put strained partnership back on track
fields.byline: Jon Henley  in Paris and John Hooper  in Berlin
fields.body:
It may not have stalled completely, but the Franco-German motor is faltering, and when Jacques Chirac, Gerhard Schröder and assorted senior ministers meet for talks at the elegant chateau of Rambouillet this evening it will be with sleeves rolled up.

Six weeks before France assumes the EU presidency, Paris and Berlin are eager to use what is billed as a "seminar" - but is actually an informal summit - to reinvigorate the relationship which was for so long the powerhouse of European postwar integration and development.

Relations have been strained since Mr Schröder's election in late 1998, and particularly since he made plain his support for Tony Blair's "third way" policies, an affront to the more orthodox socialism espoused by the French prime minister, Lionel Jospin.

But while neither Mr Jospin nor Mr Schröder is naturally inclined to be passionate about Europe, nor indeed naturally inclined to like the other very much, analysts say both now recognise the need - partly for domestic political reasons - to bury their differences and forget a string of minor spats.

"There's no doubt the French were worried by Schröder," a diplomat in Paris said.

"They basically sulked after the business of the Blair-Schröder pact. But now there's an understanding that in the public eye Europe is getting bogged down, that it lacks a long-term vision - and that France and Germany must be at the heart of that."

The first signs that France and Germany may be about to push the engine up to full speed came in a speech last week in which the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, set out his "personal vision" of a federal Europe in which the existing nation states, rather than the regions, would be the basic units.

If that was enough to distress Eurosceptics, he also alarmed British Europeans by arguing the need for an inner core of countries to press on towards unification once the union was enlarged, and by saying that no European project would succeed without "the closest Franco-German cooperation".

Political observers in Berlin believe that part of Mr Fischer's aim was to raise his personal standing in Germany when his party, the Greens, is floundering. If so it paid off: even Bild Zeitung, the influential conservative tabloid, lauded him.

Another factor is the perceived need to "put the frighteners" on London every so often by raising the threat of exclusion.

Much as it may upset the Eurosceptics, London's line on that is that Europe can only benefit from a close and fruitful Franco-German relationship, as long as it does not become exclusive.

Britain too recognises the need for more political impulsion behind the European project, and has no objection to different groups of countries working more closely together on different projects. What it does not want is a select inner circle of states which would automatically exclude any single partner from everything.

But there is no question but that Mr Fischer has found a receptive audience for his ideas among those in Germany and France who are concerned about the evident lack of dynamism in relations between their countries.

"When France and Germany do not cooperate well on particular issues, as has been the case for the past 18 months or so, the whole European agenda suffers," a French government official said.

"That's why we now must make a genuine effort to find areas of agreement."

One development in particular has pushed the issue up the political agenda: the weakness of the euro, which many commentators blame on an apparent lack of political will in the key partners in the single currency project.

Mr Jospin's popularity has been sliding in recent months, and Paris observers say he is deeply concerned by the negative impact on domestic opinion - and on his image - of the euro's dramatic decline.

fields.headline: The law 'n' order auction
fields.standfirst: Hardline tactics have a record of failure
fields.trailText: William Hague is right on one point. There was indeed a hidden consensus on crime between the two major parties. Away from their persistent jousting for the most macho position on law 'n' order, both recognised the need to make our regressive criminal justice system more effective.
fields.body:
William Hague is right on one point. There was indeed a hidden consensus on crime between the two major parties. Away from their persistent jousting for the most macho position on law 'n' order, both recognised the need to make our regressive criminal justice system more effective. The key to achieving the most important goal, reducing crime, could not be prison, when only two out of every 100 offences ever ends with a conviction. The key was better crime prevention programmes (more secure homes, businesses, cars), earlier intervention, and better supervision, together with extensive literacy and numeracy projects to give the illiterate and innumerate options other than crime.

It was not Labour but a hardline Tory home secretary, David Waddington, who wrote a white paper concluding that prison was "an expensive way of making bad people worse". Of course prison was still needed, but a succession of Tory home secretaries - Whitelaw, Brittan, Hurd, Clarke, Waddington - reluctantly recognised the unequivocal message of criminal research: in terms of crime reduction, reinforcing homes and business premises achieved 36 times as big a fall as prisons for every £1 spent. Prisons prevent the incarcerated from committing further crimes - at a cost of £25,000 per inmate per year - but it takes a 25% increase in prison numbers to achieve a 1% reduction in crime.

There was a consensus on the course, but not enough commitment to push the system down the planned road. Then, with the Tories in dire political trouble, along came Michael Howard. Breaking with his five predecessors, Howard opted for the populist "prison works" approach. A country which already had the highest numbers in prison in Europe increased the total by a further 50% in five years. Mr Howard then passed his infamous mandatory minimum sentences for burglary, drugs, sex and violent offences - sentences which, for fear of being labelled "soft", Jack Straw then implemented. By their inflexible nature, they guarantee increased injustice with little deterrence effect. So now we have a hard-right consensus which pays no attention to research, history or justice. Yet this is a system which William Hague still tries to label "liberal".

Now both Mr Hague and, to his shame, Mr Straw want to reintroduce preventive detention. Mr Hague has a ludicrous list of "scourges" he wants put away. Mr Straw is targeting low-level persistent offenders. Both would switch the focus from the crime to the offender. Both would be be ready to punish offenders for things done in the past for which they have already been punished - or for what they might do in the future - rather than for the crime before the court. Both demonstrate an abysmal ignorance of history. This approach has already been tried in 1869 (Habitual Criminals Act), 1908 (Prevention of Crime Act), and 1948 (Criminal Justice Act) all of which led to such grave injustices - years in prison for minor offences - that the courts revolted and repeal followed.

The best put-down to Mr Hague came from Douglas Hurd, who told him to stop playing macho games. Mr Straw faces a different challenge. He knows his researchers are right but refuses to educate the public. Instead of trumpeting his serious moves - help for 2m householders to make their homes more secure, earlier intervention under a reformed juvenile justice system, better targeting of police resources - he opts for a habitual offenders act to pre-empt William Hague. This is pathetic politics. It insults the public's intelligence.

fields.headline: Spilling the MI5 beans
fields.standfirst:
Dame Stella has plenty to tell us

Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: The Stella Rimington story has precedents. Senior Whitehall types have not always gone silent to the grave. Some contented themselves with guides to writing style and neutral descriptions of how the machine works. Others were determined to lift the curtain's edge and show off some of the secret world they had inhabited. The classic case is Maurice Hankey, creator of the cabinet office and architect of the official secrets regime in whose decadence we are now living.
fields.body:
The Stella Rimington story has precedents. Senior Whitehall types have not always gone silent to the grave. Some contented themselves with guides to writing style and neutral descriptions of how the machine works. Others were determined to lift the curtain's edge and show off some of the secret world they had inhabited. The classic case is Maurice Hankey, creator of the cabinet office and architect of the official secrets regime in whose decadence we are now living. Hankey fought for years for official approval for his memoirs - not because he had turned into a whistleblower but because, and why not, he felt pride in, even part ownership of, the great events he had witnessed.

It would be stretching the truth to say that during her tenure as director general of the Security Service Stella Rimington walked with history - though Arthur Scargill may have considered himself its personification. But she may feel a sense of achievement as one of Whitehall's top women, even fancy herself a dab hand with a pen after a lifetime of memo writing. That is for the literary editors to judge. Head prefect Sir Richard Wilson should speed her access to print. He is in the midst of a grand exercise in "modernising" the machinery of state, opening its upper reaches to new blood, especially women and ethnic minorities. The intelligence agencies must be no less subject to the tests of efficiency and effectiveness - or representativeness - being applied elsewhere in Whitehall. A Rimington memoir could help.

The public might benefit, too. Even if it reads like a piece of Emmenthal, any book by her is bound to provoke yet more questions about the cost and purpose of these hidden intelligence empires. Perhaps in her retirement Dame Stella has hit upon a truth recognised by police officers high and low. Preventive work - the main function of any security service - succeeds in proportion to the public's trust in those who carry it out.

fields.headline: Paul Bartel
fields.standfirst: Film director whose black humour lampooned America's dark side
fields.trailText: Paul Bartel, who has died aged 61 after undergoing surgery for cancer of the liver, said early on in his career, "I'm very interested in doing eccentric, individual low-budget films" - and he hardly ever swerved from that intention.
fields.body:
Paul Bartel, who has died aged 61 after undergoing surgery for cancer of the liver, said early on in his career, "I'm very interested in doing eccentric, individual low-budget films" - and he hardly ever swerved from that intention.

It was Death Race 2000 (1975), a typical Roger Corman production, that gave Bartel the chance to make his name. A campy, sci-fi comedy, which, like the best comic-books, caricatured the horrors of contemporary society, the film involved a trans-American car race in which every pedestrian is fair game, the winner being determined by the quickest time and highest body count. It starred the then-unknown Sylvester Stallone, as "Machine Gun" Viterbo. Although much of it was Corman's conception, many of the quirky nasty bits came from Bartel.

It was a terrific hit with the Saturday night crowd, and, as a result, Corman gave him another car-crash movie, Cannonball, the following year, in which the participants in a cross-country race include a mad German, comic feminists and crooked country-and-western singers. The comedy was broader, but no less black, than in the first film; among the in-jokes were appearances by Corman, as a district attorney who wants to ban the race, Martin Scorsese and Bartel himself, bald, bearded and portly.

Bartel came to the movies after taking a four-year course in film and theatre at the University of California, Los Angeles. He spent a year on a Fulbright scholarship at the Centro Sperimentale film school in Rome, before returning to the US to make television commercials, and a couple of comic-erotic shorts, The Secret Cinema (1966), about a New York secretary for whom everybody's paranoid fantasy becomes a reality, and the self-explanatory Naughty Nurse (1970).

This led to his first feature, a bad-taste sexual comedy called Private Parts (1972), which told of a runaway teenage girl taking refuge in a seedy San Francisco hotel inhabited by perverts.

While serving on the jury of the 1979 Berlin film festival, Bartel wrote the initial script for Eating Raoul. Filming began in November 1980, a weekend at a time, and was finished more than a year later. As Bartel explained: "I wanted to make a film about two, greedy uptight people who are not so unlike you and me and Nancy and Ronnie [Reagan], and to keep it funny and yet communicate something about the perversity of these values."

In the film, Bartel and Mary Woronov (from Andy Warhol's Factory) play Paul and Mary Bland, who dream of buying a house and a restaurant in the country. But the only way they can finance their dream is by murdering every swinger and sleazeball in Hollywood, who, according to Paul, are "horrible, sex-crazed perverts that nobody will miss anyway."

Bartel and Woronov, who had previously appeared together in Rock 'n' Roll High School (1979), play the couple in a wonderfully deadpan manner. Black comedy is a difficult art to carry off, but he strikes the right comic chord from the start, and there is not a drop of blood visible.

After this satire, he turned out a surprisingly feeble comedy, Not For Publication, and a relentlessly camp B-western spoof, Lust In The Dust (both 1984). The latter starred Divine, the drag queen of trash, as dancehall "girl" Rosie Velez, who is rescued by gunman Tab Hunter, the former Hollywood pin-up boy and pop singer.

Bartel then returned to the sadistic world of Eating Raoul with Scenes From The Class Struggle In Beverly Hills (1989), in which he played Dr Mo Van de Camp. But, whereas the former film had a unity of tone, the latter was a strained soap opera lampoon, frenziedly trying to shock. The movie ends with the Cole Porter song Let's Be Outrageous (Let's Misbehave), something Bartel did both well and badly over the years.

The final film he directed was Shelf Life (1995), in which three grown-up children act out scenes from television. He also appeared regularly in friends' movies. In Joe Dante's Hollywood Boulevard (1975), Bartel steals the show as a pretentious exploitation director, anxious to "spice up the crucifixion scene".

In Desire And Hell At Sunset Motel (1992), he played the sinister manager, and he had small parts in The Usual Suspects (1995), Basquiat (1996) and in the gay romance Billy's Hollywood Screen Kiss (1998). His valedictory screen appearance was as Osric in an ill-conceived Hamlet (2000), starring Ethan Hawke.

Bartel, who was openly gay, is survived by his father and two sisters.

 Paul Bartel, film actor and director, August 6 1938; died May 13 2000

webTitle: The best blond scene:  The virgin suicides

fields.headline: The best blond scene:  The virgin suicides
fields.trailText: Grosse Pointe, Michigan. Five teenage boys stand by the side of an anonymous suburban road, staring at an anonymous suburban house. One of their number, Tim (Jonathan Tucker) speaks in voiceover.
fields.body:
Grosse Pointe, Michigan. Five teenage boys stand by the side of an anonymous suburban road, staring at an anonymous suburban house. One of their number, Tim (Jonathan Tucker) speaks in voiceover.

"Everyone thinks the demise of our neighbourhood was due to the suicides of the Lisbon girls. People saw their clairvoyance in the wiped-out elms, the harsh sunlight, in the continuing decline of our auto industry.

"Even then, as teenagers, we tried to put the pieces together. We still can't. Now, whenever we run into each other at business lunches or cocktail parties, we find ourselves in the corner going over the evidence one more time. Trying to understand those five girls, who, after all these years, we can't get out of our minds."

Suddenly, a gaggle of virtually identical blonde teenage girls stroll out of the house into the sunshine. Tim narrates as the first girl approaches camera.

"Cecilia, the youngest, was 13."

Then the next.

"And Lux was 14."

Then another.

"Bonnie was 15."

Then another.

"Mary was 16."

Then, finally, the last.

"And Therese was 17."

Cut to a dowdy, middle-aged couple (James Woods and Kathleen Turner) hovering behind the girls.

"No one could understand how Mrs Lisbon and Mr Lisbon, our maths teacher, had produced such beautiful creatures."

See also: The Real Blonde, Blonde Crazy, Follow That Blonde

Don't see also: Blonde Fist

Pointless trivia: Sofia Coppola and her brother Roman co-directed the video for Air's Playground Love, used prominently throughout The Virgin Suicides.

fields.headline: Across the borderline
fields.standfirst: Duncan Campbell welcomes a spate of new films and TV dramas that at last bring the Latino experience of the US to the screen
fields.trailText: Duncan Campbell welcomes a spate of new films and TV dramas that at last bring the Latino experience of the US to the screen
fields.body:
The traditional cry of the jornaleros, the Latino day labourers who stand patiently on street corners in big American cities hoping for casual work, is "Yo, yo, llevame a mi !" (Choose me!) If they are lucky, they will get a few hours' work on a construction site or in a suburban garden and some dollar bills in their hand at the end of the day. But now they and their compatriots and fellow immigrants who do the dirty cleaning jobs of corporate America have been chosen in a rather different way - as film heroes and heroines.

La Ciudad, which opens next week, looks at the lives of illegal Latino immigrants in the "broken promise land" of New York. And Cannes has had an early chance to see Ken Loach's feature film, Bread and Roses, set among the office cleaners of Los Angeles. The films arrive in the week CBS decides whether or not to sign up what would be a prime-time network series called American Family about a Latino family in LA. It is made by Gregory Nava, the director whose 1983 film, El Norte, first charted the waters of the Central American immigrant crossing the border from a Latino perspective. Now those involved in the Latino film business are waiting to see whether a rather more amorphous border can be crossed.

La Ciudad (The City), is directed by David Riker who, like Spike Lee and Martin Scorsese, is a graduate of the New York University film school. Shot by cinematographer Harlan Bosmajian, it follows the borderline lives of a group of immigrants, day labourers and sweatshop workers. Loach's film, which will open in Britain later this year, focuses on the janitors of LA who only last month were out on the streets taking part in a successful strike for better wages. The slogan, inscribed on their T-shirts, has been "Si, se puede" - yes, it's possible - and it's possible that a whole slice of American life that has often gone unnoticed in film is finally being recognised.

In the early days of the silent films, Mexican-born stars like Ramon Novarro and Dolores del Rio shone brightly in Hollywood, but the talkies meant that parts for Mexican actors dried up. There were always Latino stars but most of the world was unaware that Rita Hayworth was born Margarita Cansino and started her career as a teenage dancer in Mexican clubs, or that Raquel Welch was originally Raquel Tejada, a Bolivian American.

Now Welch is playing alongside Sonia Braga in Nava's television pilot, American Family, and she told the LA Times last week that it was nice to be "Raquelita for a change, instead of having to play against it and be so Anglo".

Few of the main characters in La Ciudad or Bread and Roses have much chance of being mistaken for Anglos. Although salsa has replaced ketchup on the tables of America's diners and Latinos will make up a quarter of the nation by 2050, the change has barely been reflected on the screen.

Nava, who grew up in the border city of San Diego and has cousins and aunts who still live in Mexico, said it had taken years to get the financing - partly from Channel 4 - to make El Norte, which subsequently received an Oscar nomination for best screenplay.

"It was supremely difficult to get the film made," said Nava. "It was about two refugees from Guatemala and the cast had to be unknown. Today it is a little different but not that different." He was told then that if he had cast Brooke Shields and Robby Benson, it would have happened quicker. His 1993 film, Mi Familia (East LA when shown in Britain) starred Puerto Rican Jimmy Smits and gave Jennifer Lopez her first film role.

Nava said that one of the reasons so few films dealing with the Latino experience had been made was that many people saw all Latinos as immigrants: "in fact, the Latino population in Texas, for instance, is older than the white population. The non-Latino population want to simplify it and simply see it as an immigrant situation. It's much more complex than that." His film, Selena (1997), which also starred Lopez, told the story of a Latino crossover singer, whose father had found himself unwelcome both in white clubs because he was Mexican and in Mexican bars because he sang in English.

Producer Barbara Martinez of El Norte films, which is behind American Family, said there had been a long struggle to get recognition for the Latino experience in film: "the Latino community, in terms of its demographics, is very different from the African-American community because there is this continuous flow of immigrants... People are confused about where to put us."

Another film on the theme of the Latino experience, Luminarias, has just opened in the US. It is a romantic comedy based on a play by Evelina Fernandez about four middle-aged, middle-class Latino women in LA and their personal lives. Director Jose Luis Valenzuela aims to show a very different type of Latino experience, in that the women are a lawyer, psychotherapist, dress designer and painter, but maintain varying degrees of allegiance to their Latino heritage.

This manifests itself as the women socialise over margaritas and gossip about the premise that white women are basically tarts and white men are basically poorly endowed and that Latinos still feel a simmering rage about being patronised. "He's nice but he's white," says one of the women of her new boyfriend. "No one's perfect," says her friend in an echo of the final line in Some Like It Hot.

"The US is fast becoming Latino, particularly in Los Angeles, New York and Miami, and yet you don't really see that in movies the way you do in pop music with Ricky Martin and Gloria Estefan and Jennifer Lopez," said Peter Rainer, the Los Angeles-based film critic of New York magazine. "It took a long time for Hollywood to wake up to the fact that there was a black audience and not just for black exploitation films like Shaft and Superfly."

He said that one possibile reason why the Latino experience was rarely reflected in films was that studio executives "don't want to see movies about the people they underpay to cut their hedges and take out their garbage. Perhaps if Gloria Estefan or Jennifer Lopez played an illegal sweatshop worker it could be financed but that doesn't seem to have happened. There has been no breakthrough hit or star to push it along."

Rainer also pointed to the political context: "Underlying much of the situation of the Latino workers is the fact that they are being exploited by the richer elements of American society to do the work that white Anglos do not want to do.

"Tackling their basic problems means tackling capitalism full on. While a film like Erin Brockovich can show the little person beating a corporation, the stories are essentially of one rogue company behaving badly and being brought to book by the law or the media. In film terms, it is politics lite. There is no happy ending yet to the situation of the migrant worker. For now, it's basically a ghettoised genre about ghettos."

Sometimes the only people who seem to be out and about in Los Angeles in those darkest hours just before dawn are the cleaners and the film-makers both heading for work. For once they will have been heading in the same direction.

 La Ciudad opens next Friday. Bread and Roses opens later this year.

"It was supremely difficult to get the film made," said Nava. "It was about two refugees from Guatemala and the cast had to be unknown. Today it is a little different but not that different." He was told then that if he had cast Brooke Shields and Robby Benson, it would have happened quicker. His 1993 film, Mi Familia (East LA when shown in Britain) starred Puerto Rican Jimmy Smits and gave Jennifer Lopez her first film role. Nava said that one of the reasons so few films dealing with the Latino experience had been made was that many people saw all Latinos as immigrants: "in fact, the Latino population in Texas, for instance, is older than the white population. The non-Latino population want to simplify it and simply see it as an immigrant situation. It's much more complex than that." His film, Selena (1997), which also starred Lopez, told the story of a Latino crossover singer, whose father had found himself unwelcome both in white clubs because he was Mexican and in Mexican bars because he sang in English. Producer Barbara Martinez of El Norte films, which is behind American Family, said there had been a long struggle to get recognition for the Latino experience in film: "the Latino community, in terms of its demographics, is very different from the African-American community because there is this continuous flow of immigrants... People are confused about where to put us." Another film on the theme of the Latino experience, Luminarias, has just opened in the US. It is a romantic comedy based on a play by Evelina Fernandez about four middle-aged, middle-class Latino women in LA and their personal lives. Director Jose Luis Valenzuela aims to show a very different type of Latino experience, in that the women are a lawyer, psychotherapist, dress designer and painter, but maintain varying degrees of allegiance to their Latino heritage. This manifests itself as the women socialise over margaritas and gossip about the premise that white women are basically tarts and white men are basically poorly endowed and that Latinos still feel a simmering rage about being patronised. "He's nice but he's white," says one of the women of her new boyfriend. "No one's perfect," says her friend in an echo of the final line in Some Like It Hot. "The US is fast becoming Latino, particularly in Los Angeles, New York and Miami, and yet you don't really see that in movies the way you do in pop music with Ricky Martin and Gloria Estefan and Jennifer Lopez," said Peter Rainer, the Los Angeles-based film critic of New York magazine. "It took a long time for Hollywood to wake up to the fact that there was a black audience and not just for black exploitation films like Shaft and Superfly." He said that one possibile reason why the Latino experience was rarely reflected in films was that studio executives "don't want to see movies about the people they underpay to cut their hedges and take out their garbage. Perhaps if Gloria Estefan or Jennifer Lopez played an illegal sweatshop worker it could be financed but that doesn't seem to have happened. There has been no breakthrough hit or star to push it along." Rainer also pointed to the political context: "Underlying much of the situation of the Latino workers is the fact that they are being exploited by the richer elements of American society to do the work that white Anglos do not want to do. "Tackling their basic problems means tackling capitalism full on. While a film like Erin Brockovich can show the little person beating a corporation, the stories are essentially of one rogue company behaving badly and being brought to book by the law or the media. In film terms, it is politics lite. There is no happy ending yet to the situation of the migrant worker. For now, it's basically a ghettoised genre about ghettos." Sometimes the only people who seem to be out and about in Los Angeles in those darkest hours just before dawn are the cleaners and the film-makers both heading for work. For once they will have been heading in the same direction.  La Ciudad opens next Friday. Bread and Roses opens later this year.

fields.headline: Scientology fight fever
fields.trailText: If I wanted to make a skipful of money I'd start a religion. And if I wanted to make really serious cash - the kind that can finance jihads and subdue nation states - I'd start a religion in Hollywood, California, the perfect location for an aggressive young belief-system with something to prove.
fields.body:
If I wanted to make a skipful of money I'd start a religion. And if I wanted to make really serious cash - the kind that can finance jihads and subdue nation states - I'd start a religion in Hollywood, California, the perfect location for an aggressive young belief-system with something to prove.

The basis of any wised-up religion is simple: forget redemption, the do-unto-others, the life ever after, and all that crap. These days what you need first is a state-of-the-art drug-rehab programme, or better yet, a "Regimen" (it sounds holier) that uses strongarm nursing staff, heavy leather restraints, and forced mental realignment based on a combination of extreme self-loathing and vigorous cheque-writing.

Just ask the Honorable Elijah Muhammad, who cashed in nicely after he dreamed up his Nation of Islam on the back of a good detox programme. Once you've broken an addict's will, you can make him believe anything - even the fantastical nonsense Muhammad was selling about a mad scientist named Dr Yacub who cooked up an evil race of white devils in his laboratory.

Your next requirement is an endless supply of gullible people, some with low self-esteem and heavy drug habits, and this is where that Hollywood location starts to make so much sense. They say that all the loose nuts inevitably end up in California, and they're right.

First there are the intelligent nutters ranging from the deadly to the odd who dream up these rubbishy religions - Charles Manson and his coming race war, the Helter Skelter; the suicidal castratos of Heaven's Gate; the flying-saucer fanatics known as the Unitarians and of course, Scientology founder L Ron Hubbard, known to his craven adherents as "Ron". And then there are the benighted masses from whom they recruit their flocks: people prepared pay through the nose for a shot at redemption.

For most people, Scientology is an abstraction. In Hollywood, it's local, something like a pillar of the community. Anyone who thinks the church of Scientology will one day be legislated out of existence by the US government or discredited to death by tabloid revelations should consider its profile in Los Angeles, where it has been edging slowly towards respectability for more than a decade. This city is the world capital of manufactured perceptions, and the appearance of respectability is worth much more here than the real thing.

Hubbard had a street - well, a service alley - named after him a few years ago, and though the mayor didn't show up for the christening, he did send a representative, an unmistakeable sign of acknowledgement from the city's political establishment.

Through the sumptuous Celebrity Centre on Franklin Avenue, the church has strengthened its links with the city's other power centre, the movie business. Hanging out with Tom and Nicole and John Travolta must beat the hell out of working in a leper colony or nursing crack babies. No arcane rituals, no Bible, no guilt-trips about sex or money, just a lot of career networking, beautiful people and purchasable salvation.

No wonder Hollywood loves this stuff. Given that the church has been a fully tax-exempt religious organisation since 1993, I predict that it will be assimilated into the realm of political and religious respectability within the next 10 years. After all, the Mormons have been legit for decades, notwithstanding their one-time predilection for polygamy.

Like them, the Scientologists no longer publicly parade their core beliefs - which include a healthy serving of little green men and flying saucers - preferring instead to emphasise their good works and allegedly benign intentions. This isn't bad going for a former pulp sci-fi novelist who once wrote a short story about a man who founds a religion in order to get rich quick.

And it was in his capacity as sci-fi writer that Hubbard hit our screens last weekend. The John Travolta-produced adaptation of Hubbard's last major novel, Battlefield Earth, failed to topple Gladiator from the top spot. And no wonder. Look at the reviews: "It's a battle not to walk out"; "a hunk of junk"; "a ludicrously bad film", and my favourite, "Apocalypse? No!"

The cheapo paperback movie tie-in (published by the church) is an astounding 1,048 pages - you could beat someone to death with it if you sneaked up on them from behind.

Appropriately, this is the experience that watching the movie most resembles. Director Roger Christian (who, just to confuse us, is a Buddhist) did second-unit work on The Phantom Menace, and Battlefield Earth is strongest when it relies on special effects. When it has to depend on Hubbard's dimwit dialogue and situations, it's lost in space.

Travolta plays Terl, the villain, the 10ft tall head of security for the Psyclos, an evil race that has enslaved the human race. He's dressed up like a praying mantis in dreadlocks and exudes cartoonish horridness. Ranged against him is Barry Pepper, the god-bothering sniper from Private Ryan, as Johnnie Goodboy Tyler (I shit you not) the apple-cheeked young feller who'll save the world.

I felt my brain cells dying at a worryingly rapid rate while watching Battlefield Earth. Not since Forrest Gump have I seen a movie that made me feel stupider with every passing minute of screen time. If I write another word about it, I'll start forgetting my alphabet and soon they'll have to water me twice daily.

For non-believers there still was the madly successful Gladiator, the new sword-and-sandal epic from Leni Riefenstahl - I mean Ridley Scott. One question I find useful as a movie writer is this: "How much would Hitler like it?" And much as I enjoyed Gladiator, I couldn't help thinking that the Fhrer would have liked it all too much, especially Scott's kitschy, biscuit-tin aesthetics, and his computer-generated Ancient Rome, which bears an eerie resemblance to Albert Speer's blueprints for the rebuilding of Berlin. Still, everyone on the screen was a pagan, thank God, with not a Scientologist in sight.
