fields.headline: Crash course
fields.standfirst: Hollywood may be borrowing heavily from the videogame industry, but, Steven Poole argues, the fully interactive movie will never get off the ground
fields.trailText: Hollywood may be borrowing heavily from the videogame industry, but, Steven Poole argues, the fully interactive movie will never get off the ground
fields.body:
A spectre is haunting Tinseltown. An entertainment industry that is only 30-odd years old is already outgrossing the Hollywood cinema. Videogames in this country last year made very nearly £1bn - that's 60% more than total box-office receipts. The question for the cigar-chewing moguls is: what are they going to do about it?

If you can't beat 'em, maybe you should join 'em. Already Bafta holds annual Interactive Entertainment Awards: soon the Oscars will probably follow suit. And making a film out of a successful videogame is a perfect way to guarantee a large audience.

As the Pokémon movie demonstrates, however, the golden rule so far is that such films are always scabby, stinking dogs. Yet people in both industries have been talking for years about "convergence", about some mythical future species of "interactive movie". George Lucas has owned a highly respected videogame studio, LucasArts, for years, and now DreamWorks is muscling in on the videogame action. Is this a sign of rapprochement between the competing monsters of mass entertainment? Could convergence ever happen?

Well, it is certainly true that films are already stealing aesthetically from videogames. Consider, for example, the beautiful low-gravity kung-fu and joyously excessive bullet-play of The Matrix. The immediate precedent for such playful physics, it seems, is a cinematic tradition: the Hong Kong guns'n'kung-fu movie, as perfected by John Woo before he defected to Hollywood and began to make inferior, bloated copies of his earlier work. But the Hong Kong movie itself owes much to the exaggerated dynamics and superhuman violence of the beat-'em-up videogame, which first blossomed in the 80s.

The Jackie Chan movie City Hunter explicitly acknowledges this aspect of its heritage: Chan is knocked into an arcade beat-'em-up machine, initiating a comic sequence in which, dazed by the blow, he imagines his assailant as different digitally generated videogame characters, finally winning the fight in the virtual world and so too in the real one. Japanese videogame giant Namco repaid the compliment in 1998 with Tekken 3, two of whose characters look remarkably like real-life martial-arts film stars. Namco won't admit that Forest Law is supposed to be Bruce Lee, or that Lei Wulong is Jackie Chan, but this arch denial surely has more to do with licensing problems than aesthetic decisions.

Science fiction is another cinematic genre in which films and videogames seem to be interpollinating successfully. Sci-fi movies of course rely heavily on computerised special effects, and Nintendo's last game console was designed around a Silicon Graphics chip that was once cutting-edge Hollywood technology. Many videogames over the years have paid visual homage to the blasted, neon-lit milieu of Ridley Scott's Blade Runner, yet the production designer of that film has admitted he was himself inspired by the artwork on the side of an arcade-game cabinet.

But last year's Star Wars Episode 1: The Phantom Menace exemplified perfectly the limits on importing videogame paradigms into film. The pod-racing sequence, a messy and confusing homage to the Ben-Hur chariot race, caused many film critics to wrinkle their noses and complain that it was just like a videogame. But the reason it is so bad is that it's not like a videogame at all. You're not playing that pod-racing sequence interactively. You just have to sit and watch. And that's boring. That sequence was merely a 10-minute commercial for the videogame that was based on it, which was far more aesthetically satisfying.

Hollywood therefore is doomed to fail if it tries to jump the videogame bandwagon without considering why the source is successful. The recent announcement that sex-kitten Angelina Jolie is to play Lara Croft in a Tomb Raider movie spawned much salivating on game websites, but such a movie is in danger of falling prey to the same sort of problem. Croft works as a videogame character precisely because she is so defiantly abstract: a collocation of attitudinal signs - ballistic breasts, shades, hotpants, thigh holsters - that conjures (to some, at least) a Platonic ideal of sassy, self-sufficient womanhood rather than any individual. She represents, more fully than any human film star could, a blank screen on which the player can project a desire that can never in principle be reciprocated.

One company that recognises this is Japanese videogame studios Square, which recently heroically refused a $1bn buyout offer from Microsoft. Square is pumping $100m into making a commercial movie that will be entirely computer-generated. Actors of the calibre of Donald Sutherland and James Woods have been signed up to voice the characters, but the Final Fantasy film will otherwise be entirely digital. For once, it will probably be superior to the bafflingly successful videogame series it is based on, whose only aesthetic merit lies in the linear CGI sequences the player gets to watch between bouts of head-crushingly boring gameplay.

But really, to diagnose the likelihood of film and videogame convergence, we need to consider one thing in detail: what the camera is doing. Modern 3D videogames often operate with a variety of "cameras" that show the action on screen from different points of view. It may be hideously expensive to shoot a film sequence with 30 different cameras in order to intercut between the viewpoints in the editing suite, but in a videogame it's cheap.

Many games are learning from cinematic camera techniques. The "survival-horror" videogame genre, comprising Resident Evil and last summer's cause celebre, Silent Hill, takes its cue from the seminal zombie flicks of George Romero, breeding a powerful sense of atmosphere with disorienting camera angles and sadistically nerve-jangling soundtracks. But the fact is that such "cinematic" camerawork often interferes to the detriment of the gameplay. The player often gets eaten by a zombie because she couldn't see it coming.

In a videogame you are controlling the action: a camera swoop or crazy angle that heightens the atmosphere is also by necessity disorienting you and making it harder to choose the right course of action. That is frustrating and annoying in a videogame, but often useful in a movie. Indeed, a film director often breeds suspense by withholding information from the viewer. When Janet Leigh mounts the staircase of the Bates house in Psycho, Hitchcock chooses a tight angle on her hand moving up the banister, inducing tension through dramatic irony, as we know what awaits her at the top of the stairs. But there can be no dramatic irony in videogames, because it depends on a knowledge differential between protagonist and spectator, and in a videogame the player is both protagonist and spectator at once.

Film pleasurably manipulates the viewer, but a game depends on being manipulable. This again explains why the pod-racing sequence in Phantom Menace is such celluloid garbage from both points of view. It is a hyperactive mess of jump-cuts, glued together in the editing room. It fails as cinematic montage. But cinematic montage in a videogame is in principle a mistake, anyway. The virtue of videogame racing action is that, unlike The Phantom Menace's pod-racing, it is always perfectly spatially coherent, as a result of the greased-lightning maths processing going on in the belly of the machine. But in order to be able to control the action, the player must have a consistent point of view: if the camera is constantly jumping around the vehicle from different angles, you'll find it impossible to control, and you'll crash and burn.

One of the most brilliant videogames yet made, 1999's Metal Gear Solid, deals with this problem very cleverly by importing quasi-filmic montage techniques only when they do not interfere with the player's requirements of action. When the hero backs up against a wall to hide from an enemy guard, the virtual "camera", which normally takes a functional aerial viewpoint that allows the player to see a large section of his immediate environment, swoops in to ankle level to frame the hero and the guard walking past obliviously.

But function takes precedence over style: true montage is still not used. An action movie would rightly cut from a close-up of the hero's face to his point of view of approaching enemies, then back to a mid-shot of the hero with his gun drawn, and so on. Yet such confrontations in the videogame must take place in long shot.

These two paradigms of camera usage - tight montage for cinema; surveyable, functional space for the videogame - seem irreconcilable. What makes the fight sequences in Ridley Scott's Gladiator so extraordinarily, viscerally exciting - the tight angles, the fast cutting, the strobing effect of dropped frames - is exactly the opposite of what would be required in a videogame recreation of the Colosseum.

This distinction also provides a clue as to the real reason why cinema will never be supplanted by the videogame. In a game, you are in control: you choose what to do. But we still flock to the multiplex because the lure of a great cinematic story depends on our helplessness. No amount of pantomime-style shouting of "It's behind you!" can alter the inexorable machinery of tragedy or farce taking place on the silver screen. And that, in the end, is why stories move us: because we can't do anything about them. To take control of the moving image in a videogame is a fascinating new aesthetic pleasure, but in other moods, we will always want to be manipulated.

 Steven Poole's Trigger Happy: The Inner Life of Videogames is out now (Fourth Estate, £12), and is available from the Guardian CultureShop (0800 3166 102) for £9 plus 99p p&p.

When the hero backs up against a wall to hide from an enemy guard, the virtual "camera", which normally takes a functional aerial viewpoint that allows the player to see a large section of his immediate environment, swoops in to ankle level to frame the hero and the guard walking past obliviously. But function takes precedence over style: true montage is still not used. An action movie would rightly cut from a close-up of the hero's face to his point of view of approaching enemies, then back to a mid-shot of the hero with his gun drawn, and so on. Yet such confrontations in the videogame must take place in long shot. These two paradigms of camera usage - tight montage for cinema; surveyable, functional space for the videogame - seem irreconcilable. What makes the fight sequences in Ridley Scott's Gladiator so extraordinarily, viscerally exciting - the tight angles, the fast cutting, the strobing effect of dropped frames - is exactly the opposite of what would be required in a videogame recreation of the Colosseum. This distinction also provides a clue as to the real reason why cinema will never be supplanted by the videogame. In a game, you are in control: you choose what to do. But we still flock to the multiplex because the lure of a great cinematic story depends on our helplessness. No amount of pantomime-style shouting of "It's behind you!" can alter the inexorable machinery of tragedy or farce taking place on the silver screen. And that, in the end, is why stories move us: because we can't do anything about them. To take control of the moving image in a videogame is a fascinating new aesthetic pleasure, but in other moods, we will always want to be manipulated.  Steven Poole's Trigger Happy: The Inner Life of Videogames is out now (Fourth Estate, £12), and is available from the Guardian CultureShop (0800 3166 102) for £9 plus 99p p&p.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: The Straight Story | Happy Texas | Romper Stomper
fields.trailText: The Straight Story | Happy Texas | Romper Stomper
fields.body:
The Straight Story
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
FilmFour/VCI Cert U
****

A David Lynch film, but the only surreal note is the opening credit: Walt Disney presents a film by David Lynch. I'd love to hear Lynch's pitch for this in Hollywood. "This old bloke goes to see his brother on a lawn-mower." "OK, Dave. Any severed ears, any dwarves speaking Atlantean?" "Nope."

This is a film as simple and uncluttered as its title, and for those of us who battled through 90s Lynch - the endless excess of Wild at Heart, the incomprehensibility of Lost Highway - it is entirely a good thing. This is Lynch back on track and it couldn't be more straight and narrow.

The Straight Story is paced as gently as its lead character's speed. It observes the countryside and the weather changes and it's not afraid of silence. Richard Farnsworth, in the lead role, gets a very rare chance to play a lead character in his 70s - he's 79 playing 73 - and he's presented with the kind of dignity you usually find only in Oriental movies. He's stubborn, but he's no cantankerous grumpy old man.

On his ponderous journey from Iowa to Wisconsin, based on a real journey made in 1994, he encounters people - a pregnant runaway, a distraught woman who has run over a deer, a clump of cyclists, a family who let him camp out while the mower is repaired. Gradually, parts of his past life are revealed and his presence puts others' lives in perspective.

If this sounds horribly sentimental, it's a trap that is consistently, if narrowly, avoided. Farnsworth's trip looks lovely and lets you enjoy the scenery at a natural speed (compared to a Sinclair C5, this is luxury travel). Lynch allows a little comic relief in twin cycle repairmen who are like Tweededum and Tweedledee and the only mistake is putting some background battle noises on a war veterans' conversation. Straight and damn fine - it's the kind of movie Twin Peaks' Agent Cooper might have made.

Happy Texas
Rental
Buena Vista Cert 12
***

An amiable and engaging comedy and further evidence of the greatness of William H Macy, who turns a minor role as a sheriff discovering his latent homosexuality into a monument of broken-hearted stoicism. Lead characters, Jeremy Northam and Steve Zahn, break out of a chain gang and steal a car belonging to a couple of gays on their way to present the Little Miss Fresh-Squeezed Pre-Teen contest.

You can imagine the rest of the plot but writer Ed Stone and first-time director Mark Illsley pull some surprises and throw in a few nice lines: "He was lookin' at you the way a fat man looks at fried food", frustrated Ally Walker is told. Walker turns in a memorably likeable performance as the bank manager drawn to the apparently gay Northam and Zahn, whose dim stoner was one of the best things in Out of Sight, is fun again as the con who gets serious about preparing his charges for the pageant. The real theme is the effect of small town attitudes.

Romper Stomper
DVD (£17.99)
Medusa
Cert 18
***

Man of the moment Russell Crowe made his name as a demonic tattooed Mein Kampf-reading neo-nazi in Melbourne in a provocative and uncompromising 1993 release, debuting on DVD. It begins with a ferocious skinheads v Vietnamese battle with baseball bats and knives.

Writer-director Geoffrey Wright, a former critic, gives the film a terrific adrenalin rush and Crowe's malevolent stare puts him in the league of Tim Roth and Ed Norton for scary, intelligent swastika-fans. Oddly, while other members of the gang turn out to have been abused children or suffered absent parents, Crowe is given no backstory at all, he just seems malevolent by nature. One scene coupling classical music (Bizet here) with the old u/v inevitably recalls A Clockwork Orange but mostly Romper Stomper is its own animal, not as thought-provoking as France's skinhead saga La Haine, but undeniably powerful and disturbing.

fields.headline: The Virgin Suicides
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: ...The tragic ending is arguably excessive, but Coppola's direction engagingly avoids the coming-of-age cliches
fields.body:
Sofia Coppola's The Virgin Suicides, from the novel by Jeffrey Eugenides, has a strange and slightly unwholesome intensity, one part sophomoric mawkishness to four parts humid adolescent longing.

It is told from the point of view of four local boys in Grosse Pointe, Michigan in the 70s who become obsessed with five beautiful sisters, the unlikely fruit of a maths teacher and his uptight religious wife (discreetly and sympathetically played by James Woods and Kathleen Turner). They gain a glimmering insight of "the imprisonment of being a girl" when the youngest sister commits suicide, and the tender and erotic mystery of the surviving four attains an unbearable piquancy.

Something in the narrative is perhaps a little thin and unrealised, and the tragic ending is arguably excessive, but Coppola's direction engagingly avoids the coming-of-age cliches and the film boasts an excellent performance from Kirsten Dunst as Lux, the tearaway oldest sister.

fields.headline: One Day in September
fields.standfirst: Peter Bradshaw on a chilling documentary about the massacre at the 1972 Munich Olympics
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: For all its occasional naivety and bias, Macdonald's film is a riveting and hallucinatory recapitulation of 20th-century history
fields.body:
Kevin Macdonald's documentary One Day in September is the bizarre story of great events repeating themselves, not as farce but as minor Olympic event. For all its occasional naivety and bias, Macdonald's film is a riveting and hallucinatory recapitulation of 20th-century history: in 1945, the horrifying crimes of Germany lead to the foundation of the state of Israel, which in turn lead to the mass dispossession of the Palestinian people, and 27 years later the Germans, the Jews and the Arabs meet in a bloody, slapstick collision at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich.

On September 5, 1972, eight members of the Black September terrorist group attempted to draw attention to the Palestinian plight by disguising themselves as athletes at the Munich games and taking the Israeli athletes hostage. Within 24 hours all the hostages and all but three of the terrorists were dead in a bizarre tale of high drama, low cunning and bad faith, mainly on the part of the West German authorities - hapless, shrugging incompetents whom the film indicts as effectively complicit in the murder of the Israelis.

The social and political fabric of 70s continental Europe, as revived in Macdonald's film, has an unearthly strangeness: not larky retro naffness, but a weird mixture of paranoia and earnest liberalism. The idealism of the 60s was beginning to sour; anger and violence were becoming part of the currency of politics, but - yet to atone for the war - a faintly amnesiac social democracy and righteousness was being propagated in West Germany (and how ancient that partitionist term already sounds).

The atmosphere was a mixture of Frederick Forsyth and Heinrich Böll. And it was into this sideburned world that Mary Peters, Olga Korbut and Mark Spitz made their entrance to compete for Olympic glory and, extraordinarily, were instructed by the International Olympic Committee to keep doing so even while the hostages were dead and dying.

One Day in September reminds us of the bizarre sight of the children of all nations of the globe in the Olympic village sunbathing and playing ping-pong live on TV as the horrible carnage proceeded - a hyperreal paradigm of an uncaring but fully media-connected world. And far from showing solidarity with the Israelis, Mark Spitz made an inglorious and panicky exit from West Germany on the grounds that as a Jew he was in "danger". The irony is almost hilarious: if ever there was a time when the Israelis needed the Germans to show their ruthless, efficient Nazi steel, it was now. But no. The postwar settlement meant they had no proper military, so a Dad's Army of border guards got beginners' training in machine pistols and then manoeuvred into position, wearing tracksuits. But this disguise was undermined by their wearing old-fashioned achtung- Englander! coal-scuttle helmets. A bit of a giveaway. Also, the terrorists could watch them live on TV.

Later, when a crack troop of armed German police was supposed to overpower the terrorists at a nearby airfield, they took a vote and unilaterally called off the action because it was too dangerous. Not exactly the spirit of Rommel.

Macdonald's footage, though seen before, remains jaw-dropping. Interviews with an old Mossad chief make it clear that Israeli rage at this is still fresh, and they are still bitter about the fact that Germans refused to let the Israelis mount a rescue mission on their soil. Their suspicion is unmistakeable: the Germans can be chillingly militaristic, but only when they feel like it. Macdonald's interviews with the German civilian and military personnel make uncomfortable viewing. One middle-aged general gigglingly admitted that it was an uproarious foul-up and smirkingly confessed that the West German government did indeed conspire to stage a phoney kidnap drama so that the three remaining Black September terrorists could be shipped out to Libya without the necessity of a trial.

If Macdonald's film is tough on the Germans, it is lax and naive about the Palestinian cause. There are plenty of gung-ho and faintly redundant computer reconstructions of the abortive police ambush strategy on the night; the families of murdered Israeli athletes are extensively and sympathetically interviewed, and gruesome police pictures of the corpses are shown, but there is no balancing attempt to make sense of the Arab and Palestinian experience of oppression. The sole surviving Black September gang member - Jamal Al-Hashey - is interviewed in shadow, and the film passes very lightly over the fact that he was kept at the Chatila refugee camp, without dwelling on the resonance of that.

But getting him to speak on camera at all is something. Israeli assassination squads have already taken out the two other terrorist survivors of the Munich games, and there is no peace process for Al-Hashey, no Stormont-type jobs, no Mo Mowlam hugs. All he can expect, and clearly does expect, is a bullet in the back of the head.

The film could have done with more interviews with the athletes of the time, who would all have had fascinating tales to tell, and Macdonald could have used more penetrative talking-head pieces, as Leon Gast did for When We Were Kings, teasing out the intersection of sport, politics and history in the 1974 Ali-Frasier rumble in the jungle. But for all its faults, Macdonald's documentary is very watchable: an under-reported chapter in the secret history of the 20th century.

webTitle: British Energy deals new blow to BNFL

fields.headline: British Energy deals new blow to BNFL
fields.trailText: British Energy, the UK's main nuclear power producer, is in confidential talks with British Nuclear Fuels to end its £300m a year reprocessing contracts at Sellafield and move to storage of toxic waste in an attempt to win favour with the green lobby - and boost its shrivelled share price.
fields.body:
British Energy, the UK's main nuclear power producer, is in confidential talks with British Nuclear Fuels to end its £300m a year reprocessing contracts at Sellafield and move to storage of toxic waste in an attempt to win favour with the green lobby - and boost its shrivelled share price.

The move is another blow for BNFL, which has suffered a series of reverses since it admitted that its workers had falsified quality control records for plutonium fuel destined for Japan. Spent fuel shipments to Sellafield from Switzerland and Germany have been suspended and there have been calls from the Irish and Danish governments to end reprocessing.

British Energy has already indicated it wants to renegotiate its contracts with BNFL, but Peter Hollins, BE's chief executive, said it wanted to end reprocessing and persuade BNFL to offer storage facilities at its Sellafield reprocessing site.

It is understood that BE believes the move to dry storage could help to convince environmental pressure groups that nuclear power is a safer way to meet the UK's target of reducing greenhouse gases by a fifth by 2010 than unwanted climate change taxes.

Environmentalists have long argued that reprocessing is more expensive than storage and recovers bomb making plutonium that would otherwise remain locked up. Until now the nuclear industry has resisted an end to reprocessing because it says that to store and dispose of fuel is a waste. It argued that plutonium is too valuable as an energy source not to recover it.

Mark Johnston, of Friends of the Earth, welcomed the apparent change of heart. He said the move was clearly due to City pressure over BE's share price - which has lost 80% of its value in the last year - and acknowledged that storage was "the least worst option".

"But," he added, "the question is where? The best place is at the point of generation but BE would rather BNFL stored spent fuel rods rather than face costly planning inquiries.

BE's contracts account for around a third of BNFL's reprocessing business and Mr Johnston said that the state-owned group, which is itself switching into waste management, could abandon reprocessing "within the decade and probably five years and maybe much sooner".

Earlier this month the US government pulled the plug on a £4.5bn contract with BNFL to turn radioactive waste into glass logs because of an "outrageously expensive" estimate on when the operation would be completed.

webTitle: World Bank defies US with loan to Iran

fields.headline: World Bank defies US with loan to Iran
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: Overriding US opposition, the World Bank yesterday approved a $232m (£155m) loan to Iran, the first in seven years.
fields.body:
Overriding US opposition, the World Bank yesterday approved a $232m (£155m) loan to Iran, the first in seven years.

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, said she had asked other governments to oppose the loans while Iran was conducting a "show trial".

The US voted against the loans also because Iran sponsors terrorism and has not adopted economic reform programmes, Ms Albright said. But she said a number of countries thought extending the loans would strengthen the hand of reform elements in Iran.

Alluding to the current closed-door trial in Iran of 13 Jews charged with spying for Israel, the World Bank's president, James Wolfensohn, said several bank shareholders expressed deep concern with current events in Iran.

Mr Wolfensohn said shareholders did not want their support of the loan to be "construed as support for the current events". He said Inaamul Haque, who represents Iran on the board, "would personally pass on to his authorities the sentiments expressed".

The Clinton administration urged that the board withhold the loans while the trial was under way. Also, the US must by law vote against loans for any country on its list of sponsors of terrorism.

"We continue to be concerned about the policy environment in Iran, and believe it is premature to resume World Bank lending," a treasury department official said.

He said the Iranian government had yet to demonstrate "a unified commitment to economic reform necessary to encourage sustained economic development".

Board members discussed the possibility of delaying the loans but decided to go ahead, Mr Wolfensohn said. "Executive directors have noted that the consideration of economic and human needs underpins the approval of these loans."

 AP

fields.headline: Telewest bids for League
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Telewest, Britain's second largest cable television business, yesterday emerged as a contender for the pay-per-view rights package on offer from football's Premier League.
fields.body:
Telewest, Britain's second largest cable television business, yesterday emerged as a contender for the pay-per-view rights package on offer from football's Premier League.

Adam Singer, who recently took control of the combined Telewest/Flextech business, said a bid had been lodged before the deadline set by league officials last week.

The pay-per-view deal over 40 games carries additional rights to screen matches via video-on-demand and mobile phones.

"We have gone for pay-per-view rather than the main package, which will turn up on Telewest through Sky anyway," he said. "The main package will become more and more a loss leader to whoever wins it.

"Pay-per-view fits in with our strategy. We are interested in broadband content where we can actually make money."

Telewest aims to start its own mobile service later this year and offer a national service on BT's network.

BSkyB is understood to have made separate and all-in bids for the main, live rights package of 60 games and the pay-per-view rights.

Telewest revenues in the first quarter were 27% higher than last year at £239m and pre-tax losses increased marginally to £137m.

fields.headline: Nuclear firm plans switch from waste reprocessing to storage
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: British Energy, the UK's main nuclear power producer, is in confidential talks with British Nuclear Fuels to end its £300m a year reprocessing contracts at Sellafield and move to storage of toxic waste in an attempt to win favour with the Green movement - and boost its much-shrivelled share price.
fields.body:
British Energy, the UK's main nuclear power producer, is in confidential talks with British Nuclear Fuels to end its £300m a year reprocessing contracts at Sellafield and move to storage of toxic waste in an attempt to win favour with the Green movement - and boost its much-shrivelled share price.

The move is another blow for BNFL, which has suffered a series of reverses since it admitted that its workers had falsified quality control records for plutonium fuel destined for Japan. Spent fuel shipments to Sellafield have been suspended from Switzerland and Germany and there have been calls from the Irish and Danish governments to end reprocessing.

British Energy (BE) has al ready indicated it wants to renegotiate its contracts with BNFL, but Peter Hollins, BE's chief executive, said it wanted to end reprocessing and persuade the equally troubled group to offer storage facilities at its Sellafield reprocessing site.

It is understood that BE believes the move to dry storage could help to convince environmental pressure groups that nuclear power is a safer option to meet the UK's target of reducing greenhouse gases by a fifth by 2010 than unwanted climate change taxes.

Environmentalists have long argued that reprocessing is more expensive than storage and recovers bomb-making plutonium that would otherwise remain locked up. Until now the nuclear industry has argued that plutonium is too valuable as an energy source not to recover it.

Mark Johnston, of Friends of the Earth, welcomed the apparent change of heart. He said the move was clearly due to City pressure over BE's share price - which has lost 80% of its value in the last year - and acknowledged that storage was "the least worst option".

BE's contracts account for around a third of BNFL's reprocessing business and Mr Johnston said the state-owned group, which is itself switching into waste management, could abandon reprocessing "within the decade and probably five years and maybe much sooner."

Earlier this month the US government pulled the plug on a £4.5bn contract with BNFL to turn radioactive waste into glass logs because of an "outrageously expensive" estimate to complete the operation.

fields.headline: Unlicensed GM crops to stay
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: The government was last night resisting calls to destroy crops unwittingly contaminated with genetically modified pollen as ministers left hundreds of farmers to decide whether to press on and harvest them.
fields.byline: James Meikle, Jon Henley  in Paris and  John Hooper in Berlin
fields.body:
The government was last night resisting calls to destroy crops unwittingly contaminated with genetically modified pollen as ministers left hundreds of farmers to decide whether to press on and harvest them.

Officials insisted ministers did not have the power to order destruction of plants grown from the contaminated seed since there was no risk to human health or the countryside. A total of 11,600 acres are thought to have been planted this spring and crops from twice that acreage, harvested last year, are already thought to have been used in food or industrial oils.

As seed merchants yesterday tried to track down farmers to whom the rape seed had been sold, the National Farmers' Union said it would be taking "every step" to ensure farmers affected by the mistake did not lose out financially. It said: "These farmers, if they want to, must be allowed to continue to grow these crops. They were planted legally and there is no food safety risk."

Sweden has announced its intention to destroy similar crops, but France will not do so and German authorities are considering what action to take. The difficulties followed the news on Wednesday that conventional seeds, grown and prepared for the international company Advanta Seeds in Canada, contained GM material believed to have come from GM crops 800 metres away.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, robustly defended the government's stance, countering claims that there had been unnecessary delays since officials were informed of the contamination by Advanta a month ago. Tories demanded an inquiry into the affair and Liberal Democrats and anti-GM campaigners said Britain must follow Sweden's lead.

Mr Brown told the Commons "I regret these developments but I repeat there has been no threat to health or the environment. We moved quickly to establish the facts and officials have been in continuous contact with the company.

"These events have made it clear that there are gaps in the arrangements relating to seed purity at international level."

The government said it would take steps to put this right, spot check for GM material on seed imports from June 1 and work with the seed industry to produce new guidance on the production and sowing of seed including separation distances between crops.

Friends of the Earth said there ought to be a proper criminal investigation into the affair since it was an offence to market GM seed that did not have commercial sales consent.

webTitle: Thirty flirt with liquidators as recriminations begin

fields.headline: Thirty flirt with liquidators as recriminations begin
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Boo.com might be sold as early as next week, with around 30 potential bidders having already expressed an interest, liquidators KPMG said yesterday.
fields.body:
Boo.com might be sold as early as next week, with around 30 potential bidders having already expressed an interest, liquidators KPMG said yesterday.

Founders Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander said they had agreed to stay on to smooth the sale process although recriminations about the company's failure have already begun, with senior company insiders placing much of the blame on its backers.

"We're particularly disappointed with the performance of LVMH," one source said, referring to Bernard Arnault's French luxury goods empire. "The Boo model was complex and ambitious. At times we lacked direction and felt isolated when we were left to operate it ourselves."

An LVMH source said: "We have done all we can to try and find a solution but there is only so much you can do."

Interested parties have until tonight to lodge a refundable deposit of £1m before they can bid. Mick McLoughlin, a partner in KPMG's corporate recovery department, said the deposit ensures only serious buyers come to the table.

Shareholders who invested a total of $120m in little more than a year have lost all rights to ownership of the firm and creditors, mainly advertisers and delivery firms, are owed $25m.

"Because of the type of business and the need to maintain the core group of very talented staff, it is essential that the sale procedure is completed in days not weeks," Mr McLoughlin said. "We are seeking to sell the business whole or possibly in its two constituent parts as a going concern."

KPMG emphasised the potential value of the technology and fulfilment platform Boo developed. "People were able to order goods in 18 countries in any of seven languages and have them delivered to their door. The infrastructure has a huge capacity."

Kingfisher and Chello have been touted as potential bidders for all or part of the business, along with minority shareholder Eden and eLuxury, another LVMH vehicle.

Dan Wagner, the colourful chief executive of Brightstation (formerly Dialog), was interested in taking on many of the staff. "There are some excellent people within the Boo.com team," he said.

Boo does not have enough cash in the bank to pay its staff, many of whom have not received wages since last month. Ms Leander said last night she and Mr Malmsten would "take time off to reflect on what has happened and digest this whole thing" once the sale was completed.

"Maybe we did not have the best financial controls," Mr Malmsten said. "We were very ambitious and the technology delays did not help. Now we just want to help the employees get new jobs."

However, they remain convinced the internet will transform business. "We absolutely believe dot.com business is the future," Ms Leander said.

Boo's burnout and a Merrill Lynch estimate that threequarters of European internet companies will disappear over the next few years cast a shadow over London-listed internet firms. The Techmark index closed down 53 points at 3,344 with e-tailers under most selling pressure.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: E-finance: special report
fields.body:
 Blooming Online natural health remedy retailer ThinkNatural.com has secured £10m in its first round of investment since its start last year. The company began with less than £3m. The Kingfisher Group, owner of the B&Q, Comet and Superdrug chains, has committed to £4.5m with the remainder coming from existing investors Amadeus Partners and Gilde IT Fund, and a number of new investors including Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.

 Phone deal Up to 150,000 customers of the online bank Egg are to receive mobile Internet phones from BT as part of the telecoms company's bid to sign up 500,000 WAP phone customers by the end of the year. The terms of the deal with Egg, which owner Prudential will float in June, were not immediately available. Halifax said earlier this month it would give free WAP phones to the first 150,000 customers signing up for its Intelligent Finance Internet bank.

 Net trawl Spanish stock market regulator CNMV yesterday began investigating 22 internet sites offering financial services to investors, for "possible irregularities". The regulator said investigators were looking for fraudulent offers to investors, price manipulation, spreading of false or malicious information or dealing with privileged information.

webTitle: Trimble risks all to back new peace deal

fields.headline: Trimble risks all to back new peace deal
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, yesterday signalled that he was embarking on an all-out battle to sell a return to government with Sinn Fein to his sceptical party.
fields.body:
The Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, yesterday signalled that he was embarking on an all-out battle to sell a return to government with Sinn Fein to his sceptical party.

He announced he was delaying the critical meeting of his 860-strong party council, scheduled for tomorrow, until next week so he could win over delegates following the IRA's unprecedented offer to put its arms beyond use.

Mr Trimble is putting his career on the line and is expected to quit after five years as leader if he fails to convince the council, which is currently split, to support him.

The soul of Unionism, the survival of the Good Friday agreement, and even the future of the peace process now rest on Mr Trimble, after 13 days of uncertainty.

The meeting was postponed after Mr Trimble held lengthy discussions with assembly members and party officers at Stormont. They told him that one full day of campaigning was too little to claw back ground lost to the anti-agreement Ulster Unionists.

Figures currently indicate a 60:40 split within the 960-member council against returning to the power-sharing executive with Sinn Fein. It is understood that Mr Trimble has not yet been able to persuade John Taylor, deputy leader of the parliamentary party, to back the deal.

One of Mr Trimble's close advisers said last night: "The stakes are as high as they could be. We have talked of them before, but this really is the defining moment for politics in Northern Ireland."

Mr Trimble's move follows two weeks of wrangling after the British and Irish governments unveiled proposals at Hillsborough Castle for devolution to be restored next Monday, the second anniversary of the referendum on the agreement and the original date for the completion of paramilitary decommissioning.

The Hillsborough proposals were followed by the IRA's unprecedented offer to put arms verifiably beyond use. It said it would allow some of its secure dumps to be regularly inspected, a move which falls short of the destruction Ulster Unionists were demanding.

Mr Trimble secured statements from Tony Blair and, significantly, the Taoiseach, Bertie Ahern, yesterday that allowing weapons inspectors to look at IRA dumps was only a first step towards decommissioning. The inspectors are to be the former ANC secretary general, Cyril Ramaphosa, and the former Finnish president, Martti Ahtisaari.

"What we have been doing over the last 10 days is to explore the detail," Mr Trimble said last night. "Our party should not have to resort to deadlines arbitrarily set by others, and if we need more time we should take it."

webTitle: MPs furious as Straw lets Tyson in again

fields.headline: MPs furious as Straw lets Tyson in again
fields.standfirst: Boxing: special report
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, last night cleared the way for Mike Tyson, the American boxer and convicted rapist, to visit Britain for the second time in six months, provoking bitter clashes with his own MPs at Westminster and in Edinburgh.
fields.byline: Alan Travis, Lucy Ward  and  Kirsty Scott
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, last night cleared the way for Mike Tyson, the American boxer and convicted rapist, to visit Britain for the second time in six months, provoking bitter clashes with his own MPs at Westminster and in Edinburgh.

Mr Straw said he had allowed Tyson in for a three week visit to take part in a bout in Glasgow because there were once again "exceptional circumstances" to exempt him from the immigration rule that prevents convicted criminals who have served more than a year in prison from entering the country.

Although the decision can be taken only by the home secretary, the strength of feeling in Scotland will be tested when Glasgow city council is asked to approve an entertainments licence for the fight, against the Italian-American Lou Savarese, on June 24. The promoter is expected to announce the venue today.

The exceptional circumstances cited by Mr Straw included the "loss of economic benefit to the UK" if the match, which is expected to be a "pay per view" broadcast on Sky television, was cancelled; that any risk to the public would be minimised by his high media profile and the presence of his entourage; the limited duration of the visit and his satisfactory behaviour when he came in January.

But Labour politicians and women's groups accused Mr Shaw of making a mockery of the government's efforts to tackle domestic violence. They were also angered at how little time Mr Straw had allowed for representations.

Mr Straw tried to defuse the row by saying he regarded the immigration rules as inconsistent because they tended to catch only the celebrity villain. He published proposals to change the law so that convicted criminals from outside Europe who had served a prison sentence would be expected to disclose their convictions to the immigration authorities.

At the same time he wants to raise the threshold at which criminals are normally refused entry, from having served one year in prison to 10.

Maria Fyfe, Labour MP for Glasgow Maryhill, who pressed the case for keeping Tyson out, said: "This case has been decided in double-quick time and I doubt they have had the opportunity to consider the representations from Scotland and women's groups, not to mention the 69 members of parliament who signed a motion opposing Tyson's visit.

"This runs totally counter to the government's domestic violence strategy and the message women are going to get is that a boxing match matters more than the fight against violence."

Members of the Scottish parliament from all parties said they would put pressure on Glasgow city council to try to stop the fight.

"That's round one in London, but round two is in Scotland," said Gil Paterson, of the Scottish National party.

webTitle: Autonomy puts voice recognition in context

fields.headline: Autonomy puts voice recognition in context
fields.standfirst:
And here's one young hi-tech company that's actually making a profit

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Autonomy, the Cambridge-based intelligent software company, is to turn its attention to voice recognition after reporting a pre-tax profit for the first time.
fields.body:
Autonomy, the Cambridge-based intelligent software company, is to turn its attention to voice recognition after reporting a pre-tax profit for the first time.

Chief executive Mike Lynch said Autonomy has bought a majority stake in SoftSound and will marry Autonomy's technology, which attempts to make contextual sense of text rather than simply identifying keywords, with SoftSound's speech technology to enable voice and speech records to be managed automatically.

Mr Lynch did not disclose the price paid for SoftSound, which is also based in Cambridge.

"The amount of information moving around the average big company is doubling every three months and 80% of it is unstructured," he said. "The prospect of handling that information manually, be it voice mails, telephone inquiries or emails, is becoming unlikely and they will have to automate it.

"The currency of human interaction is unstructured information. The computer will have to fit the human, not the other way round. I don't believe there will be any significant piece of software on the market in two years' time that cannot handle unstructured information."

Mr Lynch was speaking after unveiling a pre-tax profit of $440,000 (£294,000) for the three months to March 31, compared with a $885,000 loss in the previous period. Revenues rose from $7.2m to $11.7m and gross margins increased to 93%.

Mr Lynch added: "It's good to be on the right side of profit - we've actually come in on a basis which is considerably ahead of what people were expecting. It all comes down to what the business does, and that is to make money."

He said growth had been boosted by partnership agreements with customers including General Motors, Eli Lily and the Nationwide Building Society. The US now accounts for 56% of revenues and the company is eyeing the Asia-Pacific and Latin American markets. "We want to get our technology into every little bit of software and need to have enough cash to be sure to get there," Mr Lynch said. Autonomy has $130m in cash at its disposal following its Nasdaq listing in March.

Mr Lynch claims Autonomy's technology, which is based on mathematical probability theory, is the most advanced in the world and that it is a fundamental part of the "plumbing" of the internet.

Investors have backed him and shares in Autonomy, which are listed on Easdaq, have outperformed that market by 157% so far this year. Last night the shares closed down $1.13 at $132.

fields.trailText: Contrary to the impression given in the profile of William Klein, The Angry Icon, in the Weekend magazine of April 22, a retrospective of William Klein's films was organised by the British Film Institute in February 1997.
fields.body:
Contrary to the impression given in the profile of William Klein, The Angry Icon, in the Weekend magazine of April 22, a retrospective of William Klein's films was organised by the British Film Institute in February 1997.

In an article suggesting selective blindness on the part of the prime minister, page 19, May 17, we seemed to connect Nelson's famous act of raising the telescope to his blind eye with the Battle of Trafalgar. In fact it occurred in 1801 at the Battle of Copenhagen.

Homophone corner, (an old favourite) from page 4, G2, May 17, "The length of time he has served in the army suggests he must have towed the line at some stage."

webTitle: Flexing muscles for a bout of shadow boxing

fields.headline: Flexing muscles for a bout of shadow boxing
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Glasgow doesn't scare easily. Taggart. Old Firm. No mean city. So it seemed right that the Scottish parliament was sitting temporarily in the west on the day that London told Mike Tyson he was free to fight at Hampden or Celtic Park.
fields.body:
Glasgow doesn't scare easily. Taggart. Old Firm. No mean city. So it seemed right that the Scottish parliament was sitting temporarily in the west on the day that London told Mike Tyson he was free to fight at Hampden or Celtic Park.

Shifted from their already impermanent lodgings in Edinburgh to make way for the annual general assembly of the Church of Scotland, they have been forced to set up shop in the old Strathclyde region council chambers. Technically homeless. And technically powerless, too. Left to rage and bluster as a decision on Tyson's visa was taken at Whitehall.

Boxing and immigration weren't even on the agenda. Fish stocks were, and community care, and slopping out in Scottish jails, and a host of other devolved matters.

But devolution has never stopped Dorothy-Grace Elder. The nippy sweetie of the Scottish National party seized her chance as the chamber rose for lunch, as yet unaware that a decision had already been made. Dorothy-Grace likes a good fight, but only if it's verbal and only if it's fair.

What, she demanded to know, was the parliament going to do about this? The presiding officer, Sir David Steel, had pre-empted her. He was on his way, he said, to phone Jack Straw and let him know the strength of opposition across all parties to Tyson's application. The clock read 12.35. Too late.

When the parliament reconvened for the afternoon session there was nothing in Lord Steel's face to betray discomfiture at his timing. But Alex Salmond's gave him away. Lips pursed and brows lowered, the SNP leader laid into the acting first minister, Jim Wallace. Did he share his horror at the decision? Would he seek a judicial review? Did he accept that he was totally powerless to control this issue? That it would fall now to the local council to let Tyson fight or send him packing?

Jim Wallace is a nice man. Congenitally affable, say some. But even he got riled. The parliament's views had been made clear to Mr Straw, he said, but immigration was a reserved matter. What he could offer was a commitment to zero tolerance, more money for the police. "Where this executive has powers to act we will certainly use those powers," he said, tersely.

The SNP had been waiting for that. And for a time, Holyrood, the body built from consensus, resembled Westminster. Fingers jabbed; heads shook, voices clamoured.

It lasted only a few minutes, until they all seemed to realise they were actually of one mind, the shouting died away, and the Conservatives' Scottish leader, David McLetchie, rose to his feet and steered them gently back on to the agenda; the nuts and bolts of the devolution settlement, the work they could actually do.

Outside, news of the row had reached the small crowd gathered out of curiosity at the main gate. "Are they gonnae let Tyson in then?" asked one man. The rest shrugged. "It's not up to them, is it?" said another.

And for all that that was true, the message from this rootless, restricted parliament yesterday was clear enough and strong enough.

In Glasgow there would be no welcome for someone who can turn brute strength into blatant brutality. If they had their way.

fields.trailText: Arsenal and Galatasaray supporters clashed again as they left Copenhagen last night, a day after violence had marred the Uefa Cup final.
fields.body:
Arsenal and Galatasaray supporters clashed again as they left Copenhagen last night, a day after violence had marred the Uefa Cup final.

Fighting broke out and bottles were thrown as supporters waited to board planes for England and Turkey, a Danish police spokesman said.

Police are now stepping up their preparations to deal with violence at next month's Euro 2000 championships. The National Criminal Intelligence Service yesterday said English fans were "almost guaranteed" to be in the thick of any trouble.

In the biggest outbreak of football-related violence since England supporters went on the rampage during the World Cup in 1998, 19 people were injured and more than 60 arrested in the Danish capital on Wednesday. Britons who had been arrested were yesterday released without charge.

David Davies, the FA's executive director, was adamant that England's 2006 World Cup bid would not be harmed by the rioting.

webTitle: Hirst pays up for Hymn that wasn't his

fields.headline: Hirst pays up for Hymn that wasn't his
fields.trailText: The artist Damien Hirst has agreed to pay an undisclosed sum to head off legal action for breach of copyright by the designer and makers of a £14.99 toy which bears a remarkable resemblance to his celebrated 20ft bronze sculpture Hymn, bought by Charles Saatchi earlier this year for £1m.
fields.body:
The artist Damien Hirst has agreed to pay an undisclosed sum to head off legal action for breach of copyright by the designer and makers of a £14.99 toy which bears a remarkable resemblance to his celebrated 20ft bronze sculpture Hymn, bought by Charles Saatchi earlier this year for £1m.

None of the parties would reveal the size of the settlement, but the designer, Norman Emms, said the "goodwill payment" was less than he had hoped for.

Humbrol Limited, maker of the Young Scientist Anatomy Set, has settled for contributions by Hirst to two children's charities, Children Nationwide and the Toy Trust, in lieu of royalties on the £1m sale.

The artist has also agreed to restrictions on future reproductions of the polychromatic bronze figure, described by one critic as " a masterpiece" and "the first key work of British art for the 21st century", which Hirst admitted was inspired by his son Connor's anatomy set.

Mr Emms, 57, a commercial sculptor in Hertford, made the original model for the toymakers Bluebird, which sold the rights to Humbrol. He said: "It is an exact copy, completely and utterly exact - even the hair, the eyebrows."

The toy is made of plastic, but both figures show a man stripped of his skin on one side to reveal the muscles, tendons, soft tissues and organs beneath. Humbrol, which is based in Hull, sells more than 10,000 of the toys annually.

Hymn, a pun on the masculine pronoun, is the centrepiece of the current exhibition at the Saatchi gallery in north London titled Ant Noises - an anagram of sensation.

Mr Emms, who has designed toys for Disney and created Thunderbirds models, was paid less than £2,000 for the model on which the 10in high anatomy set was based. He said: "I'm a commercial sculptor not an artsy-fartsy sculptor. My sculptures are mainly for merchandising. If I had done a 20ft one, who would have known it?"

He added: "It looks as if I'll be doing it for a while - I haven't got the money to retire."

Frank Martin, the managing director of Humbrol, said: "Naturally, we have to protect our intellectual property very carefully.

"But we think it's great that children's charities are benefiting from this. The anatomy set which inspired Hymn is, after all, an educational aid for children."

Damien Hirst said: "I'm delighted that this matter is settled to the satisfaction of all parties concerned."

The artist was on the other side of a copyright row last year, when he threatened to sue British Airways over advertisements using coloured dots for its low-cost airline, Go, which he claimed had copied one of his spot paintings.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Boo.com gave the market a scare yesterday, keeping the Techmark index in negative territory for most of the day as investors digested news of its collapse.
fields.body:
Boo.com gave the market a scare yesterday, keeping the Techmark index in negative territory for most of the day as investors digested news of its collapse.

As Boo.com called in the liquidators, PricewaterhouseCoopers did little to improve sentiment with its proclamation that 25 out of the 28 internet companies it had examined would run out of money within the next 15 months. Techmark ended 1.5% lower at 3,344.

Among the e-listed stocks that felt the pain were Lastminute.com , which fell 14.5p to 154p, Geo Interactive Media , off 47.5p to 792.5p while 365 Corp fell 3.5p to 101.5p.

Outside the bruised technology sector, however, sentiment was broadly restored from recent days when the market had been jolted by the half point rise in US interest rates. The FTSE 100 index managed to claw back 36 points to a higher close at 6,232 as "old" economy stocks such as BP Amoco , up 20.5p at 613p, and Shell , up 21.5p to 575.75p, led the charge.

Also in the ascendant was AstraZeneca , the drugs group, up £1.07 to £28.07, recovering lost ground after its pummelling over concerns about a European competition commission inquiry. A 4p rise in FTSE heavyweight Vodafone AirTouch , which ended at 265.25p, also helped the index to its higher close.

Even Granada , the media and leisure group, managed to end the day higher after a cool response from investors to its plans to fold its hospitality arm into Compass and reposition itself a pure media group. Granada gained 4.5p to end at 558.5p, apparently because Goldman Sachs was said to back the merger plan, though Compass, once a darling of the stock market, lost another 7p to 705.5p.

BSkyB lost £1.33 to £11.71 amid mounting concerns about the price it might have to foot if it is to secure the rights to screen Premier League football games. Big losses were also inflicted on a number of telecoms com panies, including British Telecom , which was down 70p at 922p even though it surprised the market with its profits figures. Anxiety about the fierce competition among telecoms companies appeared to be behind the fall, supported perhaps by further falls in Colt Telecom , which lost £2.24 to end at £20.49, and Telewest , which skimmed to new low for the year of 272p before ending at 275p, down 19.5p on the day.

Outside the leading index, Helphire Group enjoyed a 21p rise in its share price to 103.5p on the back of recent results by the accident assistance firm and share buying by its top directors.

webTitle: Nuclear group tries to turn the corner

fields.headline: Nuclear group tries to turn the corner
fields.trailText: Is Britain's main nuclear power producer, British Energy, about to turn the corner?
fields.body:
Is Britain's main nuclear power producer, British Energy, about to turn the corner?

The troubled generator - which last week stunned investors with a drop in profits and the halving of the dividend - is determined to restore City confidence. It plans to acquire another energy supplier, move into gas-fired generation and take over more nuclear power plants in north America.

The owner of Britain's eight most modern nuclear power stations, once a star of the FTSE-100, has fallen dramatically from grace. Its share price has fallen 80% in the last year, from £7.49 to £1.35, valuing the group at just £1.2bn.

Peter Hollins, chief executive, who announced a 19% fall in pre-tax profits last year to £241m, warns that the group could even go into the red this year because of a sharper than expected decline in wholesale electricity prices.

BE thought prices would fall 25% over three years but has seen a 15% drop already this year because of fiercer competition following changes of ownership in the industry and a forthcoming shakeup in the wholesale electricity market.

However, in an effort to stave off a bid from an overseas utility - such as Germany's RWE - Mr Hollins and his finance director, Mike Kirwan, plan to turn investor sentiment in their favour with a series of initiatives.

BE last year acquired a million electricity and gas customers with its £105m purchase of Swalec's supply business. In an interview with the Guardian, the two executives indicated that a further acquisition could come in the autumn; the aim was to increase the customer base to 3m or 4m.

Mr Hollins insisted BE would have turned in record earnings last year without the unplanned, temporary closure of two of its stations. He disclosed plans to cut a further 500 jobs - despite regulators' safety fears. "This is absolutely compatible with safety which is our top priority and we have agreed to adhere to a very robust procedure in our manpower reviews," he said. The aim was to help reduce unit costs by a further 20% over the next three years. Mr Kirwan added that the load factor (capacity usage) would be increased from 80% to 85%.

fields.headline: Advice for Mr Marr
fields.standfirst:
The BBC is under fire for appointing a leftwinger as its political editor. But bias will be the least of Andrew Marr's worries, says John Cole , who did the job for 11 years

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC is under fire for appointing a leftwinger as its political editor. But bias will be the least of Andrew Marr's worries, says John Cole , who did the job for 11 years
fields.body:
The sound and fury over Andrew Marr's appointment as political editor of the BBC will pass. What he will be left with is the task of mastering one of the most fascinating, if often frustrating, jobs in British journalism. I am confident his thoughts will not be dominated by any struggle of the soul about being politically fair. That will almost handle itself, while he gets on with tougher journalistic problems.

I was the BBC's political editor from 1981 until 1992. I came from 20 years on the Guardian as labour correspondent, news editor and deputy editor, and from six years on the Observer as deputy editor. So my own political views were scarcely a state secret. But I had enjoyed decent relationships with everyone from Harold Wilson and Jim Callaghan to Ted Heath, Willie Whitelaw and Margaret Thatcher, and they knew I believed in fair dealing.

No political journalist comes without baggage. It would be impossible even to decide which subjects win their place in the time limits of broadcast news, impossible to make them comprehensible to a mass audience, without having an obsessive interest and views. The question is what else you do with your views. In 1981, the BBC and ITN had a duopoly of broadcast news. Fair dealing among the parties seemed a moral imperative. I made a promise - to myself, not to anybody else - to do my best to provide it.

The BBC itself is obsessive about its reputation for impartiality. On joining, I had not lost my taste for political analysis, at greater length than broadcast news allows, so I wrote a column for the Listener and, after its closure, for the New Statesman. During Conservative attacks on the Marr appointment, I was amused to recall that the BBC was nervous when I proposed to write for the New Statesman. But I pointed out that numerous colleagues were contributing to the Spectator, not a wholly even-handed journal. The matter was dropped.

Andrew Marr's short article in the Observer last Sunday avoided stoking the controversy over his appointment. In a more relaxed age, I was less circumspect. For me, this was farewell to 36 years in newspapers, 25 of them in Fleet Street, and I felt the pain. Nor did the move to broadcasting reflect any disillusionment with print. Tiny Rowland had just taken over the Observer, and I played a leading part in resisting him at the Monopolies Commission. We lost, and Mr Rowland and I had an abrasive exchange at the Department of Trade in the middle of the night. The next morning, the BBC rang about its political editorship. We modern nonconformists are ambiguous about calvinist predestination but, in this case, I decided to make the jump.

I don't suppose nuns contemplating the veil have a last fling, but my farewell article did "cast one longing, lingering look behind". It was an unashamed exercising of favourite hobby-horses - poverty, inequality, the value of trade unions, incomes policy, peace and justice in Northern Ireland - all as I saw them. Very different from what both large political parties, or indeed the Guardian, now think, but there you go.

In passing, the article mentioned that proportional representation for Westminster elections might not be God's gift to democracy. A Liberal friend told me that this article was pinned up in their whips' office, to remind them what a desperado they were dealing with.

There were comparatively few early strains with politicians. A Panorama programme during the Falklands war caused half a dozen angry Conservative back-benchers to surround me in the members' lobby after the 10 o'clock division. I had not seen Panorama, and was concentrating on a news story about something different, so I advised them to contact the director-general with their complaint. But they were persistent to the point of rudeness, so I said huffily that I had not been introduced to several of them and would bid them good evening. Some of them kindly telephoned me to apologise.

The best contribution I could make at the BBC was to bring more of the enterprise of newspaper political reporting into broadcasting. I bumped my nose against some internal traditions. The corporation has traces of the civil service about it, and not just over impartiality. When I was required to sign the Official Secrets Act, I pointed out to a bemused executive that they had hired me to persuade cabinet ministers to shade their privy councillor's oath. Otherwise our coverage would be merely faithful recording of what Bernard Ingham was briefed to tell us.

I did spend more time than I could afford educating others in the BBC about the facts of journalistic life at Westminster. I lost one good scoop - the beginning of the row between Margaret Thatcher and Nigel Lawson over monetary policy, which eventually brought them both down - because I could not convince a programme editor it was important and comprehensible in a two-minute slot. If I had known how to use graphics better, the story would have worked, but it was still galling to be asked, by a different editor four days later, to comment on air about "this very interesting Sunday Times exclusive".

My life at the BBC was a process of reciprocal re-education. I learned a lot from colleagues, and they tolerated bravely what the Guardian historian called my tendency to make an opponent in argument "feel personally to blame for the heat-death of the universe". But there was undoubtedly far more a strain through internal debate than any strains with the political parties.

My 11 years at Westminster for the BBC were entirely during Conservative governments. This, far more than my personal opinions, dictated the agenda. Younger Labour MPs, who did not remember me as labour correspondent of the Guardian, may well have thought it was political bias which made me spend hours in the Lobby talking mostly to Tories. What distinguishes journalists from politicians is that they want to be where the story is. The story in my period was primarily in the internal Conservative debate over Thatcherism. It will be different for Andrew Marr.

This is a job where you shoot arrows in the air without knowing much about their destination. Seven years into retirement, I am still surprised how many people in the street - those who don't think I used to forecast the weather - say kind things about my political reporting on television. I feel like warning them that I was not part of the welfare state, but paid for my work. But it is a useful reminder that your ultimate bosses are neither the politicians nor the BBC, but the public.

For me, this was farewell to 36 years in newspapers, 25 of them in Fleet Street, and I felt the pain. Nor did the move to broadcasting reflect any disillusionment with print. Tiny Rowland had just taken over the Observer, and I played a leading part in resisting him at the Monopolies Commission. We lost, and Mr Rowland and I had an abrasive exchange at the Department of Trade in the middle of the night. The next morning, the BBC rang about its political editorship. We modern nonconformists are ambiguous about calvinist predestination but, in this case, I decided to make the jump. I don't suppose nuns contemplating the veil have a last fling, but my farewell article did "cast one longing, lingering look behind". It was an unashamed exercising of favourite hobby-horses - poverty, inequality, the value of trade unions, incomes policy, peace and justice in Northern Ireland - all as I saw them. Very different from what both large political parties, or indeed the Guardian, now think, but there you go. In passing, the article mentioned that proportional representation for Westminster elections might not be God's gift to democracy. A Liberal friend told me that this article was pinned up in their whips' office, to remind them what a desperado they were dealing with. There were comparatively few early strains with politicians. A Panorama programme during the Falklands war caused half a dozen angry Conservative back-benchers to surround me in the members' lobby after the 10 o'clock division. I had not seen Panorama, and was concentrating on a news story about something different, so I advised them to contact the director-general with their complaint. But they were persistent to the point of rudeness, so I said huffily that I had not been introduced to several of them and would bid them good evening. Some of them kindly telephoned me to apologise. The best contribution I could make at the BBC was to bring more of the enterprise of newspaper political reporting into broadcasting. I bumped my nose against some internal traditions. The corporation has traces of the civil service about it, and not just over impartiality. When I was required to sign the Official Secrets Act, I pointed out to a bemused executive that they had hired me to persuade cabinet ministers to shade their privy councillor's oath. Otherwise our coverage would be merely faithful recording of what Bernard Ingham was briefed to tell us. I did spend more time than I could afford educating others in the BBC about the facts of journalistic life at Westminster. I lost one good scoop - the beginning of the row between Margaret Thatcher and Nigel Lawson over monetary policy, which eventually brought them both down - because I could not convince a programme editor it was important and comprehensible in a two-minute slot. If I had known how to use graphics better, the story would have worked, but it was still galling to be asked, by a different editor four days later, to comment on air about "this very interesting Sunday Times exclusive". My life at the BBC was a process of reciprocal re-education. I learned a lot from colleagues, and they tolerated bravely what the Guardian historian called my tendency to make an opponent in argument "feel personally to blame for the heat-death of the universe". But there was undoubtedly far more a strain through internal debate than any strains with the political parties. My 11 years at Westminster for the BBC were entirely during Conservative governments. This, far more than my personal opinions, dictated the agenda. Younger Labour MPs, who did not remember me as labour correspondent of the Guardian, may well have thought it was political bias which made me spend hours in the Lobby talking mostly to Tories. What distinguishes journalists from politicians is that they want to be where the story is. The story in my period was primarily in the internal Conservative debate over Thatcherism. It will be different for Andrew Marr. This is a job where you shoot arrows in the air without knowing much about their destination. Seven years into retirement, I am still surprised how many people in the street - those who don't think I used to forecast the weather - say kind things about my political reporting on television. I feel like warning them that I was not part of the welfare state, but paid for my work. But it is a useful reminder that your ultimate bosses are neither the politicians nor the BBC, but the public.

fields.headline: Bean to France
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
Tetbury

My occasional golf partner, Dodger Norris, onetime famed Severn elver fisherman and local snooker champion, has other strings to his bow. One of these is the annual cultivation of an unnamed but highly prolific runner bean from which huge crops result in his Uley garden. I have prevailed upon Dodger to let me have a tray of his seedling beans for a couple of seasons now and last year restricted myself to growing them on in our courtyard garden here.

This season, however, has given me the opportunity to spread the fame of the Dodger Norris Eurobean in an international context. On our last visit to Brittany earlier this month I took half the tray with me and planted them, with suitable cane support, in some rich leaf mould soil close to some blackcurrant bushes I had already started. Exhaustive international comparative testing will be the pre-occupation this summer as I note the relative development of these beans under the different conditions of rural Gloucestershire and coastal Finistere.

On my limited observation the French, although enthused about haricot verts as a bean do not cultivate the runner bean of our island tradition so my cane support frame with, I hope, rapidly ascending beans, may lead to enquiries from neighbouring gardeners green with envy at this startling new crop. Providing my French is up to it, I will mutter confusing explanations of secret international plant trials being undertaken here in rural Brittany before their very eyes. And if I can follow the explanation up with a complimentary handful of locally grown runner beans then so much the better for international European understanding. Let's hope they do not suspect genetic modification trials and bring motley vagrants to wreck the plot.

The elderly neighbour up the hill who passes by with his handsome chow on a lead every morning, was with de Gaulle's Free French forces in London during the war, and may have familiarity with the runner bean from that period of exposure to English ways. If so, then Dodger's beans will not be a local mystery at all. Let's hope they prove to be the dependable success they do in the home context.

fields.headline: Granada and Compass
fields.trailText: There was finally some respite for the directors of Granada and catering group Compass yesterday as the freefall in the price of their shares, which has accompanied the planned merger of the two businesses, slowed.
fields.body:
There was finally some respite for the directors of Granada and catering group Compass yesterday as the freefall in the price of their shares, which has accompanied the planned merger of the two businesses, slowed.

During the day Granada shares went up by as much as 7.6% and Compass recovered 2.3% of its value. By the end of the day's trading, however, the respective directors' charm offensive in the City had failed to make any real impact, with Granada only 5p higher at 558.5p and Compass off another 9.5p and settling at 702.5p.

Prior to the announcement of the deal, Granada shares had reached 740p and Compass 951p. So far it has hardly been the fanfare which Gerry Robinson, the chairman of Granada, would have hoped for.

Compass chairman Francis Mackay appeared confident at the presentation of the deal on Wednesday that the markets would change their views when the reasoning behind the planned merger had been explained properly.

A number of investors have been surprised by the intensity of the City's reaction to the deal. Doubts about Granada's hotels and the slowdown in growth of Compass's catering business do not appear to have been assuaged by Mr Mackay's assertion that the combined business would remain in the projected growth ranges.

Another worry on the Compass side is the decision to burden the hospitality business with all of Granada's debt - although again Mr Mackay argues that interest cover will be higher in the combined operation than it was before the merger.

Compass would like to turn the nil-premium argument of the deal on its head and points out that it is effectively reversing into Granada's hospitality business and acquiring its assets without paying a premium.

Some investors noted yesterday that the weakness in the two prices could present a chance to buy either stock at a discount.
