webTitle: Many a hitch on the way to the altar

fields.headline: Many a hitch on the way to the altar
fields.standfirst: Problems pile up for hurried stock exchange marriage
fields.trailText: At the announcement of the merger of the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges a French journalist provoked mirth when he asked the Deutsche Börse chairman, Rolf Breuer, about the prospects of the parties actually making it to the altar.
fields.body:
At the announcement of the merger of the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges a French journalist provoked mirth when he asked the Deutsche Börse chairman, Rolf Breuer, about the prospects of the parties actually making it to the altar.

The reason for the mirth was that Mr Breuer has some very recent experience of a failed merger. For he is also head of Deutsche Bank - which a few weeks before had been planning a "merger of equals" with Dresdner Bank only to see it collapse amid disagreements about the future of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson in London.

Mr Breuer had the grace to respond with a smile - albeit with a touch of frost - and made a suitably emollient response.

But while it is too early to start wondering whether Mr Breuer is, on Lady Bracknell's reckoning, unfortunate or careless in the matter of mergers, the problems are piling up for the London and Frankfurt deal.

At first sight this might look surprising. It is hard to find a voice raised against the principle of the plan. It is seen as the crucial step towards to goal of pan-European share trading - notwithstanding the planned merger of the Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam stock exchanges. Milan and Madrid are already keen to climb aboard. No criticism there, then.

The devil, however, is in the detail.

In a sense - and with the benefit of hindsight - the problems stem from the fact that the deal appears to have been put together in a rush. Its architects apparently had two ideas at the forefront of their thinking: it needed to be presented as a merger of equals and it needed to be presented quickly.

Other things could be left until later. "It does all look rather back of the envelope," said one source in the stock market.

As far as the former went, London got the chairmanship of the merged exchange, the administration and trading in blue chip stocks. Frankfurt got the chief executive's job, its trading platform was on the one chosen for the two exchanges and it got the market for high tech stocks.

Even at that level the plan has misfired. In Britain Frankfurt is seen as having got the best end of the deal, not least because it got trading in growth stocks. This has lead to worries that the dynamic end of the business - the public offers with their armies of advisers - will inevitably shift to Germany.

In Frankfurt, however, the concerns are that once companies had succeeded on the hi-tech market in Frankfurt, London would insist they then be transferred to the blue chip market.

Ironically there are those outside London and Frankfurt who suggest that the real win ner from the deal is the US exchange, Nasdaq, which - under the deal - will have a link into the merged market in high technology stocks. Cheap at the price of giving up its own independent pan-European trading scheme.

This week the German exchange's deputy chairman, Manfred Zass, warned that if the details of this "merger of equals" indicated domination by London - which could be "the aggregate impact of the small print" - he would not vote in favour.

Mr Zass isn't the only one who must be considering vot ing against. The small and medium players in the British market - investors, brokers, fund managers and quoted companies - all have their worries, too.

This does not amount to opposition, yet. But the uncertainties left by the original announcement have bred disquiet.

Although the merger could open up opportunities, many brokers are concerned about costs which, on some estimates, could run to several hundred thousands of pounds as firms have to change or uprate their technology.

Questions about settlement and clearing remain unresolved. Some are concerned that UK investors will be carrying currency risks because of stocks being listed in euros rather than sterling - though the exchange is trying to set such fears at rest. Small and medium sized companies are apprehensive that they could be marginalised under the new regime.

"The objective is right but it is how to achieve that objective without disadvantaging some parts of the customer base. This is just as important to the small firms and private investors as it is to the big houses," said one broker.

According to Angela Knight the chief executive of the Association of Private Client Investment Managers and Stockbrokers, the alliance strategy is correct, "but there are justifiable concerns which need to be listened to."

Even some of the big institutions which are driving the consolidation process are less than happy about some aspects of the plan, notably clearance and settlement.

For the smaller brokers this is make or break time. Arguably their shares in the stock exchange will be worth more if the Frankfurt deal goes through than if it falls. But this is their last chance to make their voting clout really felt. Once the merger goes through their collective muscle will be diluted and power will lie firmly with the big players.

The exchange is promising more details of the deal at the beginning of July. It should be wary of presenting them as a fait accompli. Unless it takes on board some of the disquiet currently abroad it could have problems getting the deal through. Mr Breuer could be jilted again.

webTitle: WorldCom and Sprint face merger hurdle

fields.headline: WorldCom and Sprint face merger hurdle
fields.trailText: US regulators are ready to block WorldCom's proposed $115bn takeover of Sprint because of the dominant market position of the merged telecommunications group, analysts said last night.
fields.body:
US regulators are ready to block WorldCom's proposed $115bn takeover of Sprint because of the dominant market position of the merged telecommunications group, analysts said last night.

Senior lawyers from both companies are expected to meet Joel Klein, the assistant attorney general in charge of anti-trust issues, next week to discuss some of the concerns raised by the department's six-month investigation into the merger.

A decision on whether the merger should go ahead is expected to take several more weeks. Analysts believe that the justice department, which is in the middle of a landmark anti-trust suit against Microsoft, is particularly concerned about WorldCom/Sprint's position in the internet backbone and US long-distance markets.

The companies could head off the threat to their merger by agreeing to significant sell-offs. Sprint has already indicated willingness to spin off its internet business in order to placate government concerns that a merged group would control internet switching.

Company executives suggested yesterday that the deal was on track in spite of the concerns raised by the government.

Richard Devlin, general counsel for Sprint, suggested the department should consider the fast-changing circumstances of the telecoms industry.

"We believe that the changes in the law, in business institutions, technology, in the competitive landscape and in consumer demand should be determinative and that the merger should be approved.

"We look forward to the opportunity to present the facts ... to senior justice department officials in the next few weeks."

WorldCom and Sprint are the second and third largest long-distance carriers in the US.

Sources close to the company said yesterday that there had been no discussion between the companies and the government about selling off part of the long-distance network.

Bernard Ebbers, head of WorldCom, has said that he would be unwilling to sell UUNet, WorldCom's internet business. The federal communications commission and the European Commission are also investigating the proposed merger.

webTitle: Post Office may have less majesty

fields.headline: Post Office may have less majesty
fields.trailText: The Post Office is considering changing its trade name, the Royal Mail, when it operates abroad, for fear of offending states which are monarchies.
fields.body:
The Post Office is considering changing its trade name, the Royal Mail, when it operates abroad, for fear of offending states which are monarchies.

Officials are also concerned that the centuries-old Royal Mail name does not reflect the group's changing, and increasingly international, activities. Its cruciform logo does not play well to Muslim audiences, either, and the PO's research shows the name does not go down well in foreign monarchies.

The PO accepts that it cannot ditch the Royal Mail name. It is one of the most recognised brand names in the country, estimated to be worth about £3bn.

But it wants to leverage the value of the name in a way which will demonstrate the organisation's wider interests in electronic services and logistics. It is considering whether to promote strong new sub-brands under the banner of its existing brands.

For example, its secure website service, which enables companies to send electronic forms without risk of interception, is called ViaCode, although it is promoted as a Royal Mail product.

The Post Office is examining how best to portray itself overseas now that it has acquired numerous foreign distribution businesses.

Its formal name is the Post Office Corporation and it is generally referred to as "the Post Office" in this country. Overseas it is frequently called the British Post Office to distinguish it from local postal organisations.

A PO spokesman said the Royal Mail, Post Office and Parcelforce brands were associated with trust and reliability.

The opportunity for new PO brands will increase as new services are introduced after completion of the £1bn computer network linking all post offices. Such services are needed to replace the revenue local post offices will lose when the government starts paying state benefits directly into bank accounts in 2003.

The PO plans to start a scheme in the summer which will enable people buying goods on the internet to have them delivered to their local post offices for collection at a convenient time.

In just over a year the PO has bought companies in the Netherlands, Denmark, Austria, France, Ireland, Germany and the United States. It has just set up a small office in Amsterdam to run its overseas parcels business.

fields.headline: £200m alliance for First Choice
fields.standfirst: Investment by US company will give travel firm war chest for acquisitions in Europe
fields.trailText: First Choice has joined the flight for consolidation in the holiday industry by agreeing a strategic alliance with US cruise ships operator Royal Caribbean.
fields.body:
First Choice has joined the flight for consolidation in the holiday industry by agreeing a strategic alliance with US cruise ships operator Royal Caribbean.

Royal Caribbean is investing £200m in convertible preference shares which, if fully converted, are equivalent to a 20% stake in First Choice.

The two groups are getting together to launch an assault on the fast growing market for cruises among middle-aged Europeans. First Choice's chief executive, Peter Long, said: "This is the commencement of a commercial relationship. We both see the European market as having huge potential."

First Choice's businesses include Unijet, Air 2000 and the Travel Choice chain. The company already operates two cruise ships in the Mediterranean. Under the deal, First Choice will use its distribution network to sell Royal Caribbean's cruises throughout Europe.

The two partners will also each invest £32m in a new jointly owned ship, Viking Serenade, with a carrying capacity of 1,500 passengers.

Mr Long said: "Royal Caribbean see the European market as very promising and it's a market where they don't really have a position."

About 60% of cruise passengers are aged between 45 and 64. Mr Long expects cruises to become more popular because Europe's population is ageing and because such holidays are attracting an increasing number of younger couples.

Royal Caribbean's investment gives First Choice a war chest to make acquisitions in Europe. Mr Long said the com pany was particularly interested in buying tour operators serving French, Spanish and Italian holidaymakers.

Mr Long said: "Scale is important in holidays - it's all about buying power for hotel beds and spreading the risk in different marketplaces."

The move follows a spate of big deals in the travel industry. Thomson Travel this week agreed to a £1.8bn takeover by Preussag, the German group which controls Thomas Cook.

Mr Long rejected suggestions that the tie-up could lead to an eventual takeover by Royal Caribbean, pointing out that the alliance includes an undertaking from the US company not to buy more than 29.9% of First Choice. Furthermore, First Choice owns an airline - Air 2000 - and aviation regulations generally prohibit changes in a carriers' national ownership.

Most analysts welcomed the deal. One said: "It makes sense for them. They'll be able to use the money to expand, giving them more muscle when they're negotiating in the resorts."

Royal Caribbean's stake is likely to provide a defence for First Choice against other predators. The company's shareholders rejected a £1.5bn merger proposal with Swiss rival Kuoni last year, and the European Commission later blocked a proposed takeover by Airtours. First Choice's shares yesterday slipped 1.5p to 157p.

Analysts say the recent outbreak of bidding fever in the sector is partly due to changes in Germany, where complex cross-shareholding structures in the industry have recently been unwound, opening the door to consolidation.

fields.bodyText: First Choice has joined the flight for consolidation in the holiday industry by agreeing a strategic alliance with US cruise ships operator Royal Caribbean. Royal Caribbean is investing £200m in convertible preference shares which, if fully converted, are equivalent to a 20% stake in First Choice. The two groups are getting together to launch an assault on the fast growing market for cruises among middle-aged Europeans. First Choice's chief executive, Peter Long, said: "This is the commencement of a commercial relationship. We both see the European market as having huge potential." First Choice's businesses include Unijet, Air 2000 and the Travel Choice chain. The company already operates two cruise ships in the Mediterranean. Under the deal, First Choice will use its distribution network to sell Royal Caribbean's cruises throughout Europe. The two partners will also each invest £32m in a new jointly owned ship, Viking Serenade, with a carrying capacity of 1,500 passengers. Mr Long said: "Royal Caribbean see the European market as very promising and it's a market where they don't really have a position." About 60% of cruise passengers are aged between 45 and 64. Mr Long expects cruises to become more popular because Europe's population is ageing and because such holidays are attracting an increasing number of younger couples. Royal Caribbean's investment gives First Choice a war chest to make acquisitions in Europe. Mr Long said the com pany was particularly interested in buying tour operators serving French, Spanish and Italian holidaymakers. Mr Long said: "Scale is important in holidays - it's all about buying power for hotel beds and spreading the risk in different marketplaces." The move follows a spate of big deals in the travel industry. Thomson Travel this week agreed to a £1.8bn takeover by Preussag, the German group which controls Thomas Cook. Mr Long rejected suggestions that the tie-up could lead to an eventual takeover by Royal Caribbean, pointing out that the alliance includes an undertaking from the US company not to buy more than 29.9% of First Choice. Furthermore, First Choice owns an airline - Air 2000 - and aviation regulations generally prohibit changes in a carriers' national ownership. Most analysts welcomed the deal. One said: "It makes sense for them. They'll be able to use the money to expand, giving them more muscle when they're negotiating in the resorts." Royal Caribbean's stake is likely to provide a defence for First Choice against other predators. The company's shareholders rejected a £1.5bn merger proposal with Swiss rival Kuoni last year, and the European Commission later blocked a proposed takeover by Airtours. First Choice's shares yesterday slipped 1.5p to 157p. Analysts say the recent outbreak of bidding fever in the sector is partly due to changes in Germany, where complex cross-shareholding structures in the industry have recently been unwound, opening the door to consolidation. webTitle: Stingy shoppers point way on interest rates

fields.headline: Stingy shoppers point way on interest rates
fields.standfirst: Price pressures under lock and key
fields.trailText: First inflation falls to a record low of 1.9%, then earnings growth eases and now retail sales drop. Far from suggesting the need for a further interest rate increase, this week's batch of economic data points to the the next move in borrowing costs being down.
fields.body:
First inflation falls to a record low of 1.9%, then earnings growth eases and now retail sales drop. Far from suggesting the need for a further interest rate increase, this week's batch of economic data points to the the next move in borrowing costs being down.

Given uncertainties about the labour market, where good news on the earnings front was offset by a sharp acceleration in the speed at which unemployment is falling, and lingering concern about the reliability of the soggy first quarter GDP figures, the first cut in in terests rates is still probably some way off. But even the hawks on the monetary policy committee can not fail to be impressed by the way upward price pressures remain under lock and key on the high street.

Yesterday's retail sales figures, showing a surprising 0.3% drop in volumes last month compared with March, were no doubt artificially depressed by the poor weather in April, the wettest month since 1776.

However, they also appear to reflect the reluctance of shoppers to pay higher prices. Michael Saunders, an economist at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney Citibank, points out that the retail prices rose 0.3% month-on-month whereas in the previous six months they had fallen by an average of 0.1% each month.

It seems that, despite the strength of economic growth, rising real, inflation-adjusted, incomes and the wealth-effect associated with rising house prices, consumers remain as cost-conscious as ever, continuing to play cat and mouse with retailers to ensure they get value for money. When prices rise, consumers go on a buyers' strike; when they fall, or are held steady, they open their wallets.

As well as helping to keep the lid on the rate of inflation, this bodes well for the future if sterling falls against the euro. The minutes of this month's monetary policy committee meeting, published on Wednesday, showed that some members live in fear of a weakening of the pound, arguing that it will unleash a wave of inflationary pressure which would have to be tackled by sharp rises in interest rates.

If consumers were spending recklessly, they could well be right. But the evidence from yesterday's figures suggests that shoppers continue to watch price tags closely.

BT better in bits

By the end of the financial year BT's gearing is expected to be around 100%. For a company which traditionally has a debt-to-equity ratio considerably nearer zero than the three figure mark BT's apparent insouciance in the face of such a figure appears remarkable.

The reality is that by the standards of the industry the figure is conservative. Telecoms is a business which gobbles cash at a rate to test the strongest nerves - look no further than the bidding for the third generation mobile phone licences.

BT is already involved in the bidding elsewhere - no doubt hoping that at least some governments will prefer beauty parades (based on business plans, investment and employment) to hefty upfront fees. But while money flows out readily enough, traditional cash cows such the British fixed line business are facing growing competitive pressure.

The question is whether BT has the resources to drive the business forward. The top management is confident it has. They could be right. The balance sheet can take plenty more strain yet, but it is worth noting that other formerly state-owned groups are developing alternative fire power. Deutsche Telekom, for example, floated its internet business T-Online with the express intention of using its shares as an acquisition currency. T-Mobil is being pencilled in for a stock market launch too. Telefonica has floated TPI and Terra Networks, which has just bought Lycos.

BT has been rather slower off the mark. Only Yell, the Yellow Pages subsidiary, is definitely being groomed for demerger, though other bits of the business may follow. So they should. BT is likely to need the resources thus generated as well as the boost such a pro gramme would give the share price. These days stock market ratings mean at least as much as credit ratings.

Fair enough

On the face of it, Stephen Byers's plans for the office of fair trading, look reasonable enough. The OFT will get new powers so there is a case for a new structure. Broadening the range of skills and expertise available by adding a board with at least five members should guard against future directors-general becoming over mighty or out of touch.

But, given the strained relations between the government and the outgoing director-general, John Bridgeman, it is worth pondering if this is not another example of the administration's fondness for giving institutions greater freedom of action and then seeking some way of checking that independence.

fields.headline: EC inspectors raid Coca-Cola offices
fields.trailText: Inspectors from the European Commission have raided the Uxbridge offices of Coca-Cola Enterprises in an investigation into whether the company is exerting unfair influence on supermarkets.
fields.body:
Inspectors from the European Commission have raided the Uxbridge offices of Coca-Cola Enterprises in an investigation into whether the company is exerting unfair influence on supermarkets.

In a simultaneous swoop yesterday morning, the commission searched the Brussels headquarters of the company's Belgian subsidiary.

The raids are the latest twist in a long-running inquiry into the cola market, triggered by complaints from PepsiCo -Coke's biggest rival.

Coca-Cola Enterprises insisted it had done nothing wrong. A spokesman said: "We are cooperating fully with the investigation. We are confident that we are in full compliance with all the relevant national and international laws."

The company is a partially owned subsidiary of the Atlanta-based Coca-Cola Corporation. It manufactures and distributes Coke, Fanta and Sprite under licence throughout Britain and western Europe.

Brands owned by the Coca-Cola Corporation account for about half of all soft drink sales in Europe. Rivals have accused Coca-Cola companies of using their dominance to demand a prominent position on supermarket shelves.

Last July commission seized 10,000 pages of documents in raids on three other Coke bottlers, including Coca-Cola Beverages, the east European distributor listed on the London stock exchange. Documents were also taken from the British offices of Coca-Cola's parent company in Hammersmith, west London.

The commission's powers extend to fining companies up to 10% of their turnover depending on the severity of infringements.

The commission said there was no deadline for the completion of the investigation.

The Coca-Cola Enterprises spokesman claimed the raids were normal. "For any big business in a competitive environment, it is quite normal for the competition authorities to be keeping tabs on activities."

fields.headline: Filmgroup scales down float valuation
fields.trailText: Filmgroup yesterday said it intends to press ahead with a stock market flotation although, like its video-on-demand rival Yes Television, it will be at a reduced valuation.
fields.body:
Filmgroup yesterday said it intends to press ahead with a stock market flotation although, like its video-on-demand rival Yes Television, it will be at a reduced valuation.

The business will be capitalised at around £177m against original estimates of up to £300m.

Fimgroup chief executive Simon Franks said the scaled down offer price, a range of 175p-230p a share, took account of the volatility of financial markets.

"I'd much rather see us priced conservatively. In a young business, team spirit is essential and if you push for cash in an unstable market you will see volatility which does not boost morale."

The company is offering 40m new shares, accounting for around 31% of the enlarged share capital and raising £81m. Mr Franks, 28, owns around 20.5% of the company while Demon Internet founder Cliff Stanford has 40.9%.

Filmgroup combines a film distribution business with a video-on-demand operation which will deliver content over broadband internet networks. The key opportunity arrives when British Telelcom converts its network with ADSL technology.

Yes TV, which was also rocked by a spate of bad publicity in the run-up to its flotation, will be valued at around £500m.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: When Essex man washes his car or flushes his loo, he can thank John Morton, a 15th-century bishop of Peterborough, for the privilege. The cleric started the draining of the East Anglian fens, which now allows 160 million gallons of spare Norfolk water to be piped to Essex each day. In Waterlands (11.0am, Radio 4), Paul Heiney chronicles the story of how a dank and mosquito-ridden swamp was transformed from the drain of the Midlands into an agricultural cornucopia - and the threat it faces from global warming.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
600 jobs to go at Dunlop plant
Tyre maker Goodyear is to cut 600 jobs at its Dunlop factory in Birmingham by the end of the year. Production of car and light truck tyres would be phased out but around 500 jobs would remain. The cutbacks begin in September. Managers blamed continuing pressure on prices, the weakness of the euro and the fall in British car output.
fields.body:
600 jobs to go at Dunlop plant
Tyre maker Goodyear is to cut 600 jobs at its Dunlop factory in Birmingham by the end of the year. Production of car and light truck tyres would be phased out but around 500 jobs would remain. The cutbacks begin in September. Managers blamed continuing pressure on prices, the weakness of the euro and the fall in British car output.

Mortgage loan growth slows
Mortgage lending remained strong in April but was less buoyant than the previous month, according to figures released yesterday by Barclays. Gross mortgage lending was up 15% year on year, but fell 6% over the month. Although lending was still strong, there were indications that the market was slowing. The bank predicts that annual growth in lending will fall to single figures by the year-end.

Welfare advice for chancellor
Maeve Sherlock, director of the National Council for One Parent Families, was yesterday appointed to the chancellor's council of economic advisers.

The Treasury said Ms Sherlock, who has worked in the voluntary sector for 15 years, would advise ministers on welfare to work, child poverty and other issues. The council has three other members, all from outside Whitehall: Chris Wales, a City tax expert; labour market economist Paul Gregg; and Shriti Vadera, who specialises in public finance and international debt.

Scottish Widows plans bonuses
The top 30 fund managers at Scottish Widows, recently bought by Lloyds TSB, are to be locked in to the operation through a new "partnership" structure. Under the new name Scottish Widows Investment Partnership, they will earn extra pay on top of salaries and bonuses. Scottish Widows said the payments were to give them a sense of ownership and an incentive to boost corporate performance.

MFI executive to make fitting exit
MFI'S finance director is to leave the furniture company after just eight months in the job. Michael Williamson, 42, will get close to £200,000 in compensation. His departure was announced yesterday. A spokesman said: "I think there's probably been a slight issue over fit" and insiders suggested that Mr Williamson was not as pushy as other members of the management team.

Cadbury in joint Nabisco bid
Cadbury Schweppes and Danone of France are understood to be exploring a joint bid for the food business of Nabisco, the US biscuits and confectionary company. They are interested in different parts of the group and it is thought they are discussing a joint bid to outflank Philip Morris, the US tobacco and food group that is also bidding.

fields.headline: Whitehall launches second colonisation
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: "I've never been to a country where so many people genuinely ask us if we could recolonise. They really mean it," said the British force commander in Freetown.
fields.body:
It came as a bit of a shock to Brigadier David Richards, as it does to most Britons who spend enough time in Sierra Leone. "I've never been to a country where so many people genuinely ask us if we could recolonise. They really mean it," said the British force commander in Freetown.

Some think it is already happening. They do not mean the virtual British military occupation of Freetown. Months before this crisis, a quieter British invasion was under way.

There is barely a government ministry that does not have some Whitehall bureaucrat checking the books or offering what is euphemistically called "advice".

"I wouldn't say we're running the country but it is fair to say that it's better run because we're here," said one British official. "We have a certain expertise to offer. They can do with the help and it doesn't do any harm for them to know we're keeping an eye on things. It discourages too much funny business."

According to the British high commission, the accountant general in the finance ministry, who keeps a close eye on the numbers, is provided by the UK. There are also Britons advising in the departments dealing with revenue, economic organisation and finance.

British officials are also scrutinising Sierra Leone's customs and revenue service to see if it requires extra help. The forerunner for this is Mozambique, where UK customs runs the service.

But it is at Sierra Leone's ministry of defence that the British are most pervasive. There is a civilian adviser whose job is to show the Sierra Leoneans how to develop political control of the army and a military adviser whose role is, in part, to ensure the soldiers understand why they are subject to civilian direction.

British soldiers are overseeing the creation of a new army, and a British official sits on the commission responsible for reintegrating former combatants into civilian life. UK civil servants set up the demobilisation camps out of which ex-soldiers streamed last week to go back to war.

Last year, a contingent of British soldiers began training Sierra Leonean army officers. Despite the collapse of the peace accords, Whitehall is soon expected to announce that 60 more British soldiers will be sent there to run a long-term training programme.

The best known of the British imports is the commander of the Sierra Leone police, Inspector General Keith Biddle, formerly of the Greater Manchester and Kent forces. He was first dispatched to Sierra Leone two years ago by the British government to assess the state of the uniformed police and the detective branch, the CID.

"The force was completely run down by political neglect and the attitude of the army when it came to power," he said. "But the CID is actually very good."

Last year, Ahmed Tejan Kabbah, the Sierra Leonean president, asked the British government for a new police chief. Mr Biddle was dispatched with his appointment almost a foregone conclusion.

His appointment met with a mixed reaction. "Some people were not pleased. Equally, some were extremely happy. Some think their careers have been cut short because of my appointment," he said. "But people here are not uncomplimentary any more about the police force."

The truth is that most Sierra Leoneans despised the police for their corruption and violence. So Mr Biddle reassigned the traffic officers, prosecuted corrupt policemen and doubled a constable's pay from 70 pence a day.

But he says that one of the problems he faces is the legacy of colonialism. Practices redundant in Britain live on in Sierra Leone.

"The colonial policeman came out here as an officer and had the life of Riley. The Sierra Leoneans who took over, adapted to the colonial masters airs and graces and were very hands-off when it came to work," he said.

And there are still some of the old pressures. President Kabbah's son is keen to get Mr Biddle to move the police account to a bank he runs.

Britain's £70m in aid over the past two years is also funding schemes such as reform of the judiciary. But the image of foreign efficiency has been tarnished by the business with Freetown's ferry.

In March, the UK paid $1m (£650,000) to buy a new ferry to link Freetown with the international airport the other side of the Sierra Leone river. It was delivered with much fanfare, and the British supplied a captain and chief engineer to "shadow" their Sierra Leonean counterparts.

The vessel then broke down and has done several times since, to the mirth of local newspapers.

"The force was completely run down by political neglect and the attitude of the army when it came to power," he said. "But the CID is actually very good." Last year, Ahmed Tejan Kabbah, the Sierra Leonean president, asked the British government for a new police chief. Mr Biddle was dispatched with his appointment almost a foregone conclusion. His appointment met with a mixed reaction. "Some people were not pleased. Equally, some were extremely happy. Some think their careers have been cut short because of my appointment," he said. "But people here are not uncomplimentary any more about the police force." The truth is that most Sierra Leoneans despised the police for their corruption and violence. So Mr Biddle reassigned the traffic officers, prosecuted corrupt policemen and doubled a constable's pay from 70 pence a day. But he says that one of the problems he faces is the legacy of colonialism. Practices redundant in Britain live on in Sierra Leone. "The colonial policeman came out here as an officer and had the life of Riley. The Sierra Leoneans who took over, adapted to the colonial masters airs and graces and were very hands-off when it came to work," he said. And there are still some of the old pressures. President Kabbah's son is keen to get Mr Biddle to move the police account to a bank he runs. Britain's £70m in aid over the past two years is also funding schemes such as reform of the judiciary. But the image of foreign efficiency has been tarnished by the business with Freetown's ferry. In March, the UK paid $1m (£650,000) to buy a new ferry to link Freetown with the international airport the other side of the Sierra Leone river. It was delivered with much fanfare, and the British supplied a captain and chief engineer to "shadow" their Sierra Leonean counterparts. The vessel then broke down and has done several times since, to the mirth of local newspapers.

webTitle: British forces keep up pressure on rebels

fields.headline: British forces keep up pressure on rebels
fields.standfirst:
UN calls for ceasefire after capture of RUF leader

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: British military officials intend to press ahead with the war against Sierra Leone's rebel Revolutionary United Front despite the capture of its leader, Foday Sankoh.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal  in Freetown and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
British military officials intend to press ahead with the war against Sierra Leone's rebel Revolutionary United Front despite the capture of its leader, Foday Sankoh.

As RAF Harriers based on the aircraft carrier, HMS Illustrious, flew over the west African country in what were described as reconnaissance missions, officials said 600 Royal Marines stationed offshore on the helicopter carrier, HMS Ocean, were preparing an amphibious landing.

They are expected to take over from the paratroopers deployed in and around Freetown. British sources said they could remain beyond mid-June, the time limit given by ministers for the withdrawal of all British forces from Sierra Leone.

The UN yesterday called for a ceasefire in light of Mr Sankoh's arrest. "We would hope that both parties would stop where they are and cease fighting," said spokesman David Wimhurst.

An end to the fighting seems most unlikely. Mr Sankoh's capture bolstered the confidence of the British-led pro-government forces which are pressing east from Freetown while plans are put in place to seize the diamond fields in the south and east of the country that have long funded the RUF's war.

However, the rebel leader's arrest does raise the possibility of a negotiated settlement if Mr Sankoh can be persuaded to order his men to give up the fight and surrender their weapons, and if they obey the command.

With Nigeria and other west African states planning to dispatch an additional 3,000 troops to the country, the rebels were reported to be retreating around the Port Loco area, about 35 miles from the international airport, after Wednesday's clash with British troops.

It is now believed more than 100 RUF fighters were involved in the attack on the post of 29 members of the parachute regiment and 20 Nigerian troops at Lungi Loi. It is increasingly clear that while the official line is that the paratroopers were merely defending themselves, the British had intelligence warning that the RUF column was coming and it effectively walked into a trap.

Though the army says the bodies of four rebels have been recovered, the real toll may be much higher, given that the RUF column came under persistent ground and air attack.

The additional west African troops will be a valuable addition to the pro-government forces. The Nigerians have experience and commitment in fighting the RUF and it seems likely they will not be directly integrated into the UN force.

This would give the Nigerians the freedom to go on the offensive against the rebels, which is technically beyond the UN peacekeepers' mandate. But the introduction of a sixth independent force alongside the UN, British, Sierra Leone army, Kamajor militia and former military ruler Johnny Paul Karoma's troops will raise its own problems.

The Nigerians argue that with 3,000 soldiers serving with the UN in Sierra Leone and a similar number on their way, they should have overall command of the campaign against the rebels. But for now that remains in the hands of the British commander, Brigadier David Richards.

Mr Sankoh's whereabouts are once again a mystery. He was moved from Freetown's international airport, which is under guard by the parachute regiment, to an undisclosed location on Wednesday night.

The UN said the rebels have released a further 80 peacekeepers held hostage by the RUF, but 270 others remain in captivity.

The New York-based Human Rights Watch expressed grave concern about credible reports that government-allied forces in Sierra Leone were torturing and executing suspected RUF members. It urged the authorities of Sierra Leone and the international community to take immediate steps to prevent a descent into "mob justice".

fields.headline: Ayling issues air fares alert
fields.standfirst: Sacked BA chief says industry must cut deep to meet demand for cheap flights
fields.trailText: Bob Ayling yesterday warned airlines that they faced a catastrophe unless there were huge productivity improvements to satisfy the public's desire for cheaper fares.
fields.body:
Bob Ayling yesterday warned airlines that they faced a catastrophe unless there were huge productivity improvements to satisfy the public's desire for cheaper fares.

In his first speech since being brusquely dismissed as chief executive of British Airways two months ago, he said cheaper fares were the way "the world is now and we will have to give it to them".

Mr Ayling said that air travel had increased a hundred fold since the second world war and people could now fly more cheaply between Manchester and London than rail travel costs.

At the start of the year, it had been possible to fly to New York for £109, half the normal lowest price.

Mr Ayling did not mention individual airlines but his remarks were directed at some of the second-tier European operators, such as the Italian airline Alitalia and the Spanish carrier Iberia, which may eventually be forced to merge with other companies.

It was also seen in the industry as a warning to his old company, BA, which is about to announce its worst losses since privatisation in 1987, of between £220m and £280m.

Mr Ayling thought he had begun the painful process of putting the company back on the road to recovery and he convinced the City, too. But his old ally, BA chairman Lord Marshall, thought otherwise and decided to sack him in advance of the results.

Bob Eddington, BA's new chief executive, will have to make some unpopular decisions soon. Mr Eddington is likely to have to make changes which Mr Ayling ultimately stepped back from.

Under the four-year Ayling regime, BA's workforce increased from 55,000 to 63,000. One of Mr Eddington's moves is likely to be to cut back on behind-the-scenes jobs while trying to improve customer service.

One of the first casualties of the new regime will be BA's chief financial officer, Derek Stephens, who is to retire before the end of the year. BA said last night that Mr Stephens had already indicated he wanted to leave and that will give Mr Eddington the opportunity to appoint his own person to the job.

While expressing no bitterness at his sudden departure, Mr Ayling said that he had "been dealt a number of cards" before he took over as chief executive.

He had been faced with renewing a fleet which "had done its time", a reference to second-generation aircraft which have all been replaced. He achieved this by moving away from Boeing 747s to 777s and buying some of the Airbus family of jets for the first time.

He had to deal with the problem of a strong pound and the cultural change in the company since privatisation. He claims to to have been tied down by regulation.

Mr Ayling made his comments in the Dome, which he has been closely associated with as chairman of the Millennium Experience Company. He said that the Dome was one of the world's most popular venues and 85% of customers approved of it.

Since his sacking, the day after he opened the London Eye wheel, Mr Ayling had been "spending more time with my family and not getting up so early in the morning".

He has been hill walking and notched up 62 Munros - Scottish mountains over 3,000ft (914m). He bought a boat this week and has "several irons in the fire" but does not want to say what they are.

fields.headline: Israeli bomb threat risked peace
fields.standfirst:
Security chief's warning of attack on Arafat's headquarters outraged Palestinians

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The Middle East peace process came close to collapsing this week when an Israeli general threatened to bomb Yasser Arafat's headquarters in Ramallah, Israeli and Palestinian officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
The Middle East peace process came close to collapsing this week when an Israeli general threatened to bomb Yasser Arafat's headquarters in Ramallah, Israeli and Palestinian officials said yesterday.

The showdown, which could have destroyed nearly seven years of peacemaking, occurred in the early hours of Tuesday while the streets of many towns in the West Bank and Gaza were still strewn with stones and smouldering tyres from demonstrations for the release of 1,650 prisoners in Israeli jails.

At the centre of the unrest, near the City Inn hotel in Ramallah, Palestinian policemen fighting shoulder to shoulder with stone-throwing protesters fired live rounds, setting off a gunbattle which lasted for several hours.

It was the most serious exchange of fire between Palestinian and Israeli security forces for nearly four years. In normal times, the two forces cooperate.

The battle led the prime minister, Ehud Barak, to delay the transfer of the village of Abu Dis to Palestinian control. Abu Dis is a mile from the old walled city of Jerusalem and the prospect of armed Palestinian police so near caused a storm of protest by Israeli rightwingers. The transfer is now expected at the weekend.

Hours after the Monday clashes, the tension was still knife-edge as Israeli officers met their Palestinian counterparts to seek their cooperation in reining in the protests.

During the meeting in Ramallah, Brigadier General Shlomo Oren, head of Israeli security in the West Bank, told stunned Palestinian officials that he would use Cobra attack helicopters to bomb Mr Arafat's fortified compound if he did not take immediate action to end the protests.

When the outraged Palestinians got up to leave, the Ma'ariv newspaper reported, Gen Oren told them: "You are being irresponsible leaving a meeting with this situation outside."

The Palestinians reported the threat to Mr Arafat, who told European officials and the US Middle East envoy, Dennis Ross, later that day.

The substance of Ma'ariv's report was confirmed by Israeli and Palestinian officials. "Perhaps some officer lost his temper and said something like that," the Israeli justice minister, Yossi Beilin, told Israel Radio. Senior army officers said that Gen Oren might have felt justified in making the threat after the Palestinian police fired on his men.

Palestinians showed less understanding. Saeb Erakat, their chief negotiator, wrote to Mr Barak for an apology.

Both forces are preparing for further unrest today, when Mr Arafat's Fatah faction has called for a "day of rage" to persuade Israel to release the prisoners.

fields.headline: Mugabe's veterans renew the rampage
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: An intensified barrage of state-sponsored violence swept through Zimbabwe yesterday, killing three more opposition supporters and making a mockery of the assurances President Robert Mugabe gave to the Commonwealth secretary general, Don McKinnon, that such brutal intimidation would decrease.
fields.body:
An intensified barrage of state-sponsored violence swept through Zimbabwe yesterday, killing three more opposition supporters and making a mockery of the assurances President Robert Mugabe gave to the Commonwealth secretary general, Don McKinnon, that such brutal intimidation would decrease.

Two members of the United parties (UP) were beaten to death by members of Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party in the Mudzi area of north-eastern Zimbabwe, the police confirmed yesterday.

More than 30 other UP supporters were badly beaten in Mudzi.

One more supporter of the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) was killed yesterday, bringing to 23 the total of opposition supporters who have been killed by Mr Mugabe's supporters.

Throughout the country, Mugabe supporters beat, tortured and murdered opposition supporters.

Teachers, nurses and farmers have fled their rural homes hoping to find safety in the cities.

But Mr Mugabe's party has taken its violent campaign to Harare. Takundwa Chapunza was beaten to death, reportedly in the surgery owned by Chenjerai Hunzvi, leader of the militant war veterans who support Mr Mugabe.

The surgery, in Budiriro township, is used as an interrogation centre and more than 200 people have been tortured and beaten there in the past two weeks.

Yesterday war veterans from the surgery went door to door beating township residents suspected of supporting the MDC.

Another group of war veterans in the eastern mountain town of Chimanimani dragged teachers from their classrooms, accused them of supporting the MDC, and stripped and beat them in front of their students.

They also invaded the Border Timbers factory in Chimanimani, beat up several employees and threatened the management.

The mill, Zimbabwe's biggest, with 3,500 employees, closed yesterday because of the violence.

In the central city of Kwekwe Mugabe supporters tried to kill the MDC candidate for parliament, Blessing Chibundo, and burned his house down. Mr Chibundo is standing for election against the justice minister, Emmerson Mnangagwa.

Throughout the Mashonaland East province, hundreds of teachers have fled their homes because of beatings by Mugabe supporters.

"Despite what Mugabe has told international leaders, this is a renewed reign of terror," the MDC's president, Morgan Tsvangirai, said yesterday.

"Mugabe says what they want to hear and then he gives the go ahead for more violence . . . Zanu-PF believes it has beat enough people to support it, or at least not to vote at all.

"But we believe violence cannot win elections. It has had a contrary effect to make people determined to support change."

Many Zimbabweans are clearly terrified, however.

"My mother said she doesn't want to vote. She is convinced that the war veterans will know how she votes," said Tonderai Mushamba, from the Mutoko area north-east of Harare. "They told her they will come and beat her if she votes for the MDC."

Mr Mushamba (not his real name) fled Mutoko after Mugabe supporters threatened to kill him.

"A massive public education campaign is badly needed," said an African election expert currently in Harare. "It is crucial for the public to have confidence that their votes will be secret."

Mr Tsvangirai said: "The elections cannot be free and fair, but what we and the international community must do is to try to reduce the level of subversion."

webTitle: Hard campaigning to scupper Ulster deal

fields.headline: Hard campaigning to scupper Ulster deal
fields.standfirst:
Trimble's travails: As a key supporter prevaricates, a confident opposition camp battles to win over doubters on the UUP council

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Early yesterday morning, half a dozen Ulster Unionists opposed to a quick return to government stopped off at Pithika Kebab House in south Belfast. They were ravenous after bashing the phones to council delegates, and retired to discuss their night's work.
fields.body:
Early yesterday morning, half a dozen Ulster Unionists opposed to a quick return to government stopped off at Pithika Kebab House in south Belfast. They were ravenous after bashing the phones to council delegates, and retired to discuss their night's work.

Philip Weir, 28, chairman of the Young Unionists, had taken a week's holiday, while Simon Hamilton, 23, chairman of Ulster Unionists at Queen's University, was passing on revision for forthcoming law exams. All were spending every night this week campaigning, stealing a march on pro-agreement colleagues.

Dr Weir said: "It is one key difference. We have the commitment. Many of the party leadership's canvassers would be employees. We tend to put in that extra phone call. It could prove crucial."

Operational HQ is a warehouse in east Belfast, while other canvassing centres are at the offices of anti-agreement MPs Jeffrey Donaldson and Martin Smyth. The Orange Order also helps to fund their campaign.

They have worked unchallenged for a week, focusing particularly on the middle third of the 860-strong ruling council and on new delegates who took their places in March. They believe the vote against a return to the executive with Sinn Fein on the basis of the IRA offer is running about 60 to 40 in their favour.

That was the message which party officers were delivering to David Trimble yesterday. To give himself just one full day's campaigning was too little, particularly as he has spent almost the last two weeks publicly highlighting the flaws in the deal.

Those against restored devolution are largely those who opposed the agreement and who voted for Mr Smyth, South Belfast MP, in the leadership election two months ago. But they say delegates previously unquestioningly loyal to Mr Trimble are switching.

With Mr Trimble winning by a 57 to 43 majority against Mr Smyth in March, they will win if they can persuade 60 people to switch. They have built up a database on every delegate, and have earmarked specific party figures to speak to doubters after initial calls.

Mr Hamilton, who alone made 25 calls on Wednesday evening, said: "Many people want to talk at length about the issues. They feel a little unloved by the other side. Even in areas which have strongly been behind the leadership, we are making heartening inroads."

The meeting of the party council, which will now take place a week on Saturday, is the fourth in seven months. The anti-agreement camp has refined its tactics and adopted a more coherent structure.

Those who call delegates for the first time are aided with a crib sheet. They admit it is rather like cold calling.

Dan Ross, 24, an insurance broker, said: "The IRA's offer is the usual rhetoric and vague in the extreme. It makes no sense to go back into government without decommissioning when it was because there had been none that the institutions were suspended in February."

Peter Weir, the Ulster Unionist assembly member who last year lost the party whip because of his vocal opposition to the agreement, joined the others later. He is now the Ulster Unionist parliamentary candidate in North Down, much to Mr Trimble's fury.

He was helping them draw up their latest letter. As well as the IRA issue, they are emphasising devolution will signal the return of the former IRA chief of staff Martin McGuinness as education minister.

He is now the Ulster Unionist parliamentary candidate in North Down, much to Mr Trimble's fury. He was helping them draw up their latest letter. As well as the IRA issue, they are emphasising devolution will signal the return of the former IRA chief of staff Martin McGuinness as education minister.

fields.headline: Thugs prepare for Euro 2000 war
fields.standfirst:
Fears that the appalling street violence of Copenhagen will be repeated at next month's championships

More about violence in Copenhagen
fields.trailText: Police and football officials are preparing for fresh outbreaks of violence at next month's Euro 2000 championships following the clashes between English and Turkish supporters that marred the Uefa Cup final in Copenhagen on Wednesday night.
fields.body:
Police and football officials are preparing for fresh outbreaks of violence at next month's Euro 2000 championships following the clashes between English and Turkish supporters that marred the Uefa Cup final in Copenhagen on Wednesday night.

The National Criminal Intelligence Service yesterday warned that hooliganism was once again on the increase, and predicted that English fans were "almost guaranteed" to be in the thick of any trouble in Holland and Belgium.

In the worst outbreak of widespread football-related violence since England supporters went on the rampage during the 1998 World Cup, 19 people were injured and more than 60 arrested in clashes between Arsenal and Galatasaray.

Last night there were reports of fresh fighting between the supporters at Copenhagen airport. Bottles were thrown and fights broke out between the rival factions as fans waited to board planes home, a Danish police spokesman said.

Earlier, 15 Britons arrested during the troubles were released without being charged. Danish police said their priority was to get the fans out of the country as quickly as possible. But this was condemned by their British counterparts who said hooligans causing trouble abroad should be put through the judicial process as a deterrent.

Mark Steels, a spokesman for NCIS, which shares intelligence on hooligans with police forces at home and abroad, said the organisation was not surprised by the violence in Copenhagen. He said that statistics for this season, due out in August, will show hooliganism has risen, particularly violent confrontations away from grounds and between supporters of non-Premiership clubs.

The authorities have also become increasingly concerned about an apparent shift in the rules of engagement in the fighting between rival gangs. Police have recorded a significant rise in the number of weapons being used this season. "This is not handbags at dawn stuff. It is very nasty, an NCIS spokesman said. "We are talking about people with iron bars, sticks, knives. It is very vicious. these people are not deterred by legislation. They are a new generation."

Attention will now switch to Euro 2000, which is being co-hosted by Belgium and Holland. Mr Steels said: "I don't think people can say any more that this sort of thing won't happen in Euro 2000."

"We have fears about the security of the tournament full stop. I'm afraid to say that we have fears wherever English fans go at club level and quite often, indeed more often, at international level.

"We fear that English fans are going to cause trouble at Euro 2000, and I can almost guarantee you that if there is any trouble at Euro 2000, English fans will be part of it."

Wednesday night's violence was the latest in a series of clashes between English and Turkish fans since two Leeds United supporters were murdered in Istanbul on the eve of the club's semi-final tie against Galatasaray. On Tuesday, Paul Dineen, an Arsenal fan from north London, was stabbed in the back in Copenhagen.

Many Arsenal fans arriving at Luton airport yesterday said a rivalry had now been established between the two country's hooligans which would carry on this summer. Both sets of supporters could be in Eindhoven at roughly the same time and the two teams could meet in the quarter finals of the tournament on June 24.

The British authorities are hoping that police in Belgium and Holland, who have been co-ordinating closely with NCIS in the run up to the tournament, will have learned from Wednesday night.

Despite warnings that Arsenal hooligans were planning to travel to the match, Danish police adopted a "softly softly" approach to security.

British police yesterday refused to condemn the tactics employed, but privately they believe the Danish police adopted a low key approach because it worked for the 1998 Cup Winners' Cup Final in Stockholm, when 17,000 Chelsea fans travelled to Sweden and there was only one arrest.

The organisers of Euro 2000 yesterday insisted they were ready to handle any hooligan threat. A spokesman, Jan de Grave, said. "We cannot guarantee a 100% safe tournament but we are confident we've had the right preparation."

While Uefa played down the risk of trouble at Euro 2000 the Dutch authorities were less sanguine. An interior ministry spokesman, Harald Hameleers, said: "It shows we will have to be very alert."

David Davies, the FA's executive director, said a meeting with the Turkish FA had been brought forward in an attempt to "restore the normal relationship between the two footballing nations".

Mr Davies said he was "disappointed" by the violence and offered an apology to the people of Copenhagen. But he was adamant that England's 2006 World Cup bid would not be harmed. "The decision on 2006 will be about which country has the best facilities, the best infrastructure, the best grounds," he added.

Mr Davies suggested that the government may need to tighten controls to stop hooligans travelling to Euro 2000.

The former head of the government's Football Taskforce, David Mellor, called for new laws allowing police to confiscate fans' passports if officers convince magistrates there is firm evidence of them being suspected hooligans.

webTitle: Surprise attack by Arsenal fans seeking revenge sparked battle

fields.headline: Surprise attack by Arsenal fans seeking revenge sparked battle
fields.standfirst: More about violence in Copenhagen
fields.trailText: Vivek Chaudhary reports on the aftermath of running battles in Copenhagen.
fields.body:
Like civilians returning to their homes after a war, the people of central Copenhagen began reclaiming their streets yesterday.

In the City Hall Square, scene of some of the ugliest violence, the plastic chairs and tables that had been put out in case of trouble were replaced by metal and wooden ones.

The stallholder whose vegetables had been scattered in the fighting laid out her produce, the only danger now coming from scavenging birds.

The roar of violence was replaced by a violinist playing Bach. Sanity had returned to the centre of Copenhagen and the madness had disappeared.

Following two days of intermittent violence between Galatasaray and Arsenal fans, the statistics speak for themselves. Four stabbed, 11 injured, one with a serious head wound and 54 fans arrested.

But this time the English alone cannot be blamed. Sections among both sets of supporters must bear responsibility for the vicious scenes which unfolded.

Once again the old defence that only a minority took part has been raised by police and football officials. Indeed, not all fans were fighting and there were moments of sportsmanship and goodwill, with rival fans swapping scarves and shaking hands.

Trouble first flared early on Wednesday as an army of Galatasaray fans began arriving in the city, outnumbering their Arsenal rivals by almost five to one.

The Turkish fans, singing songs and waving flags, took control of City Hall Square. Most of the Arsenal fans were in four nearby pubs and it quickly became obvious that some among the Turkish contingent were itching for a fight.

A group of Galatasaray fans marched out of the square towards the Bar Absalon, where Arsenal fans were drinking, and once outside, started singing songs and baiting their opponents.

Insults were exchanged but the police appeared reluctant to move in until a bottle flew out of the bar, narrowly missing a Galatasaray fan. The gesture was returned and riot police moved in, only for the mob to break away and turn their venom on other pubs inhabited by Arsenal fans.

The windows of the Scotsman pub on another side of the square were smashed and then fans clashed outside the nearby Rosie McGee pub. Fighting spilled on to the road and Paul Dineen, a 41-year-old Arsenal fan was stabbed.

Riot police eventually moved in and separated the two factions - but it was clear that as far as some Arsenal fans were concerned revenge had to be had.

It came on Wednesday afternoon. Once again, a group of Galatasaray supporters came to a halt outside Bar Absalon. Riot police moved in, quickly pushing them away to one side of the square. The atmosphere was becoming increasingly tense as fans hurled bottles and glasses.

Suddenly a roar ripped across the square and a mob of around 500 Arsenal fans had mounted a carefully orchestrated rearguard attack catching Galatasaray fans, locals and police by surprise.

For around 20 minutes the situation was out of control as rival fans charged at each other, fighting toe to toe and using chairs, tables and metal poles as weapons.

It was a vicious, brutal battle that soon spilled on to surrounding streets as rival mobs charged at each other and some among both groups could be seen wielding knives and clubs.

Not even the firing of tear gas above the heads of the crowd managed to quell them. The screams of innocent people caught up in the trouble could be heard above the roars.

Questions will now be asked as to why the fighting was allowed to spiral out of control, given that Danish police had claimed that they would be mounting one of the biggest security operations in Copenhagen's history.

Danish police were clearly not prepared to deal with troublesome football crowds and were slow to intervene. At the height of the fighting, a line of riot police stood alongside ordinary citizens watching it go on.

Uefa, European football's governing body, also needs to re-examine the staging of major events and ensure proper security measures are in place. The 2,000 police officers the Danes had promised only emerged after the worst of the violence was over.

Galatasaray

webTitle: UN called in to tackle Zimbabwe deadlock

fields.headline: UN called in to tackle Zimbabwe deadlock
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The United Nations yesterday announced it is to intervene to try to break the deadlock between Britain and Zimbabwe in the land dispute.
fields.body:
The United Nations yesterday announced it is to intervene to try to break the deadlock between Britain and Zimbabwe in the land dispute.

The UN move was negotiated behind the scenes during the past few days by the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, who was in London yesterday for talks with Tony Blair.

Mr Blair, anxious to avoid the embarrassment of having the UN adjudicate, denied at a Downing Street press conference that the UN involvement amounted to mediation. Mr Mbeki, who is on a two-day visit to Britain, diplomatically backed him up.

But the United Nations development programme has been called in to investigate the issues at the heart of the dispute between Britain and Zimbabwe: the 1998 British-Zimbabwe agreement on land compensation.

A spokesman for the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, said he hoped the involvement of the UNDP would " help defuse the current confrontation and pave the way for a just and equitable resolution of the problem".

Mr Annan had asked the UNDP to "explore the possibility of helping facilitate a renewed land reform programme in Zimbabwe".

His spokesman added: "The inequitable land ownership patterns have long been a source of political and economic tension in the country."

Most of the fertile land was in the hands of a small number of farmers, many of them white, while the bulk of the rural population was crowded on to small areas of communal land.

The UN aimed for a "mutually acceptable plan of action" that would involve:

 more equitable redistribution of land;

 an adequately funded land purchase programme that would provide compensation at fair market prices;

 a transparent process;

 a commitment to ensuring that the poorest people benefit from the international assistance.

Mr Mbeki has been holding talks with both Mr Annan and the Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe.

Mr Blair paid tribute to Mr Mbeki: "We appreciate Mr Mbeki's quiet diplomacy in this matter. South Africa has a key role to play in using its influence to restore stability to the region."

Mr Mbeki said: "All violence must come to an end. We want a land reform that is beneficial to all Zimbabweans - without conflict or confrontation."

Talks between the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and a delegation of ministers from Zimbabwe ended in failure last month. Mr Cook insisted that Zimbabwe meet various conditions regarded as essential for any land reform programme, in particular respect for law and assurances that it would help the rural poor rather than Mr Mugabe's cronies. In return Britain would provide a £36m aid programme.

The crisis stems directly from illegal seizures of land held by white farmers. The Zimbabwe delegation last month accused Britain of having a colonial attitude and demanded the £36m without conditions. It accused Britain of reneging on the 1998 settlement and insisted Britain must compensate white farmers for land lost in Zimbabwe.

webTitle: Regulators admit defeat over News at Ten

fields.headline: Regulators admit defeat over News at Ten
fields.standfirst: Commission hopes for compromise as ITV is given deadline to rethink proposals to halt slide in viewing figures for evening bulletins
fields.trailText: Television regulators have given up the fight to bring back News at Ten. The independent television commission yesterday rejected ITV's proposals to boost flagging viewing figures for its news bulletins, but has decided not to force the return of the flagship programme.
fields.body:
Television regulators have given up the fight to bring back News at Ten. The independent television commission yesterday rejected ITV's proposals to boost flagging viewing figures for its news bulletins, but has decided not to force the return of the flagship programme.

Instead, the commission gave the channel a month to rethink its plans, and is holding out for ITV to agree a compromise of bringing forward the problematic 11pm news to 10.30pm. The commission is also looking for more cash for regional news, which has suffered a particularly dramatic decline in ratings since News at Ten was scrapped and the schedules rearranged last year.

Sir Robin Biggam, the ITC's chairman, said yesterday: "The ITC attaches great importance to ITV delivering the full range of its public service obligations and we are not convinced that their proposals will deliver the necessary required improvements. This will be ITV's last opportunity to present proposals since the uncertainty cannot be allowed to continue."

A commission source stressed that it recognised the increased commercial pressures that have been placed on ITV in the last year. Sky and ON Digital have been giving away digital television equipment, and the terrestrial channels are suffering from the increased competition. In such an environment, the pressure on ITV to maintain its audience share with top films, drama and documentaries in peak time - the reason why News at Ten was scrapped in the first place - was even greater. "The return of News at Ten is doubtful," the source conceded.

Last month, the regulator expressed grave concern about the decline in ratings for ITV's evening news bulletins, which fell by 13.9% in the 12 months since News at Ten was scrapped. The viewing figures for regional news programmes dropped by 22% in the same period. Then the commission gave ITV a month to come up with a plan to stem the decline.

In its proposals, presented to the commission yesterday, ITV is understood to have pledged up to £20m more for programmes between 9pm and 11pm to increase the audience "inheritance" for the 11pm news.

The commission welcomed the plans for more investment, and it is thought that ITV will now look at boosting the sum, and in particular directing more cash to regional news. Such a move would be greeted positively by the ITC, which next meets on June 22. ITV executives are, however, extremely reluctant to bring forward the Nightly News to 10.30pm, since it would prevent the channel from showing two hour dramas starting at 9pm, and hour-long current affairs shows at 10pm.

ITV has taken legal advice which supports its belief that the commission has no power to dictate where it should schedule its news programmes, and it is understood that the ITC does not want to force the issue. "We don't want to dictate, we don't want to be prescriptive," the commission source said. "We are hopeful that the ITV will come up with a plan that is acceptable."

The axing of News at Ten last year caused a political storm. Tony Blair and the culture secretary, Chris Smith, were unhappy about the move, and the media select committee, chaired by Gerald Kaufman, demanded earlier this year that the bulletin should return.

Former editors and presenters at ITN, which provides ITV's news bulletins, joined the fight.

Mr Kaufman renewed his call to ITV chiefs yesterday: "They have five weeks to come up with new proposals but I don't see how they can come up with proposals that can improve on those they have already put to the ITC. The only answer is to bring back News at Ten and I hope that on June 22 that is what the ITC order them to do."

webTitle: Appeal court bars sterilisation of woman with learning disabilities

fields.headline: Appeal court bars sterilisation of woman with learning disabilities
fields.trailText: The court of appeal yesterday stopped doctors from performing a hysterectomy on a 29-year-old woman with learning disabilities, overturning a decision by a high court judge that the operation could go ahead.
fields.body:
The court of appeal yesterday stopped doctors from performing a hysterectomy on a 29-year-old woman with learning disabilities, overturning a decision by a high court judge that the operation could go ahead.

Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the family division, said: "The patient has the right, if she cannot herself choose, not to have drastic surgery imposed upon her unless or until it has been demonstrated that it is in her best interests."

In what was seen as an important test case, three appeal judges laid down guidance for future cases. They said judges had to decide - looking at the patient's welfare as a whole, not just her medical welfare - what treatment would be in her best interests. It was not enough to declare that a range of treatments would be lawful. The judge had to choose the one which would be best.

The mother of the woman, identified only by her initials SL, wanted the operation. The official solicitor, Laurence Oates, representing SL, argued for a less invasive option: inserting a Mirena coil which reduces menstrual bleeding to little or nothing.

In January, Mr Justice Wall said either treatment would be lawful, and therefore SL's mother could choose.

Mr Oates took the case to appeal, arguing that the judge's decision was against the weight of the medical evidence, which supported the coil. The judge had used the wrong test in not opting for a single treatment as best.

The appeal judges ruled that, in the light of advances in contraception, the less intrusive option of a coil should be tried first. Mr Oates said: "I welcome the greater clarity in the law and practice these judgments have brought for all who have to consider these difficult welfare cases."

SL, who has severe learning difficulties and very limited speech, lives with her mother. She has a younger sister of normal intelligence and a brother with similar problems to her own who lives in sheltered accommodation. Dame Elizabeth said SL's mother "is now about 55 and recognises that she cannot indefinitely care for SL and that her daughter will have to go into accommodation similar to that provided for her son".

Although SL attended a day centre and social club, she was not easy to care for and was prone to irritability and mood swings. "S is an extremely attractive girl who is at present being cared for by her mother who keeps a close watch on her activities and supervises her.

"If she goes into a local authority home there is a risk that she might move unsupervised in mixed circles and might either form a close emotional relationship or be the victim of a sexual assault with the possibility of a pregnancy."

In the high court, Mr Justice Wall was told that SL would not be able to understand pregnancy and would find it frightening and traumatic. She had an obsession with cleanliness and bodily functions and was distressed by her menstrual cycle which she regarded as "dirty".

He accepted her mother's view that a hysterectomy was preferable to fitting a coil which would need replacing from time to time under a general anaesthetic. But Dame Elizabeth said: "The concerns of a caring mother and the problems of dealing with S during her menstrual periods do not, on the facts of this case, tilt the balance towards major irreversible surgery."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Matthew Norman
fields.trailText: Matthew Norman
fields.body:
 Already the Lockerbie trial, currently adjourned but expected to last until next spring, has made a media figure of Andrew Fulton: as "visiting professor of law" with Glasgow University's Lockerbie trial briefing unit, the Prof's trial analyses are widely quoted in British papers, on news wires and on both domestic TV and CNN. This reinvention as a legal authority on a matter with such potent intelligence overtones surprises former colleagues, who remember Andrew Fulton as a very senior officer in - where else? - MI6, an organisation with such a strong interest in the trial's outcome. Blimey. We ring the Prof to ask him to confirm this MI6 background. "I worked for Her Majesty's government as a diplomat for 30 years," he replies equably. Yes, but officers posted to Saigon during the Vietnam war and Berlin at the height of the cold war (like yourself?) are listed officially as Foreign Office staff. So you were 6? "You can ask that, and I can reply, as I have just done, that I worked for HM government." Right, thank you, you carry on being such an impartial visiting professor then, and we'll hear nothing more about 6.

 Speaking of spooks, it's good to know that the old Whitehall gift for circumlocution survives. Asked on the Today programme if he is suprised that former MI5 boss Stella Rimington is writing her memoirs, former cabinet secretary Lord Armstrong - he who admitted to economy with the truth in the Spycatcher trial - replied: "I shouldn't have been surprised if she had decided not to do it." Marvellous.

 After an outing to the wildly popular Tate Modern on the Thames, I am relieved to learn that there is no need to worry about future overcrowding. Managers are keeping a close eye on the numbers, we gather, and at the first sign that they are approaching dangerous levels they will bring in Pierre-Yves Gerbeau from the Dome at once.

 Following Wednesday's item about how - despite a pledge last year to spend the first eight months of this year at Wycliffe Hall, Oxford, preparing for a theology degree - Jonathan Aitken appears not to be at the college after all, we receive a call from Wycliffe principal Alister McGrath. "He's not formally in residence," says Dr McGrath of the old con. "I understand he's undertaking private study at home, but he comes to see us from time to time." That's nice. In his parole statement, Jonathan pledged to "dedicate my life to some form of Christian service" if released early. Whether the odd sherry at Wycliffe qualifies, I think we can turn a blind eye so long as he hands over that £507,000 he stashed away in Monaco from the sale of a house.

 In the Spectator, Stephen Glover turns his attention to myself, and is kind enough to plug a new literary endeavour. Excited by a report in the Times, Steve mentions the play I am writing with one of his own favourite novelists, Ronan Bennett... a New Labour farce set at Chequers, with the working title No (More) Sex Please (news of which may appear here in the year ahead as, touch wood, we move towards a West End first night). With his unerring instinct, Steve assumes the Times report was a spoof, but it is, as Ronan told that paper, in "deadly earnest". Meanwhile, we are engaged in a deconstruction of Steve's column and will have some insights on Tuesday.

 At a recent lunch for Tory ideologues, that doughtiest of section 28 defenders, Baroness Young, was intriguing Roger Scruton and others with the usual malevolent imbecilities about homosexuality "not being natural". Ranting on about being "deluged" by the gay lobby, she spluttered about her one-woman battle against a rising tide of filth. "What I'm trying to say," crescendoed the baroness, "is that it's like I'm sticking my finger in the hole of a large dyke." Much appreciative nodding, of course, and not a single one of them laughed.
