webTitle: Labour peer warns party to beware of 'fixers' tag

fields.headline: Labour peer warns party to beware of 'fixers' tag
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour is in danger of developing an undesirable reputation as political "fixers", a leading Labour peer warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Labour is in danger of developing an undesirable reputation as political "fixers", a leading Labour peer warned yesterday.

Lady Helena Kennedy, a leading QC specialising in human rights and civil liberties and chairwoman of the British Council, cited Labour's problems over the selection of its candidate for London mayor, and its House of Lords reforms.

In an interview for New Statesman magazine, Lady Kennedy said: "I'm good at tuning in to what folk think. My warning to Labour is that, just as sleaze was the downfall of the Conservatives, ours is much more likely to be seen as being fixers." She pointed to the furore over the way Labour chose Frank Dobson as its official candidate for mayor, and its incomplete reforms to the make-up of the House of Lords, as examples of instances which might be interpreted as evidence of a fix-it mentality.

She also criticised the approach of the home secretary, Jack Straw, on race issues. "He is a committed anti-racist. However... he is sometimes influenced in unhelpful ways on issues such as race. You have to be very careful not to create mood music for very unpleasant, atavistic feelings in people. Jack knows this. I've discussed it with him."

fields.headline: Fear grips Glasgow addicts
fields.standfirst:
Dead junkies barely registered on the conscience of Scotland's second city - until 11 died in three weeks

Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: She is starting to rattle, but just one more punter and she can go. It has been a quiet night, she planned to go home ages ago - before the beginnings of the shakes that mean she needs another fix appeared. It will not be long though: another £15 - a blow job - and she will have enough for the smack for her and her man.
fields.body:
She is starting to rattle, but just one more punter and she can go. It has been a quiet night, she planned to go home ages ago - before the beginnings of the shakes that mean she needs another fix appeared. It will not be long though: another £15 - a blow job - and she will have enough for the smack for her and her man.

But tonight Karen is scared. She owes her normal dealer money for some stuff she got on tick last week. She will have to go to someone else. In Glasgow - where the death of another man yesterday means that 11 people have now died, eight of them women, in the past three weeks from a horrific heroin-induced illness - that is something no one wants to do.

"Course I don't want to go to anyone else for my stuff: there's all these women dying," she says. "I've got weans and I've OD'd before. You can be careful about not OD-ing: I know what I'm doing, I'm not exactly new to this. But there's nothing you can do about this. It has shook me up."

Dead junkies barely register on the conscience of Scotland's second city. In some of its worst housing schemes heroin is a more common currency than money, and children are dying of overdoses. It has been like that since the eighties. Some years the death toll spirals - the heroin is too pure or addicts combine it with Temazepam. It merits brief publicity and more well-intentioned strategies. This time, among women addicts at least, it is different.

"It has been mainly women who have been dying and getting sick which, apart from anything else, means lots of children are without their mums," says Iona Colvin, principal addiction officer with the city council. "It's not enough to make them stop using, but there's definitely fear out there."

There is obvious justification for the fear. In Glasgow there are 11 dead, another one in Aberdeen. At least 25 people are ill, some very seriously. The only way to be sure of safety is to quit injecting, start smoking. But that is often too expensive.

The problem surfaced three weeks ago. In the casualty department of a hospital on the southside of the city, two female addicts were being treated for large abscesses - a relatively common symptom for long-term heroin users. The women were treated, routinely, with antibiotics.

Their condition, however, quickly deteriorated. They developed an illness similar to septicaemia and, despite intensive medical intervention, within hours they suffered multiple organ failure and died. Outside the confines of the hospital, other addicts were also falling ill.

In nearby Govanhill, a small southside area, 13 addicts, again mainly women, were struck down with similar abscesses. Only at this point did alarm bells begin ringing among public health officials.

The clues were stark. All those affected were intravenous heroin users. Most had used citric acid bought from the same shop to dissolve the heroin. Many were homeless. Most were women - and women, because of the larger fat covering on their body, are more prone to "skin-popping" than men. Outside of drug-speak, this means they are simply more likely - deliberately or otherwise - to miss veins and inject in their muscles.

An inquiry team set up in response to the outbreak initially concluded a toxin in contaminated citric acid was to blame. But then more people became ill. This time people from across the Clyde in Glasgow's northern Sighthill estate. The only common link was now the heroin; it had to be somehow contaminated.

The smack was sent to various laboratories for testing. Blood samples from those affected were also winged to medical labs, including Porton Down, in Wiltshire.

Laurence Gruer, a senior public health consultant, contacted contemporaries in London and New York. No one had ever heard of addicts dying this way. Then, on Wednesday, it was reported that the anthrax bacterium, the disease used in biological weapons, could be responsible for the deaths.

Scientists at Porton Down confirmed blood samples from two of the victims contained antibodies to anthrax. The disease is relatively common among animals in the far east, where the drug is grown.

The tests, however, were inconclusive and yesterday scientists said anthrax was an increasingly remote possibility. "The contaminated heroin seems to be from one batch and the cases that we have got have come from two areas of Glasgow. That in itself suggests the contamination is more likely to be local rather than from Afghanistan or wherever," says Dr Gruer.

Meanwhile, at the Turning Point Scotland drug crisis centre workers guard a list of the dead. The names have not been made public, but addicts can ask workers if their friends are among them.

Across the city, outside the Inglefield Street hostel for homeless women, the women do not have to ask any questions; they can be sure they knew someone who has died.

"I don't think I'm going to die, but, aye, I'm scared," says Bernie, one of the residents. "If you have an overdose that's one thing, right. But if you get this thing then you know it's not going to be immediate. If you're in a hostel then you've got nowhere to go, no one to go to.

"And, I'm a junkie right, but nobody wants to die on their own."

Some names have been changed.

webTitle: Blowing with the political wind, marching to an unheard drum

fields.headline: Blowing with the political wind, marching to an unheard drum
fields.standfirst:
John Taylor, the heavy hitter causing anxiety to his leader

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: He is the pantomine dame of Northern Ireland politics, a heavyweight operator with a wicked sense of humour and machiavellian adroitness. Trouble is, no one can ever be sure which script John Taylor is using to extemporise.
fields.body:
He is the pantomine dame of Northern Ireland politics, a heavyweight operator with a wicked sense of humour and machiavellian adroitness. Trouble is, no one can ever be sure which script John Taylor is using to extemporise.

Mr Taylor, leader manqué of the Ulster Unionists, was yesterday resisting all appeals to appear shoulder to shoulder with his nominal boss, David Trimble, to sell the Hillsborough proposals. This despite his resounding and vital backing for them 11 days ago.

More than any reason, it was Mr Taylor's growing disquiet about a quick return to devolution which persuaded an exasperated Mr Trimble to delay for a week tomorrow's critical meeting of the Ulster Unionist council. He expressed his reservations often this week, much to the frustration of Trimble loyalists.

One Ulster Unionist said: "When David knows John Taylor is behind him, he doesn't quite know whether he is supporting him or wielding a knife. David always pays tribute to John's support, and recognises its importance, but he is pulling out his hair."

That view echoes a warning the weekend before last, as Mr Taylor, seduced by Tony Blair and Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, spoke warmly of the devolution plan, and then hailed the IRA's statement on arms. He usually prefers to bask in the spotlight until the last minute before declaring his position.

One party member said at the time: "The trouble with John is that when you see him coming over the hill, you never know if he is the cavalry or the Indians. He is an enigma."

One Ulster Unionist delegate said at an earlier council meeting: "He is like a corncrake. You know he is out there. But you never know which field he is in."

And so it is proving. Mr Taylor, known as the weathervane because he moves whichever way the wind is blowing, has speedily shifted in the past fortnight towards the no camp.

He first lowered his initial expectation that the IRA move had a 90% chance of gaining council support for a return to the power sharing government to 60%. By Wednesday, he was asking Mr Mandelson whether it might be easier simply to stick with direct rule.

He was due to miss tomorrow's meeting. He has been absent from previous crucial party summits, also citing parliamentary business.

Insiders suggest Mr Taylor, simply by declaring, can sway 8% of votes at council, vital in such a close contest.

His conversion on the eve of last November's council meeting was a key factor in swaying it for Mr Trimble in agreeing to set up the power-sharing executive with Sinn Fein before IRA decommissioning. He was also vital in Mr Trimble's initial decision to back the Good Friday agreement and in securing council backing for it.

Mr Taylor says his doubts come from the government's failure to spell out what the IRA offer means, plus a lack of clarity on the issues of the RUC and the union flag over Stormont. He denies he was handed a letter of comfort from Mr Mandelson but believes he was let down on the necessary assurances.

Mr Taylor was favourite to succeed James Molyneaux as leader in September 1995. He was by then seen as a moderate, and had the overwhelming support of the media. Republicans privately thought he was the candidate with whom they could best do business.

But he delivered a terrible speech at the election meeting, allowing Mr Trimble, then seen as a hardliner, to come from behind. For a politician who reads the mood in the party so well, he inexplicably appeared to take the ruling council for granted.

A civil engineer, he owns a string of newspapers. He is well off, and critics say politics seems to be more a hobby these days.

In 1972, the Official IRA shot him at point blank range as he was leaving the family civil engineering business in his home town of Armagh. He was hit in the chest, jaw and face. But he quickly recovered.

Over the following years, the ex-Ulster Defence Regiment major gradually moderated and was increasingly seen as a pragmatist.

Now, Mr Taylor insists he holds no ambition to run the party, but he likes everyone to recognise the clout he carries. Because of the deep mistrust he engenders, few believe he will ever lead the party, except perhaps in a caretaker capacity.

webTitle: Vaccines and stress may have led to Gulf war illness

fields.headline: Vaccines and stress may have led to Gulf war illness
fields.trailText: The multiple vaccinations given to protect soldiers from biological weapons during the Gulf war combined with the stress of deployment may be partly responsible for the multiple illnesses veterans have suffered, according to new research.
fields.body:
The multiple vaccinations given to protect soldiers from biological weapons during the Gulf war combined with the stress of deployment may be partly responsible for the multiple illnesses veterans have suffered, according to new research.

Some 5,000 veterans are still suffering from Gulf war syndrome nearly 10 years on, according to John Nichol, president of the Gulf veterans branch of the Royal British Legion, and 500 have died from a variety of causes following ill health brought on, he believes, by their Gulf service. Yesterday he welcomed the results of the study, which he said "reinforce what the veterans themselves have been saying for a number of years".

The symptoms of Gulf war syndrome are many and resemble those of chronic fatigue syndrome. For the purposes of the study, scientists from King's College, London, concentrated on veterans who reported fatigue, muscle pains and problems with concentration and memory.

The study, published in the British Medical Journal, found that veterans with multi-symptom illness were up to five times more likely to have been given a cocktail of five or more vaccinations - including anthrax, plague and pertussis (whooping cough) to activate the immune system against the anthrax - after they had been deployed rather than before they were sent out.

Matthew Hotopf and colleagues from the Gulf war illnesses unit at King's suggest that the stresses of being in the Gulf, which included a change of climate, living conditions, diet, sleeping patterns and physical activity as well as fears for their lives and separation from their families, may have acted with the vaccinations to cause illness.

"It may be that multiple vaccines cause an increased risk of side effects and these reactions - which are usually self-limiting - gain new salience in settings of stress, such as being deployed to the Gulf," says the paper.

The researchers used data from a health survey completed by 3,284 veterans of the Gulf war, but focused on the 923 (28%) who still had their vaccination records from the time.

The researchers could not find any association between vaccines and either the use of pesticides or what they call "traditional military stressors" - such as coming under fire or witnessing death and injury.

"The lack of an association with military stressors does not necessarily indicate that there is no interaction between stress and vaccines," they say.

"Such military stressors may be less important for trained service personnel than the general stress associated with deployment."

Dr Hotopf said yesterday: "We obviously don't claim that this is the end of the story - that we have found a cause of Gulf war illness. We have found one piece in a complicated jigsaw. There are a lot of other health hazards veterans were exposed to."

fields.headline: Tories oppose EU anti-racism directive
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Plans to introduce binding anti-racism laws across the European Union were condemned last night by the Conservatives who claimed that "red tape" would only damage job prospects for members of ethnic minorities.
fields.body:
Plans to introduce binding anti-racism laws across the European Union were condemned last night by the Conservatives who claimed that "red tape" would only damage job prospects for members of ethnic minorities.

As MEPs in Strasbourg voted by 179 to 48 to back a controversial new directive, Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, warned that the measures could do more harm than good.

But the Tories - attacking "gesture politics" by the left - in turn came under furious fire for seeking to derail efforts to tackle racism.

Under the new laws racial harassment and victimisation would be outlawed while sweeping protection against race discrimination in education, employment and in access to grants and scholarships, social protection and social security would be introduced.

Some of the measures, being pushed in response to fears about the rise of rightwing extremism across the continent, already exist in principle in national laws.

But the directive will offer more safeguards and make it easier to bring legal action. "We fully support any measures that will stamp on race hatred and racial abuse," Mr Maude said in a statement.

He added: "Jobs must be won on merit and not race, but we have doubts as to whether this well meaning but muddle-headed directive will be effective.

"As it stands, the directive threatens to damage the job prospects of ethnic minorities. It sends the message that employers who hire ethnic minorities will be faced with more red tape burdens."

Supporters have praised the measures as the most far reaching moves since Britain's 1976 Race Relations Act.

The directive will need the backing of EU ministers who are expected to approve it next month.

Its terms include the reintroduction of an anti-racist measure called "contract compliance" which was outlawed in Britain under the last Conservative government.

It would once more oblige companies to prove that they comply with anti-discrimination law before awarding a contract.

Another controversial feature is the reversal of the burden of proof in civil race discrimination cases.

This would mean the onus would be on the accused to prove their innocence "once the complainant has clearly established facts from which a court or tribunal can presume discrimination."

British Tory MEPs said they were opposing the measure on the grounds that the reverse had "formed one of the foundations of UK law for centuries".

webTitle: Lib Dems challenge low pay claims

fields.headline: Lib Dems challenge low pay claims
fields.trailText: The minimum wage is failing to tackle the gap between rich and poor in Britain, according to new figures released by the Liberal Democrats yesterday which showed that a mere 3% of recipients have been taken off benefits.
fields.body:
The minimum wage is failing to tackle the gap between rich and poor in Britain, according to new figures released by the Liberal Democrats yesterday which showed that a mere 3% of recipients have been taken off benefits.

The Liberal Democrats said at least 250,000 people were still being paid "poverty wages" which have to be topped up by benefits.

Matthew Taylor, the party's treasury spokesman, said: "The government's claims that the minimum wage is tackling poverty are totally exaggerated. People's wages are increasing, but their income isn't."

His remarks came after the government admitted, in a written parliamentary answer, that only 60,000, out of the 2m people who have benefited from the minimum wage, have been removed from social security.

This shows, the Liberal Democrats say, that "several hundred thousand people remain in the poverty trap". But Labour dismissed figures, saying the minimum wage had given 1.5m people a pay rise. However, Labour leftwingers are likely to use the figures to renew their criticism of the government for setting the minimum wage too low. The wage will be increased this year from £3.60 an hour to £3.70.

The Liberal Democrats also challenged the government's claim that the minimum wage encourages people back to work.

In a written parliamentary answer, the Department of Trade and Industry quoted the low pay commission which "found no indication so far of significant effects on the economy as a whole".

Mr Taylor called on the government to embrace the Liberal Democrat policy of cutting the 10p starting income tax rate to zero.

This "would take 1.6m low paid people out of paying tax altogether and ensure that people on the lowest incomes don't have to pay out money they can't afford".

webTitle: Doctors accused of stealing human eggs

fields.headline: Doctors accused of stealing human eggs
fields.trailText: Two leading Israeli fertility experts were under house arrest yesterday amid police investigations into a bizarre trade in human ova, extracted from unsuspecting patients and sold to scores of other women.
fields.body:
Two leading Israeli fertility experts were under house arrest yesterday amid police investigations into a bizarre trade in human ova, extracted from unsuspecting patients and sold to scores of other women.

According to Aryeh Edelman, the Tel Aviv police officer heading the investigation, the gynaecologists would routinely remove extra eggs from the ovaries of patients undergoing fertility treatment, and then use them to offer treatment to a number of other women.

"It was like a factory," he said.

It is uncertain how many women were treated by the doctors - or indeed how many children were born of the ova extracted from the unwitting donors over a four-year period. Mr Edelman said the donors would prefer not to know. However, he confirmed that all of the ova were transferred to women in Israel.

Some of the donors had no idea that the doctors were harvesting extra eggs; others were offered discounts of up to 10,000 shekels (£1,600) on their fertility treatment in return for the donations, Mr Edelman said.

"Some of them were willing to donate, but they had no idea of the results of this act. They thought they were giving eggs only to one woman or two. What they did not know was that the eggs were going to 10 or 12 women," Mr Edelman said.

Israeli law bars women from donating ova unless they are undergoing fertility treatment, and there is a severe shortage of human eggs at clinics.

All the donors interviewed by police were themselves undergoing fertility treatment and collecting eggs for in vitro fertilisation or other means of medically assisted pregnancy. The doctors' actions could have undermined their own efforts to have children because their ova were donated elsewhere.

There are also concerns about the hormones used by the doctors to stimulate the production of ova.

One of the doctors, Zion Ben-Rafael, is a leading fertility expert, and heads the gynaecology department of the Rabin Medical Centre at Petah Tikva in central Israel.

Mr Ben-Rafael and Ya'akov Ashkenazi, who works in the in vitro fertility treatment centre at the Sharon hospital in the same town, are under house arrest until Monday while police gather further evidence to press charges of fraud, breach of trust, and possibly, endangering the health of their patients.

According to police, the doctors conducted all of their unauthorised harvesting of ova at the private clinics they attend after hours.

Although they are allowed to continue their practices, they must now perform all medical procedures under police supervision.

For some bio-ethicists, the revelations of a traffic in hu man ova in Israel comes as little surprise. In the early days of the Jewish state, couples were exhorted to have large families as part of their religious and patriotic duty - and were paid a handsome bonus for their 10th child.

Pressure to have one's own children remains intense. Israel has the highest rate of fertility treatments in the world - and its national health system is exceedingly generous to couples seeking assisted pregnancies.

Fertility treatment is unrestricted and remains entirely free until a woman gives birth to her second child. In contrast, contraception is not available free of charge, and access to abortion is restricted.

However, many women, including the patients of the two accused doctors, still opt to go private.

"I think there is tremendous stress on fertility and making women feel they really have not fulfilled their social and societal role if they have not had children," said Alice Shalvi, a representative of the Israel Women's Network.

She added: "There is a lot of pressure on couples to do everything in their power to have children of their own rather than adopting. Obviously these doctors were cashing in on this, knowing that they had a market for ova."

"Some of them went to a public hospital and when the doctors saw that those women are capable of giving many eggs, they persuaded them to go to private hospital to donate," Mr Edelman said. "Some of them were suffering very much with the doctors taking out the many eggs."

fields.headline: Serial killer 'not mad'
fields.trailText: A serial killer claiming to be an "angel of God", who murdered his victims as he drifted around the US railway network, faced the death penalty yesterday after a Texas jury rejected his plea of insanity.
fields.body:
A serial killer claiming to be an "angel of God", who murdered his victims as he drifted around the US railway network, faced the death penalty yesterday after a Texas jury rejected his plea of insanity.

Angel Maturino Resendiz, a Mexican immigrant worker, showed no emotion as the jury convicted him of the murder of Claudia Benton, a Houston doctor who was bludgeoned and stabbed to death in 1998.

Prosecutors said they would seek the death penalty on the grounds that the killing was aggravated by rape and robbery, making it a "capital murder" under Texas law.

His killing spree, which began in 1997, spread panic across the country as victims turned up near railway tracks.

Dubbed the "railroad killer", Resendiz was briefly on the FBI's 10 most wanted list until he surrendered last July.

Confronted with a wealth of physical evidence, defence lawyers admitted he had killed Benton, 39, as well as eight other people. The defence had asked jurors to find him innocent of capital murder by reason of insanity.

His lawyers had shown the jury letters Resendiz had written, in which he claimed to be an "angel of God" possessing supernatural powers. They said that he believed his victims were all "evil and deserved to die".

webTitle: US expert says 'Son of Star Wars' does not work

fields.headline: US expert says 'Son of Star Wars' does not work
fields.trailText: A top American scientist accused Pentagon officials and defence contractors yesterday of deliberately trying to hoax the US government and the public about the effectiveness of America's planned national missile defence (NMD) system.
fields.body:
A top American scientist accused Pentagon officials and defence contractors yesterday of deliberately trying to hoax the US government and the public about the effectiveness of America's planned national missile defence (NMD) system.

An analysis of the Pentagon's test-flight data claims to show that the US's planned anti-missile interceptor system is incapable of distinguishing between a missile and a decoy, a former defence department adviser said.

Assertions that the US would be able to protect its citizens against incoming enemy missiles by taking them out with interceptors cannot be sustained on the basis of the data from the current US test programme, Professor Theodore Postol of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology says.

If Mr Postol is correct, President Clinton's decision later this summer about whether to go ahead with the $60bn (£40bn) NMD project will be taken on unreliable scientific evidence, and the anti-missile system which the US would install might not work.

The potentially devastating charges against NMD come as Nato foreign ministers prepare to debate the US plan at a summit in Italy next week. Currently, no Nato member state other than the US favours the system.

Mr Postol, who was scientific adviser to the Pentagon's chief of naval operations under President Ronald Reagan from 1982 to 1984, says that the data from the first of four NMD system tests prove that the anti-missile interceptor "will be defeated by the simplest of balloon decoys".

In that test, which took place in June 1997 and involved a "fly-by" by an interceptor, the interceptor was unable to differentiate between warheads and balloon decoys.

The Pentagon's Ballistic Missile Defence Organisation (BMDO) and its contractors subsequently "attempted to hide this fact" by tampering with the data and by changing subsequent tests to obscure "programme-stopping facts", Mr Postol charged in a letter sent to the White House on May 11.

Later tests, including the scheduled June 26 test on the basis of which Mr Clinton is due to make his deployment decision, have consisted only of a warhead and a single, intensely illuminated balloon decoy. This has enabled the interceptor to make a simple differentiation between the two objects and has allowed the Pentagon to claim that its test programme has been more successful than it really has been, Mr Postol says.

"It is an elaborate hoax. It appears to be a piece of science when in fact it is just mumbo-jumbo," Mr Postol said yesterday "It is a pretty coordinated fraud between the BMDO and its contractors. The system is not in any way workable. If an adversary deployed a bunch of aluminium balloons, the interceptor would not be able to tell which was the missile."

The letter called for additional analysis of the NMD system by independent scientists.

A White House spokesman said that it was premature to create an outside review of the NMD test programme. A spokesman for the BMDO said that a detailed written response to Mr Postol's charges was being prepared.

President Clinton has said that the decision to deploy NMD - which is bitterly opposed by almost every government in the world, including Russia, China and, less vocally, the United Kingdom - will depend upon four factors: whether it works, what it will cost, whether it is judged necessary, and its impact upon international arms control.

While it would be difficult for Mr Clinton to deploy the NMD system if it was shown not to work, the political imperatives of a US election year may compel him to do so.

webTitle: Channel 4 thinks about privatising its subsidiaries

fields.headline: Channel 4 thinks about privatising its subsidiaries
fields.trailText: Channel 4, long a fierce opponent of its own privatisation, yesterday admitted that it may seek stock market flotations for some of its commercial operations, such as the pay television business FilmFour.
fields.body:
Channel 4, long a fierce opponent of its own privatisation, yesterday admitted that it may seek stock market flotations for some of its commercial operations, such as the pay television business FilmFour.

The organisation opened the door to raising funds in the City as it detailed plans to invest up to £100m in the launch of E4, its digital entertainment channel, later this year.

The broadcaster is committing an increasing amount of cash to commercial interests and also intends to set up a dedicated horse racing channel and a clutch of online services, including one aimed at the gay community.

FilmFour has 300,000 subscribers but lost £20m last year and is not targeted to break even until 2003.

Michael Jackson, Channel 4 chief executive, said there were no immediate plans to float any of the commercial enterprises, but conceded that the organisation was "open to the possibility".

He said: "Have we got all the resources to do everything we would like to? The answer is clearly no. With some parts, particularly joint ventures, the option of taking subsidiaries [to the market] may be a good one."

Chairman Vanni Treves added: "Five years ago it was beyond contemplation that we would be where we are today. Goodness knows where we will be five years from now."

Channel 4 has come under criticism from commercial rivals for being allowed to use funds raised from its public service to compete in pay TV and the internet. Publication of Channel 4's annual report yesterday showed a 7% increase last year in advertising and sponsorship revenues to £600m, producing profits of £46m, up from £26.3m in 1998.

Although primary legislation would be needed to allow a change in status to Channel 4 itself, the broadcaster would not need permission to float subsidiaries. Mr Treves said the organisation's stand against privatisation of the main channel remained implacable.

E4, which is likely to be a joint venture with one or more other media companies, will be used as the platform for the first run of Friends and ER, the US shows for which Channel 4 paid £120m last year.

The horse racing pay TV channel is likely to be set up with the BBC and cable company NTL as partners, assuming their negotiations for exclusive rights to screen the "Super 12" courses are sealed.

Mr Treves also conceded that motivation of senior management was an issue facing Channel 4 amid the pervasive culture of share options. The annual report disclosed that Mr Jackson's salary last year was £494,000.

"There are three things we need to be aware of - motivation of management, creation of joint ventures with commercial partners, and flotation of subsidiaries, which still has to be a way off," Mr Treves said.

"If you take the racing channel as an example, it could be massively successful and our partners could say, 'We are sitting on a tonne of money, what can we do to get at it? One thing is to float it'. It would be irrational and stupid to say that was impossible."

Channel 4 has come under criticism from commercial rivals for being allowed to use funds raised from its public service to compete in pay TV and the internet. Publication of Channel 4's annual report yesterday showed a 7% increase last year in advertising and sponsorship revenues to £600m, producing profits of £46m, up from £26.3m in 1998. Although primary legislation would be needed to allow a change in status to Channel 4 itself, the broadcaster would not need permission to float subsidiaries. Mr Treves said the organisation's stand against privatisation of the main channel remained implacable. E4, which is likely to be a joint venture with one or more other media companies, will be used as the platform for the first run of Friends and ER, the US shows for which Channel 4 paid £120m last year. The horse racing pay TV channel is likely to be set up with the BBC and cable company NTL as partners, assuming their negotiations for exclusive rights to screen the "Super 12" courses are sealed. Mr Treves also conceded that motivation of senior management was an issue facing Channel 4 amid the pervasive culture of share options. The annual report disclosed that Mr Jackson's salary last year was £494,000. "There are three things we need to be aware of - motivation of management, creation of joint ventures with commercial partners, and flotation of subsidiaries, which still has to be a way off," Mr Treves said. "If you take the racing channel as an example, it could be massively successful and our partners could say, 'We are sitting on a tonne of money, what can we do to get at it? One thing is to float it'. It would be irrational and stupid to say that was impossible."

webTitle: Civil rights leader hits at delay on Shayler offer

fields.headline: Civil rights leader hits at delay on Shayler offer
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: David Shayler proposed a deal, supported by the police special branch, whereby the renegade MI5 officer would return voluntarily to Britain so long as he was granted bail, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
David Shayler proposed a deal, supported by the police special branch, whereby the renegade MI5 officer would return voluntarily to Britain so long as he was granted bail, it was revealed yesterday.

The offer, made four months ago, is disclosed in a letter written yesterday by John Wadham, director of the civil rights group Liberty, and Mr Shayler's lawyer, to Roland Phillips, the Treasury solicitor in charge of the case.

Mr Wadham made the offer at a meeting in January with Mr Phillips and officials from the attorney general's office and the crown prosecution service.

"I said that given the fact that he was going to return voluntarily I saw no reason why, subject to any conditions the court might impose, he should not be given bail."

Mr Wadham adds: " I know that this was the view also taken by the special branch officer in charge of the case and wanted some reassurance that this would be the view taken by the authorities and he would be treated fairly".

He also sought an assurance that Mr Shayler would only be charged under the Official Secrets Act with alleged disclosures that were actually reported in the media. These would include MI6 knowledge of a plot to assassinate the Libyan president, Muammar Gadafy, and MI5 activities surrounding IRA attacks in Britain and the 1994 bombing of the Israeli embassy in London.

Mr Shayler is also alleged to have taken a number of documents from MI5 when he first disclosed information about the agency's activities - in cluding the holding of files on government ministers - in 1997 to the Mail on Sunday. The newspaper has since returned the documents to MI5.

Mr Phillips told Mr Wadham earlier this year that Whitehall was "considering the proposals" and "meetings are continuing".

With no response forthcoming, Mr Wadham asked for a meeting with the attorney general, Lord Williams. He was told a meeting was "not necessary or appropriate".

Mr Wadham said yesterday: "I've spent years trying to negotiate a sensible settlement in this case. The only way I can characterise the government's approach is, all the lights are on but no one's at home."

Whitehall agencies - including the Home Office, MI5, MI6, the special branch, and the attorney general's office - are engaged in an intense debate about how to handle the Shayler case.

An equally intense argument is taking place in Whitehall about how to respond to the decision by Dame Stella Rimington, the former head of MI5, to write her memoirs.

In a separate development yesterday, Richard Tomlinson, the former MI6 officer previously jailed for sending a book synopsis to an Australian publisher, told the Guardian that two British special branch officers, accompanied by Italian police, had taken all his personal computers, mobile phone and address book and refused to allow him to take a copy of the information in them.

He said from his hotel in Rimini that the police claimed he was "dealing with Russian intelligence".

Mr Tomlinson has been negotiating with a Moscow publisher about a book - not, he insists, about his time in MI6, but about how he was being hounded across Europe by the British police.

webTitle: Britain steps out of line on incinerators

fields.headline: Britain steps out of line on incinerators
fields.trailText: Europe is moving to phase out the building of huge incinerators just as Britain is planning a new chain across the country as part of the government's waste strategy, Ludwig Kraemer, head of the EU waste management directorate, revealed last night.
fields.body:
Europe is moving to phase out the building of huge incinerators just as Britain is planning a new chain across the country as part of the government's waste strategy, Ludwig Kraemer, head of the EU waste management directorate, revealed last night.

"In France, Belgium, Holland, Italy, Germany and Portugal no more new incinerators are being built because the public will not stand for them.

"They are treated in the same way as nuclear power stations - people no longer want them," he said.

Mr Kraemer said concerns about public health and traffic congestion and pollution caused by the lorries required to deliver hundreds of thousands of tons of waste to each incinerator had turned the public against them.

"Once they are built we are talking about creating waste streams for the next 25 years to keep the incinerators going," he said.

His warning follows revelations from the United States that Britain's new generation of incinerators could pose a cancer threat to local residents.

Mr Kraemer's comments will put more pressure on Michael Meacher, the environment minister, to justify plans to build incinerators across the country.

He is already under pressure from the Downing Street policy unit and the Cabinet Office to modify a policy that could cost Labour votes in its heartland seats and among many of the people who switched to Labour in the south-east of England.

Mr Meacher yesterday ordered the early publication of the government's revised waste strategy after a last minute tussle with his civil servants over increasing the amount of recycling programmes at the expense of planned incinerators.

Civil servants have been lobbied by the waste industry to increase incineration, but Mr Meacher secured last minute changes before the paper went to the printers.

Mr Kraemer, who oversees waste policies across the EU, said he hoped Britain would adopt recycling as its main way to dispose of waste. At present 70% of Britain's waste is dumped in landfill sites and less than 9% is recycled.

Britain's proposals are expected to split the disposal of waste three ways - through landfill dumps, recycling and burning .

fields.headline: Former archbishop of Canterbury dies
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Lord Coggan, a former archbishop of Canterbury, died on Wednesday at the age of 90, the Church of England announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Lord Coggan, a former archbishop of Canterbury, died on Wednesday at the age of 90, the Church of England announced yesterday.

He received a life peerage on his retirement in 1980. He was a Cambridge-educated theologian and academic, seen by some during his five years at Canterbury as a remote figure, out of touch with the modern church. He was the last archbishop to have been previously also archbishop of York.

The present archbishop, George Carey, said from Canada where he is on a visit: "Dr Donald Coggan's death at the age of 90 brings to an end an illustrious ministry as a distinguished Hebrew scholar, devoted pastor and dedicated archbishop.

"He will be remembered particularly for his remarkable contribution to the New English Bible and the Revised English Bible and for his unfailing support for the Council for Christians and Jews."

Apart from a period as a curate in 1930s Islington, north London, Lord Coggan was always an academic, spending most of the war as a professor in Canada before returning to become principal of the London College of Divinity in 1944. He was appointed bishop of Bradford in 1956, and archbishop of York in 1961.

In Monica Furlong's book, C of E, The State It's In, Derek Pattinson, formerly the church's chief civil servant, described Lord Coggan as an old man in a hurry who could not delegate: "His was the world of sung matins and very formal pre-war evangelicalism... he was a good preacher, a deeply honest man and he carried off public occasions well."

fields.headline: Lord Coggan of Canterbury
fields.standfirst:
Archbishop who revived morale within the church of England, opened a dialogue with Rome and supported women's ordination

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Lord Coggan, the former Archbishop of Canterbury, who has died at the age of 90 after a long illness, was (until George Carey) the first 20th-century Cantuar who enjoyed, or suffered, the label of being an evangelical. He was also one of the most sagacious, uncompromising and punctilious archbishops of All England, a quiet-mannered family man who wore the purple amethyst on his ring finger humbly.
fields.body:
Lord Coggan, the former Archbishop of Canterbury, who has died at the age of 90 after a long illness, was (until George Carey) the first 20th-century Cantuar who enjoyed, or suffered, the label of being an evangelical. He was also one of the most sagacious, uncompromising and punctilious archbishops of All England, a quiet-mannered family man who wore the purple amethyst on his ring finger humbly.

His primacy, from 1974 to 1980, although comparatively short in years, revived the morale of the church of England without arresting its statistical decline. He gave new impetus within the worldwide Anglican communion; initiated vigorous attempts to unify, or at least bring closer together, churches of different confessions; and made a series of bold, if naive, attempts to evangelise the nation.

Coggan's disciplined and distinctive primatial style was heightened from its outset by the contrast it set when compared with that of his immediate predecessor, the Rt Rev Michael (later Lord) Ramsey. A visibly spiritual figure, whose white hair was in the clouds while his feet seemed more at home in carpet slippers, Ramsey spent 13 years trying to avoid administration. Coggan, whose dedication was equally transparent, was the scholarly theologian with a tape recorder handy for prompt dictation, and a meticulousness equal to that of any company director.

His first meeting with the media, on a spring day in 1974 as the 101st primate-elect, was typical. Shortly before going into Church House, Westminster, he knew he would be questioned closely about being only a "caretaker primate." After all, he was already 65, and, at most, could serve little more than five years, according to the church of England's new laws.

Coggan saw the significance, excused himself and took a purposeful stroll beneath the trees. He returned with a well-phrased reply for the waiting journalists. Yes, he said, taking "caretaker" at its broadest meaning, he would regard it as an honour to take care of his beloved church for five or whatever number of years.

So it was that his primacy was distinguished by good, if not altogether fulfilled, intentions. Throughout, he re-emphasised and reaffirmed the importance of the parochial ministry as the bedrock of the church of England's ties with the English people. He sought, as a priority, to strengthen and encourage the Anglican family, 65m souls around the globe, uncertain at that time of the way it was travelling and with whom.

Coggan's primacy was, in fact, a turning point for the Anglican communion. A Lambeth conference, the gathering of the communion's bishops every 10 years, was due. An indefatigable host, he broke with precedent and led the spiritual elders into secret conclave on a Canterbury hilltop - up till then they had met in London and in public. Real and deep anxieties were aired.

If his time on the throne of St Augustine had a flaw, it was simply that Coggan often seemed to be an archbishop in a hurry. Certainly, his translation from the archbishopric of York had left him with little time. He was also obviously - and early - influenced by what he saw of the world. Even then, it seemed to many to be rushing to the point of exhaustion, weighed down by over-population and depleting natural resources, and failing to bridge the gap between the rich and poor.

Coggan's Call To The Nation (1975), which grew out of his earlier Call To The North, written while he was still at York, was brave, but sociologically ill-prepared and verbally uninspired. It never fulfilled its potential. Nevertheless, it stirred 28,000 ordinary people to write to Lambeth palace about the way of life they most desired. They included those who addressed the primate as "Dear Lord," and some others as "Your Grace, Chief Godman." The nationwide initiative in evangelism, another of his personally inspired outreach projects, showed similar faults.

But Coggan had an ecclesiastical courage which owed nothing to naivety. In 1977, for example, on the Pope's own patch in Rome, he jettisoned all diplomacy and called for inter-communion between the Anglican and Roman Catholic churches. His plea was uncharacteristically spectacular.

He took another such stance a year later when he preached in Westminster cathedral. This time, out of courtesy to his close friend across the Thames, Cardinal Basil Hume, Coggan made his text known to him in advance.

But each time, he knowingly stirred the brethren, some to react in an unbrotherly way, in pursuit of his deep desire for the reunion of Christendom. He attended the enthronement in 1978 of Pope John Paul II, the first archbishop of Canterbury to be present at such a ceremony since the reformation.

He was a strong - and early - supporter of the ordination of women; indeed, he proposed the reform at the Lambeth conference in 1970. Reaching out to other faiths, he will also be remembered for his support for the Council of Christians and Jews.

Donald Coggan was born in Highgate, north London, educated at Merchant Taylors' school, Northwood, Middlesex, and St John's College, Cambridge, and was in his mid-teens when the call to be ordained came to him.

The orderliness, which was to characterise his ministry, immediately began to show itself. Instead of reading theology straight away, he chose to equip himself with an adequate background for studying the Bible by reading oriental languages. He found Hebrew and Syriac to his liking, and excelled in both. It followed naturally that his first position, from 1931 to 1934, was as a lecturer in semitic languages and literature at Manchester University.

Ordained into the priesthood in 1935 - the same year that he married - his first curacy, at St Mary's, Islington, had a moving effect on him. Coggan always maintained that he learned much, both of life itself and of the meaning of ministry, during his three years amid the poverty, unemployment and inadequate housing of that part of inner north London in those prewar days. He would have made a superb parish priest, but he found the call of college work irresistible.

Coggan went to Canada in 1937 as professor of New Testament at Wycliffe College, Toronto. He returned to England in 1944 as principal of the London College of Divinity, and stayed for 12 strenuous years to re-establish the status, as well as the buildings, of the famous evangelical college. In 1956, he was appointed bishop of Bradford. He was enthroned as archbishop of York in 1961, and completed 18 creative years in the north before his translation to Canterbury. He retired in 1980, when he was made a life peer, surrounded by honour and affection.

In the years between 1944 and 1997, he had also found time to write more than 20 books, ranging from studies in theology to evangelical tracts and biographies of the saints. His last book, Meet Paul: An Encounter With The Apostle, was published in 1997.

Coggan had preached more sermons and travelled more miles than any other of his predecessors. Yet his term demonstrated once more that no man, however gifted, can be expected to excel in four jobs at the same time: bishop of the diocese of Canterbury; metropolitan of the province of Canterbury; titular head of the Anglican communion; and chief chaplain to the mixed pickles of church and state.

Throughout his primacy, his wholesome humanity ran like a golden thread from start to finish of his ministry. "The joy of being a priest," Coggan once said, "is that your work never ends until they carry you out. Then another begins - that's elsewhere."

He is survived by his wife, Jean, and two daughters, Ruth and Anne.

 The Rt Rev Dr (Frederick) Donald Coggan, Lord Coggan of Canterbury and Sissinghurst, cleric, born October 9 1909; died May 17 2000

 Baden Hickman, the Guardian's former churches correspondent, prepared this obituary before his own death earlier this year. It has been revised

fields.headline: Property millionaire fined for contempt
fields.trailText: Nicholas van Hoogstraten, 55, the property millionaire notorious for his forthright views, has described ramblers wishing to use a footpath across his East Sussex estate as "perverts". When he picked on a barrister, however, it was a costly mistake.
fields.body:
Nicholas van Hoogstraten, 55, the property millionaire notorious for his forthright views, has described ramblers wishing to use a footpath across his East Sussex estate as "perverts". When he picked on a barrister, however, it was a costly mistake.

Yesterday he was fined £1,500 at Hove crown court for contempt of court after calling Graham Campbell "a dirty bastard" during a case last year. He has a fortune in excess of £200m and the fine should be affordable, but that did not stop him calling the penalty extortionate.

"There is one law for the rich and one for the poor," he said.

His ill chosen observation came while he was successfully defending a writ from seven tenants who claimed he had stopped them buying the freeholds to their homes.

The millionaire, who also has homes in Cannes, Monte Carlo and Florida, said to Mr Campbell: "You dirty bastard ... in due course you are going to have it."

Commenting on his return from Zimbabwe, where he owns 1m acres and is a financial backer of Robert Mugabe, he said: "If I was not a multi-millionaire I would not have been fined at all."

Commenting on his return from Zimbabwe, where he owns 1m acres and is a financial backer of Robert Mugabe, he said: "If I was not a multi-millionaire I would not have been fined at all."

webTitle: UN experiments with one-year arms embargo

fields.headline: UN experiments with one-year arms embargo
fields.standfirst: Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: The UN security council imposed a one-year arms embargo on Ethiopia and Eritrea yesterday in an attempt to force an end to the conflict.
fields.body:
The UN security council imposed a one-year arms embargo on Ethiopia and Eritrea yesterday in an attempt to force an end to the conflict.

Placing a time limit on sanctions is an innovation for the UN. The resolution, agreed after three days of horse-trading, is a French compromise between the US and British wish for an indefinite ban and Russia and China's opposition to any embargo. The vote was unanimous.

Nancy Soderberg, the deputy US ambassador, said: "I think it sends an unequivocal and strong message to the parties to bring an end to this conflict."

The ban covers the sale and supply of weapons, ammunition, military vehicles, equipment and spare parts and the provision of training and technical aid.

It has no immediate impact on British arms trade, as an EU ban has been in place since last year.

It will be terminated as soon as the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, reports that "a peaceful definitive settlement of the conflict" has been concluded.

The compromise was born of the concern of some council members about the sanctions on Iraq, now in their 10th year.

Eritrea and Ethiopia both denounced the ban. The Eritreans said it was unfair because Ethiopia was the aggressor. The Ethiopian spokesman said it was "wrong and meaningless."

The ban will have little practical effect in the short term, other than sending a message to both countries that the UN is concerned about the serious consequences for regional stability.

Russia, which had been supplying arms to both sides, objected that diplomatic means had not been exhausted, but backed down when the compromise was offered.

At Russia's request, the resolution calls for a representative from the Organisation of African Unity to visit the area to try to secure a peace deal.

Eritrea will agree to a ceasefire only if both sides pull back to their original positions on the disputed border. Ethiopia wants a peace deal agreed before a ceasefire.

The resolution regretted that the diversion of resources to the conflict was affecting efforts to address the region's food crisis.

fields.headline: Ethiopia scents victory in 'senseless' war
fields.standfirst:
The cost is huge and the concept of sovereignty meaningless to the dead and captive

Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: Usually the eyes go first. Bloated and now stinking corpses are scattered by the roadside and birds have begun to feast on them.
fields.byline: David Gough in Ethiopian occupied Eritrea
fields.body:
Usually the eyes go first. Bloated and now stinking corpses are scattered by the roadside and birds have begun to feast on them. You notice the smell soon after passing the trench from which the Ethiopians launched the offensive which gave them control yesterday of the western battle front with Eritrea.

More than 200,000 Eritreans are now in flight after the fall of the strategic town of Barentu, which they had occupied since May 1998.

The effort expended by two of Africa's poorest countries on this fruitless border war is enormous. An hour-long flight in an Ethiopian army helicopter, feet above tree level, reveals mile after mile of deserted trenches, with no signs of life and little sign of battle. Behind the lines, years of drought have left millions facing starvation.

But Ethiopia says that recapturing lost territory comes first. "Sovereignty is not a luxury for the rich alone," said Meles Zenawi, the prime minister, who last month appealed for 800,000 tons of emergency food aid.

Boxes of ammunition, heavy machine guns, rocket-propelled grenades and empty Coca-Cola cases litter the small military camps which the Eritrean army clearly evacuated in a hurry.

Along the roadside the advancing Ethiopians have tied red ribbons to the trees as a warning of land mines. tens of thousands have been planted since the war broke out. Ethiopian T-55 tanks are careful not to stray from the dust track that passes for a road.

Ethiopian troops, on leave from the front, mill around the town of Tokombia, which they captured on Saturday and have been looting ever since. The thousands of empty beer bottles are perhaps the clearest sign that the army feels it is on the verge of victory.

Colonel Ghebre Kidan of the Ethiopian army said the capture of Barentu had cut the Eritrean supply lines and had effectively ended the war on the western front.

But his aim of "ensuring that this invading army is never capable of occupying our territory again" seems a more distant objective.

There remain the central Zalambessa front and the eastern Bure front, both of which have seen heavy fighting in the past few days.

The offensive began on Friday, just days after the US ambassador to the UN, Richard Holbrooke, completed the latest of a series of efforts by African and western leaders and diplomats to end the conflict peacefully.

In a show of strength and a test of political will, the Eritrean forces pushed into Ethiopia in May 1998 as relations between the two former allies deteriorated because of economic differences.

Eritrea did not plan for the disaster that has since unfolded in a bitter conflict which has divided families and friends and cost both countries hundreds of millions of pounds, tens of thousands of lives, and a significant loss of standing in the international community.

Ethiopian officials, not known for their candour, are now openly giddy with their troops' success in the past few days.

They now control large swaths of southern Eritrea, and hope that this offensive will put an end to the war, put Eritrea in its place, and let their countries restart their much needed development.

The international community was swift to condemn the latest outbreak of fighting, calling it a "senseless war", and gave both parties 72 hours to end hostilities or face sanctions.

That call went unheeded and the United Nations, blighted by a string of recent peacekeeping failures in Africa, has now imposed a one-year arms embargo on both countries.

But that may be too late. Both sides have embarked on costly rearmament programmes since the war began, and an Ethiopian spokesman said yesterday: "We are now getting all the weapons we need from the defeated Eritrean forces.

In Ethiopian held Eritrea, an Eritrean MiG-29 screamed through the sound barrier, firing flares to distract heat-seeking missiles before dropping its load close to an Ethiopian artillery battery and a small group of western journalists.

Ethiopian sources said later that the plane had been shot down soon after releasing its bombs.

But for now thousands of Eritrean prisoners of war like Michaele Stefanos must await the outcome of the war before they know their fate.

When the fighting began two years ago Mr Stefanos was a student in the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa. In March he was deported because he is Eritrean, and when he arrived back in Eritrea he was conscripted into the army, because he is young and fit.

He said that he was glad to have been captured, that he had never wanted to fight, and that he still did not understand what thousands of young men and women were dying for. "From now on I never want to see another bullet again."

fields.headline: Head in the clouds
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Kevin McCloud is an interior designer. Once, on Home Front, he taught us all about the different kinds of light we could use in our homes and which colours go with which, with use of a "colour wheel". He writes books too - about lights and colours - but they are of the kind that you flick through in a bookshop cafe (taking notes if necessary) but don't actually buy. A few weeks back, he was on the front of the Radio Times in its embarrassing Vanity Fair rip-off gatefold cover of Ones To Watch during the spring. Wes Bentley, he ain't. Which isn't to say Kevin is rubbish. He isn't. Actually, he's a jolly chap who isn't half as annoying as Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen, and nowhere near as flouncy. Yet none of this explains why he was climbing the Forth Bridge last night.
fields.body:
Kevin McCloud is an interior designer. Once, on Home Front, he taught us all about the different kinds of light we could use in our homes and which colours go with which, with use of a "colour wheel". He writes books too - about lights and colours - but they are of the kind that you flick through in a bookshop cafe (taking notes if necessary) but don't actually buy. A few weeks back, he was on the front of the Radio Times in its embarrassing Vanity Fair rip-off gatefold cover of Ones To Watch during the spring. Wes Bentley, he ain't. Which isn't to say Kevin is rubbish. He isn't. Actually, he's a jolly chap who isn't half as annoying as Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen, and nowhere near as flouncy. Yet none of this explains why he was climbing the Forth Bridge last night.

The only explanation for Don't Look Down (BBC2) was provided by Kevin, who said he didn't like heights and so, as a 40th birthday present to himself, decided to climb some of the country's highest buildings and landmarks. Why he didn't go out and have an affair like any normal man having a midlife crisis, he doesn't say, but perhaps that wouldn't have made a very good series. (Certainly, it wouldn't have lent itself to swooping helicopter shots and grand pseudo-poetic moments about magnificient erections).

Instead, as Kevin climbs (Kevin Climbs would have been a much better title; it doesn't leave you with the lingering thought that a dwarf in a red anorak might turn up), he treats us to a history of the Forth Bridge, engineering marvel that it is, and the impact it's had on the surrounding communities.

For the most part, it worked well, being both educational and fun - especially when Kevin took tottering baby steps along some really wobbly planks as the wind and rain swirled round him. With little demonstrations of How The Bridge Works, the series is surely an attempt to make architecture more accessible to the masses, but with a bit too much of a schools programme feel about it - it goes a baby step too far in its Idiot's Guide To Big Buildings. And still, why Kevin? Next week: Anne McKevitt goes in search of the world's deadliest snakes.

Dr Chen's Sex Revolution (BBC2) charted China's foremost sex doctor's mission to give the masses a much-need sex education. An insight into the most delicate of matters in a country famed for its inscrutableness, it juxtaposed the poignant and the bizarre. Forty-year-old men spoke like teenagers in awe of their bodies as they sat in a line sheathed in Dr Chen's "patented genital apparatus". The good doctor displayed his collection of genital-shaped stones before displaying his business card, complete with winged pop-up penis. Cao Yuping, Chen's cleaning lady, explained how shocked she was, as a country girl, that city folks held hands in public, before she read patients' notes and realised the wide horizon of sexual experience.

Chairman Mao and the horrific repression of the Cultural Revolution got the blame for Dong Qian's anxiety-induced progressive impotence and premature ejaculation (and having the cleaner reading his notes won't have helped), but after 10 sessions with his genitals in apparatus, he could once again get an erection. Dr Chen advised him not to have sex for a while (and not to tell Kevin McCloud either), and sent him to the marital aid department of a chemist instead. Just past the sign for "Pudendum Cleaning Aerosol", (I kid you not) he bought his wife a vibrator which resembled one of those vegetable-chopping devices they sell on QVC. "It needs batteries," the sales assistant said. It needed locking up, by the looks of it.

These weird moments aside - when the Chinese appeared a lot less repressed than us - Dr Chen's Sex Revolution was a sensitive, illuminating depiction of China's changing attitudes. The saddest moment of all came early on though, when Dr Chen told of how, during the Cultural Revolution, all books about love were banned. It would break your heart.

Friends (Sky 1) raised some questions. Firstly, do Aniston et al get paid the same salaries when the episode consists of flashbacks like The One With Mac And C.H.E.E.S.E did? Secondly, what's happened to Bruce Willis's comic timing since he was in Moonlighting? And thirdly, why wasn't the double bill called The Ones Where Chandler's A Chubster, Monica's Skinny And Phoebe Bears An Uncanny Resemblance To Linda McCartney? We should be told.

fields.headline: Hurd attacks 'frivolous' Tory prison policies
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The former Tory home secretary, Douglas Hurd, last night rounded on William Hague's new Conservative law and order policy by warning that prisons were not simply "wastepaper baskets into which we can toss those of our fellow citizens about whom we wish to hear nothing further".
fields.body:
The former Tory home secretary, Douglas Hurd, last night rounded on William Hague's new Conservative law and order policy by warning that prisons were not simply "wastepaper baskets into which we can toss those of our fellow citizens about whom we wish to hear nothing further".

As penal reformers last night estimated that Mr Hague's latest plans outlined to the Police Federation yesterday could add 15,000 to the current prison population, and the party leader's spokesman declined to publish any costings, Lord Hurd warned: "An adversarial competition between the parties simply shouting 'I can send more people to prison than you' gets us nowhere, indeed will drive us backwards."

Mr Hague's remarks in the wake of the Tony Martin case had already made him anxious, he said. "There is certainly a case for looking carefully at the definition of reasonable force in self defence. But hard cases make lousy law."

Lord Hurd said any criminal justice policy statement which failed to include an analysis of the state of prisons was inadequate. "It gives credence to the illusion that we need not bother about our prisons because they are simply wastepaper baskets into which we can toss those of our fellow citizens about whom we wish to hear nothing further," he said in a Prison Reform Trust article written before Mr Hague's well-trailed speech yesterday.

He argued that it was "frivolous to propose yet further increases in the prison population without tackling, or even acknowledging" the problem that prison overcrowding meant they simply became nurseries of further crime. The Conservative leader, in a speech well received by his police audience in Brighton, attacked exactly this kind of "liberal thinking" on crime which he claimed had pervaded the criminal justice system for the last 40 years. The only period when crime had fallen was when Michael Howard was home secretary. Criminals were not victims and he wanted to see a criminal justice system that "scares the hell out of criminals".

Without directly attacking Sir William Macpherson, the author of the official report into the murder of black teenager, Stephen Lawrence, Mr Hague won warm applause when he complained that his finding of 'institutional racism' in the police had been "lifted out of context and used by some to brand tens of thousands of decent, unprejudiced police officers as racists.

"This is a travesty of the truth... we need more police officers and less political correctness. In other words we need more PCs and less PC," he said.

After making clear that he is a firm admirer of the American "zero tolerance" policies and intends to develop a British version, Mr Hague outlined his new policy proposals. They included:

 Abolition of early release on licence so criminals serve the full term ordered by the judge in open court.

 Halt the early release of serious criminals from prison by restricting the home detention curfew tagging scheme.

 Court action to be taken after first breach of a probation order.

 Breach of conditional discharge will lead automatically to sentencing for the original crime.

 Up to 10 more secure training centres to take persistent young offenders off the streets.

 Extend attorney general's right of appeal against lenient sentences to offences such as grievous bodily harm, actual bodily harm, burglary and racially aggravated offences.

 Reaffirming the Tory commitment to restore the cut in police numbers over the past three years.

Last night the home secretary, Jack Straw, wrote to Mr Hague telling him Labour would be coming forward soon with its own proposals to extend the right of appeal against lenient sentences, and asking why he and Ann Widdecombe voted against similar proposals two years ago.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Il Postino
fields.body:
Il Postino

(Michael Radford, 1994)

6am, Sky Premier

On the breathtaking isle of Capri, a failed fisherman becomes a postman. He shyly strikes up a friendship with the illustrious poet, Neruda (Philippe Noiret), who is living there in exile, and haltingly woos a beautiful waitress (Maria Grazia Cucinotta). Weaving romance, poetry and politics into a captivating whole, it's hard to say how much of the film's poignance derives from the knowledge that Massimo Troisi, who plays the postman and co-wrote the script, died the day after shooting finished.

Diva

(Jean-Jacques Beineix, 1981)

8pm, FilmFour

The debut of Betty Blue's Beineix - part thriller, part romance - is a wholly seductive visual experience. Young messenger and opera fan Frederic Andrei illicitly records the performance of the woman he loves from afar: American diva Wilhelmenia Wiggins Fernandez. He is then hunted through Paris by two thoroughly nasty killers, including vicious punk Dominique Pinon (Delicatessen and Alien Resurrection) until the timely arrival of an enigmatic friend. Former ad-man Beineix has an eye for a stunning image - a film noir in blue, usually allied to the haunting tones of La Wally.

Razor Blade Smile

(Jake West, 1998)

10pm, Sci-Fi

fields.headline: What's up, Doc?
fields.standfirst: Is it the beginning of the end for Frasier? This week, broadcaster NBC announced that Dr Crane and co are being moved to an inferior time slot in the US schedules.  Adam Sweeting  thinks the prognosis is bad
fields.trailText: Is it the beginning of the end for Frasier? This week, broadcaster NBC announced that Dr Crane and co are being moved to an inferior time slot in the US schedules. Adam Sweeting thinks the prognosis is bad
fields.body:
Fans of Frasier felt a tremor of apprehension this week when rumours of the demise of the superior sitcom came floating across the Atlantic. NBC Television was thought to be putting the much-loved seven-year-old out to pasture, terminating what one critic has dubbed "the classical comedy of our time".

In the event, Frasier survived, though only by dint of a reshuffling of the schedules which may ultimately amount to a slow death by bleeding ratings. NBC have decided to whip it out of its 9pm Thursday slot and plonk it at the same time on Tuesdays, to the disgust of its star Kelsey Grammer and the show's production company, Paramount TV. Analysts of American TV reckon that moving long-established series around in the schedules is guaranteed to trigger a drop in ratings, and Frasier has already suffered three such switches since it launched in 1993.

Still, maybe we should merely marvel at the fact that Frasier has already survived for so long. The show's unique eco-system of sibling rivalry, generational friction, professional jealousy, laughable pomposity and its inevitable come-uppance has been able to evolve with apparently organic naturalness, thanks to the seamless interplay of one of the most finely tuned performing ensembles on the box. Frasier's discerning devotees are nauseated by the "love-me-I'm-so-cute" simperings of Friends, and don't want the coy domestic mini-dramas of Mad About You. They want to see Dr Frasier Crane, the psychiatrist who really wants to be on Broadway, failing to heed his own counselling and demonstrating all the wrong ways to run personal relationships. They're alert to the subtle distinctions of class and social standing - who on earth ever managed to sell the notion that there's no class system in America? - which cause such needling friction between the Crane brothers.

Viewers like the way Frasier's dad can make him look ridiculous. They can't get enough of his failure to comprehend how women can find his mixture of clumsy collegiate gaucheness and helium-filled male ego resistible. They love to see him being taken down a peg or two by his remorselessly critical brother Niles, as he was in last week's episode on Channel 4. Bowing to the rampaging ambition of his agent, Bebe - played like Bette Davies on a tankful of martinis by Harriet Sansom Harris - Frasier had let himself get talked into doing a cosy two-on-the-couch daytime TV show called AM Seattle. Frasier wanted to interview Susan Sontag, but instead he got Baby Leo, the World's Biggest Two-Year-Old. "It's the final step in your descent from legitimate psychiatrist to dancing bear," Niles declared.

"I was drawn to the theatre because of its disciplined and collaborative spirit!" Frasier boomed indignantly, before riding out in front of the cameras on a mule, wearing a sombrero hat and poncho.

But you don't have to be a professor of media studies to spot the flaw in Frasier's make-up. It's a demographic freak, daring to assume the existence of an educated, urbane audience who might be interested in sitcom relationships that go beyond teenagers having sex, twentysomethings getting jobs and having sex, or thirtysomethings having sex and buying houses together. In many respects it seems like a flashback to the Hollywood comedies of the 30s and 40s, when even the minor roles were filled with skilled character actors and it hadn't yet occurred to anybody that you didn't begin shooting before you'd found a well-crafted script, after which you spent time honing and polishing it. The Frasier actors' collective bristles with strength in depth, from David Hyde Pierce's Emmy-winning efforts as Niles to Peri Gilpin's loudly blue- collar Roz Doyle and Jane Leeves' deeply eccentric personification of Daphne, the Mancunian home-care worker who stumbles blithely through the shenanigans in the Crane family madhouse.

The rest of the week's TV news from the States spelt out what Frasier is up against on the ratings battlefield. Into its about-to-be-vacated Thursday slot come the "younger" comedies Will & Grace and Just Shoot Me, while NBC has guaranteed its survival for the foreseeable future by caving in to the latest exorbitant demands by the cast of Friends. The pampered sextet will each receive $20m to film 24 new episodes next year. They'll each bag 750,000 bucks per episode compared to the piffling $125,000 they currently earn, and receive an increased chunk of the show's syndication profits, which should total $40m each over two years.

Kelsey Grammer has seen the writing on the wall. In a move that would reduce Frasier to luvvie-style tears, Grammer is heading to Broadway to play Macbeth (it's in the blood - apparently Grammer had already memorised most of the role by the time he was 14). He is also working on pilots for various series through his own production company, Grammnet Productions, and has another project on the boil for NBC in the shape of Neurotic Tendencies, which was dreamed up by his wife Camille. Cagily, Grammer maintains that he's committed to Frasier for "as long as we're having fun with the show". For Frasier-fanciers, that probably all adds up to "enjoy it while it lasts".

Frasier, tonight, 10pm, Channel 4

webTitle: Who are you? What the Lucozade ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you? What the Lucozade ad says about you
fields.trailText: The ad: This commercial opens on a computer game featuring action cyber babe Lara Croft swinging through the jungle, hotly pursued by a bald-headed chainsaw-wielding brute. Suddenly she takes a tumble, and just as she is about to be sawn apart, the words "GAME PAUSED" come up on screen. The ad cuts to a real-life bloke behind the controls in his living room. He goes out of the room for a loo break, and, while he's away, Lara and her pursuant have a break too. They sit back and relax, and she tosses him a bottle of Lucozade. "Oooh, thanks luvvie," he squeals camply. The player returns to the living room, Lara springs back into position and the effeminate baddie calls his dogs back: "Spartacus, Boris, I'll give you woof woof." The endline reads: "Lucozade. The refreshing pause."
fields.body:
The ad: This commercial opens on a computer game featuring action cyber babe Lara Croft swinging through the jungle, hotly pursued by a bald-headed chainsaw-wielding brute. Suddenly she takes a tumble, and just as she is about to be sawn apart, the words "GAME PAUSED" come up on screen. The ad cuts to a real-life bloke behind the controls in his living room. He goes out of the room for a loo break, and, while he's away, Lara and her pursuant have a break too. They sit back and relax, and she tosses him a bottle of Lucozade. "Oooh, thanks luvvie," he squeals camply. The player returns to the living room, Lara springs back into position and the effeminate baddie calls his dogs back: "Spartacus, Boris, I'll give you woof woof." The endline reads: "Lucozade. The refreshing pause."

The jargon: This ad builds on the notion of Lucozade as an energy drink rather than something syrupy for recuperating invalids. It's aimed at making people feel that Lara Croft gets her energy from Lucozade, so they can too.

Personality: You're 18 to 30 years old, you're on the go a lot, you work hard and play hard, etc, and you could equally be male or female (Lara was chosen because she appeals to both sexes: women think she represents girl power, while men, well, they just fancy her).

Financial status: At less than £1 a bottle, Lucozade is neither a premium product nor particularly expensive.

Telling lifestyle detail: Chances are you like going to clubs and drinking Lucozade the following day for its instant, glucosey, pick-me-up qualities.

Other relevant data: The ad was made entirely in Australia - for the UK market (it's cheaper to make ads over there, plus there are very good production facilities). The agency has a global deal with computer giant Eidos to use Lara on a worldwide basis, but she's never given a voice, so as to maintain her special mystique (she never speaks in the video games either).
