fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Will Carling is a family man. At least, that's what his PR man would have us believe, placing in Monday's Sun the heart-rending tale of Will's battle to spend more time with his son. A sob story indeed. But the real facts about just how cuddly our Will is emerged from behind the screen, as it were, this week.
fields.body:
Will Carling is a family man. At least, that's what his PR man would have us believe, placing in Monday's Sun the heart-rending tale of Will's battle to spend more time with his son. A sob story indeed. But the real facts about just how cuddly our Will is emerged from behind the screen, as it were, this week.

Carling was on parade with his new wife at last Sunday's television Bafta awards. Now, Will's closest connections with TV may well be some out-of-date rugby footage, an implicit presence in that Panorama interview with Di, and another of his exes, Jules, who brightens up VH1 for those of us who choose to watch it at weekends. But that didn't stop the PR man from inviting Will along to the TV bash - and there he was.

Touchingly, he showed complete devotion to the new wife in an act of selfless generosity.

Requesting a pen, Carling disappeared for a full 10 minutes, only to re-emerge from the crowds, slightly hotter and clutching a battered piece of card. "Have you been signing autographs?" asked an innocent table neighbour. "No. But the wife thinks Carol Vorderman is fantastic... so I got this for her." He proffered the Brainy One's etching across the table to a truly elated Lisa Carling. So sweet.

Elsewhere in the word of etching, Channel 4 late-night cartoon House Of Rock (animated by the Guardian's Andy Watt), is planning a spin-off: the House Of Rock Awards, which will hit the screens in the autumn. The dead stars who feature (Freddie Mercury, et al) will present gongs to animated versions of living rock legends such as Noel Gallagher.

The Oasis man is thought to have agreed to do his own voiceover for the 'toon, as have the Chemical Brothers. Now the company making the show, Fireside Favourites, hopes that London's favourite rock import, Madonna, will come on board too. Come on, Maddie, be a sport.

Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: My trouble-making ex has moved in next door. Should I stay or go?
fields.trailText: My trouble-making ex has moved in next door. Should I stay or go?
fields.body:
A year ago my ex-partner (who is the father of four of my children) and the woman for whom he left me moved in next door. My ex has told me that the move was not made in the interests of the children - who live with me, my new partner and our toddler - but because he liked the house. They have spent a lot of money on it and yet he cannot contribute to his four children. The children see their father for four hours one weekday and four hours on Saturday. A month ago one daughter asked if she could stay the night, only to be told that he was busy. He was also too "busy" to see his kids on Christmas Day. Our proximity seems to be an irritant to him, and it has even been suggested that we "move, if you don't like it". What can we do?

Ask nicely, then leave

Have you tried appealing to your ex-partner's better nature or getting your new partner to appeal to his better nature? I did. But I am ashamed to say that I also resorted to sending hate mail, throwing overripe tomatoes at their windows and putting rotten eggs through their letterbox. In the end I moved house and got on with my life. It was unfair and costly but my bitterness has eased with time, and taking responsibility for escaping the situation enabled me to leave the past behind and, as a bonus, claim the moral high ground.
HT Close, Norwich

Make him pay up

Your ex's little games are clearly designed to provoke you - perhaps because you had the temerity to make a new life for yourself - and your best response is to ignore them. As for his not supporting the children, he has a legal obligation to do so. Contact the child support agency.
Susan Kelly, London

Don't wait - get moving

Five years ago my partner of 10 years and I moved away from a situation similar to yours. My ex-husband built a new house on land adjacent to our home: our assets had been divided 50-50 so that I could remain in the matrimonial home with our two children, aged seven and 10 at the time of the divorce. (Some people have expressed surprise that such an arrangement was appropriate, but we lived in a small community and wanted to do our best for the children.) A final settlement had been persistently delayed by the children's father; it was not until I met my new partner that he accepted the marriage was over and a financial agreement was reached so that my new husband and I could take out a mortgage.

Things reached a head when my 14-year-old daughter had a series of arguments with us and decamped temporarily next door to stay with her father and his new partner. Although my new husband had been effectively a second father to her, she had always been torn, and I believe that her father played on this for his own selfish purposes.

We felt aggrieved that it seemed to be up to us to go, but we found the situation intolerable. So we took the plunge, found a buyer for our home and bought a much smaller property. Unfortunately the sale of our old house fell through - in part because my ex began disputing the boundary. Some time and a large overdraft later we acquired good tenants but even now would be in a dire financial situation if they left.

In the meantime, we have turned our move into a positive one. We love our new home and have jobs here. My regret is that my children's education was interrupted. My husband's only regret is that we didn't move away from my ex as soon as we got together, while the children were young. We haven't moved far, so contact could have been continued easily. My advice: you must respond to this gross intrusion of your privacy.
Name and address withheld

Next week

I have just received a wedding invitation in the post. I was delighted when I realised what it was, but then dismayed to find that the names of the bride, the groom, the bride's mother and the bride's father all fail to ring any bells whatsoever with me. I must know them, or at least one of them, unless it's some bizarre practical joke. I have checked with my mother, and she also claims never to have heard of any of them. Emails to friends have failed to provide clues. I could simply refuse the invite, but I'm now extremely curious about the happy couple. How can I find out who they really are without completely putting my foot in it and offending them?

Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, preferably giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; fax 020-7239 9935; email private.lives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

fields.headline: Green belt
fields.trailText: David Walker writes of the problems of the Greens in defining their political identity (Analysis, May 17).
fields.body:
David Walker writes of the problems of the Greens in defining their political identity (Analysis, May 17). This may be the case in continental Europe, but in Oxford the Greens now hold the balance of power between Labour (21) and the Lib Dems (21).

They are now using their pivotal position to sort out the city's transport mess, to fight for the retention of local schools, to stop subsidising city centre car parks, to preserve Oxford's green spaces ...

The UK's Greens do have a clear political identity: we are standing up for ordinary people and communities against cynical party machines.
Oliver Tickell
Oxford

 You could have included mention of Robin Harper MSP, the UK's first Green parliamentarian, and the two Green MEPs, Caroline Lucas and Jean Lambert. Where elections are held using a fair voting system, Greens are elected - witness the recent very significant vote in London which returned three Greens to the new assembly.
Steve Burgess
Scottish Green party

They are now using their pivotal position to sort out the city's transport mess, to fight for the retention of local schools, to stop subsidising city centre car parks, to preserve Oxford's green spaces ... The UK's Greens do have a clear political identity: we are standing up for ordinary people and communities against cynical party machines. Oliver Tickell Oxford  You could have included mention of Robin Harper MSP, the UK's first Green parliamentarian, and the two Green MEPs, Caroline Lucas and Jean Lambert. Where elections are held using a fair voting system, Greens are elected - witness the recent very significant vote in London which returned three Greens to the new assembly. Steve Burgess Scottish Green party

fields.headline: Way to press complaints
fields.trailText: Gerald Isaaman (Letters, May 17) shows an enthusiasm for a statutory system of press regulation which he did not exhibit when he was for a short while a member of the Press Complaints Commission
fields.body:
Gerald Isaaman (Letters, May 17) shows an enthusiasm for a statutory system of press regulation which he did not exhibit when he was for a short while a member of the Press Complaints Commission before my time, nor, I imagine when he was editor of a local paper in north London. He was right then and wrong now.

The Jonathan Aitken adjudication is consistent with the European Convention on Human Rights. Gerald's views are not. As an editor Gerald would not have tolerated a regime of fines and the like, imposed by a commission made up in part by his competitors. I can't see how he would reasonably expect the current generation of editors to tolerate it either.

I hope Gerald is not building too many hopes on the European convention. He need only to look at Scotland, where this legislation has already brought the Scottish legal system to a grinding halt, and then he should read the terms of the act itself, which was amended to avoid precisely the sort of disaster scenario Gerald predicts. In legislating, the government moved - rightly and com mendably - to enshrine the special importance of freedom of expression, and the position of independent, effective self-regulation.

The best protection for ordinary people is a free and easy, accessible system of self-regulation that has a commendable record of raising standards over the years. It certainly isn't perfect, but the legal costs of a statutory system would put it out of the reach of most of us.

Given the millions of news stories written every year in national and local newspapers and periodicals, I would suggest that standards of accuracy are astonishingly high - certainly the PCC receives only a fraction of the complaints that the Office of Supervision of Solicitors receives about the conduct of solicitors, for instance. Of course things go wrong. When they do, the PCC helps put them right or criticises a newspaper if it cannot get satisfaction for a complainant. It does so in an average of 40 days and without cost to the complainant.
Lord Wakeham
Chairman,
Press Complaints Commission

fields.headline: Felled by a distant error
fields.standfirst:
The government's GM strategy is ruined

GM food: special report
fields.trailText: The government's carefully constructed policy on the growing of genetically modified crops lies today in ruins. With the discovery that around 13,500 acres have been planted with rape seed contaminated by GM, the worst fears of environmentalist campaigners and the worst suspicions of the public have proved to be justified: all the national and international regulations on GM are not worth the paper they are printed on.
fields.body:
The government's carefully constructed policy on the growing of genetically modified crops lies today in ruins. With the discovery that around 13,500 acres have been planted with rape seed contaminated by GM, the worst fears of environmentalist campaigners and the worst suspicions of the public have proved to be justified: all the national and international regulations on GM are not worth the paper they are printed on.

The seed company, Advanta, is "gobsmacked" by the discovery that its rape seed grown on the Canadian prairies was contaminated by GM crops 800 metres away. Yet scientists warned of just this possibility, and the politicians refused to listen and promised us that a mere 200 metres offered a cordon sanitaire in UK test sites. Now this has been proved wrong, the government has made matters much worse by sitting on the information for a month and then slipping it out surreptitiously in a written parliamentary answer. Why should we now believe Nick Brown on anything he says on GM? Ministers' credibility on this subject is irrevocably damaged and they largely have themselves to blame.

This sorry tale raises serious questions about whether the GM genie is now out of the bottle, beyond the control of any national government - the Advanta seed has been planted in Germany, France and Sweden. It shows how impossible it has become to produce GM-free seeds; Advanta has moved its seed production out of Alberta to eastern Ontario, New Zealand and Montana in a bid to keep its seeds GM-free. But such is the dramatic advance of GM in major agricultural countries like the US, Brazil, China and India that keeping any part of the globe GM-free is now close to an impossible dream. This is an abysmal failure of international action.

But it is not yet time to throw up our hands in despair. At the very least the government has a responsibility to give us accurate information in this brave new GM world. It has belatedly announced that it will follow the lead of the German state of Baden-Wurttemberg, which discovered the Advanta rogue seeds, and institute spot checks on conventional seeds. Now to shore up its credibility, the government should vigorously defend the policy commitments it has made to have no commercial GM crops until 2003. And that means digging up and destroying these GM contaminated crops as soon as possible.

fields.headline: Upsetting the natural order
fields.trailText: Prince Charles's sense that the current rush towards genetic modification in agriculture represents some kind of spiritual offence is shared by large sections of the public, including those who are not explicitly religious (Prince courts controversy, May 17).
fields.body:
Social research carried out at Lancaster University suggests that Prince Charles's sense that the current rush towards genetic modification in agriculture represents some kind of spiritual offence is shared by large sections of the public, including those who are not explicitly religious (Prince courts controversy, May 17).

However, Charles may be less in step with the wider public - and theologians - in suggesting that there is some timeless order of nature that must never change. While our respondents expressed great anxiety about possible irreversible changes in natural systems, their deepest unease seemed to be less about change per se and more about the spirit in which genetic technologies are developed - the motives that animate those responsible, the assumptions being made about human beings and their place in the world, and the level of seriousness and respectfulness with which potentially momentous steps are taken.
Dr Bronislaw Szerszynski
Lancaster University
bron@lancaster.ac.uk

 My own work has shown that there exists a widely held belief that nature does not exist only for our convenience. But all agriculture, however environmentally friendly, is a manipulation of nature. This tension can be resolved by ensuring that manipulation of nature is kept to a justifiable minimum. In agriculture, this point is probably organic agriculture; chemical agriculture is one stage beyond acceptability and GM crops two stages beyond. This insight is not anti-science, but it does suggest that scientific endeavour should be directed towards improving organic yields rather than creating GM crops.
Dr Peter Quaife
Birmingham
zpquaife@aol.com

 As a lay-reader of New Scientist each week for 40 years, I admire science and the immense benefits that flow from it. But Prince Charles is right. Humans need the spiritual and intuitive dimensions in our brief lives. Most great discoveries are attributed, by scientists, to the irrational (sacred/secret) powers of intuition in the Eureka moment. We habitually use more reliable and greater powers than our serial processing intellect, which may be incapable of comprehending the whole and enabling us to manage our environment. For balance, the Guardian should commission Prince Charles to write a weekly column on the sacred, neglected aspects of our lives.
Noel Hodson
Oxford
noelhodson@msn.com

 Environmental sustainability is not a matter of replacing rational thought with a "wisdom of the heart", but of recognising that there are different rationalities and working to bring them into balance. The dominance of scientific rationality leads to "solutions" like the Green Revolution of the 70s and genetic engineering in the 90s. What is required is a dose of ecological rationality, which points in the direction of finding solutions compatible with preserving biodiversity, as suggested by Vandana Shiva (Feeding frenzy, May 17).
Prof Andrew Dobson
Keele University
a.n.h.dobson@pol.keele.ac.uk

 The "traditional agriculture" applauded by the prince has, over the centuries, totally transformed the British landscape and flora from the highlands of Scotland to farms in the Duchy of Cornwall estates in south-west England. Pre-second world war farming, akin to present organic farming, can only feed a population of 3-4bn.

Remarkable advances in plant genetics and agricultural engineering have allowed food production to just about keep pace with population growth over the last 50 years. Applying the "precautionary principle" we need to embrace not reject science as key to environmentally sustainable global food security for 8-9bn in mid-century against a background of progressive loss of prime agricultural land to desertification and urbanisation; changing diets in China and other countries engaged in rapid modernisation; and consumer demands for more nutritious and healthy foods. Recourse to a nostalgic view of traditional farming will not do.
Chris Lamb
Director, John Innes Centre
Chris.Lamb@bbsrc.ac.uk

 Putting science on "hold" is not a new demand. The Victorian upper class, including the Prince Consort, would rather risk "natural" typhus than spend money on new sewerage technology, preferring traditional methods. So Albert died in his 40s - a "natural" age to die. Charles now includes as natural and traditional: piped drinking water, a centrally heated palace or two, most babies living to 70, heart operations, pacemakers, racehorses and corgis.
Ken Bates
Nottingham
ken.bates@diamond.co.uk

 The prince in a Wicker Man (Letters, May 18) has its appeal, but it's likely this would be ineffectual as (according to the film) the person sacrificed has to be a virgin.
S Saxby
Wrexham

 Why does Prince Charles gets so worked up about scientific advances? Is he afraid GM plants won't talk to him?
Eric Thompson
London

 Was the lecture written by HRH or one of those plants he's forever yakking to?
Shaun Joynson
London

fields.headline: No cop out
fields.trailText: John Wadham (Accountable Cops, May 17) highlights an urgent priority for the new Metropolitan police authority
fields.body:
John Wadham (Accountable Cops, May 17) highlights an urgent priority for the new Metropolitan police authority - the setting up of an independent body to investigate complaints against the police. It took a year of pressure to succeed in getting the Police Complaints Authority to investigate a case in Haringey where a young black man had been arrested and charged 14 times. Every case was dropped or thrown out of court. No one should have to fight so hard for answers, so hard to get an investigation and or so hard for justice.

Moreover, when the PCA concludes an investigation, there are no explanations and no information as to why or how a judgment has been reached.
Lynne Featherstone
Greater London Assembly

fields.trailText: Call me a cynic, but spectacular bio-blunders (Rogue GM seeds taint UK crops, May 18) are perhaps the only way the bio-tech industry will ever overcome virulent strains of GM-resistant public opinion
fields.body:
Call me a cynic, but spectacular bio-blunders (Rogue GM seeds taint UK crops, May 18) are perhaps the only way the bio-tech industry will ever overcome virulent strains of GM-resistant public opinion.
Neil Goodwin
London

 Prof Anthony Trewavas (Letters, May 18) continues to peddle discredited claims of E.coli 0157:H7 contamination of organic food. The professor's independent opinions on organic farming can be read on Monsanto's website.
ED Goff
Oswestry, Shropshire

 So there is no "major alternative" to the FA Cup Final, (Stand-off on Saturday afternoon, May 18). Well, there's the Welsh rugby cup final between Llanelli and Swansea. Even the Twickenham fraternity might prefer that to a rerun of My Fair Lady.
Anne Cowper
Swansea

 You suggest mass redundancies in the textile industry have not received the same level of attention as Longbridge and Dagenham because those affected are women, and where do you put the article? On the Women's page (G2, May 16).
Carol Dunnett
Guildford, Surrey

 So Jack Straw is horrified adults may purchase videos showing vaginal penetration (Straw's fury at obscenity verdict, May 17). Is he aware such activities often take place in the same house as a child, sometimes within only a few feet of the sleeping innocent?
Dave Neale
Wakefield

 Alfred Tamer's letter praising masturbation (May 17) had a sentence of 79 words. According to previous correspondents (May 13 and 18), any woman should be pleased to relieve him of the necessity of performing this act.
Dudley Turner
Westerham, Kent

webTitle: Locked on a Horn of Africa dilemma

fields.headline: Locked on a Horn of Africa dilemma
fields.trailText: You rightly say that Ethiopia is "primarily responsible for the latest upsurge in violence" in the conflict with Eritrea (Leader, May 18).
fields.body:
You rightly say that Ethiopia is "primarily responsible for the latest upsurge in violence" in the conflict with Eritrea (Leader, May 18). After a ceasefire which had lasted since June 1999, Ethiopia launched a massive offensive against Eritrea on three fronts and is wholly and solely responsible for an act of aggression which contravenes the UN charter and international law. The OAU had been trying hard to get agreement on a peace formula based on a framework agreement which the two states had accepted.

In proximity talks held in Algiers at the end of April, Ethiopia refused to sign the documents, ostensibly on the grounds that the technical arrangements for their implementation had still to be agreed, but in reality because they couldn't sign up to peace when their preparations for relaunching the war had reached their final stages.

This offensive was not planned and executed in a few days; it was a premeditated act of aggression, prepared while the Ethiopian foreign minister was going through the motions of talking peace in Algiers. The present military operations are not designed to recover the small amounts of territory claimed by Ethiopia, but to crush the Eritrean army and dictate the terms of a settlement.
Lord Avebury
EricAvebury@compuserve.com

 I was a development worker in the now disputed area in 1996-97: social facilities built in Ethiopia as part of that work now fall within the area invaded by Eritrea in 1998. Eritrea is the clearly the aggressor in this conflict. Many countries including UK have used tactics, including the suspension of long-term development aid, to try to force Ethiopia to accept a peace treaty which would not have reversed the results of Eritrea's aggression. Unfortunately, Ethiopia has learned that the only way to restore the status quo ante is by establishing "facts on the ground", hence the current renewal of the conflict.

It is wasteful, it is a tragedy, it will set back development many years, but it is still important for the international community to condemn the aggressor and act accordingly, instead of effectively rewarding aggression through ambivalent political stances.
Nick Chisholm
Cork, Ireland
n.chisholm@ucc.ie

webTitle: Government 'gave up' stake in Dolly cloning

fields.headline: Government 'gave up' stake in Dolly cloning
fields.standfirst:
Gene patenting: special report
The Roslin Institute
fields.trailText: An investigation into whether the taxpayer has lost billions of pounds from a share of the commercial exploitation of the cloning of Dolly the sheep is to be launched by the national audit office.
fields.body:
An investigation into whether the taxpayer has lost billions of pounds from a share of the commercial exploitation of the cloning of Dolly the sheep is to be launched by the national audit office.

Parliament's financial watchdog has decided to hold an inquiry into the giveaway of patent and intellectual property rights owned by the Ministry of Agriculture by the last Tory government.

The inquiry announced by David Davis, the Conservative chairman of the Commons public accounts committee in letters to Bill Cash, Tory MP for Stone, and Nigel Griffiths, Labour MP for Edinburgh South, follows a Guardian article in February. It will include a thorough inquiry into the Dolly the sheep cloning at Roslin Institute, Edinburgh.

The auditors will examine whether the government has lost out because the Tory government in 1995 and 1996 gave away patents on Dolly the sheep to a private company as part of the wholesale transfer of assets of research institutes so it could cut its science budget. Taxpayers' money given to develop the cloning of Dolly the sheep will now benefit private shareholders in California and Britain instead of the government following a deal on patents this year.

The cloning of Dolly the sheep was one of the most remarkable breakthroughs of the decade by British scientests. It raises the possibility of cloning cells to fight degenerative diseases. Scientists are putting together complementary British and American patents which will allow potential medical applications for a wide range of serious diseases. These include diabetes, Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, heart attacks, hepatitis, cirrhosis of the liver, cancer, serious burns and muscular dystrophy.

The last government decided that the biotechnology and biological science research council should turn the Roslin Institute in Edinburgh into a private non-profit making company. It transferred all the assets and equipment and existing patents to the company for "nil consideration". This included £2.9m of assets. The government also continued to fund research projects. These included the Dolly cloning at the rate of £250,000 a year.

The patent for Dolly the sheep was jointly owned by the private company, the Ministry of Agriculture, and the state-owned biotechnology council.

But in 1998 Roslin set up its own private commercial company, Roslin Bio-med, and assigned the patents - previously jointly owned - to it. It is this commercial offshoot that has merged with the Californian company. Geron Bio-med now holds the sole rights to cloning for the next 17 years.

Mr Cash welcomed the announcement yesterday: "It will now mean that the national audit office can thoroughly investigate the situation and find out whether it amounts to one of the biggest scandals of recent times because of the loss of money to the taxpayer."

Mr Griffiths said yesterday: "Taxpayers have lost a share of billions of pounds that could have been spent elsewhere because of these decisions. I am very pleased that there is going to be a full inquiry."

The Roslin Institute did not comment yesterday but is known to believe there was no other way to exploit the science.

Grahame Bulfield, director of the Roslin Institute, told the Guardian this year: "The government cannot have its cake and eat it. They cannot both cut research and expect to benefit from it. Without the joint development with Geron [the Californian company that has merged with Roslin Bio-med to develop Dolly and other inventions] these benefits would not be available at all. Geron's involvement will mean there will be inward investment into Britain."

But in 1998 Roslin set up its own private commercial company, Roslin Bio-med, and assigned the patents - previously jointly owned - to it. It is this commercial offshoot that has merged with the Californian company. Geron Bio-med now holds the sole rights to cloning for the next 17 years. Mr Cash welcomed the announcement yesterday: "It will now mean that the national audit office can thoroughly investigate the situation and find out whether it amounts to one of the biggest scandals of recent times because of the loss of money to the taxpayer." Mr Griffiths said yesterday: "Taxpayers have lost a share of billions of pounds that could have been spent elsewhere because of these decisions. I am very pleased that there is going to be a full inquiry." The Roslin Institute did not comment yesterday but is known to believe there was no other way to exploit the science. Grahame Bulfield, director of the Roslin Institute, told the Guardian this year: "The government cannot have its cake and eat it. They cannot both cut research and expect to benefit from it. Without the joint development with Geron [the Californian company that has merged with Roslin Bio-med to develop Dolly and other inventions] these benefits would not be available at all. Geron's involvement will mean there will be inward investment into Britain."

webTitle: Beijing offers olive branch to Taiwan's new leader

fields.headline: Beijing offers olive branch to Taiwan's new leader
fields.standfirst: Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: Beijing has sent an unexpectedly mild signal to Taiwan's incoming president, Chen Shui-bian, with a last-minute conciliatory message before his inauguration speech tomorrow.
fields.body:
Beijing has sent an unexpectedly mild signal to Taiwan's incoming president, Chen Shui-bian, with a last-minute conciliatory message before his inauguration speech tomorrow.

In carefully chosen language, Mr Chen was exhorted yesterday to move "in the direction of accepting" the principle of One China. This is much softer than Beijing's previous insistence that he must outright accept China's rule over Taiwan.

The official People's Daily editorial also acknowledged that Mr Chen has "recently made some gestures towards improving relations between the two sides".

Mr Chen is expected to make his speech as emollient as possible, although the issue of Beijing's sovereignty over the island remains a sticking point. Mr Chen has described the relationship with Beijing as one "between brothers and sisters", but he warns that siblings can become estranged.

"The president will be very careful not to use words that will provoke Beijing," says the prominent journalist Antonio Chiang, who led the speech's drafting process.

Yesterday, Mr Chen said that Taiwan was "always willing to talk reason with the mainland" and that he did not wish to say anything that would "make trouble". But he has previously made it clear he will only accept the One-China formula as an agenda item, not as a principle for talks.

The editorial was also carried by the armed forces' newspaper. In spite of the Chinese military's habitual hard line, it, like Beijing, has refrained from denouncing Mr Chen by name. But army leaders express themselves more forcefully in private.

Beijing's milder tone is thought to be partly influenced by the approach of next week's vote in the US house of representatives that could grant permanent trade benefits to China.

Beijing has drawn a distinction between Mr Chen's positive gestures and the pro- independence views of his outspoken vice-president, Annette Lu. It says that her policy of Taiwan becoming a "sovereign independent state" will destroy peace in Asia and have "disastrous consequences". This has left room for Mr Chen to seek middle ground with Beijing while Ms Lu, who has been described in the Chinese media as the "scum of the nation", draws China's fire.

Mr Chen is likely to make only an indirect reference to the "One China" concept, and may offer an alternative formula such as "one people". He is also expected to offer more detail on plans for establishing direct trade, transport and postal links across the Taiwan Straits.

His speech will be studied word by word in Beijing before being discussed by the ruling politburo. If it is found wanting, the Chinese media will quickly harden its tone. But the Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, is believed to have ruled out military action until it is clear that Mr Chen can make further no concessions.

fields.headline: Ian Armour-Chelu
fields.trailText: In 1955, the artist Ian Armour-Chelu, who has died aged 71, had a meeting that transformed his life. It was with another artist, the Slade-trained Angela Burfoot. They married, and eked out a living from any work they could find: book jackets, house plans, a vast family tree for a Belgian aristocrat. Ian even won the one-off Inn Sign Championship of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
In 1955, the artist Ian Armour-Chelu, who has died aged 71, had a meeting that transformed his life. It was with another artist, the Slade-trained Angela Burfoot. They married, and eked out a living from any work they could find: book jackets, house plans, a vast family tree for a Belgian aristocrat. Ian even won the one-off Inn Sign Championship of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

In 1961, the couple moved from west London to Suffolk, and in 1967 put a poster outside their house announcing an exhibition of their paintings. To their astonishment, the works sold.

That summer there was a joint show at the Yoxford gallery, and, in 1968, another in Aldeburgh. The first of Ian's successful one-man shows was at the Sladmore gallery, in London, in 1972. For 15 years, he developed the Suffolk watercolours which made his name. The increasingly hedgeless countryside distressed him; but in all the paintings, there was yearning for a lost golden age.

In 1983, he made his first trip to Venice, which resulted in wonderful transcendent watercolours. Later, trips to France led him towards oils, and rich, warm landscapes.

Ian came from the large family of an Essex railway clerk. He went to 27 different schools and, at the age of 10, experienced the first of his mother's periodic abandonment of her children - they were taken into Dr Barnardo's for five months. In 1940, the children were evacuated to East Anglia, an encounter with the countryside that Ian called "a magic time".

In 1942, scenting commercial possibilities, his mother entered Ian's paintings in an Aid To Russia exhibition. Later, he began an art course at West Ham municipal college, but his mother removed him during his second year. At 15, he took a job with the London Press Exchange. He became a farm labourer and, by 1946, was working as a staff artist for the Methodist Missionary Society - while attending evening classes at Chelsea School of Art.

Ian was full of a passionate integrity, intolerant of the second-rate. He was also tender, compassionate and funny. At the heart of his life was Angela, who, with his four daughters, survives him.

 Ian Armour-Chelu, artist, born October 10 1928; died April 8 2000

fields.headline: Wonders snatched from rising water
fields.standfirst: Hydroelectric dam will drown countless more unknown treasures as Turkey puts economy before homes and antiquities
fields.trailText: In the shadow of the Birecik dam, Turkish archaeologists are racing against the rising waters.
fields.body:
In the shadow of the Birecik dam, Turkish archaeologists are racing against the rising waters.

In the past nine months they have unearthed from this dusty site near the banks of the river Euphrates some of the finest Roman mosaics found anywhere in the world. But the river is becoming a lake. Soon the dig will disappear.

"What we've discovered here is quite simply amazing," Yusuf Yavas said as he watched his colleagues preparing to remove another priceless example of ancient art.

Two thousand years ago this was the site of the flourishing Roman garrison town of Zeugma. Its position on the trade routes along the Euphrates brought great wealth to its inhabitants, who competed with each other to boast of the most beautiful mosaics.

The ruins of the town, which was apparently destroyed by fire, invasion and an earthquake, have lain undisturbed for centuries. But in the past nine months vivid scenes from Greek mythology have emerged from under piles of rubble, miraculously unscathed.

The dry climate of this region helped preserve scenes of stunning complexity. When the dust is wiped away the Trojan wars, Poseidon on his chariot and Perseus saving Andromeda from a sea monster sparkle into life.

In all, 60 mosaics have been found around Zeugma, and there are likely to be dozens more hidden beneath the surface. Given time, the archaeologists believe, this could become the best collection in the world.

But time is precisely what they do not have. In a matter of weeks the current dig will be submerged. Other parts of the ancient town still to be unearthed will be damaged by corrosion and damp.

Sporadic excavations have been conducted in Zeugma for several years, but it was only last September that serious money was made available.

"I just can't understand why we're not being given more time," said Jelal Kucuk, an art restorer, who is helping remove the mosaics to a museum in the nearby city of Gaziantep.

"Just a few months could make a huge difference".

But the state has made its decision. Any delay to the hydroelectric project will cost millions of pounds a month. The lake will soon be full and the generators fully working.

Birecik is part of the same ambitious scheme as the pro posed Ilisu dam, which has caused such controversy in Britain. Opponents of Ilisu argue that British money should not finance a project which will flood the ancient town of Hasankeyf. But the Ilisu dam is still on the drawing board: the loss of Zeugma is an imminent reality.

Under a blazing sun, the mosaics are covered in white fabric and cut between the tiny stones into sections. Then they are dug carefully from the dusty earth.

At the Gaziantep museum the most recent arrivals are simply stacked in the garden waiting to be pieced back together.

"Of course I'm upset," the museum's acting director Hakki Alkan, said.

"But this is state policy. Energy issues always take precedence over any cultural considerations."

Belatedly, the state has devised a plan to try to save as much as possible of what could become a huge tourist attraction and a site of international interest.

Optimists hope that on the hill-tops above the water of the new lake will be as yet undiscovered wonders of the past, including ancient Zeugma's temple.

"We will excavate the second and third layers of the old city, the tourism minister said on a visit to a site which is about to disappear. "There is no need for any delay."

But a huge amount will be lost under the water. "Every room has a mosaic," Yusuf Yavas said. "There may be one hundred villas here that we will never have the chance to find."

About half way between the archaeological dig and the imposing new dam stands the present-day village of Belkis. It is about to share the fate of its ancient predecessor.

The school is almost submerged. Clusters of yellow-brick buildings have already become isolated islands in the calm blue waters.

Bewildered villagers say they have yet to receive all the compensation they are owed by the state. Some of them are still hard at work knocking down their own houses. They will take the bricks and timber with them to sell, rather than watch them disappear intact.

"I've seen the mosaics, they're beautiful", said Ali Ozler. "But I rather liked my house as well. Who cares about that?"

Perhaps no one will ever know quite what is being lost at Zeugma. A unique bronze statue of the war god Mars was found a few weeks ago, as well as the largest collection of ceramic Roman seal inscriptions anywhere in the world.

Within weeks it will all be academic. As the waters seep into the ruins, Turkey will take another step towards alleviating its electricity shortage and irrigating new tracts of land to create badly needed jobs.

Fifteen metres below the surface of a man-made lake, the unknown treasures of ancient Rome will be abandoned for ever.

fields.headline: Serial killer 'couldn't resist beauty'
fields.trailText: A Sudanese mortuary assistant who has confessed to killing 51 women said he could not resist the urge to kill his victims.
fields.body:
A Sudanese mortuary assistant who has confessed to killing 51 women said he could not resist the urge to kill his victims.

"When I see women, and especially beautiful ones, something happens inside me and I can't resist something pushes me to kill and I even enjoy it," Mohammed Adam Omar was quoted as saying by September 26, a weekly newspaper.

Mr Omar, an employee at Sana'a University, confessed after his arrest last Friday to having raped, killed and mutilated five women, police said. They say he later confessed to killing 51 women in Kuwait, Jordan, Lebanon, and Yemen since 1975.

"My motive in killing them was to send them to heaven," Mr Omar told the newspaper.

It said that during the interview, Mr Omar approached a female reporter and said: "beautiful women like you should not be allowed to live." The woman screamed and ran away.

Mr Omar, who claimed to be a former Sudanese boxing champion, said he lured women medical students into the university mortuary promising to help them with their studies. He killed them with a blow to the head.

He denied selling his victims' body parts but told the police he cut off their hands and feet, dissolved them in chemicals and kept the bones as mementos.

"I regret what I did and I want to purify myself by turning to God. Executing me would purify me from my sins," he said to the newspaper.

Police say Mr Omar tried to commit suicide after his arrest by cutting his wrists with his spectacles, but he was overpowered.

Police are looking for three associates whom they suspect of involvement in the murders.

Among his victims were a Yemeni woman and an Iraqi student whose mutilated bodies were found last week in a room near the university mortuary. The Iraqi medical student had disappeared in December.
AP

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: US warned over vote on Kosovo
fields.body:
US warned over vote on Kosovo

Nato's secretary general, Lord Robertson, yesterday warned that US domestic political manoeuvring could encourage more violence by the Yugoslav leader, Slobodan Milosevic.

His warning came on the eve of last night's vote in the Senate on a bill amendment that would set a July 2001 date for withdrawal of US ground troops from Kosovo unless Congress approves an extension.
Ian Black, Brussels

Fires prompt radiation fears

Israeli embassy staff in Minsk were evacuated yesterday and sent for checks, amid concern about radiation released by forest fires in Belarus - the country worst affected by the 1986 Chernobyl disaster.

Fires across Belarus and northern Ukraine have freed radiation in the roots and stems of vegetation, releasing radioactive dust.
Amelia Gentleman, Moscow

Blasts kill five in Philippines

Explosions in a busy market and a bakery in the southern Philippines yesterday killed at least five and injured at least 58.

Police suspect Islamic separatist guerrillas could be to blame. Abu Sayyaf rebels are holding 21 hostages on Jolo, where one of the attacks occurred. The other blast took place in Zamboanga on nearby Mindanao.
AP, Jolo

Rhymes given Indian slant

Mary and her lamb will turn into Meera and her cat when new English textbooks come into use in 60,000 language schools in Maharashtra next month. "Rain, rain come again" will replace "Rain, rain go away," in the water-thirsty Indian state.
AP, Bombay

fields.headline: Regal snarl
fields.standfirst: Unique T rex fossil fills some gaps
fields.trailText: Unique T rex fossil in Chicago fills some gaps
fields.body:
The ferocious face of Sue, a reconstruction of the most complete Tyrannosaurus rex fossil ever found, unveiled to an applauding crowd in Chicago yesterday and live on the Field Museum's website (www.fieldmuseum.org).

The museum said 10,000 people came to see it in the first few hours. It revealed that the fossil, bought at auction for $8.4m (£5.25m), had provided some scientific surprises.

One was the presence of a wishbone, the first found in a T rex and additional evidence that dinosaurs are related to birds, to which the wishbone is otherwise unique. Another was the first find in a T rex of an ear drum bone called a stapes, also found in birds.

"This delicate ear bone is almost never preserved in dinosaur fossils," the head of the museum's geology department, John Flynn, said. "Its presence allows us to better understand the evolution of ear bones and hearing in dinosaurs and in birds."

Experts said Sue probably walked at about 6mph, with a top speed of perhaps 15mph, and had a keen sense of smell, thanks to huge olfactory lobes, suggesting that it might have moved through life "nose first," but shedding no light on whether it was a predator or a scavenger.

The fossil was called after its finder, Sue Hendrickson, because it was thought to be female, but now that it has been assembled palaeontologists are no longer certain of the sex.

webTitle: Fears for the sick building of Europe

fields.headline: Fears for the sick building of Europe
fields.trailText: The deadly airborne bacteria that cause legionnaire's disease has been found lurking in the machine room of the European parliament's spanking new £250m headquarters in Strasbourg.
fields.body:
The deadly airborne bacteria that cause legionnaire's disease has been found lurking in the machine room of the European parliament's spanking new £250m headquarters in Strasbourg.

Alarmed MEPs demanded immediate action over the building that has been so plagued by design faults and problems since it was opened last summer, that it has already earned the nickname "Faulty Towers".

"If this was an old people's home, I am sure it would have been evacuated by now," protested the British Conservative Robert Goodwill, after a notice went round to MEPs and staff. "I have demanded that we move out of here for our next monthly meeting and use our Brussels headquarters for our June meeting."

MEPs are already locked in battle over use of the 17-storey structure with 1,100 rooms and no fewer than six restaurants. It is only used once a month for plenary sessions of parliament.

Most routine business is done in the parliament's lavish £640m Brussels headquarters, known as the Caprice of the Gods after a French cheese of similar shape.

But MEPs have to meet in Strasbourg because European Union leaders decreed - in what many regard as a classic secret stitch-up between governments - that the city on the Rhine is its "official" home.

With the EU already high in the white elephant stakes - the Berlaymont building that once housed the European commission in Brussels is still being gutted to remove deadly asbestos - this discovery is bound to fuel the long-running row.

"It is unacceptable that a building that cost millions of pounds and which was opened officially less than six months ago was found to have thousands of faults and is now found to be a potential threat to the health of the people working in it," said Eluned Morgan, of the Socialist group.

"This is yet another reason to move the seat of the parliament to Brussels."

Routine checks carried out by a German firm found legionella in humidifiers in three machine rooms, which were not in operation. "All the humidifiers were immediately switched on so that their temperature increased to about 100C," said the notice. "This causes legionella cultures to be destroyed by heat."

Mr Goodwill said: "Legionnaire's disease is a killer - and now that the air conditioning has been switched off because of the finding, people are beginning to suffer from the atmosphere inside the building.

"We are told it will be another two weeks before the results of further tests are known, and I am urging the parliament president to agree that we move to Brussels, where we have a perfectly good building, until the necessary modifications to this building are carried out."

Roy Perry, a Tory MEP, said: "Whatever happens the costs to fix this mess must fall on those responsible and not on European taxpayers. They already pay £90m a year for a needless travelling circus."

Alarmed MEPs demanded immediate action over the building that has been so plagued by design faults and problems since it was opened last summer, that it has already earned the nickname "Faulty Towers". "If this was an old people's home, I am sure it would have been evacuated by now," protested the British Conservative Robert Goodwill, after a notice went round to MEPs and staff. "I have demanded that we move out of here for our next monthly meeting and use our Brussels headquarters for our June meeting." MEPs are already locked in battle over use of the 17-storey structure with 1,100 rooms and no fewer than six restaurants. It is only used once a month for plenary sessions of parliament. Most routine business is done in the parliament's lavish £640m Brussels headquarters, known as the Caprice of the Gods after a French cheese of similar shape. But MEPs have to meet in Strasbourg because European Union leaders decreed - in what many regard as a classic secret stitch-up between governments - that the city on the Rhine is its "official" home. With the EU already high in the white elephant stakes - the Berlaymont building that once housed the European commission in Brussels is still being gutted to remove deadly asbestos - this discovery is bound to fuel the long-running row. "It is unacceptable that a building that cost millions of pounds and which was opened officially less than six months ago was found to have thousands of faults and is now found to be a potential threat to the health of the people working in it," said Eluned Morgan, of the Socialist group. "This is yet another reason to move the seat of the parliament to Brussels." Routine checks carried out by a German firm found legionella in humidifiers in three machine rooms, which were not in operation. "All the humidifiers were immediately switched on so that their temperature increased to about 100C," said the notice. "This causes legionella cultures to be destroyed by heat." Mr Goodwill said: "Legionnaire's disease is a killer - and now that the air conditioning has been switched off because of the finding, people are beginning to suffer from the atmosphere inside the building. "We are told it will be another two weeks before the results of further tests are known, and I am urging the parliament president to agree that we move to Brussels, where we have a perfectly good building, until the necessary modifications to this building are carried out." Roy Perry, a Tory MEP, said: "Whatever happens the costs to fix this mess must fall on those responsible and not on European taxpayers. They already pay £90m a year for a needless travelling circus."

webTitle: 'The death of rep has stifled opportunity ... lack of work affects the craft'

fields.headline: 'The death of rep has stifled opportunity ... lack of work affects the craft'
fields.trailText: Actor James Casey got a total of 10 weeks' work in the theatre last year. He is currently temping for Croydon health authority.
fields.body:
Actor James Casey got a total of 10 weeks' work in the theatre last year. He is currently temping for Croydon health authority.

"I had two acting jobs last year, a London fringe production of Julius Caesar and a Restoration comedy in Guildford. I started on £150 a week. Then for eight weeks I earned the Equity union minimum of £210," Mr Casey said.

He has a classics degree from Cambridge University and has spent two years looking for a long-term acting contract.

Between acting jobs, Mr Casey, 22, signed on to the jobseeker's allowance, temped, and worked as a website designer and a school computer technician. "Everyone who goes into acting knows it's oversubscribed. The death of rep has stifled opportunity," he said.

The latest British Actors Equity Association survey shows that professional actors get an average of 11 weeks' theatre work a year. Dancers get 14 weeks' work, variety performers, such as ventriloquists and cabaret acts, get 15 weeks a year, and stage managers get 17 weeks.

Around 42% of performers earn under £5,000 a year from the entertainment industry. A total of 24% earn nothing at all from entertainment.

"The lack of theatre work affects the craft because out of work actors are not practising or using their voices.

"A lot of resting actors I know do unpaid amateur dramatics because it allows them to keep their hand in," Mr Casey said.

"Every now and again I wonder if I'm wasting my time, but you cannot do this unless you secretly believe that one day you will make it."

Strategies for success ... or recovery

The New Victoria Theatre, Newcastle-under-Lyme, Staffordshire

Tonight's first night of Jack To A King at the Vic, an in-the-round auditorium with 605 seats, is already sold out.

The Vic's strategies, featuring a broadening of its programming to win new audiences, are broadly in line with those suggested by the Arts Council in its report published yesterday.

Two years ago the theatre had a deficit of of £208,000. That has now been whittled down to £60,000. "We were adamant that the deficit should not increase but we decided to trade our way out of our problems rather than reduce our activities," said the general manager Ludo Keston. "We have increased our activities from 44 to 49 weeks a year, increased the number of performances, and established an education and outreach department to reconnect the theatre to the community."

Aware of the decline in the traditional audience for drama, the Vic has varied its programme and substantially increased the number of concerts and one night stands it presents.

"It's a question of diversifying the product," added Mr Keston. "Theatres exist to serve all the audiences of their districts, not just playgoers. We are using sophisticated marketing techniques to persuade people who come to one night events to come to plays as well."

The theatre has set up links with theatres in Bolton and Scarborough and has invested £20,000 on preparing a bid for funding, which brought in £70,000 over three years for work with young people at risk of offending, people with learning disabilities, and chil dren under seven and their families.

"We have worked with 12,000 people in the first year," added Mr Keston. "It's an example of how investment can reap rewards."

The Wolsey Theatre, Ipswich, Suffolk

The 400-seat Wolsey opened in Ipswich, the home town of Trevor Nunn, who is now the director of the Royal National Theatre, in 1977, and ran as a traditional rep theatre for many years.

It was funded with £5.75m of public money but went dark last year, with a deficit of £198,000, after lean years in which it struggled to stay afloat.

It eventually went into receivership and sold off its stock of costumes and props. Now it is planning to stage a comeback, and five applicants for the £35,000-a-year job of artisitic director will be interviewed next week.

The person appointed will be charged with creating a mixed programme with a wide appeal, and some shows will be bought in.

"We are going to make sure we go back to an extremely high standard," said Robin Chesterman, chairman of the theatre's trust.

He added: "We have to find a younger audience and we have to create networks with theatres in Norwich, Bury St Edmunds and Colchester.

"Our loyal playgoers will have to be nurtured, but in line with the Arts Council report, we have to go out and seek new audiences."

One possible change, designed to find extra seats on which to plant bums, will be to move from the present thrust stage arrangement to a traditional proscenium.

webTitle: £25m a year needed for crisis-hit theatres

fields.headline: £25m a year needed for crisis-hit theatres
fields.trailText: The Arts Council of England said yesterday that £25m a year needed to be pumped into subsidised theatre to breathe new life into what it described as an "art form in crisis".
fields.body:
The Arts Council of England said yesterday that £25m a year needed to be pumped into subsidised theatre to breathe new life into what it described as an "art form in crisis".

The council's chairman, Gerry Robinson, said at the launch of a report which tells of declining audiences, fewer performances and tours, less challenging plays and soaring deficits: "Although our theatre is among the best in the world, it is in dire need.

"We must reinvent the best of the past and encourage the writers, artists and productions of tomorrow."

The council says the status quo - caused by inadequate funding lasting more than 15 years - is not an option.

Without new cash some theatres would probably close.

It outlines a scheme of reinvigoration which is likely to depress traditionalists who will see it as the final nail in the coffin of the rep system. But it is likely to be welcomed by others eager to win new young audiences for high-quality productions.

Victoria Todd, director of the National Campaign for the Arts, said: "I applaud this idea and £25m would be a big increase in arts spending.

"But my fear is that it will all be tears before bedtime if the money does not come through. I'll be the first to jump on my desk and cheer if it does but theatres have been in crisis for so long it could be too late."

The report, The Next Stage, amplifies issues identified in research commissioned from Peter Boyden Associates which bluntly pointed out that the producing theatres' problems were caused by years of underfunding.

The council and the 10 regional arts boards now spend £70m a year on 40 touring companies, 160 theatres which buy in productions, and 50 theatres from Plymouth to Newcastle upon Tyne which produce their own shows.

But the report shows that producing theatres have run up a total deficit of £4.4m and performances by touring companies have fallen by 24% in six years leading to an audience drop of 28%.

The average actor now worked for only 11 weeks a year, said the report.

An "attitudinal change" was needed among funders and the theatre community, parts of which had become "insular and territorial" and unable because of repeated cash crises to commission new work or take advantage of new talent.

"Theatre cannot rely on the recollections of a post-war golden era and the loyalty of audiences who grew up in a period when theatre was the dominant art form.

"A dynamic contemporary theatre must draw on that which has meaning and substance from the past but without being constrained by it.

"It must also respond to a multicultural Britain, embracing a wider range of forms and traditions; to a digital Britain seeking creative uses for emerging technologies; and to a Britain of the regions which celebrate local cultural distinctiveness alongside a commitment to international excellence."

The council wants to create a more flexible theatre network which can preserve the best of the past and encourage the writers and artists of tomorrow, while developing new education and community schemes.

The network should engage a new generation of young people with work that was relevant to their lives and would surprise them "with its immediacy and imaginative power".

More theatres are likely to present a mixed economy of in-house, touring and bought-in work.

However, some, such as Birmingham Rep and the Royal Exchange in Manchester, will probably continue principally as production centres.

The council says that it will no longer dilute its ambition by funding theatres at less than effective levels.

In a clear warning to the government, it adds: "If insufficient funds are available, the Arts Council may not be able to make available the resources to fund all the theatres who buy into its policy and vision.

"Some may have to scale down, some may have to close."

The report is the first stage in the creation of a national policy for theatre in England.

Over the next two months, wide ranging discussions will take place with arts boards, local councils and the theatre community to agree the policy and decide on ways it can be delivered.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Met to aid South African police
fields.body:
Met to aid South African police

Britain is to train an elite South African police unit in a bid to help crack down on the country's spiralling crime rate, Tony Blair said yesterday before meeting South African president Thabo Mbeki for the annual UK-South Africa summit at Downing Street.

A £500,000 training pro gramme has been set up by the Metropolitan police for 100 officers from the Scorpions investigation unit to help equip them to tackle organised crime.

Police recover stolen Lowrys

Detectives recovered 50 stolen LS Lowry paintings in late night raids in Queenborough, Isle of Sheppey, Kent, police said yesterday. A 47-year-old man was arrested.

The artworks were from a haul of 72 paintings worth £1.6m by the matchstick figures artist taken in a burglary in south Northamptonshire on January 16.

Two men were arrested in January in connection with the theft and another was arrested in March. All three were released on police bail until August.

Women soccer fans know best

Women football fans know more about the offside rule than men, according to a survey published today.

Of the thousands of supporters surveyed, 53% of male fans could explain the law correctly, compared with 68% of women.

The survey, commissioned by Guinness, found Tottenham had the most knowledgable fans, followed by Newcastle and Liverpool.

Referees said they felt most intimidated by Manchester United fans, followed by those of West Ham and Sunderland.

Ex-astronaut to wed Anna Ford

BBC television newsreader Anna Ford is planning to marry a retired Nasa astronaut, Colonel David Scott, who led the 1971 Apollo 15 mission.

She said they were happy together and eventually planned to marry

Ms Ford, 56, has two daughters, Claire, 18, and Kate, 15, by her second husband, the cartoonist Mark Boxer, who died in 1988.

Col Scott, 67, who walked on the moon on the Apollo 15 mission and drove the first lunar vehicle, has two sons.

webTitle: Warne quickly warms to his task

fields.headline: Warne quickly warms to his task
fields.standfirst:
Hampshire 229
Leicestershire 89-3
fields.trailText:
Hampshire 229
Leicestershire 89-3
fields.body:
This is turning into an absorbing seminar on leg-spin. Two of the world's most dextrous exponents, Shane Warne and Anil Kumble, so different in physical stature and technique, seem likely between them to determine the pattern of this match. Both have already manifested their guileful mischief.

Sixty-six overs were lost to rain yesterday. There was time enough, however, for Warne, sweatered shoulders hunched in the cold, fingers twitching constantly in the way of a pianist impatient to reach the keyboard, to bamboozle immediately. He was on by the 12th over, Darren Maddy having gone already to an lbw decision which surprised him, and took a wicket with his first ball. It was slipped down the leg side for the sharpest of stumpings of Trevor Ward by Adrian Aymes.

Warne mixed his riddles, inhibited only by a troublesome boot which appeared to turn him additionally into a busy cobbler. He went on to entrap Darren Stevens and there were plenty of unavailing appeals to follow, as Aftab Habib and Ben Smith stayed to close the gap to 140 at the close.

As for Kumble, Leicestershire's worries are that he will be another shortly whisked away with unscheduled haste for the Asia Cup. "We are disappointed," said the manager Jack Birkenshaw, diplomatically masking the concern shown by various counties.

Hampshire's last pair had lasted only another four balls. Aymes had every reason to be pleased with a not-out innings of sensible application. Increasingly it seems that, amid the county's batting frailties, he will be pressingly needed.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Yesterday's Second Division programme was severely curtailed by rain, with the second day at Edgbaston completely washed out. But the experience of Jack Russell and Mark Alleyne put Gloucestershire back in the hunt in their match with Nottinghamshire at Trent Bridge.
fields.body:
Yesterday's Second Division programme was severely curtailed by rain, with the second day at Edgbaston completely washed out. But the experience of Jack Russell and Mark Alleyne put Gloucestershire back in the hunt in their match with Nottinghamshire at Trent Bridge.

An unbroken partnership of 115 between the captain Alleyne, who finished on 58, and the former captain Russell (32) held up the hosts for 44 overs.

 Sussex and Worcestershire were restricted to an hour's play on the opening day in Hove. Glenn McGrath removed Toby Peirce for 21 as the hosts reached 51 for one after choosing to bat.

 Mark Waugh is to follow in his twin brother Steve's footsteps by playing for Ireland. The 34-year-old Australian will play two games over a three-week period in June.

fields.headline: Cassar cures Munton blues
fields.standfirst:
Derbyshire 303
Yorkshire 171-6
fields.trailText:
Derbyshire 303
Yorkshire 171-6
fields.body:
Since he moved from Warwickshire to Derbyshire, Tim Munton has been magically transformed from one of county cricket's most respected players into someone marginally more accident-prone than Jacques Tati's Monsieur Hulot.

In the previous match against Yorkshire, at Headingley this month, he suffered painful blows on each arm and had to retire. Then, while practising, he took a heavy blow on a knee. And yesterday, while having a few gentle throw-downs in the indoor school before the start of play, one delivery reared and struck him between the eyes.

He was taken to hospital and when, hours later, it was reported that he was still there, there were fears of complications. In fact he needed only a few stitches above his left eye. But running into a five-hour wait at A&E represents a nasty accident in itself.

It is hardly surprising, then, that when Munton asked to play in a club match recently the club refused to grant permission, fearing he would do himself a mischief.

When Yorkshire, replying to 303, were 112 without loss, Derbyshire's captain Dominic Cork must have missed Munton hugely. But then something happened.

Matthew Cassar's cricket career is so modest that he is best known for being the husband of Jane Cassar, the England women's wicketkeeper. But he is having a good match.

On Wednesday he scored 47, more than anything he managed last season. And now he took three wickets in nine balls without conceding a run.

First he had David Byas caught behind, then he had Richard Blakey well caught by Paul Aldred at third slip, and bowling with gathering pace he had Richard Harden caught behind with a sharp lifter.

Normally a tepid third-change seamer, Cassar was by now bowling with real hostility. The coach Colin Wells said afterwards: "Matt has had a lot of injuries but is more confident in his body these days."

With Vic Craven also falling, this time to the off-spin of Simon Lacey, Yorkshire, who in the morning had led the provisional table, had lost four wickets in as many overs for four runs.

They closed on 171 for six, 132 adrift, after Matt Wood had been caught behind and the nightwatchman Paul Hutchison had perished leg-before offering only a half-hearted stroke, both victims of Cork.

In only his second championship innings Craven, 19, played with surprising maturity and restraint for his maiden first-class half-century. Most of his seven fours were cuts off Lacey.

Earlier Derbyshire, resuming on 285 for eight, were all out when Trevor Smith was bowled by Gavin Hamilton. With Munton at the mercy of the NHS the innings closed with nine down. Rain then washed out play until after lunch.

fields.headline: Lord's without the hordes
fields.trailText: Harry Pearson on the day that English cricket provided something so singularly dismal as to make a ticket tout look poignant.
fields.body:
Outside St John's Wood underground station yesterday morning the burly geezers in Tommy Hilfiger sweatshirts were selling, but not buying. Their furtive invitations ("Test match tickets. Grandstand. Mound Stand"), usually confident, sounded half-hearted and unhopeful.

A scalper who offered "all seats together, lads" to a group of eight men in matching panamas wore the hangdog expression of a man who had invested the family fortune in the Betamax video system. With only 8,500 tickets sold for the day he'd have made more money flogging Beastie Boys bootlegs in the Long Room.

It takes something singularly dismal to make a ticket tout look poignant. English cricket has managed it.

Lord's always has a tranquil atmosphere. It is the only major sports ground in the country where the call of the song thrush is audible above the sound of the crowd. Sometimes, it is said, the blackbirds in the copper beeches behind the Warner Stand chirrup so loudly they even drown out the noise of an MCC tie.

Yesterday, however, the traditional serenity had an eerie edge to it. The blue-and-yellow cappuccino trolleys (apparently modelled on the Sinclair C5) trundled down the thoroughfares unhindered by coveys of corporate coves noisily discussing trends in the ornamental faucet industry; Mahony's traditional Irish pub-trailer was unmobbed by bogus Celts; the "beer fast lane" at the Father Time bar appeared as superfluous as an ashtray on a motorbike.

By lunchtime the Home of Cricket was only a third full. If it hadn't been for several large groups of schoolchildren, whose piping cries of support for Ed Giddins seriously threat ened the glass in the hospitality boxes, the stewards in the lower Mound Stand would have outnumbered the punters.

In the gardens behind the Warner Stand, MCC members had bagged their mealtime benches with plaid rugs, wicker-hampers and cool boxes in the manner of German holidaymakers marking the poolside recliners. It was an act of habit rather than necessity. At lunch the diners had plenty of room to spread themselves and their ample provender. Surrounded by thermos flasks, game pies and bottles of claret they were symbolic figures. For if, as Mark Twain said, golf is a good walk spoiled, then English test cricket is a nice picnic ruined.

To find the culprits you have only to look out to the middle. On the eve of this match Nasser Hussain expressed concern that during a seven-test summer his side might "peak too early". In the current mood of despondency it appeared the sort of twisted, black humour usually only found in the films of Lars von Trier.

Victory breeds interest. It brings even fringe sports into the centre of the national consciousness. In the days of Curry and Cousins, ice skating was celebrated in Britain as the very pinnacle of athletic and artistic endeavour. Once Torvill and Dean retired it dropped out of sight again.

Cricket has further to fall, but the way it has been nose-diving it shouldn't be long before it is eclipsed in the public mind by biathlon and bog-snorkelling.

Other factors contributed to the low turn-out, of course. Zimbabwe, Henry Olonga's singing aside, are hardly inspirational and this was the first test match in England that had begun before the FA Cup final.

Most people have not yet quite grasped the idea that the cricket season has started. Neither has the weather. A wind circled the ground with such icy severity that the woman in the coffee stand made a plaintive appeal for somebody to manufacture a Polartec pinny. Thunder rumbled menacingly for much of the day.

At least the rain it heralded did something to brighten the mood of the touts. The way the visitors were playing, the game looked likely to be over by teatime today. With the prospect of that rarest of collector's items, an England win, the boys may yet recoup their losses tomorrow. Though you wouldn't bet on it.

webTitle: Five wickets at headquarters comes easy after swimming with piranhas

fields.headline: Five wickets at headquarters comes easy after swimming with piranhas
fields.trailText: David Hopps on a triumphant return for Ed Giddins.
fields.body:
Ed Giddins's analysis of five for 15 will soon be inscribed on the Lord's honours board in the England dressing room, but it was a different statistic that was etched most firmly on his mind last night: 9.38am, the time when the waiting ended and his second test for England was confirmed.

Giddins had not done himself justice in his debut test against New Zealand at the Oval in August, the last played on English soil. He was more nervous than he had anticipated and his body ached after a long county season. When the touring party was chosen for South Africa, his name was absent. That he would return automatically yesterday was far from certain.

"It was not an ideal situation, but it was a hard decision to make," he said. "I just kept telling myself I would be playing."

A holiday in Brazil during the winter, where he swam in piranha-infested rivers, had satisfied his taste for the exotic, before he returned to enrol on a fitness course at Lilleshall, committing £7,000 of his own money. It was a regimented regime, starting with a daily run at six o'clock each morning.

He was up at 6am again yesterday, but only with the intention of drawing back the curtains to check the cloud cover. "At that time there wasn't a cloud in the sky," he said. "But by the time the match started the conditions were perfect for my style of bowling."

Giddins's flick of the wrist is as pronounced as that of any England fast bowler in history. It is this wrist action that provides his whippiness, as he lopes into his delivery stride with the loose-limbed enthusiasm of a greyhound with a slightly dicky front leg.

He had been uncertain at which end to bowl but watched Andrew Caddick swing the ball down the hill, and opted, like him, for running into a buffetting wind. That meant cutting his pace and risking Darren Gough's rumbustious mockery.

"After one stoppage, the first ball slipped out at 75mph and I heard Goughie pissing himself laughing. I heard a few suggestions last summer that I was a county plodder. I hope I can put a few of those phrases to bed."

His most-valued wicket was the first, not just because it was Andy Flower, Zimbabwe's most accomplished batsman, but because a wicket with his fourth ball immediately slipped him into the groove. His dismissal of Guy Whittall brought more banter from Gough - "I beat him for pace: a lack of it," recalled Giddins - and there was even an opportunity for some impromptu Gough clowning as he held Neil Johnson's skier, second attempt, off his chest.

In the self-effacing manner in which the English specialise, Lord's worried itself gallantly about how limited the Zimbabweans might be. If the political troubles escalate back home, and the white minority shrinks further, who is to know whether Zimbabwe's test status will survive the decade.

But Giddins will be convinced of the value of their visit. As Dave Houghton, Zimbabwe's former coach remarked, Giddins is now set up with the summer, and perhaps England, too. For Houghton, it was the bleakest experience. Zimbabwe's first test in England was a momentous occasion that they singularly failed to grasp. They batted so timidly that Houghton might have been tempted, at 43, into another comeback.

"They so wanted to provide a reason for pleasure back in Zimbabwe," he said. "But for some reason, they just froze. It's desperately disappointing."
