fields.headline: Zimbabwe skittled by Giddins
fields.standfirst:
Caddick paves way as England concede under 100 for first time in 21 years
Zimbabwe 83 all out
England 29 for 1
fields.trailText: Speculate to accumulate, they say. Last winter, on the back of comment suggesting that after his solitary test at the Oval he was not sufficiently fit for the rigours of test-match bowling, Ed Giddins delved into his piggy bank and coughed up £7,000 for a 12-week course at Lilleshall. If nothing else it was a strong statement of his commitment, and yesterday at Lord's, in destroying Zimbabwe's innings, he began the process of reaping the dividends.
fields.body:
Speculate to accumulate, they say. Last winter, on the back of comment suggesting that after his solitary test at the Oval he was not sufficiently fit for the rigours of test-match bowling, Ed Giddins delved into his piggy bank and coughed up £7,000 for a 12-week course at Lilleshall. If nothing else it was a strong statement of his commitment, and yesterday at Lord's, in destroying Zimbabwe's innings, he began the process of reaping the dividends.

Coming on as first change after Andy Caddick had imparted the most severe of wounds to Zimbabwe's top order, Giddins, bowling at a skittish pace from the Nursery End and moving the ball just sufficiently away down the slope, took five for 15 in seven overs as the visitors were bowled out for 83 on their test debut in England. It is two matches since they made only 63 in Port of Spain in March.

It is the first time in 21 years, since Ian Botham got rid of India for 96 on this ground, that England have dismissed a side for fewer than three figures and it is the lowest total against them since New Zealand made 67, also at Lord's, the year previous to that. Had Nasser Hussain posted a third man instead of a mid-on, as he did later, Zimbabwe might well not have reached 50. Almost half the runs came in that area.

It always pays to be mindful of the potential the game has for turnarounds. Only last October, in Mohali, New Zealand put India in and bowled them out for the same total, took a substantial first-innings lead but then barely clung on for a draw.

Zimbabwe, however, do not possess a Rahul Dravid or Sachin Tendulkar to bail them out, and England, at 29 for one, are already in control. This is despite the loss of Mark Ramprakash to what proved to be both the last ball before tea and of the day because of a torrential rainstorm, the most violent of a number during the day.

By any standards the speed with which England disposed of Zimbabwe was quite stunning, as if the batsmen were rehearsing their own special procession for the queen mum's birthday bash. In 1924, Arthur Gilligan and Maurice Tate disposed of South Africa in 12.3 overs, the fastest ever, and in that match in Mohali, Chris Cairns, Dion Nash and Shayne O'Connor required only 27 overs to see off India.

Yesterday it took Giddins, together with Darren Gough (two for 36), and Caddick (three for 28) all of 30.3 overs. Chris Schofield, the young leg-spinner making his debut, England having omitted Craig White and Steve Harmison, never got a sniff and if the pitch remains frisky under the covers he may well not do.

Zimbabwe may consider themselves unfortunate in some regards. The situation at home must be preying on their minds more than they care to let on. Because of the weather they have not had a decent run-up to this match and they lost a toss they dearly would have loved to win. Hussain has now won seven out of nine since he became captain.

Then they encountered Caddick, who produced an inspirational opening burst that brought him three wickets in nine balls, removing Grant Flower - beautifully yorked - and Trevor Gripper, caught at the wicket, with deliveries of world class, and Alistair Campbell courtesy of a stroke he will wish to bury with a stake through its heart.

He ought to have had a fourth wicket too, when Andy Flower got an inside edge to Alec Stewart behind the stumps only to see the umpire Dave Orchard turn down the appeal.

This, it seemed, was to be Caddick's day and, competitive fellows that these bowlers are, each wishing to outdo the other, he must have been seething quietly that it was not. After eight overs Giddins replaced him and with his fourth ball had Andy Flower, Zimbabwe's most prolific test batsman, caught at first slip.

It was shortly before lunch that Giddins got his big break, for had Guy Whittall seen out the last over of the session then Caddick surely would have returned after the interval. Insteadan attempted bouncer - let us be charitable here - was miscued on to his stumps as he tried to pull.

Giddins had one ball of the over remaining and when play resumed he continued his spell. Bad light and a rain shower intervened in the middle of another over from him and when Heath Streak edged the first ball of the resumption to first slip it would have taken a nuclear blast to have got the ball from Giddins.

Bryan Strang was promptly caught at short leg and Neil Johnson, who made a century against Australia on this very strip in the World Cup - the last time it was used - skied to extra cover.

England's reply was far from steady. Ramprakash almost dragged his second ball on to his stumps, was dropped horrendously at the wicket by Andy Flower when seven and would have been run out by Brian Murphy's brilliant fielding when 15 had the throw hit. In the following over, though, he propped forward to Streak and, after due deliberation, was given out lbw by Peter Willey.

Some years ago in similar circumstances Ramprakash, disgruntled, muttered to another umpire, Darrell Hair, that he was "messing with my career". He would have thought twice with Willey, who like all the international umpires is now sponsored by Happy Shopper. Willey does not do happy.
